	<h1 id="id_Hlk135302275" class="block_4">UNIT -1 <b class="calibre6">LAWS OF MOTION</b></h1>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_1">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-5.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of GWQY4" class="calibre7"/></p>
	<p class="block_">At the end of this lesson students will be able to:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Understand the concepts of force and motion.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Explain inertia and its types.</li>
	<li class="block_7">State the three laws of Newton.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Apply Newtonian concept of force and motion.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Define force, momentum and impulse.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Distinguish between mass and weight</li>
	<li class="block_7">Analyze weightlessness and the principle of conservation of momentum.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Explain the law of gravitation and its applications.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Understand the variations in 'g' due to height and depth.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Solve numerical problems related to force and motion</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_2">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">Human beings are so curious about things around them. Things around us are related to one another. Some bodies are at rest and some are in motion. Rest and motion are interrelated terms.</p>
	<p class="block_">In the previous classes you have learnt about various types of motion such as linear motion, circular motion, oscillatory motion, and so on. So far, you have discussed the motion of bodies in terms of their displacement, velocity, and acceleration. In this unit, let us investigate the cause of motion.</p>
	<p class="block_">When a body is at rest, starts moving, a question that arises in our mind is ‘what causes the body to move?’ Similarly, when a moving object comes to rest, you would like to know what brings it to rest? If a moving object speeds up or slows down or changes its direction. what speeds up or slows down the body? What changes the direction of motion?</p>
	<p class="block_">One answer for all the above questions is ‘Force’. In a common man’s understanding of motion, a body needs a ‘push’ or ‘pull’ to move or bring to rest or change its velocity. Hence, this ‘push’ or ‘pull’ is called as ‘force’.</p>
	<p class="block_">Let us define force in a more scientific manner using the three laws proposed by Sir Isaac Newton. These laws help you to understand the motion of a body and also to predict the future course of its motion, if you know the forces acting on it. Before Newton formulated his three laws of motion, a different perception about the force and motion of bodies prevailed. Let us first look at these ideas and then eventually learn about Newton’s laws in this unit.</p>
	<p class="block_">Mechanics is the branch of physics that deals with the effect of force on bodies. It is divided into two branches, namely, statics and dynamics.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Statics:</b> It deals with the bodies, which are at rest under the action of forces.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Dynamics:</b> It is the study of moving bodies under the action of forces. Dynamics is further divided as follows.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Kinematics:</b> It deals with the motion of bodies without considering the cause of motion.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Kinetics:</b> It deals with the motion of bodies considering the cause of motion.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_3">1.1 FORCE AND MOTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">According to Aristotle a Greek Philosopher and Scientist, the natural state of earthly bodies is ‘rest’. He stated that a moving body naturally comes to rest without any external influence of the force. Such motions are termed as ‘natural motion’ (Force independent). He also proposed that a force (a push or a pull) is needed to make the bodies to move from their natural state (rest) and behave contrary to their own natural state called as ‘violent motion’ (Force dependent). Further, he said, when two different mass bodies are dropped from a height, the heavier body falls faster than the lighter one.</p>
	<p class="block_">Galileo proposed the following concepts about force, motion and inertia of bodies:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">The natural state of all earthly bodies is either the state of rest or the state of uniform motion.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A body in motion will continue to be in the same state of motion as long as no external force is applied.</li>
	<li class="block_7">When a force is applied on bodies, they resist any change in their state. This property of bodies is called ‘inertia’.</li>
	<li class="block_8">When dropped from a height in vacuum, bodies of different size, shape and mass fall at the same rate and reach the ground at the same time.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_4">1.2 INERTIA</h2>
	<p class="block_9">While you are travelling in a bus or in a car, when a sudden brake is applied, the upper part of your body leans in the forward direction. Similarly, when the vehicle suddenly is moved forward from rest, you lean backward. This is due to, anybody would like to continue to be in its state of rest or the state of motion. This is known as ‘inertia’.</p>
	<p class="block_9">The inherent property of a body to resist any change in its state of rest or the state of uniform motion, unless it is influenced upon by an external unbalanced force, is known as ‘inertia’.</p>
	<p class="block_10">Activity 1</p>
	<p class="block_">Take a glass tumbler and place a small cardboard on it as shown in the figure. Now, keep a coin at the center of the  cardboard. Then, flick the cardboard quickly. What do you observe?</p>
	<p class="block_">The cardboard falls off the ground and the coin falls into the glass tumbler.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-6.png" alt=" This is a picture. It explain about a inertia due to rest ia given. In this picture a glass tumbler, card board and a coin" class="calibre8"/></p>
	<p class="block_">In activity described above, the inertia of the coin keeps it in the state of rest when the cardboard moves. Then, when the cardboard has moved, the coin falls into the tumbler due to gravity. This happens due to ‘inertia of rest’.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_5">1.2.1 Types of Inertia</h3>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-7.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of XF6DH" class="calibre9"/></p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_13">a) Inertia of rest: The resistance of a body to change its state of rest is called inertia of rest.</div>
	<div class="block_13">b) Inertia of motion: The resistance of a body to change its state of motion is called inertia of motion.</div>
	<div class="block_14">c) Inertia of direction: The resistance of a body to change its direction of motion is called inertia of direction.</div>
</div>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_6">1.2.2 Examples of Inertia</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">An athlete runs some distance before jumping. Because, this will help him jump longer and higher. (Inertia of motion)</li>
	<li class="block_7">When you make a sharp turn while driving a car, you tend to lean sideways, (Inertia of direction).</li>
	<li class="block_8"> When you vigorously shake the branches of a tree, some of the leaves and fruits are detached and they fall down, (Inertia of rest).</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">Figure 1.1 Inertia of motion</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image162.png" alt="Tis is a picture. It explains inertia due to motion. In this picture, a girl with scatting is moving continuously is given." class="calibre11"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_7">1.3 LINEAR MOMENTUM</h3>
	<p class="block_">The impact of a force is more if the velocity and the mass of the body is more. To quantify the impact of a force exactly, a new physical quantity known as linear momentum is defined. The linear momentum measures the impact of a force on a body.</p>
	<p class="block_">The product of mass and velocity of a moving body gives the magnitude of linear momentum. It acts in the direction of the velocity of the object. Linear momentum is a vector quantity.</p>
	<p class="block_">Linear Momentum = mass × velocity</p>
	<p class="block_">p = m v<span class="tab">      </span> (1.1)</p>
	<p class="block_9">It helps to measure the magnitude of a force. Unit of momentum in SI system is kilogram metre second power minus one and in C.G.S system its unit is gram centimeter second power minus one.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_8">1.4 NEWTON’S LAWS OF MOTION</h2>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_9">1.4.1 Newton’s First Law</h3>
	<p class="block_9">This law states that everybody continues to be in its state of rest or the state of uniform motion along a straight line unless it is acted upon by some external force. It gives the definition of force as well as inertia. body.</p>
	<p class="block_">Force has both magnitude and direction. So, it is a vector quantity.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_10">1.4.3 Types of forces</h3>
	<p class="block_">Based on the direction in which the forces act, they can be classified into two types as:</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_13">a) Like parallel forces and </div>
	<div class="block_14">b) Unlike parallel forces.</div>
</div>
	<p class="block_">(a) Like parallel forces: Two or more forces of equal or unequal magnitude acting along the same direction, parallel to each other are called like parallel forces.</p>
	<p class="block_">(b) Unlike parallel forces: If two or more equal forces or unequal forces act along opposite directions parallel to each other, then they are called unlike parallel forces. Action of forces are given in Table 1.1.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_11">1.4.4 Resultant Force</h3>
	<p class="block_">When several forces act simultaneously on the same body, then the combined effect of the multiple forces can be represented by a single force, which is termed as ‘resultant force’. It is equal to the vector sum (adding the magnitude of the forces with their direction) of all the forces.</p>
	<p class="block_">Table 1.1 action of forcres</p>

	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image164.jpeg" alt="This is a picture. Railway workers working on the railway embankment, and fixing the rails which shows the unbalanced forces" class="calibre19"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">(b) Unbalanced forces – Action of a lever</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-11.png" alt="This is a picture.Image shows the one worker pulling the load and other worker pushing from back to help the other which is shown as example for Like Parallel forces." class="calibre20"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">(c) Like parallel forces</p>
	<p class="block_">If the resultant force of all the forces acting on a body is equal to zero, then the body will be in equilibrium. Such forces are called balanced forces. If the resultant force is not equal to zero, then it causes the motion of the body due to unbalanced forces</p>
	<p class="block_">Examples: Drawing water from a well, force applied with a crowbar, forces on a weight balance, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_">A system can be brought to equilibrium by applying another force, which is equal to the resultant force in magnitude, but opposite in direction. Such force is called as ‘Equilibrant’.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_12">1.4.5 Rotating Effect of Force</h3>
	<p class="block_9">Have you observed the position of the handle in a door? It is always placed at the edge of door and not at some other place. Why? Have you tried to push a door by placing your hand closer to the hinges or the fixed edge? What do you observe?</p>
	<p class="block_9">The door can be easily opened or closed when you apply the force at a point far away from the fixed edge. In this case, the effect of the force you apply is to turn the door about the fixed edge. This turning effect of the applied force is more when the distance between the fixed edge and the point of application of force is more.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 1.3 Rotating effect of a force</p>
	<p class="block_23"><img src="images/image-12.png" alt="This is a picture.A person open a door is shown. The door rotates according to hinges is represented by the rotation axis along the +z axis. In the picture hinges marked.  " class="calibre21"/></p>
	<p class="block_">The axis of the fixed edge about which the door is rotated is called as the ‘axis of rotation’. Fix one end of a rod to the floor/wall and apply a force at the other end tangentially. The rod will be turned about the fixed point is called as ‘point of rotation’.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_13">1.4.6 Moment of the Force</h3>
	<p class="block_">The rotating or turning effect of a force about a fixed point or fixed axis is called moment of the force about that point or torque(τ). It is measured by the product of the force (F) and the perpendicular distance (d) between the fixed point or the fixed axis and the line of action of the force.</p>
	<p class="block_">τ = F × d (1.2)</p>
	<p class="block_">Torque is a vector quantity. It is acting along the direction, perpendicular to the plane containing the line of action of force and the distance. Its SI unit is Newton metre.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Couple:</b> Two equal and unlike parallel forces applied simultaneously at two distinct points constitute a couple. The line of action of the two forces does not coincide. It does not produce any translatory motion since the resultant is zero. But a couple results in causes the rotation of the body. Rotating effect of a couple is known as moment of a couple.</p>
	<p class="block_">Examples: Turning a tap, winding or unwinding a screw, spinning of a top, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_">Moment of a couple is measured by the product of any one of the forces and the perpendicular distance between the line of action of two forces. The turning effect of a couple is measured by the magnitude of its moment.</p>
	<p class="block_">Moment of a couple = Force × perpendicular distance between the line of action of forces</p>
	<p class="block_">M = F × S (1.3)</p>
	<p class="block_9">The unit of moment of a couple is newton metre (N m) in SI system and dyne centi metre in CGS system.</p>
	<p class="block_9">By convention, the direction of moment of a force or couple is taken as positive if the body is rotated in the anti-clockwise direction and negative if it is rotate in the clockwise direction. They are shown in </p>
	<p class="block_19">Figures 1.4 (a and b)</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-13.png" alt="This is a picture.In the heading clockwise moment apply the balanced forces along the opposite direction in clockwise moment on the first ring. in the picture centre of the ring s and forces are marked." class="calibre22"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_14">1.4.7 Application of Torque</h3>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-14.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of K8ZFL" class="calibre23"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">1. Gears</b>:</p>
	<p class="block_">A gear is a circular wheel with teeth around its rim. It helps to change the speed of rotation of a wheel by changing the torque and helps to transmit power.</p>
	<p class="block_19">2. Sea-saw</p>
	<p class="block_9">Most of you have played on the sea-saw. Since there is a difference in the weight of the persons sitting on it, the heavier person lifts the lighter person. When the heavier person comes closer to the pivot point (fulcrum) the distance of the line of action of the force decreases. It causes less amount of torque to act on it. This enables the lighter person to lift the heavier person.</p>
	<p class="block_19">3. Steering Wheel</p>
	<p class="block_9">A small steering wheel enables you to manoeuvre a car easily by transferring a torque to the wheels with less effort.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_15">1.4.8 Principle of Moments</h3>
	<p class="block_9">When a number of like or unlike parallel forces act on a rigid body and the body is in equilibrium, then the algebraic sum of the moments in the clockwise direction is equal to the algebraic sum of the moments in the anticlockwise direction. In other words, at equilibrium, the algebraic sum of the moments of all the individual forces about any point is equal to zero.</p>
	<p class="block_23"><img src="images/image-15.png" alt="This is a picture. In this picture principle of moment is explained . " class="calibre24"/></p>
	<p class="block_">In the illustration given in figure 1.5, the force F one produces an anticlockwise rotation at a distance d one from the point of pivot P (called fulcrum) and the force F two<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>produces a clockwise rotation at a distance d two from the point of pivot P. The principle of moments can be written as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_">Moment in clockwise direction = Moment in anticlockwise direction </p>
	<p class="block_">F1 × d1 = F2 × d2 (1.4)</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_16">1.5 NEWTON’S SECOND LAW OF MOTION</h2>
	<p class="block_9">According to this law, “the force acting on a body is directly proportional to the rate of change of linear momentum of the body and the change in momentum takes place in the direction of the force”.</p>
	<p class="block_9">This law helps us to measure the amount of force. So, it is also called as ‘law of force’. Let, ‘m’ be the mass of a moving body, moving along a straight line with an initial speed ‘u’ After a time interval of ‘t’, the velocity of the body changes to ‘v’ due to the impact of an unbalanced external force F.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Initial momentum of the body P initial = m u </p>
	<p class="block_9">Final momentum of the body P final = m v </p>
	<p class="block_9">Change in momentum Δp = P final minus P initial </p>
	<p class="block_9">= m v minus m u</p>
	<p class="block_">By Newton’s second law of motion,</p>
	<p class="block_">Force, F is proportional to rate of change of momentum </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_24">Here, k is the proportionality constant.<br class="calibre26"/> <span class="text_"> (1.5)</span></p>
	<p class="block_25">Since, acceleration = change in velocity/ time, </p>
	<p class="block_25"> </p>
	<p class="block_25">Hence, we have </p>
	<p class="block_26"><b class="calibre6">F= m times a </b>(1.6)</p>
	<p class="block_">Force = mass × acceleration</p>
	<p class="block_9">No external force is required to maintain the motion of a body moving with uniform velocity. When the net force acting on a body is not equal to zero, then definitely the velocity of the body will change. Thus, change in momentum takes place in the direction of the force. The change may take place either in magnitude or in direction or in both.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Force is required to produce the acceleration of a body. In a uniform circular motion, even though the speed (magnitude of velocity) remains constant, the direction of the velocity changes at every point on the circular path. So, the acceleration is produced along the radius called as centripetal acceleration. The force, which produces this acceleration is called as centripetal force, about which you have learnt in class IX.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Units of force: SI unit of force is newton (N) and in C.G.S system its unit is dyne.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Definition of 1 newton (N): The amount of force required for a body of mass 1 kiloram produces an acceleration of 1 metre second power minus two, 1 N = 1 kilogram metre second power minus two</p>
	<p class="block_9">Unit force: Definition of 1 dyne: The amount of force required for a body of mass 1 gram produces an acceleration of 1 centi metre second power minus two, 1 dyne = 1 gram centi metre second<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>power minus two; also 1 N = 10 power<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>five<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>dyne.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">The amount of force required to produce an acceleration of 1 metre second<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>power minus two in a body of mass 1 kilogram is called ‘unit force’.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Gravitational unit of force:</p>
	<p class="block_9">In the SI system of units, gravitational unit of force is kilogram force. In the CGS system its unit is gram force.</p>
	<p class="block_9">1 kilogram force = 1 kilogram × 9.8 metre second power minus two = 9.8 N;</p>
	<p class="block_9">1 gram orce = 1 gram × 980 centi metre second power minus two = 980 dyne</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_17">1.6 Impulse</h2>
	<p class="block_">A large force acting for a very short interval of time is called as ‘Impulsive force’. When a force F acts on a body for a period of time t, then the product of force and time is known as ‘impulse’ represented by ‘J’</p>
	<p class="block_">Impulse, J = F × t<span class="tab">      </span>(1.7)</p>
	<p class="block_">By Newton’s second law</p>
	<p class="block_">F =Δp by t (Δ refers to change) Δp = F × t<span class="tab">      </span>(1.8)</p>
	<p class="block_">From 1.7 and 1.8</p>
	<p class="block_">J = Δp</p>
	<p class="block_">Impulse is also equal to the magnitude of change in momentum. Its unit is kilogram metre second power minus one or N s.</p>
	<p class="block_">Change in momentum can be achieved in two ways. They are:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">a large force acting for a short period of time and</li>
	<li class="block_8">a smaller force acting for a longer period of time.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Examples:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Automobiles are fitted with springs and shock absorbers to reduce jerks while moving on uneven roads.</li>
	<li class="block_8"><span class="calibre28">In cricket, a fielder pulls back his hands while catching the ball.  He experiences a smaller force for a longer interval of time to catch the ball, resulting in a lesser impulse on his hands.</span></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_27">Figure 1.6 Example of impulsive force</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image172.jpeg" alt="Image shows The wicket keeper is catching the ball." class="calibre29"/> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_18">1.7 NEWTON’S THIRD LAW OF MOTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">Newton’s third law states that ‘for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. They always act on two different bodies.</p>
	<p class="block_">If a body A applies a force F A on a body B, then the body B reacts with force F B on the body A, which is equal to F A in magnitude, but opposite in direction. F B = minus F A</p>
	<p class="block_12">Examples:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">When birds fly, they push the air downwards with their wings (Action) and the air pushes the bird upwards (Reaction).</li>
	<li class="block_7">When a person swims, he pushes the water using the hands backwards (Action), and the water pushes the swimmer in the forward direction (Reaction).</li>
	<li class="block_8">When you fire a bullet, the gun recoils backward and the bullet is moving forward (Action) and the gun equalizes this forward action by moving backward (Reaction).</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_19">1.8 PRINCIPLE OF CONSERVATION OF LINEAR MOMENTUM</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-16.png" alt="A QR Code for here with code of IJ9CQ" class="calibre30"/></p>
	<p class="block_">There is no change in the linear momentum of a system of bodies as long as no net external force acts on them. </p>
	<p class="block_">Let us prove the law of conservation of linear momentum with the following illustration:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-17.png" alt="This is a picture. In this picture  conservation of liner momentum is explained." class="calibre31"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Proof:</p>
	<p class="block_">Let two bodies A and B having masses m 1 and m 2 move with initial velocity u 1 and u 2 in a straight line. Let the velocity of the first body be higher than that of the second body that is . During an interval of time t second, they tend to have a collision. After the impact, both of them move along the same straight line with a velocity v 1 and v 2 respectively.</p>
	<p class="block_28">Force on body B due to A,  F A = m2 times (v 2 minus u 2) divided by t</p>
	<p class="block_29">Force on body A due to B, F B = m 1 times (v 1 minus u 1) divided by t</p>
	<p class="block_30">By Newton’s III law of motion, </p>
	<p class="block_30">Action force = Reaction force </p>
	<p class="block_30">F A<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>= minus F B</p>
	<p class="block_30">m 1 times (v 1 minus u 1) divided by t = minus m2 times (v 2 minus u 2) divided by t</p>
	<p class="block_">m 1 v 1 + m 2 v 2 = m 1 u 1 + m 2 u 2<span class="text_1"><span class="tab">      </span></span><span class="text_1"> equation </span>(1.9)</p>
	<p class="block_">The above equation confirms in the absence of an external force, the algebraic sum of the momentum after collision is numerically equal to the algebraic sum of the momentum before collision.</p>
	<p class="block_">Hence the law of conservation linear momentum is proved.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_20">1.9 ROCKET PROPULSION</h2>
	<p class="block_">Propulsion of rockets is based on the law of conservation of linear momentum as well as Newton’s III law of motion. Rockets are filled with a fuel (either liquid or solid) in the propellant tank. When the rocket is fired, this fuel is burnt and a hot gas is ejected with a high speed from the nozzle of the rocket, producing a huge momentum. To balance this momentum, an equal and opposite reaction force is produced in the combustion chamber, which makes the rocket project forward.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">While in motion, the mass of the rocket gradually decreases, until the fuel is completely burnt out. Since, there is no net external force acting on it, the linear momentum of the system is conserved. The mass of the rocket decreases with altitude, which results in the gradual increase in velocity of the rocket.  At one stage, it reaches a velocity, which is sufficient to just escape from the gravitational pull of the Earth. This velocity is called escape velocity. (This topic will be discussed in detail in higher classes).</span></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_21">1.10 GRAVITATION</h2>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_22">1.10.1 Newton’s universal law of gravitation</h3>
	<p class="block_9">This law states that every particle of matter in this universe attracts every other particle with a force. This force is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the centers of these masses. The direction of the force acts along the line joining the masses.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Force between the masses is always attractive and it does not depend on the medium where they are placed.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-18.png" alt="This is a picture. It explains about Gravitational force between two masses." class="calibre32"/></p>
	<p class="block_31">Let, m 1<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>and m 2<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>be the masses of two bodies A and B placed <i class="calibre33">r </i>meter apart in space</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-19.png" alt="F proportional to m1 multiply m2 F proportional one devided by R power 2 on combining the above two expressions F is proportional to m1 multiply m2 divided by r power two F proportional Gm1m2 devide by r power two " class="calibre34"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Where Gravity is the universal gravitational constant. Its value in SI unit is </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_23">1.10.2 Acceleration due to gravity (g)</h3>
	<p class="block_">When you throw any object upwards, its velocity ceases at a particular height and then it falls down due to the gravitational force of the Earth.</p>
	<p class="block_">The velocity of the object keeps changing as it falls down. This change in velocity must be due to the force acting on the object. The acceleration of the body is due to the Earth’s gravitational force. So, it is called as ‘acceleration due to the gravitational force of the Earth’ or ‘acceleration due to gravity of the Earth’. It is represented as ‘g’. Its unit is m s power minus 2.</p>
	<p class="block_">Mean value of the acceleration due to gravity is taken as 9.8 m s power minus 2 on the surface of the Earth. This means that the velocity of a body during the downward free fall motion varies by </p>
	<p class="block_">9.8 m s power minus 1 for every 1 second. However, the value of ‘g’ is not the same at all points on the surface of the earth.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_24">1.10.3 Relation between g and G</h3>
	<p class="block_">When a body is at rests on the surface of the Earth, it is acted upon by the gravitational force of the Earth. Let us compute the magnitude of this force in two ways. Let, M be the mass of the Earth and m be the mass of the body. The entire mass of the Earth is assumed to be concentrated at its centre. The radius of the Earth is R = 6378 km (= 6400 km approximately). By Newton’s law of gravitation, the force acting on the body is given by <span class="calibre28">F = GMm divided by R power 2  </span>equation 1.11</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-20.png" alt=" This is a picture, It explains about relation between g and G is explained." class="calibre35"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Here, the radius of the body considered   is negligible when compared with the Earth’s radius. Now, the same force can be obtained from Newton’s second law of motion. According to this law, the force acting on the body is given by the product of its mass and acceleration (called as weight). Here, acceleration of the body is under the action of gravity hence a = g</span></p>
	<p class="block_32">F=m a = m g</p>
	<p class="block_33"><span class="text_2">F = weight = m g  </span><span class="text_3">equation</span><span class="text_2"> (1.12)</span></p>
	<p class="block_34">Comparing equations (1.7) and (1.8), we get</p>
	<p class="block_"><i class="calibre33"> </i>  mg=GMm  divided by R power two equation 1.13</p>
	<p class="block_35">Acceleration due to gravity </p>
	<p class="block_"> g =GMm divided by R power two equation 1.14</p>
	<p class="block_36">1.10.4 Mass of the Earth (M) </p>
	<p class="block_36">Rearranging the equation (1.14), the mass of the Earth is obtained as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_36">Mass of the Earth M = g R power 2 by G</p>
	<p class="block_36">Substituting the known values of g, R and G, you can calculate the mass of the Earth as</p>
	<p class="block_36">M = 5.972 × 10 power 24 kg</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_25">1.10.5 Variation of acceleration due to gravity (g):</h3>
	<p class="block_">Since, g depends on the geometric radius of the Earth, (g is proportional  1 by R power 2), its value changes from one place to another on the surface of the Earth. Since, the geometric radius of the Earth is maximum in the equatorial region and minimum in the polar region, the value of g is maximum in the polar region and minimum at the equatorial region.</p>
	<p class="block_">When you move to a higher altitude from the surface of the Earth, the value of g reduces. In the same way, when you move deep below the surface of the Earth, the value of g reduces. (This topic will be discussed in detail in the higher classes). Value of g is zero at the centre of the Earth.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_26">1.11 MASS AND WEIGHT</h2>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Mass</b>: Mass is the basic property of a body. Mass of a body is defined as the quantity of matter contained in the body. Its SI unit is kilogram (kg).</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Weight:</b> Weight of a body is defined as the gravitational force exerted on it due to the Earth’s gravity alone.</p>
	<p class="block_37">Weight = Gravitational Force</p>
	<p class="block_38">= mass (m) × acceleration due to gravity (g).</p>
	<p class="block_9">g = acceleration due to gravity for Earth (at sea level) = 9.8 m s power minus 2.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">Weight is a vector quantity.  Direction of weight is always towards the centre of the Earth. SI unit of weight is newton (N). Weight of a body varies from one place to another place on the Earth since it depends on the acceleration due to gravity of the Earth (g) weight of a body is more at the poles than at the equatorial region.</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">The value of acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the moon is 1.625 m s power minus-2<span class="calibre15">. This is about 0.1654 times the acceleration due to gravity of the Earth. If a person whose mass   is 60 kg stands on the surface of Earth, his weight would be 588 N (W = mg = 60 × 9.8). If the same person goes to the surface of the Moon, he would weigh only 97.5 N </span></p>
	<p class="block_9">(W = 60 × 1.625). But his mass remains the same (60 kg) on both the Earth and the Moon.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_27">1.12 APPARENT WEIGHT</h2>
	<p class="block_9">The weight that you feel to possess during up and down motion, is not same as your actual weight. Apparent weight is the weight of the body acquired due to the action of gravity and other external forces acting on the body.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Let us see this from the following illustration:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-21.png" alt="This is an Image. It explains about an image shows a person in moving lift " class="calibre37"/></p>
	<p class="block_12"><span class="calibre28">  Figure 1.10 A person in a moving lift</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Let us consider a person of mass m, who is travelling in lift. The actual weight of the person is </p>
	<p class="block_">W = mg, which is acting vertically downwards. The reaction force exerted by the lift’s surface ‘R’, taken as apparent weight is acting vertically upwards. </p>
	<p class="block_">Let us see different possibilities of the apparent weight 'R' of the person that arise, depending on the motion of the lift; upwards or downwards which are given in Table </p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 1.2 Apparent weight of a person in a moving lift</p>

			<td class="td_36"><p class="block_54">R =0</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_37"><p class="block_55">Apparent weight is <b class="calibre6">greater </b>than the actual weight.</p></td>
			<td class="td_38"><p class="block_56">Apparent weight is <b class="calibre6">lesser </b>than the actual weight.</p></td>
			<td class="td_39"><p class="block_57">Apparent weight is <b class="calibre36">equal </b>to the actual weight.</p></td>
			<td class="td_40"><p class="block_58">Apparent weight is equal to <b class="calibre6">zero</b>.</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_28">1.12.1 Weightlessness</h3>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-22.png" alt="A QR code for is given with code of XIZ9I" class="calibre38"/></p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_">Have you gone to an amusement park and taken a ride in a roller coaster? or in a giant wheel? During the fast downward and upward movement, how did you feel?</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image204.png" alt="This is a picture. In this picture The people are travelling in a roller coaster." class="calibre39"/><b class="calibre6"> </b></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 1.11 Weightlessness in a roller coaster </p>
	<p class="block_">It’s amazing. You actually feel as if you are falling freely without having any weight. This is due to the phenomenon of ‘weightlessness’. You seem to have lost your weight when you move down with a certain acceleration. Sometimes, you experience the same feeling while travelling in a lift.</p>
	<p class="block_">When the person in a lift moves down with an acceleration (a) equal to the acceleration due to gravity (g), that is , when a = g, this motion is called as ‘free fall’. Here, the apparent weight</p>
	<p class="block_"> (R = m (g – g) = 0) bracket R equal to m bracket g minus g dash  of the person is zero. This condition or state refers to the state of weightlessness. (Refer case 4 from Table 1.2).</p>
	<p class="block_">The same effect takes place while falling freely in a roller coaster or on a swing or in a vertical giant wheel. You feel an apparent weight loss and weight gain when you are moving up and down in such rides.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_29">1.12.2 Weightlessness of the astronauts</h3>
	<p class="block_">Some of us believe that the astronauts in the orbiting space station do not experience any gravitational force of the Earth So they float. But this is absolutely wrong.</p>
	<p class="block_">Astronauts are not floating but falling freely around the earth due to their huge orbital<span class="calibre28"> velocity. Since space station and astronauts have equal acceleration, they are under free fall condition.  </span></p>
	<p class="block_">(R = 0 refer case 4 in Table 1.2). Hence, both the astronauts and the space station are in the state of weightlessness.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image205.png" alt="This is a picture It shows that The astronaut is floating on the space." class="calibre40"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 1.12 Weightlessness of astronauts</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_30">1.12.3 Application of Newton’s law of gravitation</h3>
	<p class="block_">1) Dimensions of the heavenly bodies can be measured using the gravitation law. Mass of the Earth, radius of the Earth, acceleration due to gravity, etcetera. can be calculated with a higher accuracy.</p>
	<p class="block_">2) Helps in discovering new stars and planets.</p>
	<p class="block_">3) One of the irregularities in the motion of stars is called ‘Wobble’ led to the disturbance in the motion of a planet nearby. In this condition the mass of the star can be calculated using the law of gravitation.</p>
	<p class="block_">4) Helps to explain germination of roots is due to the property of geotropism which is the property of a root responding to the gravity.</p>
	<p class="block_">5) Helps to predict the path of the astronomical bodies.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Points to Remember</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Mechanics is divided into statics and dynamics.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Ability of a body to maintain its state of rest or motion is called Inertia.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Moment of the couple is measured by the product of any one of the forces and the perpendicular distance between two forces.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> SI unit of force is Newton (N). C.G.S unit is dyne.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> When a force F acts on a body for a period of time t, then the product of force and time is known as ‘impulse’.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> The unit of weight is Newton or kilogram force.  </li>
	<li class="block_7"> The weight of a body is more at the poles than at the equatorial region.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Mass of a body is defined as the quantity of matter contained in the object. Its SI unit is kilogram (kg).</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Apparent weight is the weight of the body acquired due to the action of gravity and other external forces on the body.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Whenever a body or a person falls freely under the action of Earth’s gravitational force alone, it appears to have zero weight. This state is referred to as ‘weightlessness’.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_31">SOLVED PROBLEMS</h2>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Problem-1:</b> Calculate the velocity of a moving body of mass 5 kg whose linear momentum is </p>
	<p class="block_9">2.5 Kg m s power minus 1.</p>
	<p class="block_23"><b class="calibre36">Solution: </b>Linear momentum = mass × velocity </p>
	<p class="block_59">Velocity = linear momentum by mass.</p>
	<p class="block_60">V = two point five  by 5 = 0.5 m s power minus 1</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Problem 2:</b> A door is pushed, at a point whose distance from the hinges is 90 centimetre, with a force of </p>
	<p class="block_9">40 Newton. Calculate the moment of the force about the hinges.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_9">Formula: The moment of a force M = F × d Given: F = 40 Newton and d = 90 cm = 0.9 m.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Hence, moment of the force = 40 × 0.9 = 36 Nm.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Problem 3:</b> At what height from the centre of the Earth the acceleration due to gravity will be 1 by 4 th of its value as at the Earth.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_19">Data:</p>
	<p class="block_61">Height from the centre of the earth R dash  = R + h </p>
	<p class="block_61"><span class="text_4">The acceleration due to gravity at that height, g dash = g by </span><span class="text_5">4 </span></p>
	<p class="block_61">Formula:</p>
	<p class="block_61"><img src="images/image-23.png" alt="g is equal to G M by R square g dash is equal to G M by R dash square  g by g dash is equal to R dash by R whole square  is equal to R plus h by Rwhole square minus one plus h by R whole square. 4 is equal to 1 plus h by R whole square 2 is equal to 1 plus h by R or h is equal to R R dash is equal to 2 R from the centre of the earth the object is placed at twice the radius of the earth." class="calibre41"/></p>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_32">UNIT-2 OPTICS</h1>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_33"><img src="images/image-27.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of P2GKE" class="calibre45"/></h2>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_34">LearningObjectives </h2>
	<p class="block_">At the end of this lesson, students will be able to:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66"> state the laws of refraction.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> list the properties oflight.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> explain the scattering of light and its various kinds.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> understand the images formed by concave and convex lens.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> analyze the ray diagram of concave and convex lens.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> Understand the working of human eye and optical instruments</li>
	<li class="block_66"> solve numericalproblems</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_35">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">Light is a form of energy which travels in the form of waves. The path of light is called ray of light and group of these rays are called as beam of light. Any object which gives out light are termed as source of light. Some of the sources emit their own light and they are called as luminous objects. All the stars, including the Sun, are examples for luminous objects. We all know that we are able to see objects with the help of our eyes. But<span class="calibre28"> we cannot see any object in a dark room. Can you explain why?  If your answer is ‘we need light to see objects’, the next question is ‘if you make the light from a torch to fall on your eyes, will you be able to see the objects?’ Definitely, ‘NO’. We can see the objects only when the light is made to fall on the objects and the light reflected from the objects is viewed by our eyes. You would have studied about the reflection and refraction of light elaborately in your previous classes. In this chapter, we shall discuss about the scattering of light, images formed by convex and concave lenses, human eye and optical instruments such as telescopes and microscopes.</span></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_36">2.1 PROPERTIES OF LIGHT<span class="tab">      </span></h2>
	<p class="block_9">Let us recall the properties of light and the important aspects on refraction of light.</p>
	<p class="block_9">1. Light is a form of energy.</p>
	<p class="block_9">2. Light always travels along a straight line.</p>
	<p class="block_9">3. Light does not need any medium for its propagation. It can even travel through vacuum.</p>
	<p class="block_9">4. The speed of light in vacuum or air is, c = 3 × 10 power 8metre second power –1.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">5. Since, light is in the form of waves, it is characterized by a wavelength (λ) and   a frequency (ν), which are related by the following equation: c = </span>nu into lambda<span class="calibre15">  (c - velocity of light).</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">6. Different coloured light has different wavelength and frequency.</p>
	<p class="block_9">7. Among the visible light, violet light has the lowest wavelength and red light has the highest wavelength.</p>
	<p class="block_9">8. When light is incident on the interface between two media, it is partly reflected and partly refracted.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_37">2.2 REFRACTION OF LIGHT</h2>
	<p class="block_9">When a ray of light travels from one transparent medium into another obliquely, the path of the light undergoes deviation. This deviation of ray of light is called refraction. Refraction takes place due to the difference in the velocity of light in different media. The velocity of light is more in a rarer medium and less in a denser medium. Refraction of light obeys two laws of refraction.</p>
	<p class="block_12">2.2.1 First law of refraction:</p>
	<p class="block_">The incident ray, the refracted ray of light and the normal to the refracting surface all lie in the same plane.</p>
	<p class="block_12">2.2.2 Second law of refraction:</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">The ratio of the sine of the angle of incidence and sine of the angle of refraction   is equal to the ratio of refractive indices of the two media. This law is also known as Snell’s law.</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28"> sin i divided by sin r equal to mew2 divided by mew 1  2.1</span></p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_67">Refractive index gives us an idea of how fast or how slow light travels in a medium. The ratio of speed of light in vacuum to the speed of light in a medium is defined as refractive index mew of that medium.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_68">Mew  = c by v</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="2" class="block_69">The speed of light in a medium is low if the refractive index of the medium is high and vice versa.</li>
	<li class="block_69"> When light travels from a denser medium into a rarer medium, the refracted ray is bent away from the normal drawn to the interface.</li>
	<li class="block_70"><span class="calibre28"> When light travels from a rarer medium into a denser medium, the refracted ray    is bent towards the normal drawn to the interface.</span></li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_38">2.3 REFRACTION OF A COMPOSITE LIGHT- DISPERSION OF LIGHT</h2>
	<p class="block_">We know that Sun is the fundamental and natural source of light. If a source of light produces a light of single colour, it is known as a monochromatic source. On the other hand, a composite source of light produces a white light which contains light of different colours. Sun light is a composite light which consists of light of various colours or wavelengths. Another example for a composite source is a mercury vapour lamp. What do you observe when a white light is refracted through a glass prism?</p>
	<p class="block_">When a beam of white light or composite light is refracted through any transparent media such as glass or water, it is split into its component colours. This phenomenon is called as ‘dispersion of light’.</p>
	<p class="block_">The band of colours is termed as spectrum. This spectrum consists of following colours: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Red. These colours are represented by the acronym “VIBGYOR”. Why do we get the spectrum when white light is refracted by a transparent medium? This is because, different coloured lights are bent through different angles. That is the angle of refraction is different for different colours.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Angle of refraction is the smallest for red and the highest for violet. From Snell’s law, we know that the angle of refraction is determined in terms of the refractive index of the medium. Hence, the refractive index of the medium is different for different coloured lights. This indicates that the refractive index of a medium is dependent on the wavelength of the light.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_39">2.4 SCATTERING OF LIGHT</h2>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">When sunlight enters the Earth’s atmosphere, the atoms and molecules of different gases present in the atmosphere refract the light in all possible directions.  This is called as ‘Scattering of light’. In this phenomenon, the beam of light is redirected in all directions when it interacts with a particle of medium. The interacting particle of the medium is called as ‘scatterer’.</span><img src="images/image327.jpeg" alt="This is a picture. Scattering of light - Explained. When light falls on the dust particles, it is scattered into atmosphere." class="calibre46"/><b class="calibre36"> </b></p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 2.1 Scattering of light</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_40">2.4.1 Types of scattering</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">When a beam of light, interacts with   a constituent particle of the medium, it undergoes many kinds of scattering.  Based on initial and final energy of the light beam, scattering can be classified as,</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">1)  Elastic scattering   2) Inelastic scattering</span></p>
	<p class="block_12">1) Elastic scattering</p>
	<p class="block_">If the energy of the incident beam of light and the scattered beam of light are same, then it is called as ‘elastic scattering’.</p>
	<p class="block_">2) Inelastic<span class="calibre28">  </span> scattering</p>
	<p class="block_">If the energy of the incident beam of light and the scattered beam of light are not same, then it is called as ‘inelastic scattering’. The nature and size of the scatterer results in different types of scattering. They are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Rayleigh scattering</li>
	<li class="block_7">Mie scattering</li>
	<li class="block_7">Tyndall scattering</li>
	<li class="block_8">Raman scattering</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_19">Rayleigh scattering</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">The scattering of sunlight by the atoms   or molecules of the gases in the earth’s atmosphere is known as Rayleigh scattering.</span></p>
	<p class="block_19">Rayleigh’s scattering law</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">Rayleigh’s scattering law states that, “The amount of scattering of light is inversely proportional to the fourth power of its wavelength”. Amount of scattering ‘S’  </span>proportional  1 by lambta power 4 According to this law, the shorter wavelength colours are scattered much more than the longer wavelength colours.</p>
	<p class="block_9">When sunlight passes through the atmosphere, the blue colour (shorter wavelength) is scattered to a greater extent than the red colour (longer wavelength). This scattering causes the sky to appear in blue colour.</p>
	<p class="block_9">At sunrise and sunset, the light rays from the Sun have to travel a larger distance in the atmosphere than at noon. Hence, most of the blue lights are scattered away and only the red light which gets least scattered reaches us. Therefore, the colour of the Sun is red at sunrise and sunset.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Mie scattering</p>
	<p class="block_9">Mie scattering takes place when the diameter of the scatterer is similar to or larger than the wavelength of the incident light. It is also an elastic scattering. The amount of scattering is independent of wavelength.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Mie scattering is caused by pollen, dust, smoke, water droplets, and other particles in the lower portion of the atmosphere.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Mie scattering is responsible for the white appearance of the clouds. When white light falls on the water drop, all the colours are equally scattered which together form the white light.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Tyndall Scattering</p>
	<p class="block_">When a beam of sunlight, enters into a dusty room through a window, then its path becomes visible to us. This is because, the tiny dust particles present in the air of the room scatter the beam of light. This is an example of Tyndall Scattering.</p>
	<p class="block_">The scattering of light rays by the colloidal particles in the colloidal solution is called Tyndall Scattering or Tyndall Effect.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Do you Know</p>
	<p class="block_9">Colloid is a microscopically small substance that is equally dispersed throughout another material. Example: Milk, Ice cream, muddy water, smoke</p>
	<p class="block_12">Raman scattering</p>
	<p class="block_">When a parallel beam of monochromatic (single coloured) light passes through a gas or liquid or transparent solid, a part of light rays is scattered.</p>
	<p class="block_">The scattered light contains some additional frequencies (or wavelengths) other than that of incident frequency (or wavelength). This is known as Raman scattering or Raman Effect.</p>
	<p class="block_">Raman Scattering is defined as “The interaction of light ray with the particles of pure liquids or transparent solids, which leads to a change in wavelength or frequency.”</p>
	<p class="block_">The spectral lines having frequency equal to the incident ray frequency is called ‘Rayleigh line’ and the spectral lines which are having frequencies other than the incident ray frequency are called ‘Raman lines. The lines having frequencies lower than the incident frequency is called stokes lines and the lines having frequencies higher than the incident frequency are called Anti-stokes lines.</p>
	<p class="block_">You will study more about Raman Effect in higher classes.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_41">2.5 LENSES</h2>
	<p class="block_">A lens is an optically transparent medium bounded by two spherical refracting surfaces or one plane and one spherical surface.</p>
	<p class="block_">Lens is basically classified into two types.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">They are:</b> (one) Convex Lens (two) Concave Lens</p>
	<p class="block_21" id="calibre_pb_2"> </p>
</body></html>

<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:epub="http://www.idpf.org/2007/ops" lang="en" xml:lang="en">

  <body class="calibre">
<p class="block_">(one) Convex or bi-convex lens: It is a lens bounded by two spherical surfaces such that it is thicker at the centre than at the edges. A beam of light passing through it, is converged to a point. So, a convex lens is also called as converging lens.</p>
	<p class="block_">(two) Concave or bi-concave Lens: It is a lens bounded by two spherical surfaces such that it is thinner at the centre than at the edges. A parallel beam of light passing through it, is diverged or spread out. So, a concave lens is also called as diverging lens.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_42">2.5.1 Other types of Lenses</h3>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Plano-convex lens: </b>If one of the faces of a bi-convex lens is plane, it is known as a Plano convex lens.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Plano-concave lens:</b> If one of the faces of a bi-concave lens is plane, it is known as a Plano concave lens.</p>
	<p class="block_">All these lenses are shown in Figure 2.2 given below:</p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image328.jpeg" alt="This picture is about types of convex and concave lenses - Biconvex lens planoconvex lens and positive meniscus Bi concave lens  plan concave lens negative meniscus " class="calibre47"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 2.2 Types of lenses</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_43">2.6 IMAGES FORMED DUE TO REFRACTION THROUGH A CONVEX AND CONCAVE LENS</h2>
	<p class="block_">When an object is placed in front of a lens, the light rays from the object fall on the lens. The position, size and nature of the image formed can be understood only if we know certain basic rules.</p>
	<p class="block_">Rule-1: When a ray of light strikes the convex or concave lens obliquely at its optical centre, it continues to follow its path without any deviation (Figure2.3)</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image329.jpeg" alt="This picture is about the Rays passing through the optical centre " class="calibre48"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 2.3 Rays passing through the optical centre</p>
	<p class="block_">Rule-2: When rays parallel to the principal axis strikes a convex or concave lens, the refracted rays are converged to (convex lens) or appear to diverge from (concave lens) the principal focus (Figure2.4).</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image333.jpeg" alt="This picture is about the Ray passing parallel to the optic axis " class="calibre49"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 2.4 Rays passing parallel to the optic axis</p>
	<p class="block_">Rule-3: When a ray passing through (convex lens) or directed towards (concave lens) the principal focus strikes a convex or concave lens, the refracted ray will be parallel to the principal axis (Figure2.5).<img src="images/image334.jpeg" alt="This picture is about the Rays passing through or directed towards the principal focus " class="calibre50"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 2.5 Rays passing through or directed towards the principal focus</p>
	<div class="calibre51">
	<div class="block_71" id="toc_id_44"><span class="bullet_1">2.7 </span><span class="calibre52">REFRACTION THROUGH A CONVEX LENS</span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_72"><img src="images/image-28.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of 9W1HC" class="calibre42"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Let us discuss the formation of images by a convex lens when the object is placed at various positions.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Object at infinity</p>
	<p class="block_">When an object is placed at infinity, a real image is formed at the principal focus. The size of the image is much smaller than that of the object (Figure2.6).</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image331.jpeg" alt="This picture is about theObject at infinity Explained in the text book." class="calibre53"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 2.6 Object at infinity</p>
	<p class="block_12">Object placed beyond C(greater than 2F)</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image332.jpeg" alt="This picture is about the Object placed beyond C(&gt;2F) Explained in the text book " class="calibre54"/><b class="calibre6"> </b></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 2.7 Object placed beyond C( greater than 2F)</p>
	<p class="block_">When an object is placed behind the centre of curvature (beyond C), a real and inverted image is formed between the centre of curvature and the principal focus. The size of the image is the smaller than that of the object (Figure2.7).</p>
	<p class="block_12">Object placed at C</p>
	<p class="block_">When an object is placed at the centre of curvature, a real and inverted image is formed at the other centre of curvature. The size of the image is the same as that of the object (Figure2.8).</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image335.jpeg" alt="This picture is about the Image formation when the object is placed at the center of curvature " class="calibre55"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure.2.8 Object placed at C</p>
	<p class="block_12">Object placed between F and C</p>
	<p class="block_">When an object is placed in between the centre of curvature and principal focus, a real and inverted image is formed behind the centre of curvature. The size of the image is bigger than that of the object (Figure2.9).</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image336.jpeg" alt="This picture is about the Object placed between F and C " class="calibre56"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 2.9 Object placed between F and C</p>

	<p class="block_"> </p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 2.10 Object placed at the principal focus F</p>
	<p class="block_">When an object is placed at the focus, a real image is formed at infinity. The size of the image is much larger than that of the object (Figure2.10).</p>
	<p class="block_12">Object placed between the principal focus F and optical centre O</p>
	<p class="block_">When an object is placed in between principal focus and optical centre, a virtual image is formed. The size of the image is larger than that of the object (Figure2.11).</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-30.png" alt="Figure 2.11 The image formation of  lens when the Object placed between the principal focus F and optical centre" class="calibre58"/></p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_45">2.8 APPLICATIONS OF CONVEX LENSES</h2>
	<p class="block_">1. Convex lenses are used as camera lenses</p>
	<p class="block_">2. They are used as magnifying lenses</p>
	<p class="block_">3. They are used in making microscope, telescope and slide projectors</p>
	<p class="block_">4. They are used to correct the defect of vision called hypermetropia</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_46">2.9 REFRACTION THROUGH A CONCAVE LENS</h2>
	<p class="block_">Let us discuss the formation of images by a concave lens when the object is placed at two possible positions.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Object at Infinity</p>
	<p class="block_73">When an object is placed at infinity, a virtual image is formed at the focus. The size of the image is much smaller than that of the object (Figure2.12).</p>
	<p class="block_73"><img src="images/image-31.png" alt="Figure 2.12 The image formation of  Concave lens when Object at infinity" class="calibre59"/></p>
	<p class="block_74">Figure 2.12 Concave Lens-Object at infinity</p>
	<p class="block_19">Object anywhere on the principal axis at a finite distance</p>
	<p class="block_9">When an object is placed at a finite distance from the lens, a virtual image is formed between optical centre and focus of the concave lens. The size of the image is smaller than that of the object (Figure2.13).</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-32.png" alt="This is a picture about The image formation of  Concave lens when Object at a finite distance" class="calibre60"/></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">Figure 2.13 Concave Lens-Object at a finite distance</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_">But, as the distance between the object and the lens is decreased, the distance between the image and the lens also keeps decreasing. Further, the size of the image formed increases as the distance between the object and the lens is decreased. This is shown in (figure2.14).</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-33.png" alt="This is a picture which explains Concave lens-Variation in position and size of image with object distance at various position" class="calibre61"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 2.14 Concave lens-Variation in position and size of image with object distance</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_47">2.10 APPLICATIONS OF CONCAVE LENSES</h2>
	<p class="block_9">1. Concave lenses are used as eye lens of ‘GalileanTelescope’</p>
	<p class="block_9">2. They are used in wide angle spy hole in doors.</p>
	<p class="block_9">3. They are used to correct the defect of vision called‘myopia’</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_48">2.11 LENS FORMULA</h2>
	<p class="block_">Like spherical mirrors, we have lens formula for spherical lenses. The lens formula gives the relationship among distance of the object (u), distance of the image (v) and the focal length (f) of the lens. It is expressed as 1 one by f equal to 1 by v minus 1 by u equation 2.2</p>
	<p class="block_">It is applicable to both convex and concave lenses. We need to give an at most care while solving numerical problems related to lenses in taking proper signs of different quantities.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_49">2.12 SIGN CONVENTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">Cartesian sign conventions are used for measuring the various distances in the ray diagrams of spherical lenses. According to cartesian sign convention,</p>
	<p class="block_">1. The object is always placed on the left side of the lens.</p>
	<p class="block_">2. All the distances are measured from the optical centre of the lens.</p>
	<p class="block_">3. The distances measured in the same direction as that of incident light are taken as positive.</p>
	<p class="block_">4. The distances measured against the direction of incident light are taken as negative.</p>
	<p class="block_">5. The distances measured upward and perpendicular to the principal axis is taken as positive.</p>
	<p class="block_">6. The distances measured downward and perpendicular to the principal axis is taken as negative.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_50">2.13 MAGNIFICATION OF A LENS</h2>
	<p class="block_">Like spherical mirrors, we have magnification for spherical lenses. Spherical lenses produce magnification and it is defined as the ratio of the height of the image to the height of an object. Magnification is denoted by the letter ‘m’. If height of the object is h and height of the image is h´, the magnification produced by lens is m = height of the image divided by height of the object =  h dash by h equation 2.3</p>
	<p class="block_">Also, it is related to the distance of the object (u) and the distance of the image (v) as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_">M = distance of the image divided by distance of the object = v by u equation 2.4</p>
	<p class="block_">If the magnification is greater than 1, then we get an enlarged image. On the other hand, if the magnification is less than 1, then we get a diminished image.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_51">2.14 LENS MAKER’S FORMULA</h2>
	<p class="block_61">All lenses are made up of transparent materials. Any optically transparent material will have a refractive index. The lens formula relates the focal length of a lens with the distance of object and image. For a maker of any lens, knowledge of radii of curvature of the lens is required. This clearly indicates the need for an equation relating the radii of curvature of the lens, the refractive index of the given material of the<span class="calibre28"> lens and the required focal length of the lens. The lens maker’s formula is one such equation. It is given as  </span> one by f equal to mew minus one into one by R1 minus one by R2 equation 2.5</p>
	<p class="block_">where mew is the refractive index of the material of the lens; R1 and R2 are the radii of curvature of the two faces of the lens; f is the focal length of the lens.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_52">2.15 POWER OF A LENS</h2>
	<p class="block_">When a ray of light falls on a lens, the ability to converge or diverge these light rays depends on the focal length of the lens. This ability of a lens to converge (convex lens) or diverge (concave lens) is called as its power. Hence, the power of a lens can be defined as the degree of convergence or divergence of light rays. Power of a lens is numerically defined as the reciprocal of its focal length.</p>
	<p class="block_61">p equal to one by f equation 2.6</p>
	<p class="block_">The SI unit of power of a lens is dioptre. It is represented by the symbol D. If focal length is expressed in ‘m’, then the power of lens is expressed in ‘D’ Thus 1D is the power of a lens, whose focal length is 1metre. 1D = 1metre<b class="calibre6"> </b>power minus1.</p>
	<p class="block_">By convention, the power of a convex lens is taken as positive whereas the power of a concave lens is taken, as negative.</p>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_">The lens formula and lens maker’s formula are applicable to only thin lenses. In the case of thick lenses, these formulae with little modifications are used.</p>
