	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_53">2.16 HUMAN EYE </h2>
	<p class="block_">The human eyes are most valuable and sensitive organs responsible for vision. They are the gateway to the wonderful world.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Structure of the eye</p>
	<p class="block_">The eye ball is approximately spherical in shape with a diameter of about 2.3 cm. It consists of a tough membrane called sclera, which protects the internal parts of the eye. Important parts of human eye are</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Cornea:</b> This is the thin and transparent layer on the front surface of the eyeball as shown in figure 2.15. It is the main refracting surface. When light enters through the cornea, it refracts or bends the light on to the lens.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Iris:</b> It is the coloured part of the eye. It may be blue, brown or green in colour. Every person has a unique colour, pattern and texture. Iris controls amount of light entering into the pupil like camera aperture.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Pupil:</b> It is the centre part of the Iris. It is the pathway for the light to retina.</p>
	<p class="block_">Retina: This is the back surface of the eye. It is the most sensitive part of human eye, on which real and inverted image of objects is formed.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Eye Lens –</b> It is the important part of human eye. It is convex in nature.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Ciliary muscles –</b> Eye lens is fixed between the ciliary muscles. It helps to change the focal length of the eye lens according to the position of the object. </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-34.png" alt="This is a diagram which explains about the human eye with its parts is given." class="calibre62"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Working of the eye</p>
	<p class="block_">The transparent layer cornea bends the light rays through pupil located at the centre part of the Iris. The adjusted light passes through the eye lens. Eye lens is convex in nature. So, the light rays from the objects are converged and a real and inverted image is formed on retina. Then, retina passes the received real and inverted image to the brain through optical nerves. Finally, the brain senses it as erects image.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Power of Accommodation</p>
	<p class="block_">The ability of the eye lens to focus nearby as well as the distant objects is called power of accommodation of the eye. This is achieved by changing the focal length of the eye lens with the help of ciliary muscles. Eye lens is made of a flexible, jelly-like material. By relaxing and contracting the ciliary muscle, the curvature and hence the call length of the eye lens can be altered. When we see distant objects, the ciliary muscle relaxes and makes the eye lens thinner. This increases the focal length of the eye lens. Hence, the distant object can be clearly seen. On the other hand, when we look at a closer object, the focal length of the eye lens is decreased by the contraction of ciliary muscle. Thus, the image of the closer object is clearly formed on the retina.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Persistence of vision</p>
	<p class="block_9">If the time interval between two consecutive light pulses is less than 1 by 16 second, human eye cannot distinguish them separately. It is called persistence of vision.</p>
	<p class="block_12">The far point and near point of the human eye</p>
	<p class="block_">The minimum distance required to see the objects distinctly without strain is called least distance of distinct vision. It is called as near point of eye. It is 25 cm for normal human eye.</p>
	<p class="block_">The maximum distance up to which the eye can see objects clearly is called as far point of the eye. It is infinity for normal eye.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_54">2.17 DEFECTS IN EYE</h2>
	<p class="block_">A normal human eye can clearly see all the objects placed between 25cm and infinity. But, for some people, the eye loses its power of accommodation. This could happen due to many reasons including ageing. Hence, their vision becomes defective. Let us discuss some of the common defects of human eye.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Myopia</p>
	<p class="block_">Myopia, also known as short sightedness, occurs due to the lengthening of eye ball. With this defect, nearby objects can be seen clearly but distant objects cannot be seen clearly. The focal length of eye lens is reduced or the distance between eye lens and retina increases. Hence, the far point will not be infinity for such eyes and the far point has come closer. Due to this, the image of distant objects is formed before the retina (Figure 2.16-a). This defect can be corrected using a concave lens (Figure 2.16-b). The focal length of the concave lens to be used is computed as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-35.png" alt="There are two diagrams given. they are a) vision with myopia  b) corrected  vision using a concave lens" class="calibre63"/></p>
	<p class="block_61">Let a person with myopia eye can see up to a distance x. Suppose that he wants to see all objects farther than this distance, that is up to infinity. Then the focal length of the required concave lens is</p>
	<p class="block_61"> f = minus x. If the person can see up to a distance x and he wishes to see up to a distance y, then, the focal length of the required concave lens is, <i class="calibre33"> x times y by x minus y equation 2.7</i></p>
	<p class="block_12">Hypermetropia</p>
	<p class="block_">Hypermetropia, also known as long sightedness, occurs due to the shortening of eye ball. With this defect, distant objects can be seen clearly but nearby objects cannot be seen clearly. The focal length of eye lens is increased or the distance between eye lens and retina decreases. Hence, the near point will not be at 25cm for such eyes and the near point has moved farther. Due to this, the image of nearby objects is formed behind the retina (Figure 2.17-a). This defect can be corrected using a convex lens (Figure 2.17-b). The focal length of the convex lens to be used is computed as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-36.png" alt="A figure is given which explains a vision with hypermetropia  b) corrected  vision using a concave lens " class="calibre64"/></p>
	<p class="block_61">Let a person with hypermetropia eye can see object beyond a distance d. Suppose that he wants to see all objects closer than this distance up to a distance D. Then, the focal length of the required convex lens is <i class="calibre33"><span class="calibre28">  </span></i>f equal to d times D by d minus D. equation 2.8</p>
	<p class="block_12">Presbyopia</p>
	<p class="block_">Due to ageing, ciliary muscles become weak and the eye-lens become rigid (inflexible) and so the eye loses its power of accommodation.</p>
	<p class="block_">Because of this, an aged person cannot see the nearby objects clearly. So, it is also called as ‘old age hypermetropia’.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Some persons may have both the defects of vision - myopia as well as hypermetropia. This can be corrected by ‘bifocal lenses’ in which, upper part consists of concave lens (to correct myopia) used for distant vision and the lower part consists of convex lens (to correct hypermetropia) used for reading purposes.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Astigmatism</p>
	<p class="block_9">In this defect, eye cannot see parallel and horizontal lines clearly. It may be inherited or acquired. It is due to the imperfect structure of eye lens because of the development of cataract on the lens, ulceration of cornea, injury to the refracting surfaces, etcetera. Astigmatism can be corrected by using cylindrical lenses. </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_55">2.18 MICROSCOPE</h2>
	<p class="block_">This is an optical instrument, which helps us to see tiny (very small) objects. It is classified as</p>
	<p class="block_">1. Simple microscope</p>
	<p class="block_">2. Compound microscope</p>
	<p class="block_12">Simple Microscope</p>
	<p class="block_">Simple microscope has a convex lens of short focal length. It is held near the eye to get enlarged image of small object Let an object (A B) is placed at a point within the principal focus (u less than f) of the convex lens and the observer’s eye is placed just behind the lens.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-37.png" alt="This is a figure about simple microscope  f" class="calibre65"/></p>
	<p class="block_">As per this position the convex lens produces an erect, virtual and enlarged image A dash b dash. The image formed is in the same side of the object and the distance equal to the least distance of distinct vision (D) (For normal human eye D = 25 cm).</p>
	<p class="block_12">Uses of Simple microscope </p>
	<p class="block_74">Simple microscopes are used</p>
	<p class="block_74">a) by watch repairers and jewellers.</p>
	<p class="block_74">b) to read small letters clearly.</p>
	<p class="block_74">c) to observe parts of flower, insects etc.</p>
	<p class="block_74">d) to observe finger prints in the field of forensic science.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Compound microscope</p>
	<p class="block_9">Compound microscope is also used to see the tiny objects. It has better magnification power than simple microscope. Magnification power of microscopes can be increased by decreasing the focal length of the lens used. Due to constructional limitations, the focal length of the lens cannot be decreased beyond certain limit. This problem can be solved by using two separate biconvex lenses.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Construction</p>
	<p class="block_">A compound microscope consists of two convex lenses. The lens with the shorter focal length is placed near the object, and is called as ‘objective lens’ or ‘objective piece’. The lens with larger focal length and larger aperture placed near the observer’s eye is called as ‘eye lens’ or ‘eye piece’. Both the lenses are fixed in a narrow tube with adjustable provision.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Working</p>
	<p class="block_">The object (AB) is placed at a distance slightly greater than the focal length of objective lens (u &gt;of) u greater than fo. A real, inverted and magnified image (A'B') is formed at the other side of the objective lens.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-38.png" alt="Image formation in compound microscope figure is given " class="calibre66"/></p>
	<p class="block_">This image behaves as the object for the eye lens. The position of the eye lens is adjusted in such a way, that the image (A'B') A dash B dash falls within the principal focus of the eye piece. This eye piece forms a virtual, enlarged and erect image (A" B") A double dash B double dash on the same side of the object</p>
	<p class="block_">Compound microscope has 50 to 200 times more magnification power than simple microscope</p>
	<p class="block_">Travelling Microscope</p>
	<p class="block_">A travelling microscope is one of the best instruments for measuring very small length with high degree of accuracy at the order of 0.01mm. It works based on the principle of vernier. Its least count is 0.01 mm.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_56">2.19 TELESCOPE</h2>
	<p class="block_9">Have you seen the recent lunar eclipse? With our naked eye we can’t visualize the phenomena distinctly. Then, how can we see the distant object in clearer manner? It is possible with telescope.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Telescope is an optical instrument to see the distant objects. The first telescope was invented by Johann Lippershey in 1608. Galileo made a telescope to observe distant stars. He got the idea, from a spectacle maker who one day observed that the distant weather cock appeared magnified through his lens system fitted in his shop. Galileo observed the satellites of Jupiter and the rings of Saturn through his telescope. Kepler invented Telescope in1611 which was fundamentally similar to the astronomical telescope.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Types of Telescopes</p>
	<p class="block_12">According to optical property, it is classified into two groups:</p>
	<p class="block_">one) refracting telescope two) reflecting telescope</p>
	<p class="block_">In refracting telescope lenses are used. Galilean telescope, Keplerian telescope, Achromatic refractors, are some refracting telescopes.</p>
	<p class="block_">In reflecting telescope parabolic mirrors are used Gregorian, Newtonian, Cassegrain telescope are some Reflecting telescopes According to the things which are observed, Astronomical Telescope and Terrestrial Telescopes are the two major types of telescopes.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Astronomical Telescope</p>
	<p class="block_">An astronomical telescope is used to view heavenly bodies like stars, planets galaxies and satellites.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Terrestrial Telescopes</p>
	<p class="block_">The image in an astronomical telescope is inverted. So, it is not suitable for viewing objects on the surface of the Earth .There fore, a terrestrial telescope is used. It provides an erect image. The major difference between astronomical and terrestrial telescope is erecting the final image with respect to the object.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Advantages of Telescopes</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">Elaborate view of the Galaxies, Planets, stars and other heavenly bodies is possible.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Camera can be attached for taking photograph for the celestial objects.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Telescope can be viewed even with the low intensity of light.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_19">Disadvantages</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">Frequent maintenances needed.</li>
	<li class="block_66">It is not easily portable one.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_57">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Light is a form of energy which travels along a straight line</li>
	<li class="block_7">The deviation in the path of light ray is called refraction.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The ratio of speed of light in vacuum to the speed of light in a medium is defined as refractive index ‘μ’ of that medium.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The ability of the eye to focus nearby as well as the distant objects is called power of accommodation of the eye.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A microscope is an optical instrument which helps us to see the objects which are very small in dimension.</li>
	<li class="block_8"> Telescope is an optical instrument used to see the distant objects clearly.</li>
</ol>

<p class="block_12">PROBLEM 2</p>
	<p class="block_">A beam of light passing through a diverging lens of focal length 0.3m appear to be focused at a distance 0.2m behind the lens. Find the position of the object.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-39.png" alt="f equal to minus 0 point 3metre, v equal to minus 0 point 2 metre. one by f equal to one by v minus  one by u. one by u equal to one by v minus one by f. one by u equal to one by minus zero point two minus one by minus zero point three. equal to minus ten by six. u equal to minus 6 by ten. equal to minus zero point six metre." class="calibre67"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Problem3</p>
	<p class="block_">A person with myopia can see objects placed at a distance of 4m. If he wants to see objects at a distanceof20m, what should be the focal length and power of the concave lens she must wear?</p>
	<p class="block_">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_">Given that x = 4 meter and y = 20 meter.</p>
	<p class="block_">Focal length of the correction lens is f = x into y divided by x minus y<span class="calibre28">   refer eq</span>uation . 2.7</p>
	<p class="block_">f = 4 multiply by 20 divided by 4 minus 20 = 80 divided by minus 16 = minus 5 meter</p>
	<p class="block_">Power of the correction lens = 1 by f = minus 1 by 5 = minus 0.2 Diaptor </p>
	<p class="block_12">Problem4</p>
	<p class="block_">For a person with hypermetropia, the near point has moved to 1.5m. Calculate the focal length of the correction lens in order to make his eyes normal.</p>
	<p class="block_">Given that d=1.5 meter , D=25centimeter =0.25meter (For a normal eye)</p>
	<p class="block_">From equation 2.8, the focal length of correction lens is</p>
	<p class="block_">f = d in to D divided by d minus D = 1.5 multiplied by 0.25 divided by 1.5 minus 0.25 = 0.375 divided by 1.25 = 0.3 meter.</p>

	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">2. Assertion:</b> Myopia is due to the increase in the converging power of eye lens.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Reason:</b> Myopia can be corrected with the help of concave lens.</p>

	<h1 class="block_99" id="toc_id_60">UNIT-3 THERMAL PHYSICS</h1>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_61">Learning Objectives: </h2>
	<p class="block_100"><img src="images/image-43.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of 6DHGS" class="calibre71"/></p>
	<p class="block_100">At the end of this lesson, students will be able to</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_101">Understand the concept of heat and temperature</li>
	<li class="block_102">Know the absolute scale of temperature</li>
	<li class="block_102">Understand the thermal energy and the thermal equilibrium</li>
	<li class="block_102">Classification of expansion of substances</li>
	<li class="block_102">Know the fundamental laws of gases</li>
	<li class="block_102">Distinguish between real gas and ideal gas</li>
	<li class="block_102">Derive the ideal gas equation</li>
	<li class="block_102">Solve the numerical problems</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_62">INTRODUCTION:</h2>
	<p class="block_">Sun is the primary source of thermal energy for all living organisms. Thermal energy is the cause and temperature are the effect. All living organisms need a particular temperature for their survival. In the kitchen, a container with a steel bottom is placed on the induction stove. Do you know why? All of us have a common man’s understanding of thermal energy and temperature. But, in this chapter, you shall learn about thermal energy and temperature in a scientific manner. We shall also discuss about how thermal energy is transferred and the effects of thermal energy.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_63">3.1 TEMPERATURE</h2>
	<p class="block_">Temperature is defined as the degree of hotness of a body. The temperature is higher for a hotter body than for a colder body. It is also be defined as the property which determines whether a body is in equilibrium or not with the surroundings. (Or<span class="calibre28"> average kinetic energy of the molecules). Further, temperature is the property, which determines the direction of flow of heat. It is   a scalar quantity. The SI unit of temperature   is kelvin (K). There are other commonly used units of temperature such as degree Celsius (°C) and degree Fahrenheit (°F).</span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_64">3.1.1 Absolute scale (kelvin scale) of temperature</h3>
	<p class="block_">The temperature measured in relation to absolute zero using the kelvin scale is known as absolute<span class="calibre28">  scale</span> temperature. It is also known as the thermodynamic temperature. Each unit of the thermodynamic scale of temperature is defined as the fraction of 1by273.16th part of the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water. A temperature difference of 1°C is equal to that of 1Kelvin. Zero Kelvin is the absolute scale of tempter of the body.</p>
	<p class="block_">The relation between the different types of scale of temperature:</p>
	<p class="block_">Celsius and Kelvin: K = C + 273,</p>
	<p class="block_">Fahrenheit and Kelvin:  K = open bracket F PLUS 460 close bracket into 5 by 9 </p>
	<p class="block_">0 Kelvin = minus 273°C.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_65">3.1.2 Thermal equilibrium</h3>
	<p class="block_">Two or more physical systems or bodies are said to be in thermal equilibrium if there is no net flow of thermal energy between the systems. Heat energy always flows from one body to the other due to a temperature difference between them. Thus, you can define thermal equilibrium in another way. If two bodies are said to be in thermal equilibrium, then, they will be at the same temperature. What will happen if two bodies at different temperatures are brought in contact with one other? There will be a transfer of heat energy from the hot body to the cold body until a thermal equilibrium is established between them. This is depicted in Figure 3.1.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 3.1 Establishing thermal equilibrium</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image451.jpeg" alt="This is a picture. It establishing thermal equilibrium between hot and cold objects." class="calibre72"/><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_">When a cold body is placed in contact with a hot body, some thermal energy is transferred from the hot body to the cold body. As a result, there is some rise in the temperature of the cold body and decrease in the temperature of the hot body. This process will continue until these two bodies attain the same temperature.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_66">3.2 THERMAL ENERGY</h2>
	<p class="block_">If you leave a cup of hot milk on a table for some time, what happens? The hotness of the milk decreases after some time. Similarly, if you keep a bottle of cold water on a table, the water becomes warmer after some time. What do you infer from these observations? In the case of hot milk, there is a flow of energy from the cup of milk to the environment. In the second case, the energy is transferred from the environment to the water bottle. This energy is termed as “thermal energy”.</p>
	<p class="block_">When a hot object is in contact with another cold object, a form of energy flows from the hot object to the cold object, which is known as thermal energy. Thus, thermal energy is a form of energy which is transferred between any two bodies due to the difference in their temperatures. Thermal energy is also known as 'heat energy' or simply 'heat'.</p>
	<p class="block_">Heat energy is the agent, which produces the sensation of warmth and makes bodies hot. The process in which heat energy flows from a body at a higher temperature to another object at lower temperature is known as heating. This process of transmission of heat may be done in any of the ways like conduction, convection or radiation. Heat is a scalar quantity. The SI unit of heat energy absorbed or evolved is joule (J) </p>
	<p class="block_">During the process of transferring heat energy, the body at lower temperature is heated while the body at higher temperature is cooled. Thus, sometimes, this process of transfer of heat energy is termed as 'cooling'. But, in most of the cases the term 'heating' is used instead of 'cooling'. When the thermal energy is transferred from one body to another, this results in the rise or lowering of the temperature of either of the bodies.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_67">3.2.1 Characteristic features of heat energy transfer</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Heat always flows from a system at higher temperature to a system at lower temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The mass of a system is not altered when it is heated or cooled.</li>
	<li class="block_8">For any exchange of heat, the heat gained by the cold system is equal to heat lost by the hot system. </li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">Heat gained = Heat lost</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_68">3.2.2 Other units of Heat energy</h3>
	<p class="block_">Though the SI unit of heat energy is joule, there are some other commonly used units.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Calorie:</b> One calorie is defined as the amount of heat energy required to rise the temperature of 1 gram of water through 1°C.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Kilocalorie:</b> One kilocalorie is defined as the amount of heat energy required to rise the temperature of 1 kilogram of water through 1°C.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_69">3.3. EFFECT OF HEAT ENERGY</h2>
	<p class="block_">When a certain amount of heat energy is given to a substance, it will undergo one or more of the following changes:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">Temperature of the substance rises.</li>
	<li class="block_102">The substance may change its state from solid to liquid or from liquid to gas.</li>
	<li class="block_102">The substance will expand when heated.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">The rise in temperature is in proportion to the amount of heat energy supplied.  It also depends on the nature and mass of the substance. About the rise in temperature and the change of state, you have studied in previous classes. In the following section, we shall discuss about the expansion of substances due to heat.</span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_70">3.3.1 Expansion of Substances </h3>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-44.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of 07ZB3" class="calibre73"/></p>
	<p class="block_">When heat energy is supplied to a body, there can be an increase in the dimension of the object. This change in the dimension due to rise in temperature is called thermal expansion of the object. The expansion of liquids (example  mercury) can be seen when a thermometer is placed in warm water. All forms of matter (solid, liquid and gas) undergo expansion on heating.</p>
	<h4 class="block_103">a) Expansion in solids</h4>
	<p class="block_">When a solid is heated, the atoms gain energy and vibrate more vigorously. This results in the expansion of the solid. For a given change in temperature, the extent of expansion is smaller in solids than in liquids and gases. This is due to the rigid nature of solids.</p>
	<p class="block_">The different types of expansion of solid are listed and explained below:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Linear expansion</li>
	<li class="block_7">Superficial expansion</li>
	<li class="block_8">Cubical expansion</li>
</ol>
	<h5 class="block_15">1. Linear expansion:</h5>
	<p class="block_">When a body is heated or cooled, the length of the body changes due to change in its temperature. Then the expansion is said to be linear or longitudinal expansion.</p>
	<p class="block_">The ratio of increase in length of the body per degree rise in temperature to its unit length is called as the coefficient of linear expansion. The SI unit of Coefficient of Linear expansion is Kelvin power minus one . The value of coefficient of linear expansion is different for different materials.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image453.jpeg" alt="Linear expansion explained in the text book " class="calibre74"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6"><span class="calibre28">   </span></b><b class="calibre6">Figure 3.2 Linear expansion</b></p>
	<p class="block_">The equation relating the change in length and the change in temperature of a body is given below:</p>
	<p class="block_">delta L by L o equal to alpha L into delta T</p>
	<p class="block_">Delta L – Change in length (Final length minus original length)</p>
	<p class="block_">L o - Original length</p>
	<p class="block_">DELTA T – Change in temperature (Final temperature minus Initial temperature)</p>
	<p class="block_">Alpha L - Coefficient of linear expansion.</p>
	<h5 class="block_15">2.Superficial expansion:</h5>
	<p class="block_">If there is an increase in the area of a solid object due to heating, then the expansion is called <b class="calibre6">superficial or areal expansion.</b></p>
	<p class="block_">Superficial expansion is determined in terms of coefficient of superficial expansion. The ratio of increase in area of the body per degree rise in temperature to its unit area is called as <b class="calibre6">coefficient of superficial expansion</b>. Coefficient of superficial expansion is different for different materials. The SI unit of Coefficient of superficial expansion is Kelvin power minus one</p>
	<p class="block_">The equation relating to the change in area and the change in temperature is given below:</p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 3.3 Superficial expansion</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-45.png" alt="Superficial expansion - Explained in the text book" class="calibre75"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Delta A by A o equal to alpha A into delta T</p>
	<p class="block_">Delta A - Change in area (Final area minus Initial area)</p>
	<p class="block_">A o- Original area</p>
	<p class="block_">Delta T – Change in temperature (Final temperature minus Initial temperature)</p>
	<p class="block_">Alpha A- Coefficient of superficial expansion.</p>
	<h5 class="block_15">3. Cubical expansion:</h5>
	<p class="block_">If there is an increase in the volume of a solid body due to heating, then the expansion is called <b class="calibre6">cubical or volumetric expansion.</b></p>
	<p class="block_">As in the cases of linear and areal expansion, cubical expansion is also expressed in terms of coefficient of cubical expansion. The ratio of increase in volume of the body per degree rise in temperature to its unit volume is called as <b class="calibre6">coefficient of cubical expansion</b>. This is also measured in Kelvin power minus one</p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 3.4 Cubical expansion</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image455.jpeg" alt="Cubical expansion - Explained in the text book " class="calibre76"/></p>
	<p class="block_">The equation relating to the change in volume and the change in temperature is given below:</p>
	<p class="block_">DeltaV by V o equal to alpha V times delta T</p>
	<p class="block_">Delta V - Change in volume (Final volume minus Initial volume)</p>
	<p class="block_">V o - Original volume</p>
	<p class="block_">DeltaT - Change in temperature (Final temperature minus Initial temperature)</p>
	<p class="block_">Alpha V- Coefficient of cubical expansion.</p>
	<p class="block_">Different materials possess different coefficient of cubical expansion. Table 3.1 gives the coefficient of cubical expansion for some common materials.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Table 3.1 </b>Coefficient of cubical expansion of some materials</p>
	<table class="table_6">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_61"><p class="block_104">Serial number</p></td>
			<td class="td_62"><p class="block_105">Name of the material</p></td>
			<td class="td_63"><p class="block_106">Coefficient of cubic expansion(K power minus one)</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_64"><p class="block_107">1</p></td>

		</tr>

	</tbody></table>
	<h4 class="block_103">b) Expansion in liquids and gases</h4>
	<p class="block_">When heated, the atoms in a liquid or gas gain energy and are forced further apart. The extent of expansion varies from substance to substance. For a given rise in temperature, a liquid will have more expansion than a solid and a gaseous substance has the highest expansion when compared with the other two. The coefficient of cubical expansion of liquid is independent of temperature whereas its value for gases depends on the temperature of gases.</p>
	<p class="block_">When a liquid is heated, it is done by keeping the liquid in some container and supplying heat energy to the liquid through the container. The thermal energy supplied will be partly used in expanding the container and partly used in expanding the liquid. Thus, what we observe may not be the actual or real expansion of the liquid. Hence, for liquids, we can define real expansion and apparent expansion.</p>
	<h5 class="block_15">1) Real expansion</h5>
	<h5 class="block_110"> </h5>
	<p class="block_">If a liquid is heated directly without using any container, then the expansion that you observe is termed as <b class="calibre6">real expansion</b> of the liquid.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Coefficient of real expansion</b> is defined as the ratio of the true rise in the volume of the liquid per degree rise in temperature to its unit volume. The SI unit of coefficient of real expansion is Kelvin power minus one.</p>
	<h5 class="block_15">2) Apparent expansion</h5>
	<h5 class="block_110"> </h5>
	<p class="block_">Heating a liquid without using a container is not possible. Thus, in practice, you can heat any liquid by pouring it in a container. A part of thermal energy is used in expanding the container and a part is used in expanding the liquid. Thus, what you observe is not the actual or real expansion of the liquid. The expansion of a liquid apparently observed without considering the expansion of the container is called the apparent expansion of the liquid.</p>
	<p class="block_">Coefficient of apparent expansion is defined as the ratio of the apparent rise in the volume of the liquid per degree rise in temperature to its unit volume. The SI unit of coefficient of apparent expansion is Kelvin power minus one.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_71">3.3.2 Experiment to measure real and apparent expansion of liquid</h3>
	<p class="block_">To start with, the liquid whose real and apparent expansion is to be determined is poured in a container up to a level. Mark this level as L1. Now, heat the container and the liquid using a burner as shown in the Figure 3.5. Initially, the container receives the thermal energy and it expands. As a result, the volume of the liquid appears to have reduced. Mark this reduced level of liquid as L2.</p>
	<p class="block_">On further heating, the thermal energy supplied to the liquid through the container results in the expansion of the liquid. Hence, the level of liquid rises to L3. Now, the difference between the levels L1 and L3 is called as <b class="calibre6">apparent expansion</b>, and the difference between the levels L2 and L3 is called real expansion. The real expansion is always more than that of <b class="calibre6">apparent expansion.</b></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 3.5 Real and apparent expansion of liquid</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-46.png" alt="Image displays how to measure real and apparent expansion of liquid when the water in the container is heated up. " class="calibre77"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Real expansion = L 3 minus L 2<sub class="calibre25"> </sub></p>
	<p class="block_">Apparent expansion = L 3 minus L 1</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_72">3.4 FUNDAMENTAL LAWS OF GASES</h2>
	<p class="block_">The three fundamental laws which connect the relation between pressure, volume and temperature are as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_27">1. Boyle’s Law<span class="calibre28">                            </span></p>
	<p class="block_27">2. Charles's law</p>
	<p class="block_27">3. Avogadro’s law</p>
	<h3 class="block_111" id="toc_id_73">3.4.1 Boyle’s law: </h3>
	<h3 class="block_111" id="toc_id_74"><img src="images/image-47.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of C4TN2" class="calibre78"/></h3>
	<p class="block_">When the temperature of a gas is kept constant, the volume of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its pressure. This is shown in Figure 3.6.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">P  proportional one by V</span></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 3.6 Variation of volume with pressure </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-48.png" alt="Image displays the variations of volume with pressure." class="calibre79"/></p>
	<p class="block_">In other words, for an invariable mass of a perfect gas, at constant temperature, the product of its pressure and volume is a constant. that is PV = constant</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_75">3.4.2 Charles's law (The law of volume)</h3>
	<p class="block_">Charles’s law was formulated by a French scientist Jacques Charles. According to this law, When the pressure of gas is kept constant, the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the temperature of the gas.</p>
	<p class="block_"> V directly proportional to T</p>
	<p class="block_">or V by T equal to constant</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_76">3.4.3 Avogadro's law</h3>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-49.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of 9HLBD" class="calibre80"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Avogadro's law states that at constant pressure and temperature, the volume of a gas is directly proportional to number of atoms or molecules present in it.</p>
	<p class="block_">that is V proportional n</p>
	<p class="block_">or V by n is  equal to  a constant</p>
	<p class="block_">Avogadro’s number (N<sub class="calibre25">A</sub>) is the total number of atoms per mole of the substance. It is equal to Six point zero two three into 10 power twenty three per mol.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_77">3.5 GASES</h2>
	<p class="block_">Gases are classified as real gases and ideal gases.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_78">3.5.1 Real Gases</h3>
	<p class="block_">If the molecules or atoms of gases interact with each other with a definite amount of intermolecular or inter atomic force of attraction, then the gases are said to be real gases. At very high temperature or low pressure, a real gas behaves as an ideal gas because in this condition there is no interatomic or intermolecular force of attraction.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_79">3.5.2 Ideal Gases</h3>
	<p class="block_">If the atoms or molecules of a gas do not interact with each other, then the gas is said to be an ideal gas or a perfect gas.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Actually, in practice, no gas is ideal.  The molecules of any gas will have a certain amount of interaction among them. But these interactions are weaker when the pressure is low or the temperature is high because the interatomic or intermolecular forces of attraction are weak in ideal gas. Hence, a real gas at low pressure or high temperature can be termed as a perfect gas.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Ideal gases obey Boyle’s law, Charles’s law and Avogadro’s law. All these laws state the relationship between various properties of a gas such as pressure (P), volume (V), temperature(T) and number of atoms (n). In a given state of the gas, all these parameters will have a definite set of values. When there is a change in the state of the gas, any one or more of these parameters change its value. The above said laws relate these changes.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_80">3.5.3 Ideal Gas Equation</h3>
	<p class="block_">The ideal gas equation is an equation, which relates all the properties of an ideal gas. An ideal gas obeys Boyle’s law and Charles’ law and Avogadro’s law. </p>
	<p class="block_">According to Boyle’s law,</p>
	<p class="block_">PV is equal to a constant<span class="tab">      </span>equation (3.1)</p>
	<p class="block_">According to Charles’s law,</p>
	<p class="block_">V by T is equal to a constant equation 3.2</p>
	<p class="block_">According to Avogadro’s law,</p>
	<p class="block_">V by n is equal to a constant equation 3.3</p>
	<p class="block_">After combining equations (3.1), (3.2) and (3.3), you can get the following equation.</p>
	<p class="block_">PV by n T is equal to constant equation 3.4</p>
	<p class="block_">The above relation is called the combined law of gases. If you consider a gas, which contains  moles of the gas, the number of atoms contained will be equal to  times the Avogadro number, N<sub class="calibre25">A</sub>.</p>
	<p class="block_">That is n is equal to mew N A equation 3.5</p>
	<p class="block_">Using equation (3.5), equation (3.4) can be written as</p>
	<p class="block_">PV by mew N A T is equal to a constant</p>
	<p class="block_">The value of the constant in the above equation is taken to be k B, which is called as Boltzmann constant (1.38 times 10 power minus 23 joule kelvin power minus one. Hence, we have the following equation:</p>
	<p class="block_">PV by mew N A T is equal to K B</p>
	<p class="block_"> PV is equal to mew N A K B T</p>
	<p class="block_">Here, <span class="calibre28">mew N A k B  </span>is equal to  R, which is termed as universal gas constant whose value is 8.31 joule mole power minus one kelvin power minus one.</p>
	<p class="block_">PV is equal to RT<span class="tab">      </span>equation (3.6)</p>
	<p class="block_">Ideal gas equation is also called as equation of state because it gives the relation between the state variables and it is used to describe the state of any gas.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Points to Remember</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">The SI unit of heat energy absorbed or evolved is joule (J)</li>
	<li class="block_102">Heat always flows from a system at higher temperature to a system at lower temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_102">Temperature is defined as the degree of hotness of a body. The SI unit of temperature is kelvin (K).</li>
	<li class="block_102">All the substances will undergo one or more of the following changes when heated:</li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_112">Temperature of the substance rises.</li>
	<li class="block_112">The substance may change state from solid to liquid or gas.</li>
	<li class="block_112">The substance will expand when heated.</li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="5" class="block_102">All forms of matter (solid, liquid and gas) undergo expansion on heating.</li>
	<li class="block_102">For a given rise in temperature, a liquid will have more expansion than a solid and a gaseous substance has the highest expansion than the other two.</li>
	<li class="block_102">If a liquid is heated directly without using any container, then the expansion that you observe is termed as real expansion of the liquid.</li>
	<li class="block_102">The expansion of a liquid apparently observed without considering the expansion of the container is called the apparent expansion of liquid.</li>
	<li class="block_102">For a given heat energy, the real expansion is always more than that of apparent expansion.</li>
	<li class="block_102">If the atoms or molecules of a gas do not interact with each other, then the gas is said to be an ideal gas or a perfect gas.</li>
	<li class="block_102">Ideal gas equation, also called as equation of state is PV = RT. Here, R is known as universal gas constant whose value is .</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_81">Solved Problems</h2>
	<p class="block_12">Example 1</p>
	<p class="block_">A container whose capacity is 70 ml is filled with a liquid up to 50 ml. Then, the liquid in the container is heated. Initially, the level of the liquid falls from 50 ml to 48.5 ml. Then we heat more, the level of the liquid rises to 51.2 ml. Find the apparent and real expansion.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Data:</p>
	<p class="block_">Level of the liquid L1 = 50 ml</p>
	<p class="block_">Level of the liquid L2 = 48.5 ml</p>
	<p class="block_">Level of the liquid L3 = 51.2 ml</p>
	<p class="block_">Apparent expansion = L3 minus L1 </p>
	<p class="block_">= 51.2 ml minus 50 ml<span class="tab">      </span>= 1.2ml </p>
	<p class="block_">Real expansion = L3 minus L2</p>
	<p class="block_">= 51.2 ml minus 48.5ml<span class="tab">      </span>= 2.7ml </p>
	<p class="block_">So, Real expansion greater than apparent expansion</p>
	<p class="block_12">Example 2</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Keeping the   temperature   as   constant, a gas is compressed four times of its initial pressure. The volume of gas in the container changing from 20cc (V1 cc) to V2 cc. Find the final volume V2.</span></p>
	<p class="block_12">Data:</p>
	<p class="block_">Initial pressure (P1) = P </p>
	<p class="block_">Final Pressure (P2) = 4P</p>
	<p class="block_">Initial volume (V1) = 20cc = 20 cm power 3 </p>
	<p class="block_">Final volume (V2) =?</p>
	<p class="block_">Using Boyle's Law, PV = constant</p>
	<p class="block_">P1V1 is equal to P2V2</p>
	<p class="block_">V2 is equal to P1 by P2 into V1</p>
	<p class="block_">V2 is equal to P by 4P in to 20 centimetre cube</p>
	<p class="block_113"><sub class="calibre81">V2 is equal to 5 centimetre </sub><sub class="calibre81">cube</sub></p>

<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_82">TEXTBOOK EVALUATION</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-50.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of T9538" class="calibre82"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_83">ONE. Choose the correct answer</h3>
	<p class="block_">1. The value of universal gas constant </p>
	<p class="block_">a. 3.81 joule mole power minus 1 kelvin power minus 1</p>
	<p class="block_">b. 8.03 joule mole power minus 1 kelvin power minus 1</p>
	<p class="block_">c. 1.38 joule mole power minus 1 kelvin power minus 1</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_94">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">You have already learnt about electricity in your lower classes, haven’t you? Well, electricity deals with the flow of electric charges through a conductor. As a common term it refers to a form of energy. The usage of electric current in our day-to-day life is very important and indispensable. You are already aware of the fact that it is used in houses, educational in situations, hospitals, industries, etcetera. Therefore, its generation and transmission become a very crucial aspect of our life. In this lesson you will learn various terms used in understanding the concept of electricity. Eventually, you will realise the importance of the applications of electricity in day-to-day situations.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_95">4.1 ELECTRIC CURRENT </h2>
	<p class="block_9">The motion of electric charges (electrons) through a conductor (example, copper wire) will constitute an electric current. This is similar to the flow of water through a channel or flow of air from a region of high pressure to a region of low pressure. In a similar manner, the electric current passes from the positive terminal (higher electric potential) of a battery to the negative terminal (lower electric potential) through a wire as shown in the Figure 4.1</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image477.jpeg" alt=" A picture representing Electron flow is given" class="calibre87"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 4.1 Electron flow</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_96">4.1.1 Definition of electric current</h3>
	<p class="block_">Electric current is often termed as ‘current’ and it is represented by the symbol ‘I’. It is defined as the rate of flow of charges in a conductor. This means that the electric current represents the amount of charges flowing in any cross section of a conductor (say a metal wire) in unit time. If a net charge ‘Q’ passes through any cross section of a conductor in time ‘t’, then the current flowing through the conductor is  I is equal to Q by T equation 4.1</p>
	<p class="block_">4.1.2 <b class="calibre6">SI unit of electric current</b></p>
	<p class="block_">The SI unit of electric current is ampere (A). The current flowing through a conductor is said to be one ampere, when a charge of one coulomb flows across any cross-section of a conductor, in one second. Hence, 1 ampere is equal to one coulomb divided by one second.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solved Problem 1</p>
	<p class="block_">A charge of 12 coulomb flows through a bulb in 5 second. What is the current through the bulb?</p>
	<p class="block_">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_">Charge Q = 12 Coulomb, Time t = 5 second. Therefore, current I = Q by t = 12 by 5 = 2.4 Amphere</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_97">4.2 ELECTRIC CIRCUIT</h2>
	<p class="block_">An electric circuit is a closed conducting loop (or) path, which has a network of electrical components through which electrons are able to flow. This path is made using electrical wires so as to connect an electric appliance to a source of electric charges (battery). A schematic diagram of an electric circuit comprising of a battery, an electric bulb, and a switch is given in Figure 4.2.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image596.jpeg" alt="A simple electric circuit- Explained in the text book " class="calibre95"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 4.2 A simple electric circuit</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">In this circuit, if the switch is ‘on’, the bulb glows. If it is switched off, the bulb does not glow. Therefore, the circuit must be closed in order that the current passes through it.  The potential difference required for the flow of charges is provided by the battery. The electrons flow from the negative terminal to the positive terminal of the battery.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">By convention, the direction of current is taken as the direction of flow of positive charge (or) opposite to the direction of flow of electrons. Thus, electric current passes in the circuit from the positive terminal to the negative terminal.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_98">4.2.1 Electrical components</h3>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">The electric circuit given in Figure4.2 consists of different components, such as a battery, a switch and a bulb. All these components can be represented by using certain symbols. It is easier to represent the components of a circuit using their respective symbols.</p>
	<p class="block_9">The symbols that are used to represent some commonly used components are given in Table 4.1. The uses of these components are also summarized in the table.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_99">4.3 ELECTRIC POTENTIAL AND POTENTIAL DIFFERENCE</h2>
	<p class="block_9">You are now familiar with the water current and air current. You also know that there must be a difference in temperature between two points in a solid for the heat to flow in it. Similarly, a difference in electric potential is needed for the flow of electric charges in a conductor. In the conductor, the charges will flow from a point in it, which is at a higher electric potential to a point, which is at a lower electric potential.</p>
	<p class="block_19">4.3.1 Electric Potential</p>
	<p class="block_9">The electric potential at a point is defined as the amount of work done in moving a unit positive charge from infinity to that point against the electric force.</p>
	<p class="block_19">4.3.2 Electric Potential Difference</p>
	<p class="block_9">The electric potential difference between two points is defined as the amount of work done in moving a unit positive charge from one point to another point against the electric force.</p>
	<p class="block_9"> </p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-55.png" alt="This is a picture . It describes electric potential. There are two charges one is kept at A and another at B at a distance." class="calibre96"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 4.3 Electric potential </p>
	<p class="block_9">Suppose <span class="calibre15">you have moved a charge Q from a point A to another point B. Let ‘W’    be the work done to move the charge from A to B. Then, the potential difference between the points A and B is given by the following expression:</span></p>
	<p class="block_137">Potential difference V is equal to Work done divided by Charge<span class="calibre15">  </span>equation 4.2</p>
	<p class="block_9">Potential difference is also equal to the difference in the electric potential of these two points. If VA and VB represent the electric potential at the points A and B respectively, then, the potential difference between the points A and B is given by:</p>
	<p class="block_9">V = VA minus VB (if VA is more than VB) </p>
	<p class="block_9">V = VB minus VA (if VB is more than VA)</p>
	<p class="block_19">4.3.3 Volt</p>
	<p class="block_9">The SI unit of electric potential or potential difference is volt (V) The potential difference between two points is one volt, if one joule of work is done in moving one coulomb of charge from one point to another against the electric force.</p>
	<p class="block_">1volt = one joule by one coulomb</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solved Problem 2</p>
	<p class="block_">The work done in moving a charge of 10 Coulomb across two points in a circuit is 100 Joule. What is the potential difference between the points?</p>
	<p class="block_">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_">Charge, Q = 10 Coulomb Work Done, W = 100 Joule</p>
	<p class="block_"> Potential Difference V = W by Q is equal to 100 by 10</p>
	<p class="block_">Therefore, V = 10 volt</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_100">4.4 OHM’S LAW</h2>
	<p class="block_">A German physicist, George Simon Ohm established the relation between the potential difference and current, which is known as Ohm’s Law. This relationship can be understood from the following activity<b class="calibre6">.</b></p>
	<p class="block_138"><img src="images/image612.jpeg" alt="Electric circuit to understand Ohm’s law - Explained  in text book " class="calibre97"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 4.4 Electric circuit to understand Ohm’s law</p>
	<p class="block_9">According to Ohm’s law, at a constant temperature, the steady current ‘I’ flowing through a conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference ‘V’ between the two ends of the conductor.</p>
	<p class="block_139">I proportional to V. Hence, I by V is equal to constant</p>
	<p class="block_140">The value of this proportionality constant is found to be one by R</p>
	<p class="block_141">Therefore, I is equal to open bracket 1 by R close bracket V</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6"> V = I R<span class="tab">      </span></b><b class="calibre6">equation  (4.3)</b></p>
	<p class="block_">Here, R is a constant for a given material (say Nichrome) at a given temperature and is known as the resistance of the material. Since, the potential difference V is proportional to the current I, the graph between V and I is a straight line for a conductor, as shown in the Figure 4.5.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-56.png" alt="Here is a QR code with a number of PLJMI" class="calibre98"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-57.png" alt="Relation between potential difference and current is denoted with a graph  " class="calibre99"/>V (V)</p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 4.5 Relation between potential difference and current</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_101">4.5 RESISTANCE OF A MATERIAL:</h2>
	<p class="block_">In Figure 4.4, a Nichrome wire was connected between X and Y. If you replace the Nichrome wire with a copper wire and c<span class="calibre28">onduct the same experiment, you will notice a different current for the same value   of the potential difference across the wire.  If you again replace the copper wire with an aluminium wire, you will get another value for the current passing through it. From equation (4.3), you have learnt that V</span> by I must be equal to the resistance of the conductor used. The variations in the current for the same values of potential difference indicate that the resistance of different materials is different. Now, the primary question is, “what is resistance?”</p>
	<p class="block_">Resistance of a material is its property to oppose the flow of charges and hence the passage of current through it. It is different for different materials.</p>
	<p class="block_">From Ohm’s Law V by I is equal to R</p>
	<p class="block_">The resistance of a conductor can be defined as the ratio between the potential difference across the ends of the conductor and the current flowing through it.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_102">4.5.1 Unit of Resistance</h3>
	<p class="block_">The SI unit of resistance is ohm and it is represented by the symbol Ω.(ohm)</p>
	<p class="block_">Resistance of a conductor is said to be one ohm if a current of one ampere flows through it when a potential difference of one volt is maintained across its ends.</p>
	<p class="block_">1 ohm <span class="calibre28"> is equal to  one volt by one ampere</span></p>
	<p class="block_12">Solved Problem 3</p>
	<p class="block_">Calculate the resistance of a conductor through which a current of 2 Ampere passes, when the potential difference between its ends is 30 Volt.</p>
	<p class="block_">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_">Current through the conductor I = 2 Ampere, Potential Difference V = 30 Volt</p>
	<p class="block_">From Ohm’s Law: R is equal to V by I</p>
	<p class="block_">Therefore, R = 30 by 2 is equal to 15 ohm</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_103">4.6 ELECTRICAL RESISTIVITY &amp; ELECTRICAL CONDUCTIVITY</h2>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_104">4.6.1 Electrical Resistivity</h3>
	<p class="block_">You can verify by doing an experiment that the resistance of any conductor ‘R’ is directly proportional to the length of the conductor ‘L’ and is inversely proportional to its area of cross section ‘A’.</p>
	<p class="block_">R is proportional to L</p>
	<p class="block_">R is proportional to one by A</p>
	<p class="block_">hence, R is proportional to  L by A</p>
	<p class="block_">therefore, R is equal to rho into L by A. equation 4.4</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_">Where, ρ (rho) is a constant, called as electrical resistivity or specific resistance of the material of the conductor.</p>
	<p class="block_">From equation (4.4),  rho is equal to R A by L</p>
	<p class="block_">If L = 1 metre, A = 1 meter square then, from the above equation rho is equal to<span class="calibre28">  R</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Hence, the electrical resistivity of a material is defined as the resistance of a conductor of unit length and unit area of cross section. Its unit is ohm metre.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Electrical resistivity of a conductor is a measure of the resisting power of a specified material to the passage of an electric current. It is a constant for a given material.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_105">4.6.2 Conductance and Conductivity</h3>
	<p class="block_">Conductance of a material is the property of a material to aid the flow of charges and hence, the passage of current in it. The conductance of a material is mathematically defined as the reciprocal of its resistance (R). Hence, the conductance ‘G’ of a conductor is given by</p>
	<p class="block_"> G is equl to one by R. equation 4.5</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="text_7">Its <span class="calibre28">  </span></span><span class="text_7">unit  is<span class="calibre28">  ohm </span></span><span class="text_7"> <span class="calibre28">power  minus  one it is </span></span><span class="text_7">also  represented as  mho.</span></p>
	<p class="block_61"><span class="text_7">The  r reciprocal of electrical resistivity of a  material  is  called  its  electrical  conductivity. </span><b class="calibre6"> Sigma is equal to one by rho equation 4.6 </b></p>
	<p class="block_61"> </p>
	<p class="block_">Its unit is ohm power minus 1 metre power minus 1. It is also represented as mho metre power minus 1. The conductivity is a constant for a given material. Electrical conductivity of a conductor is a measure of its ability to pass the current through it. Some materials are good conductors of electric current. Example: copper, aluminium, etcetera. While some other materials are non- conductors of electric current (insulators). Example: glass, wood, rubber, etcetera</p>
	<p class="block_">Conductivity is more for conductors than for insulators. But the resistivity is less for conductors than for insulators. The resistivity of some commonly used materials is given in Table 4.2.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 4.2 Resistivity of some materials</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_106">4.7 SYSTEM OF RESISTORS</h2>
	<p class="block_">So far, you have learnt how the resistance of a conductor affects the current through a circuit. You have also studied the case of the simple electric circuit containing a single resistor. Now in practice, you may encounter a complicated circuit, which uses a combination of many resistors. This combination of resistors is known as ‘system of resistors’ or ‘grouping of resistors. Resistors can be connected in various combinations. The two basic methods of joining resistors together are:</p>
	<p class="block_">a) Resistors connected in series, and b) Resistors connected in parallel.</p>
	<p class="block_">In the following sections, you shall compute the effective resistance when many resistors having different resistance values are connected in series and in parallel.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_107">4.7.1 Resistors in series</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">A series circuit connects the components one after the other to form a ‘single loop’. A series circuit has only one loop through which current can pass. If the circuit is interrupted    at any point in the loop, no current can pass through the circuit and hence no electric appliances connected in the circuit will work. Series circuits are commonly used in devices such as flashlights. Thus, if resistors are connected end to end, so that the same current passes through each of them, then they are said to be connected in series</span><b class="calibre6">.</b></p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image630.jpeg" alt="Series connection of resistors" class="calibre100"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 4.6 Series connection of resistors</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">Let, three resistances R1, R2 and R3 be connected in series (Figure 4.6). Let the current flowing through them be I. According to Ohm’s Law, the potential differences V1, V2 and V3 across R1, R2 and R3 respectively, are given by:</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">V1 = I R1<span class="tab1">      </span> (4.7)</p>
	<p class="block_9">V2 = I R2 (4.8)</p>
	<p class="block_9">V3 = I R3<span class="tab1">      </span>(4.9)</p>
	<p class="block_9">The sum of the potential differences across the ends of each resistor is given by:</p>
	<p class="block_9">V = V1 + V2 + V3</p>
	<p class="block_9">Using equations (4.7), (4.8) and (4.9), we get V = I R1 + I R2 + I R3<span class="tab1">      </span>(4.10)</p>
	<p class="block_9">The effective resistor is a single resistor, which can replace the resistors effectively, so as to allow the same current through the electric circuit. Let, the effective resistance of the series-combination of the resistors, be RS. Then,</p>
	<p class="block_9">V = I RS<span class="tab1">      </span>(4.11)</p>
	<p class="block_9">Combining equations (4.10) and (4.11), you get,</p>
	<p class="block_9">I RS = I R1 + I R2 + I R3</p>
	<p class="block_9">RS = R1 + R2 + R3<span class="tab1">      </span>(4.12)</p>
	<p class="block_9">Thus, you can understand that when a number of resistors are connected in series, their equivalent resistance or effective resistance is equal to the sum of the individual resistances. When ‘n’ resistors of equal resistance R are connected in series, the equivalent resistance is ‘n R’.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Tht is , RS  is equal to n R</p>
	<p class="block_9">The equivalent resistance in a series combination is greater than the highest of the individual resistances.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Solved Problem5</p>
	<p class="block_9">Three resistors of resistances 5 ohm., 3 ohm and 2 ohms are connected in series with 10 V battery. Calculate their effective resistance and the current flowing through the circuit.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_9">R1 = 5 ohm, R2 = 3 ohm, R3 = 2 ohm, V = 10 Volt</p>
	<p class="block_9">R s = R1 + R2 + R3, Rs = 5 + 3 + 2 = 10, hence R s = 10 Ω</p>
	<p class="block_9">The current, I =  V by R s equal to ten by ten equal to 1 ampere.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_108">4.7.2 Resistances in Parallel</h3>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">A parallel circuit has two or more loops through which current can pass.  If the circuit is disconnected in one of the loops, the current can still pass through the other loop(s). The wiring in a house consists of parallel circuits.</span></p>
	<p class="block_23"><img src="images/image633.jpeg" alt="Parallel connections of resistors- Explained in the text book " class="calibre101"/></p>
	<p class="block_154"> </p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 4.7 Parallel connections of resistors</p>
	<p class="block_">Consider that three resistors R1, R2 and <span class="calibre28">R3 are connected across two common points   A and B. The potential difference across each resistance is the same and equal to the potential difference between A and B. This is measured using the voltmeter. The current I arriving at A divides into three branches I1, I2 and I3 passing through R1, R2 and R3 respectively.</span></p>
	<p class="block_155">According to the Ohm’s law, you have,</p>
	<p class="block_156"> I one is equal to V by R one equation 4.13</p>
	<p class="block_157"><img src="images/image1.png" alt="Image" class="calibre102"/><span class="calibre15"> I2 is equal to V by R two      </span>equation 4.14</p>
	<p class="block_158"><span class="calibre15">I3 is equal to V by R three   </span>equation 4.15</p>
	<p class="block_159">The total current through the circuit is given by</p>
	<p class="block_160">I =I 1 + I 2 + I 3<sub class="calibre25"><span class="calibre15">     </span></sub></p>
	<p class="block_161">Using equations (4.13), (4.14) and (4.15), you get</p>
	<p class="block_162">I is equal to V by R <span class="calibre15">one plus V by R two plus V by R three  </span>equation 4.16</p>
	<p class="block_163">Let the effective resistance of the parallel combination of resistors be R p. Then,</p>
	<p class="block_164">I is equal to V by R p equation 4.17</p>
	<p class="block_165">Combining equations (4.16) and (4.17), you have</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">V by Rp is equal to V by R one plus V by R2 plus V by R3  </span></p>
	<p class="block_9">One by R p = 1 by R 1 + 1 by R 2 + 1 by R 3 equation 4.18</p>
	<p class="block_166">Thus, when a number of resistors are connected in parallel, the sum of the reciprocals of the individual resistances is equal to the reciprocal of the effective or equivalent resistance. When ‘n’ resistors of equal resistances R are connected in parallel, the equivalent resistance is R by n.</p>
	<p class="block_167">that is one by R p is equal to one by R plus one by R plus one by R and so on plus 1 by R is equal to n by R</p>
	<p class="block_168">hence Rp is equal to R by n</p>
	<p class="block_168">The equivalent resistance in a parallel combination is less than the lowest of the individual resistances.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_109">4.7.3 Series Connection of Parallel Resistors</h3>
	<p class="block_168">If you consider the connection of a set of parallel resistors that are connected in series, you get a series – parallel circuit. Let R1 and R2 be connected in parallel to give an effective resistance of RP1. Similarly, let R3 and R4 be connected in parallel to give an effective resistance of RP2. Then, both of these parallel segments are connected in series (Figure 4.8).</p>
	<p class="block_168"><img src="images/image-58.png" alt="figure 4.8 Series-parallel combination of resistors is shown" class="calibre103"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 4.8 Series-parallel combination of resistors</p>
	<p class="block_168">Using equation (4.18), you get</p>
	<p class="block_169"> one by R p1 is equal to one by R 1 plus one by R 2</p>
	<p class="block_169">one by R p2 is equal to one by R 3 plus one by R 4</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_">Finally, using equation (4.12), the net effective resistance is given by R total is equal to R p1 plus R p2</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_110">4.7.4 Parallel Connection of Series Resistors</h3>
	<p class="block_">If you consider a connection of a set of series resistors connected in a parallel circuit, you get a parallel-series circuit. Let R1 and R2 be connected in series to give an effective resistance of RS1. Similarly, let R3 and R4 be connected in series to give an effective resistance of RS2. Then, both of these serial segments are connected in parallel (Figure 4.9).</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image650.jpeg" alt="Parallel-series combination of resistors - Explained in the text book " class="calibre104"/></p>
	<p class="block_19"> Figure 4.9 Parallel-series combination of resistors</p>
	<p class="block_9">Using equation (4.12), you get</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">     R</span> s1 is equal to R 1 plus R 2, R s2 is equal to R 3 plus R 4</p>
	<p class="block_9">Finally, using equation (4.18), the net effective resistance is given by</p>
	<p class="block_19">One by R total is equal to one by R s1 plus one by R s2</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_111">4.7.5. Difference between series and parallel connections</h3>
	<p class="block_9">The difference between series and parallel circuits may be summed as follows in Table 4.3</p>
