	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_112">4.8 HEATING EFFECT OF CURRENT</h2>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">Have you ever touched the motor casing of a fan, which has been used for a few hours continuously? What do you observe? The motor casing is warm. This is due to the heating effect of current. The same can be observed by touching a bulb, which was used for a long duration. Generally, a source of electrical energy can develop a potential difference across a resistor, which is connected to that source. This potential difference constitutes a current through the resistor. For continuous drawing of current, the source has to continuously spend its energy. A part of the energy from the source can be converted into useful work and the rest will be converted into heat energy. Thus, the passage of electric current through   a wire, results in the production of heat. This phenomenon is called heating effect of current. This heating effect of current is used in devices like electric heater, electric iron, etc</span>etera.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_113">4.8.1 Joule’s Law of Heating</h3>
	<p class="block_9">Let ‘I’ be the current flowing through a resistor of resistance ‘R’, and ‘V’ be the potential difference across the resistor. The charge flowing through the circuit for a time interval ‘t’ is ‘Q’.</p>
	<p class="block_9">The work done in moving the charge Q across the ends of the resistor with a potential</p>
	<p class="block_9">difference of V is VQ. This energy spent by the source gets dissipated in the resistor as heat. Thus, the heat produced in the resistor is:</p>
	<p class="block_9">H = W = VQ</p>
	<p class="block_9">You know that the relation between the charge and current is Q = I t. Using this, you get</p>
	<p class="block_9">H = V I t<span class="tab1">      </span>(4.19)</p>
	<p class="block_9">From Ohm’s Law, V = I R. Hence, you have</p>
	<p class="block_9">H = I power 2 R t<span class="tab1">      </span>(4.20)</p>
	<p class="block_9">This is known as Joule’s law of heating.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Joule’s law of heating states that the heat produced in any resistor is:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">directly proportional to the square of the current passing through the resistor.</li>
	<li class="block_66">directly proportional to the resistance of the resistor.</li>
	<li class="block_66">directly proportional to the time for which the current is passing through the resistor.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_114">4.8.2 Applications of Heating Effect</h3>
	<p class="block_19">1.Electric Heating Device:</p>
	<p class="block_9">The heating effect of electric current is used in many home appliances such as electric iron, electric toaster, electric oven, electric heater, geyser, etcetera. In these appliances Nichrome, which is an alloy of Nickel and Chromium is used as the heating element. Why? Because:</p>
	<p class="block_9">(1)it has high resistivity, (2) it has a high melting point, (3) it is not easily oxidized.</p>
	<p class="block_19">2.Fuse Wire:</p>
	<p class="block_9">The fuse wire is connected in series, in an electric circuit. When a large current passes through the circuit, the fuse wire melts due to Joule’s heating effect and hence the circuit gets disconnected. Therefore, the circuit and the electric appliances are saved from any damage. The fuse wire is made up of a material whose melting point is relatively low.</p>
	<p class="block_19">3.Filament in bulbs:</p>
	<p class="block_9">In electric bulbs, a small wire is used, known as filament. The filament is made up of a material whose melting point is very high. When current passes through this wire, heat is produced in the filament. When the filament is heated, it glows and gives out light. Tungsten is the commonly used material to make the filament in bulbs.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Solved Problem-6</p>
	<p class="block_9">An electric heater of resistance 5 ohm is connected to an electric source. If a current of 6 Ampere flows through the heater, then find the amount of heat produced in 5 minutes.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_9">Given resistance R = 5 ohm, Current I = 6 Ampere, Time t = 5 minutes = 5 × 60 second = 300 second</p>
	<p class="block_9">Amount of heat produced, H= I power 2Rt, H = 6 power 2 × 5 × 300. Hence, H = 54000 Joule</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_115">4.9 ELECTRIC POWER</h2>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">In general, power is defined as the rate   of doing work or rate of spending energy. Similarly, the electric power is defined as the rate of consumption of electrical energy. It represents the rate at which the electrical energy is converted into some other form of energy.</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">Suppose a current ‘I’ flows through a conductor of resistance ‘R’ for a time ‘t’, then the potential difference across the two ends of the conductor is ‘V’. The work done ‘W’ to move the charge across the ends of the conductor is given by the equation (4.19) as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_9">W = V I t, </p>
	<p class="block_9">Power P   = work by time = V I t by t </p>
	<p class="block_9">P = V I<span class="tab1">      </span>(4.21)</p>
	<p class="block_9">Thus, the electric power is the product of the electric current and the potential difference due to which the current passes in a circuit.</p>
	<p class="block_19">4.9.1 Unit of Electric Power</p>
	<p class="block_9">The SI unit of electric power is watt. When a current of 1 ampere passes across the ends of a conductor, which is at a potential difference of 1 volt, then the electric power is</p>
	<p class="block_9">P = 1 volt × 1 ampere = 1 watt</p>
	<p class="block_9">Thus, one watt is the power consumed when an electric device is operated at a potential difference of one volt and it carries a current of one ampere. A larger unit of power, which is more commonly used is kilowatt.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_116">4.9.2 Consumption of electrical energy</h3>
	<p class="block_9">Electricity is consumed both in houses and industries. Consumption of electricity is based on two factors: (1) Amount of electric power and (2) Duration of usage. Electrical energy consumed is taken as the product of electric power and time of usage. For example, if 100 watt of electric power is <span class="calibre15">consumed for two hours, then the power consumed is100 × 2 = 200watt hour. Consumption of electrical energy is measured and expressed in watt hour, though its SI unit is watt second. In practice, a larger unit of electrical energy   is needed. This larger unit is kilowatt hour (kWh). One kilowatt hour is otherwise known as one unit of electrical energy. One kilowatt hour means that an electric power of 1000 watt has been utilized for an hour. Hence,</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">1 kWh = 1000watt hour = 1000 × (60 × 60) watt second = 3.6 × 10 power 6 Joul</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_117">4.10 DOMESTIC ELECTRIC CIRCUITS</h2>
	<p class="block_9">The electricity produced in power stations is distributed to all the domestic and industrial consumers through overhead and underground cables. The diagram, which shows the general scheme of a domestic electric circuit, is given in Figure 4.10In our homes, electricity is distributed through the domestic electric circuits wired by the electricians. The first stage of the domestic circuit is to bring the power supply to the main-box from a distribution panel, such as a transformer. The important components of the main-box are: (1) a fuse box and (2)a meter. The meter is used to record the consumption of electrical energy. The fuse box contains either a fuse wire or a miniature circuit breaker (MCB). The function of the fuse wire or a MCB is to protect the house hold electrical appliances from overloading due to excess current</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image657.jpeg" alt="Domestic electric circuit Explained in the text book " class="calibre105"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 4.10 Domestic electric circuit</p>
	<p class="block_">You have learnt about a fuse wire in section4.8.2. An MCB is a switching device, which can be activated automatically as well as manually. It has a spring attached to the switch, which is attracted by an electromagnet when an excess current passes through the circuit. Hence, the circuit is broken and the protection of the appliance is ensured. Figure 4.11 represents a fuse and an MCB.</p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image660.jpeg" alt="MCB " class="calibre106"/><img src="images/image659.jpeg" alt="A fuse and an MCB Explained " class="calibre107"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 4.11 A fuse and an MCB</p>
	<p class="block_9">The electricity is brought to houses by two insulated wires. Out of these two wires,</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">one wire has a red insulation and is called the ‘live wire’. The other wire has a black insulation and is called the ‘neutral wire’.  The electricity supplied to your house is actually an alternating current having an electric potential of 220 V</span>olt<span class="calibre15">. Both, the live wire and the neutral wire enter into a box where   the main fuse is connected with the live wire. After the electricity meter, these wires enter into the main switch, which is used to discontinue the electricity supply whenever required. After the main switch, these wires are connected to live wires of two separate circuits. Out of these two circuits, one circuit is of a 5 A</span>mpere rating, which is used to run the electric appliances with a lower power rating, such as tube lights, bulbs and fans. The other circuit is of a 15 Ampere <span class="calibre15">rating, which is used to   run electric appliances with a </span>high-power rating, such as air-conditioners, refrigerators, <span class="calibre15">electric iron and heaters. It should be noted that all the circuits in a house are connected   in parallel, so that the disconnection of one circuit does not affect the other circuit. One more advantage of the parallel connection of circuits is that each electric appliance gets an equal voltage.</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">Do you know?</p>
	<p class="block_">In India domestic circuits are supplied with an alternating current of potential 220 or 230 volt. And frequency 50 hertz. In countries like U S A and U K domestic circuits are supplied with an alternating current of potential of 110 or 120 volt and frequency of 60 hertz.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_118">4.10.1 Overloading and Short circuiting</h3>
	<p class="block_">The fuse wire or MCB will disconnect the circuit in the event of an overloading and short circuiting. Over loading happens when a large number of appliances are connected in series to the same source of electric power. This leads to a flow of excess current in the electric circuit.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">When the amount of current passing through   a wire exceeds the maximum permissible limit, the wires get heated to such an extent that a fire may be caused. This is known as overloading. When a live wire comes in contact with a neutral wire, it causes a ‘short circuit’. This happens when the insulation of the wires </span>gets damaged due to temperature changes or some external force. Due to a short circuit, the effective resistance in the circuit becomes very small, which leads to the flow of a large current through the wires. This results in heating of wires to such an extent that a fire may be caused in the building.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_119">4.10.2 Earthing</h3>
	<p class="block_">In domestic circuits, a third wire called the earth wire having a green insulation is usually connected to the body of the metallic electric appliance. The other end of the earth wire is connected to a metal tube or a metal electrode, which is buried into the Earth. This wire provides a low resistance path to the electric current. The earth wire sends the current from the body of the appliance to the Earth, whenever a live wire accidentally touches the body of the metallic electric appliance. Thus, the earth wire serves as a protective conductor, which saves us from electric shocks.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_120">4.11 LED BULB</h2>
	<p class="block_">An LED bulb is a semiconductor device that emits visible light when an electric current passes through it. The colour of the emitted light will depend on the type of materials used. With the help of the chemical compounds like Gallium Arsenide and Gallium Phosphide, the manufacturer can produce LED bulbs that radiates red, green, yellow and orange colours. Displays in digital watches and calculators, traffic signals, street lights, decorative lights, etcetera., are some examples for the use of LEDs.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_121"><img src="images/image661.jpeg" alt="Seven segment display - Explained in the text book " class="calibre108"/></h3>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_122">4.11.1 Seven Segment Display</h3>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 4.12 Seven segment display</p>
	<p class="block_">A ‘Seven Segment Display’ is the display device used to give an output in the form of numbers or text. It is used in digital meters, digital clocks, micro wave ovens, etcetera. It consists of 7 segments of LEDs in the form of the digit 8.</p>
	<p class="block_">These seven LEDs are named as a, b, c, d, e, f and g (Figure 4.12). An extra 8th LED is used to display a dot.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_123">4.11.2 Merits of a LED bulb</h3>
	<p class="block_">1.As there is no filament, there is no loss of energy in the form of heat. It is cooler than the incandescent bulb.</p>
	<p class="block_">2.In comparison with the fluorescent light, the LED bulbs have significantly low power requirement.</p>
	<p class="block_">3.It is not harmful to the environment.</p>
	<p class="block_">4.A wide range of colours is possible here.</p>
	<p class="block_">5.It is cost-efficient and energy efficient.</p>
	<p class="block_">6.Mercury and other toxic materials are not required.</p>
	<p class="block_">One way of overcoming the energy crisis is to use more LED bulbs.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_124">4.12 LED TELEVISION</h2>
	<p class="block_">LED Television is one of the most important applications of Light Emitting Diodes. An LED TV is actually an LCD TV (Liquid Crystal Display) with LED display. An LED display uses LEDs for backlight and an array of LEDs act as pixels. LEDs emitting white light are used in monochrome (black and white) TV; Red, Green and Blue (RGB) LEDs are used in colour television. The first LED television screen was developed by James. Mitchell in 1977. It was a monochromatic display. But, after about three decades, in 2009, SONY introduced the first commercial LED Television.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_125">4.12.1 Advantages of LED television</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">It has brighter picture quality.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is thinner in size.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It uses less power and consumes very less energy.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Its life span is more.</li>
	<li class="block_8">It is more reliable.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_126">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">The magnitude of current is defined as the rate of flow of charges in a conductor.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The SI unit of electric current is ampere (A).</li>
	<li class="block_66">The SI unit of electric potential and potential difference is volt (V).</li>
	<li class="block_66">An electric circuit is a network of electrical components, which forms a continuous and closed path for an electric current to pass through it.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The parameters of conductors like its length, area of cross-section and material, affect the resistance of the conductor.</li>
	<li class="block_66">SI unit of electrical resistivity is ohm metre. The resistivity is a constant for a given material.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The reciprocal of electrical resistivity of a material is called its electrical conductivity.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_170">σ = 1 by ρ.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="8" class="block_66">The passage of electric current through a wire result in the production of heat.</li>
	<li class="block_66">This phenomenon is called heating effect of current.</li>
	<li class="block_66">One horsepower is equal to 746 watts.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The function of fuse wire or a MCB is to protect the house-hold electrical appliances from excess current due to overloading or a short circuit.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_127">Solved Problems</h2>
	<p class="block_">1. Two bulbs are having the ratings as 60 Watt, 220 Volt and 40 Watt, 220 Volt respectively. Which one has a greater resistance?</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solution: </p>
	<p class="block_">Electric power  P is equal to V square by R</p>
	<p class="block_">For the same value of V, R is inversely proportional to P.</p>
	<p class="block_">Therefore, lesser the power, greater the resistance</p>
	<p class="block_">Hence, the bulb with 40 Watt, 220 Volt rating has a greater resistance.</p>
	<p class="block_">2. Calculate the current and the resistance of a 100 Watt, 200 Volt electric bulb in an electric circuit.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solution: </p>
	<p class="block_">Power P = 100 Watt and Voltage V = 200 Volt Power P = V into I</p>
	<p class="block_">So, Current, I = P by V equal to 100 by 200 equal to 0.5 ampere</p>
	<p class="block_">Resistance, R is equal to V by I is equal to 200 by 0.5 is equal to 400 ohm.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">3. In the circuit diagram given below, three resistors R1, R2 and R3 of 5 Ω, 10 Ω and   20 Ω respectively are connected as shown. Calculate:</span></p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image665.jpeg" alt="circuit diagram GIVEN" class="calibre109"/></p>
	<p class="block_171"><span class="text_8">A. Current through each resistor</span></p>
	<p class="block_172">B. Total current in the circuit</p>
	<p class="block_172">C. Total resistance in the circuit</p>
	<p class="block_">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_173">A. Since the resistors are connected in parallel, the potential difference across each resistor is same (that is V =10 Volt) Therefore, the current through R 1 is,</p>
	<p class="block_61">I<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>1<span class="calibre28"> =  </span> V by R1 is equal to 10 by five is equal to 2 Ampere</p>
	<p class="block_61">Current through R<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>2 = I<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>2 = V by R2 equal to ten by ten equal to one ampere. </p>
	<p class="block_61">Current through R3 equal to I 3 equal to V by R3 equal to ten by twenty is equal to 0.5 ampere.</p>
	<p class="block_174">B. Total current in the circuit,<sub class="calibre25"> </sub> I is equal to I one plus I two plus I three</p>
	<p class="block_175">= 2 + 1 + 0.5 = 3.5 ampere<span class="calibre15">  </span></p>
	<p class="block_174">C. Total resistance in the circuit 1 by R p = 1 by R 1 + 1 by R 2 + 1 by R 3</p>
	<p class="block_174">= 1 by 5. + 1 by 10. + 1 by 20. = 4 + 2 + 1 divided by 20.</p>
	<p class="block_174">1 by R p = 7 by 20</p>
	<p class="block_174">Hence R p = 20 by 7 = 2.857 ohm.</p>
	<p class="block_176">4. Three resistors of 1 ohm, 2 ohm and 4 ohm are connected in parallel in a circuit. If a 1 ohm resistor draws a current of 1 A, find the current through the other two resistors.</p>
	<p class="block_">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_177">R<sub class="calibre25">1</sub>=1 ohm, R<sub class="calibre25">2</sub>=2 ohm, R<sub class="calibre25">3</sub>=4 ohm Current I 1 = 1A<span class="calibre15">   R one is equal to 1 ohm, R2 is equal to 4 ohm R3 is equal to 4 ohm current I1 is equal to one ampere</span></p>
	<p class="block_178">The potential difference across the 1 Ω resistor</p>
	<p class="block_179">I one R one equal to one into one equal to one volt</p>
	<p class="block_180">Since, the resistors are connected in parallel in the circuit, the same potential difference will exist across the other resistors also.</p>
	<p class="block_61">So, the current in the 2 ohm resistor,<span class="calibre28">  V by R2 is equal to one by two is equal to zero point five ampere.</span></p>
	<p class="block_181">Similarly, the current in the 4 ohm resistor,</p>
	<p class="block_61"> V by R3 equal to one by four equal to zero point two five ampere.</p>

	<p class="block_">b) if both the assertion and the reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion.</p>
	<p class="block_">c) if the assertion is true, but the reason is false.</p>
	<p class="block_">d) if the assertion is false, but the reason is true.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28"> 1. Assertion: Electric    appliances    with   a</span> metallic body have three wire connections.</p>
	<p class="block_"> Reason: Three pin connections reduce heating of the connecting wires</p>
	<p class="block_">2. Assertion: In a simple battery circuit the point<span class="calibre28">   of   highest potential is the positive terminal of the battery.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Reason: The current flows towards the point of the highest potential</p>
	<p class="block_">3. Assertion: LED bulbs are far better than incandescent bulbs.</p>
	<p class="block_"> Reason: LED bulbs consume less power than incandescent bulbs.</p>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_130">UNIT-5 ACOUSTICS</h1>
	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_131"><img src="images/image-62.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of QEGDX" class="calibre80"/></h1>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_132">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_9">By the end of this section, the students will be able to:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">Understand how sound is produced and transmitted.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Relate the speed of sound, its frequency, and its wavelength.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Know the speed of sound in various media.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Explain the factors affecting the speed of sound in a gaseous medium.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Demonstrate the phenomenon of reflection of sound.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Determine the speed of sound using the method of echo.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand Doppler Effect.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Solve numerical problems related to the above topics.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_133">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Sound plays a major role in our lives. We communicate with each other mainly through sound.  In our daily life, we hear a variety of sounds produced by different sources like humans, animals, vehicle horns, etc</span>etera<span class="calibre28">. Hence, it becomes inevitable to understand how sound is produced, how it is propagated and how you hear the sound from various sources. It is sometimes misinterpreted that acoustics only deals with musical instruments and design of auditoria and concert halls. But acoustics is a branch   of physics that deals with production, transmission, reception, control, and effects of sound. You have studied about propagation and properties of sound waves in </span>ninth<span class="calibre28"> standard. In this lesson we will study about reflection   of sound waves, Echo and Doppler effect.</span></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_134">5.1 SOUND WAVES</h2>
	<p class="block_">When you think about sound, the questions that arise in your minds are: How is sound produced? How does sound reach our ears from various sources? What is sound? Is it a force or energy? Let us answer all these questions.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image693.jpeg" alt=" Production of sound waves- Explained in the text book " class="calibre113"/></p>
	<p class="block_138"> Figure 5.1 Production of sound waves</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">By touching a ringing bell or a musical instrument while it is producing music, you can conclude that sound is produced by vibrations. The vibrating bodies produce energy in the form of waves, which are nothing but sound waves (Figure 5.1). Suppose you and your friend are on the Moon. Will you be able to hear any sound produced by your friend? As the Moon does not have air, you will not be able to hear any sound produced by your friend. Hence, you understand that the sound   produced   due to the vibration of different bodies needs a material medium like air, water, steel, etc</span>etera, for its propagation. Hence, sound can propagate through a gaseous medium or a liquid medium or a solid medium.</p>
	<p class="block_12">ACTIVITY 1</p>
	<p class="block_">Take a squeaky toy or old mobile phone and put it inside a plastic bag. Seal the bag with the help of a candle or with a thread. Fill a bucket with water and place the bag in the water bucket and squeeze the toy or ring the mobile. You will hear a low sound. Now place your ear against the side of the bucket and squeeze the toy or ring the mobile phone again. You will hear a louder sound.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_135">5.1.1 Longitudinal Waves</h3>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image696.jpeg" alt="Sound propagates as longitudinal waves-Explained in the text book " class="calibre114"/></p>
	<p class="block_138"> Figure 5.2 Sound propagates as longitudinal waves</p>
	<p class="block_">Sound waves are longitudinal waves that can travel through any medium (solids, liquids, gases) with a speed that depends on the properties of the medium. As sound travels through a medium, the particles of the medium vibrate along the direction of propagation of the wave. This displacement involves the longitudinal displacements of the individual molecules from their mean positions. This results in a series of high- and low-pressure regions called compressions and rarefactions as shown in figure 5.2.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_136">5.1.2 Categories of sound waves based on their frequencies</h3>
	<p class="block_74">(1<span class="calibre28">) Audible waves – These are sound waves with frequency ranging   between 20 Hz and 20,000 Hz. These are generated by vibrating bodies such as vocal cords, stretched strings etc</span>etera.</p>
	<p class="block_74">(2) Infrasonic waves – These are sound waves with a frequency below 20 Hz that cannot be heard by the human ear. example waves produced during earthquake, ocean waves, sound produced by whales, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_74">(3) Ultrasonic waves – These are sound waves with a frequency greater than 20 kHz, Human ear cannot detect these waves, but certain creatures like mosquito, dogs, bats, dolphins can detect these waves. example waves produced by bats.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_137">5.1.3 Difference between the sound and light waves</h3>
	<table class="table_10">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_111"><p class="block_192">Serial number.</p></td>
			<td class="td_112"><p class="block_193">SOUND</p></td>
			<td class="td_113"><p class="block_194">LIGHT</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_114"><p class="block_195">1</p></td>
			<td class="td_115"><p class="block_196">Medium is required for the propagation.</p></td>
			<td class="td_116"><p class="block_197">Medium is not required for the propagation.</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_114"><p class="block_82">2</p></td>
			<td class="td_115"><p class="block_198">Sound waves are longitudinal.</p></td>
			<td class="td_116"><p class="block_199">Light waves are transverse.</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_114"><p class="block_82">3</p></td>
			<td class="td_115"><p class="block_200">Wavelength ranges from</p><p class="block_201">1.65 cm to 1.65 meter.</p></td>
			<td class="td_116"><p class="block_202">Wave length ranges from </p><p class="block_202">4 times 10 power minus 7 meter to 7 times 10 power minus 7 meter.</p></td>
		</tr>

	<h3 class="block_205" id="toc_id_138"> </h3>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_139">5.1.4 Velocity of sound waves</h3>
	<p class="block_9">When you talk about the velocity associated with any wave, there are two velocities, namely particle velocity and wave velocity.  SI unit of velocity is m<span class="calibre15">etre  second power minus one.</span>.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Particle velocity:</p>
	<p class="block_9">The velocity with which the particles of the medium vibrate in order to transfer the energy in the form of a wave is called particle velocity.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Wave velocity:</p>
	<p class="block_9">The velocity with which the wave travels through the medium is called wave velocity. In other words, the distance travelled by a sound wave in unit time is called the velocity of a sound wave.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Velocity = distance travelled by time</p>
	<p class="block_61">If the distance travelled by one wave is taken as one wavelength (λ) and, the time taken for this propagation is one time period (T), then, the expression for velocity can be written as</p>
	<p class="block_206">Therefore  V is equal to lambta by T equation 5.1</p>
	<p class="block_23">Therefore, velocity can be defined as the distance travelled per second by a sound wave. Since, Frequency (n) is equal to 1, equation (5.1) can be written as</p>
	<p class="block_23"> V = n λ equation (5.2)</p>
	<p class="block_9">Velocity of a sound wave is maximum in solids because they are more elastic in nature than liquids and gases. Since, gases are least elastic in nature, the velocity of sound is the least in a gaseous medium.</p>
	<p class="block_9">So, v S<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>greater than v L greater than V G </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_140">5.1.5 Factors affecting velocity of sound</h3>
	<p class="block_9">In the case of solids, the elastic properties and the density of the solids affect the velocity of sound waves. Elastic property of solids is characterized by their elastic moduli. The speed of sound is directly proportional to the square root of the elastic modulus and inversely proportional to the square root of the density. Thus, the velocity of sound in solids decreases as the density increases whereas the velocity of sound increases when the elasticity of the material increases. In the case of gases, the following factors affect the velocity of sound waves.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Effect of density: The velocity of sound in a gas is inversely proportional to the square root of the density of the gas. Hence, the velocity decreases as the density of the gas increases.</p>
	<p class="block_207"><span class="calibre28">V is proportional to square root of one by d  </span></p>
	<p class="block_208"><span class="text_9">Effect of temperature: The velocity of sound in a gas is directly proportional to the square root of its temperature. The velocity of sound in a gas increase with the increase in temperature. V</span><span class="text_10">∝</span><span class="text_9"> √T. Velocity at temperature T is given by the following equation:</span></p>
	<p class="block_61">V T = (v 0 + 0.61 T) meter second power minus one. VT is equal to V0 plus zero point six one T with in the bracket metre second power minus one</p>
	<p class="block_9">Here, V 0 is the velocity of sound in the gas at 0° C. For air, V 0 = 331 meter second power minus one. Hence, the velocity of sound changes by 0.61 metre second power minus one when the temperature changes by one degree Celsius.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Effect of relative humidity: When humidity increases, the speed of sound increases. That is why you can hear sound from long distances clearly during rainy seasons.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Speed of sound waves in different media are given in table 5.1</p>

	<p class="block_12">Example Problem 5.1</p>
	<p class="block_">1. At what temperature will the velocity of sound in air be double the velocity of sound in air at 0<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>degree Celsius </p>
	<h6 class="block_225"><b class="calibre36">Solution</b>:</h6>
	<p class="block_226">Let T degree celsius be the required temperature. Let V 1<span class="text_11"> </span>and V 2 be the velocity of sound at temperatures</p>
	<p class="block_27">T 1 Kelvin and T 2 kelvin respectively. T 1 = 273 Kelvin (0 degree celsius) and T 2 = (T degree Celsius +273) Kelvin</p>
	<p class="block_">V 2 by V 1 = square root of T 2 by T 1 = square root of 273 + T divided by square root of 273 = 2</p>
	<p class="block_">Here it is given that V 2 by V 1 = 2</p>
	<p class="block_">So, 273 + T divided by 273 = 4</p>
	<p class="block_">T = (273 times 4) minus 273 = 819<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>degree Celsius.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_141">5.2 REFLECTION OF SOUND</h2>
	<p class="block_">When you speak in an empty room, you hear a soft repetition of your voice. This is nothing but the reflection of the sound waves that you produce. Let us discuss about the reflection of sound in detail through the following activity.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">When sound waves travel in a given medium and strike the surface of another medium, they can be bounced back into the first medium.  This phenomenon is known as reflection. In simple the reflection and refraction of sound is actually similar to the reflection of light. Thus, the bouncing of sound waves from the interface between two media is termed as the reflection of sound. The waves that strike the interface are termed as the incident wave and the waves that bounce back are termed as the reflected waves, as shown in Figure 5.3</span></p>
	<p class="block_27"><img src="images/image699.jpeg" alt="Reflection of sound Explained in text book " class="calibre115"/></p>
	<p class="block_227">Figure 5.3 Reflection of sound</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_142">5.2.1 Laws of reflection</h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_143"><img src="images/image-63.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of UV5IR" class="calibre116"/></h3>
	<p class="block_">Like light waves, sound waves also obey some fundamental laws of reflection. The following two laws of reflection are applicable to sound waves as well.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_228">The incident wave, the normal to the reflecting surface and the reflected wave at the point of incidence lie in the same plane.</li>
	<li class="block_229"><span class="text_12">The angle of incidence </span><span class="text_13">∠ </span><span class="text_12">i is equal to the angle of reflection </span><span class="text_13">∠</span><span class="text_12">r.</span></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_27">These laws can be observed from Figure 5.4.</p>
	<p class="block_27"><img src="images/image700.jpeg" alt="Laws of reflection  in the explained text book " class="calibre117"/></p>
	<p class="block_227">Figure 5.4 Laws of reflection </p>
	<p class="block_">In the above Figure 5.4, the sound waves that travel towards the reflecting surface are called the incident waves. The sound waves bouncing back from the reflecting surface are called reflected waves. For all practical purposes, the point of incidence and the point of reflection is the same point on the reflecting surface.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">A perpendicular line drawn at the point   of incidence is called the normal. The angle which the incident sound wave makes with the normal is called the angle of incidence, ‘i’. The angle which the reflected wave makes with the normal is called the angle of reflection, ‘r’.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Acoustical wonder of Golconda fort (Hyderabad, Telangana)</p>
	<p class="block_">The Clapping portico in Golconda Fort is a series of arches on one side, each smaller than the preceding one. So, a sound wave generated under the dome would get compressed and then bounce back amplified sufficiently </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_144">5.2.2 Reflection at the boundary of a denser medium</h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_145"><img src="images/image-64.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of FEB1J" class="calibre78"/></h3>
	<p class="block_">A longitudinal wave travels in a medium in the form of compressions and rarefactions. Suppose a compression travelling in air from left to right reaches a rigid wall. The compression exerts a force F on the rigid wall. In turn, the wall exerts an equal and opposite reaction R = minus  F on the air molecules. This results in a compression near the rigid wall. Thus, a compression travelling towards the rigid wall is reflected back as a compression. That is the direction of compression is reversed (Figure 5.5).</p>
	<p class="block_27"><img src="images/image704.jpeg" alt="Reflection of sound at a denser medium -Explained in the text book " class="calibre118"/></p>
	<p class="block_227">Figure 5.5 Reflection of sound at a denser medium</p>
	<p class="block_">Consider a wave travelling in a solid medium striking on the interface between the solid and the air. The compression exerts a force F on the surface of the rarer medium. As a rarer medium has smaller resistance for any deformation, the surface of separation is pushed backwards (Figure 5.6). As the particles of the rarer medium are free to move, a rarefaction is produced at the interface. Thus, a compression is reflected as a rarefaction and a rarefaction travel from right to left.</p>
	<p class="block_230"><img src="images/image702.jpeg" alt="Reflection of sound at a rarer medium  - Explained in the text book " class="calibre119"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Figure 5.6 Reflection of sound at a rarer medium  </span></p>
	<p class="block_12">More to know:</p>
	<p class="block_">What is meant by rarer and denser medium? The medium in which the velocity of sound increases compared to another medium is called rarer medium. (Water is rarer compared to air for sound).</p>
	<p class="block_">The medium in which the velocity of sound decreases compared to another medium is called denser medium. (Air is denser compared to water for sound)</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_146">5.2.3 Reflection of sound in plane and curved surfaces</h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_147"><img src="images/image-65.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of 6W1Y4" class="calibre120"/></h3>
	<p class="block_9">When sound waves are reflected from a plane surface, the reflected waves travel in a direction, according to the law of reflection. The intensity of the reflected wave is neither decreased nor increased. But, when the sound waves are reflected from the curved surfaces, the intensity of the reflected waves is changed. When reflected from a convex surface, the reflected waves are diverged out and the intensity is decreased. When sound is reflected from a concave surface, the reflected waves are converged and focused at a point So the intensity of reflected waves is concentrated at a point. Parabolic surfaces are used when it is required to focus the sound at a particular point. Hence, many halls are designed with parabolic reflecting surfaces. In elliptical surfaces, sound from one focus will always be reflected to the other focus, no matter where it strikes the wall.</p>
	<p class="block_9">This principle is used in designing whispering halls. In a whispering hall, the speech of a person standing in one focus can be heard clearly by a listener standing at the other focus. </p>
	<p class="block_9">Do You Know?<span class="calibre15">   </span></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_148">5.3 ECHOES</h2>
	<p class="block_9">An echo is the sound reproduced due to the reflection of the original sound from various rigid surfaces such as walls, ceilings, surfaces of mountains, etc.</p>
	<p class="block_9">If you shout or clap near a mountain or near a reflecting surface, like a building you can hear the same sound again. The sound, which you hear is called an echo. It is due to the reflection of sound. One does not experience any echo sound in a small room. This does not mean that sound is not reflected in a small room. This is because smaller rooms do not satisfy the basic conditions for hearing an echo.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_149">5.3.1 Conditions necessary for hearing echo</h3>
	<p class="block_">1. The persistence of hearing for human ears is 0.1 second. This means that you can hear two sound waves clearly, if the time interval between the two sounds is at least 0.1 s. Thus, the minimum time gap between the original sound and an echo must be 0.1 second.</p>
	<p class="block_">2. The above criterion can be satisfied only when the distance between the source of sound and the reflecting surface would satisfy the following equation:</p>
	<p class="block_"> velocity is equal to distance travelled by sound divided by time taken</p>
	<p class="block_"> V is equal to 2d by t</p>
	<p class="block_">d is equal to vt by two</p>
	<p class="block_">Since, t is equal to 0.1 second, then d is equal to v into zero point one divided by two is equal to v  divided by twenty.</p>
	<p class="block_">Thus, the minimum distance required to hear an echo is 1 by <span class="calibre28">20th part of the magnitude    of the velocity of sound in air.  If you consider the velocity of sound as 344 </span><span class="calibre28">  the</span> minimum distance required to hear an echo is 17.2 m.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_150"> 5.3.2 Applications of echo</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Some animals communicate with each other over long distances and also locate objects by sending the sound signals and receiving the echo as reflected from the targets.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The principle of echo is used in obstetric ultrasonography, which is used to create real-time visual images of the developing embryo or fetus in the mother’s uterus. This is a safe testing tool, as it does not use any harmful radiations.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Echo is used to determine the velocity of sound waves in any medium.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_151">5.3.3 Measuring velocity of sound by echo method</h3>
	<p class="block_12">Apparatus required:</p>
	<p class="block_">A source of sound pulses, a measuring tape, a sound receiver, and a stopwatch.</p>
	<p class="block_">Measuring velocity of sound by echo method</p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<p class="block_">1. Measure the distance ‘d’ between the source of sound pulse and the reflecting surface using the measuring tape.</p>
	<p class="block_">2. The receiver is also placed adjacent to the source. A sound pulse is emitted by the source.</p>
	<p class="block_">3. The stopwatch is used to note the time interval between the instant at which the sound pulse is sent and the instant at which the echo is received by the receiver. Note the time interval as ‘t’.</p>
	<p class="block_">4. Repeat the experiment for three or four times. The average time taken for the given number of pulses is calculated.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Calculation of speed of sound:</p>
	<p class="block_">The sound pulse emitted by the source travels a total distance of 2d while travelling from the source to the wall and then back to the receiver. The time taken for this has been observed to be ‘t’. Hence, the <b class="calibre6">speed of sound wave is given </b>by  speed of sound equal to distance travelled divided by time taken = 2 times d divided by t. </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_152">5.4 APPLICATIONS REFLECTION OF SOUND</h2>
	<p class="block_12">5.4.1.Sound board </p>
	<p class="block_">These are basically curved surfaces (concave), which are used in auditoria and halls to improve the quality of sound. This board is placed such that the speaker is at the focus of the concave surface. The sound of the speaker is reflected towards the audience thus improving the quality of sound heard by the audience.</p>
	<p class="block_12">5.4.2.Ear trumpet </p>
	<p class="block_">Ear trumpet is a hearing aid, which is useful by people who have difficulty in hearing. In this device, one end is wide, and the other end is narrow. The sound from the sources falls into the wide end and are reflected by its walls into the narrow part of the device. This helps in concentrating the sound and the sound enters the ear drum with more intensity. This enables a person to hear the sound better.</p>
	<p class="block_12">5.4.3.Megaphone</p>
	<p class="block_">A megaphone is a horn-shaped device used to address a small gathering of people. It’s one end is wide, and the other end is narrow. When a person speaks at the narrow end, the sound of his speech is concentrated by the multiple reflections from the walls of the tube. Thus, his voice can be heard loudly over a long distance.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_153">5.5 DOPPLER EFFECT</h2>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">The whistle of a fast-moving train appears to increase in pitch as it approaches a stationary listener, and it appears to decrease as the train moves away from the listener.  This apparent change in frequency was first observed and explained by Christian Doppler (1803</span> to <span class="calibre15">1853), an Austrian Mathematician and Physicist. He observed that the frequency of the sound as received by a listener is different from the original frequency produced by the source whenever there is a relative motion between the source and the listener. This is known as Doppler effect This relative motion could be due to various possibilities   as follows:</span></p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_231">The listener moves towards or away from a stationary source</li>
	<li class="block_231">The source moves towards or away from a stationary listener</li>
	<li class="block_231">Both source and listener move towards or away from one other</li>
	<li class="block_231">The medium moves when both source and listener are at rest</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">DEFINITION</p>
	<p class="block_">Whenever there is a relative motion between a source and a listener, the frequency of the sound heard by the listener is different from the original frequency of sound emitted by the source. This is known as “Doppler effect”.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image708.jpeg" alt=" Source and listener moving towards each other -Explained in the text book " class="calibre121"/> </p>
	<p class="block_74">Figure 5.7 Source and listener moving towards each other</p>
	<p class="block_">For simplicity of calculation, it is assumed that the medium is at rest. That is the velocity of the medium is zero. Let S and L be the source and the listener moving with velocities v<sub class="calibre25">S</sub>  and  v<sub class="calibre25">L</sub><span class="calibre28"> respectively. Consider   the   case   of   source   and listener moving towards each other (Figure 5.7). As the distance </span>between them decreases, the apparent frequency will be more than the actual source frequency. </p>
	<p class="block_">Let n and n dash<span class="calibre28"> be the frequency of the sound produced by the source and the sound observed by the listener respectively.  Then, the expression for the apparent frequency n' is</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><i class="calibre33"><span class="calibre28">  </span></i><i class="calibre33"> n dash is equal to v plus v1 by v minus vs into n</i></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Here, v is the   velocity   of   sound   waves in the given medium. Let us consider different possibilities of motions of the source and the listener.  In all such cases, the expression for the apparent frequency is given in table 5.2.</span></p>
	<p class="block_74"><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span><b class="calibre6"> Table 5.2 Expression for apparent frequency due to Doppler effect</b></p>

	<div class="block_250"><span class="bullet_2">b) </span><span class="calibre52">v<span class="text_11">S </span>becomes opposite to that in case2.</span></div>

			<td class="td_142"><p class="block_251"> </p><p class="block_10"><span class="calibre28">  </span></p><p class="block_61"> N dah equal to v minus v1 by v-vs into n</p></td>
		</tr>

	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<table class="table_12">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">

	<p class="block_9">Suppose the medium (say wind) is moving with a velocity W in the direction of the propagation of sound. For this case, the velocity of sound, ‘v’ should be replaced with (v + W). If the medium moves in a direction opposite to the propagation of sound, then ‘v’ should be replaced with (v minus W).</p>
	<p class="block_19">Solved problems</p>
	<p class="block_9">1. A source producing a sound of frequency 90 Hz is approaching a stationary listener with a speed equal to (1by10) of the speed of sound. What will be the frequency heard by the listener?</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Solution:</b> When the source is moving towards the stationary listener, the expression for apparent frequency is</p>
	<p class="block_61"><img src="images/image-66.png" alt="n dash is equal to v divided by v minus v s into n. equal to v by v minus one by ten into v whole bracket into n.  equal to v by 10v minus 1v by 10 whole bracket into n. equal to 10v by 9 whole bracket into 90 equal to 10 by 9 whole bracket into 90 equal to 100 Hertz " class="calibre123"/></p>
	<p class="block_261"> </p>
	<p class="block_261"> </p>
	<p class="block_261"> </p>
	<p class="block_">2. A source producing a sound of frequency 500 Hz is moving towards a listener with a velocity of 30 metre second  power minus 1. The speed of the sound is 330 metre second  power  minus1. What will be the frequency heard by listener?</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Solution</b>: When the source is moving towards the stationary listener, the expression for apparent frequency is</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_262">n dash is equal to v by v minus v s whole bracket into n</p>
	<p class="block_261"><span class="text_15">n dash is equal to 330 by 330 minus 30 whole bracket into 500</span><span class="text_16"> </span><span class="text_17">= 550 Hz</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">3. A source of sound is moving with a velocity of 50 meter second power minus 1 towards a stationary listener. The listener measures the frequency of the source as 1000 Hz. what will be the apparent frequency of the source when it is moving away from the listener after crossing him? (Velocity of sound in the medium is 330 meter second power minus 1)</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Solution:</b> When the source is moving towards the stationary listener, the expression for apparent frequency is</p>
	<p class="block_61">n dash = v divided by v – v s whole bracket multiplied by n<i class="calibre33"><span class="calibre28">                     </span></i></p>
	<p class="block_61">1000 = 330 divided by 330 minus 50 whole bracket multiplied by n</p>
	<p class="block_61">n = 1000 times 280 divided by 330</p>
	<p class="block_62">n = 848.48 Hz. </p>
	<p class="block_9">The actual frequency of the sound is 848.48 Hz. When the source is moving away from the stationary listener, the expression for apparent frequency is</p>
	<p class="block_61">n dash = open bracket v divided by v plus v s close bracket multiplied by n</p>
	<p class="block_61">= open bracket 330 divided by 330 + 50 closed bracket multiplied by 848.48</p>
	<p class="block_9">=736.84 Hz</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">4. A source and listener are both moving towards each other with a speed v by 10 where v is the speed of sound. If the frequency of the note emitted by the source is f, what will be the frequency heard by the listener?</p>
	<p class="block_263">Solution: When source and listener are both moving towards each other, the apparent frequency is</p>
	<p class="block_61"><span class="calibre28">n dash = open bracket v + v l  divided by v minus v s close bracket multiplied by n</span></p>
	<p class="block_61">n dash = open bracket v + v by 10 divided by v minus v by 10 close bracket multiplied by n</p>
	<p class="block_61">n dash = 11 divided by 9 multiplied by f</p>
	<p class="block_62">= 1.22 f</p>
	<p class="block_261"> </p>
	<p class="block_">5. At what speed should a source of sound move away from a stationary observer so that observer finds the apparent frequency equal to half of the original frequency? </p>
	<p class="block_263"><b class="calibre6">Solution:</b> When the source is moving away from the stationary listener, the expression for the apparent frequency is</p>
	<p class="block_">n dash = open bracket v by v + v s close bracket multiplied by n</p>
	<p class="block_61">n by 2 = open bracket v by v + v s close bracket multiplied by n</p>
	<p class="block_">v s = v</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_154">5.5.1 Conditions for no Doppler effect</h3>
	<p class="block_">Under the following circumstances, there will be no Doppler effect and the apparent frequency as heard by the listener will be the same as the source frequency.</p>
	<p class="block_263">(i)<span class="tab">      </span>When source (S) and listener (L) both are at rest.</p>
	<p class="block_263">(ii)<span class="tab">      </span>When S and L move in such a way that distance between them remains constant.</p>
	<p class="block_263">(iii)<span class="tab">      </span>When source S and L are moving in mutually perpendicular directions.</p>
	<p class="block_263">(iv)<span class="tab">      </span><span class="calibre28">If the source is situated at the centre    of the circle along which the listener is moving.</span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_155">5.5.2 Applications of Doppler effect</h3>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_20"><span class="bullet_">(a) </span><span class="calibre18"><b class="calibre36">To measure the speed of an automobile</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">An electromagnetic wave is emitted by a source attached to a police car. The wave     is reflected by a moving vehicle, which acts   as a moving source. There is a shift in the frequency of the reflected wave. From the frequency shift, the speed of the car can be determined. This helps to track the over speeding vehicles.</span></p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_20"><span class="bullet_">(b) </span><span class="calibre18"><b class="calibre36">Tracking a satellite</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_9">The frequency of radio waves emitted by a satellite decreases as the satellite passes away from the Earth. By measuring the change in the frequency of the radio waves, the location of the satellites is studied.</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_20"><span class="bullet_">(c) </span><span class="calibre18"><b class="calibre36">RADAR<span class="tab1">      </span>(R</b><b class="calibre36">adio<span class="tab1">      </span>Detection </b><b class="calibre36">and Ranging)</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_9">In RADAR, radio waves are sent, and the reflected waves are detected by the receiver</p>
	<p class="block_9">of the RADAR station. From the frequency change, the speed and location of the aeroplanes and aircrafts are tracked.</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_20"><span class="bullet_">(d) </span><span class="calibre18"><b class="calibre36">SONAR</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_9">In SONAR, by measuring the change in the frequency between the sent signal and received signal, the speed of marine animals and submarines can be determined.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_156">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">Wave velocity is the velocity with which the wave travels through the medium.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Velocity of a sound wave is maximum in solids because they are more elastic in nature than liquids and gases. Since gases are least elastic in nature.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Infrasonic waves are sound wave with a frequency below 20 Hz. A human ear cannot hear these waves.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Ultrasonic waves are sound waves with frequency greater than 20 kHz, A human ear cannot detect these waves.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Reflection of sound waves obey the laws of reflection.</li>
	<li class="block_66">when a compression hits the boundary of a rarer medium, it is reflected as a rarefaction.</li>
	<li class="block_66">An echo is the sound reproduced due to the reflection of the original sound wave.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The minimum distance between the source and the reflecting surface should be 17.2 m to hear an echo clearly.</li>
	<li class="block_66">“The apparent frequency” is the frequency of the sound as heard by the listener.</li>
</ol>

	<p class="block_12">II. Fill up the blanks</p>
	<p class="block_">1. Rapid back and forth motion of a particle about its mean position is called dash.</p>

	<p class="block_12">V. Assertion and Reason Questions</p>
	<p class="block_12">Mark the correct choice as</p>
	<p class="block_">a. If both the assertion and the reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.</p>
	<p class="block_">b. If both the assertion and the reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion.</p>
	<p class="block_">c. Assertion is true, but the reason is false.</p>
	<p class="block_">d. Assertion is false, but the reason is true.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">1) Assertion:</b> The change in air pressure affects the speed of sound.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Reason:</b> The speed of sound in a gas is proportional to the square of the pressure</p>
	<p class="block_">2) <b class="calibre6">Assertion:</b> Sound travels faster in solids than in gases.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Reason:</b> Solid possess a greater density than that of gases.</p>

	<li class="block_7">Relate the properties of alpha, beta and gamma rays.</li>

	<li class="block_8">Identify the precautionary measures while handling a radioactive material.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_161">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Humans are very much interested in knowing about atoms. Things around us are made up of atoms. A Greek Philosopher 'Democritus' in 400 BC believed that matter is made up of tiny indestructible units called atoms. Later, in 1803, John Dalton considered that elements consist of atoms, which are identical in nature.   J J Thomson discovered cathode rays, known as electrons, experimentally and Goldstein discovered positive rays, which were named as protons by Rutherford.  In 1932, James Chadwick discovered the charge less particles called neutrons. Presently, a large number of elementary particles like photon, meson, positron and neutrino have been discovered. In 1911, the British scientist, Ernest Rutherford explained that the mass of an atom is concentrated in its central part called Nucleus. You have already learnt about the atomic structure in the earlier classes.</span></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_162">6.1 RADIOACTIVITY</h2>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_163">6.1.1 Discovery of radioactivity</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">In 1896, French physicist Henri Becquerel finished his research for the week and stored a certain amount of uranium compound away in a drawer for the week end. By chance, an unexposed photographic plate was also stored in the same drawer. After a week he returned and noticed that the film had been exposed to some radiation. He discovered that he could reproduce the effect whenever he placed uranium near a photographic film. Apparently, uranium radiated something that could affect   a photographic plate. This phenomenon was called as Radioactivity. Uranium was identified to be a radioactive element.</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Two years later, the Polish physicist Marie Curie and her husband Pierre Curie detected radioactivity in 'Pitchblende', a tiny black substance. They were not surprised at the radioactivity of pitchblende, which   is known as an ore of uranium. Later, they discovered that the radiation was more intense from pure uranium. Also, it was found that the pitchblende had less concentration of uranium. They </span>concluded that some other substance was present in pitchblende. After separating this new substance, they discovered that it had unknown chemical properties and it also emitted radiations spontaneously like uranium. They named this new substance as 'Radium'. The radioactive elements emit harmful radioactive radiations like alpha rays or beta rays or gamma rays.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_164">6.1.2 Definition of radioactivity</h3>
	<p class="block_9">The nucleus of some elements is unstable. Such nuclei undergo nuclear decay and get converted into more stable nuclei. During this nuclear reaction, these nuclei emit certain harmful radiations and elementary particles. The phenomenon of nuclear decay of certain elements with the emission of radiations like alpha, beta, and gamma rays is called 'radioactivity' and the elements, which undergo this phenomenon are called 'radioactive elements'.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_165">6.1.3 Natural Radioactivity</h3>
	<p class="block_9">The elements such as uranium and radium undergo radioactivity and emit the radiations on their own without any human intervention. This phenomenon of spontaneous emission of radiation from certain elements on their own is called 'natural radioactivity'.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">The elements   whose   atomic   number is more than 83 undergo spontaneous radioactivity.</span> Example ; uranium, radium, Etcetera. There are only two elements, which have been identified as radioactive substances with atomic number less than 83. They are technetium (Tc) with atomic number 43 and promethium (Pm) with atomic number 61.</p>
	<p class="block_">There have been 29 radioactive substances discovered so far. Most of them are rare earth metals and transition metals.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_166">6.1.4 Artificial Radioactivity (or) Induced Radioactivity</h3>
	<p class="block_">The phenomenon by which even light elements are made radioactive, by artificial or induced methods, is called 'artificial radioactivity' or 'man-made radioactivity'.</p>
	<p class="block_">This kind of radioactivity was discovered by Irene Curie and Joliot<span class="calibre28"> in 1934. Artificial radioactivity is induced in certain lighter elements like boron, aluminium etc., by bombarding them with radiations such as 'alpha particles' emitted during the natural radioactivity of uranium.  This also results in the   emission   of   invisible   radiations and elementary particles. During such a disintegration, the nucleus which undergoes disintegration is called 'parent nucleus' and that which is produced after the disintegration is called a 'daughter nucleus'. The particle, which is used to induce the artificial disintegration is termed as projectile and the particle which is produced after the disintegration is termed as ejected particle. When the projectile hits the parent nucleus, it is converted into an unstable nucleus, which in turn decays spontaneously emitting the daughter nucleus along with an ejected particle.</span></p>
	<p class="block_138">Table 6.1 Comparison between Natural and Artificial Radioactivity</p>

	<p class="block_19">Activity 6.1</p>
	<p class="block_9">Using the periodic table, list out the radioactive elements. Also identify the name of the groups in which they are present.</p>
	<p class="block_">If you denote the parent and daughter nuclei as X and Y respectively, then the nuclear disintegration is represented as follows: X (P, E) Y. Here, P and E represent the projectile particle and ejected particle respectively.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-71.png" alt="Example Four beryllium  nine plus two helium four gives six carbon thirteen . six carbon  thirteen  gives six carbon  12 plus zero  neutron one." class="calibre127"/></p>
	<p class="block_">In the above nuclear reaction, 6 Carbon 13 is unstable and is radioactive. </p>
	<p class="block_261"><span class="text_19">This reaction can be represented as 4 Beryllium 9 (α, n) </span><span class="text_16">6 Carbon 12</span><span class="text_19">. </span></p>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_167">6.1.5. Units of Radioactivity</h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_168"><img src="images/image-72.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of BD21C" class="calibre128"/></h3>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Curie:</b> It is the traditional unit of radioactivity. It is defined as the quantity of a radioactive substance which undergoes 3.7 × 10 power 10 disintegrations in one second. This is actually close to the activity of 1 g of radium 226.</p>
	<p class="block_">1 curie = 3.7 × ten  power ten disintegrations per second.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Rutherford (Rd):</b><span class="calibre28"> It is another unit of radioactivity.  It is defined as the quantity of a radioactive substance, which produces </span> ten power of six<span class="calibre28">  </span>disintegrations in one second.</p>
	<p class="block_">1 <b class="calibre6">Rutherford</b> = ten power of six disintegrations per second.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Becquerel (Bq):</b><span class="calibre28">  The SI unit of radioactivity is becquerel. It is defined as the quantity of one disintegration per second.</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Roentgen (R): </b><span class="calibre28">It is the radiation exposure of γ and x-rays is measured by another unit called roentgen.  One roentgen   is   defined as the quantity of radioactive substance which produces a charge of 2.58 × 10</span> power -4 coulomb in 1 kg of air under standard conditions of pressure, temperature and humidity.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_169">6.2 ALPHA, BETA AND GAMMA RAYS</h2>
	<p class="block_">When a radioactive nucleus undergoes radioactivity, it emits harmful radiations. These radiations are usually comprised of any of the three types of particles. They are alpha(α), beta (β) and gamma(γ) rays.</p>
	<p class="block_">Uranium, named after the planet Uranus, was discovered by Martin Klaproth, a German chemist in a mineral called pitchblende.</p>
