	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_171">6.2.2 Radioactive displacement law</h3>
	<p class="block_">In 1913, Soddy and Fajan framed the displacement laws governing the daughter nucleus produced during an alpha and beta decay. They are stated below:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">When a radioactive element emits an alpha particle, a daughter nucleus is formed whose mass number is less by 4 units and the atomic number is less by 2 units, than the mass number and atomic number of the parent nucleus.</li>
	<li class="block_8">When a radioactive element emits a beta particle, a daughter nucleus is formed whose mass number is the same and the atomic number is more by 1 unit, than the atomic number of the parent nucleus.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_172">6.2.3 Alpha decay</h3>
	<p class="block_">A nuclear reaction in which an unstable parent nucleus emits an alpha particle and forms a stable daughter nucleus, is called 'alpha decay'.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="text_4">Example: Decay of uranium (Uranium 238) to thorium (Thorium 234) with the emission of an alpha particle.</span> <img src="images/image-73.png" alt="ninety two uranium two thirty eight gives ninety thorium two thirty four plus two helium four. this is alpha decay" class="calibre129"/></p>
	<p class="block_303"></p>
	<p class="block_">In α decay, the parent nucleus emits an α particle and so it is clear that for the daughter nucleus, the mass number decreases by four and the atomic number decreases by two as illustrated in Figure 6.1</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image1007.jpeg" alt="Alpha decay - Explained in the text book " class="calibre130"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 6.1 Alpha decay</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_173">6.2.4 Beta decay </h3>
	<p class="block_">A nuclear reaction, in which an unstable parent nucleus emits a beta particle and forms a stable daughter neuleus, is called 'beta decay'. Example.: Beta decay of phosphorous.</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-74.png" alt="Fifteen phosphorus thirty two gives  sixteen sulphur  thirty two plus  , minus one electron power of zero. this is beta decay." class="calibre131"/></p>
	<p class="block_">In β - decay there is no change in the mass number of the daughter nucleus, but the atomic number increases by one.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Note:</b> In a nuclear reaction, the element formed as the product nucleus is identified by the atomic number of the resulting nucleus and not by its mass number.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_174">6.2.5 Gamma decay</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">In a γ - decay, only the energy level of the nucleus changes.  The atomic number and mass number of the radioactive nucleus remain the same.</span></p>
	<div class="calibre132">
	<div class="block_71" id="toc_id_175"><span class="bullet_1">6.1 </span><span class="calibre52">NUCLEAR FISSION</span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">       </span><img src="images/image-75.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of SBLO7" class="calibre133"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_176">6.3.1 Definition</h3>
	<p class="block_9">In 1939, German Scientist Otto Hahn and Strassman discovered that when a uranium nucleus is bombarded with a neutron, it breaks up into two smaller nuclei of comparable mass along with the emission of a few neutrons and energy. This process of breaking (splitting) up of a heavier nucleus into two smaller nuclei with the release of a large amount of energy and a few neutrons is called 'nuclear fission'. Example:<span class="calibre15">    Nuclear    fission    of    a uranium nucleus (U235)</span></p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-76.png" alt="92 uranium 235 plus 0 neutron 1 gives  56 barium 141 plus 36  krypton  92 plus  3  0 neutron 1 plus energy." class="calibre134"/></p>
	<p class="block_">The average energy released in eae:ch fission process is about 3.2 × 10 power -11 Joule. Nuclear fission is pictorially represented in Figure 6.2.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image1008.jpeg" alt="Nuclear fission - Explained in the text book " class="calibre135"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 6.2 Nuclear fission</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_177">6.3.2 Fissionable materials</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">A fissionable material is a radioactive element, which undergoes fission in a sustained manner when it absorbs a neutron.   It is also termed as 'fissile material'.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Example: U<span class="calibre28">ranium  235</span>, plutonium (<span class="calibre28">plutonium  </span>239 and P<span class="calibre28">lutonium  </span><span class="calibre28">241) All isotopes of uranium do not undergo nuclear fission when they absorb a neutron. For   example, natural   uranium   consists of99.28 % of </span>U<span class="calibre28">ranium 92  235  </span>and  0.72 percentage of<span class="calibre28"> Uranium 92  235 </span><span class="text_11"> </span>. Of these two, Uranium 238  does not undergo fission whereas Uranium 235  undergoes fission. Hence,  Uranium 235 <sup class="calibre27"> </sup>is a fissionable material and  Uranium 238  is non- fissionable.</p>
	<p class="block_">There are some radioactive elements, which can be converted into fissionable material. They are called as fertile materials. Example : <span class="tab">      </span>Uranium-238, Thorium-232, Plutonium-240.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_178">6.3.3 Chain Reaction </h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">A uranium nucleus (U-235) when bombarded with a neutron   undergoes fission producing three neutrons.  These three neutrons in turn can cause fission in three other uranium nuclei present in the sample, thus producing nine neutrons. These nine neutrons in turn may produce twenty-seven neutrons and so on. This is known as 'chain reaction'. A chain reaction is a self- propagating process in which the number of neutrons goes on multiplying rapidly almost in a geometrical progression.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Two kinds of chain reactions are possible. They are: (One) controlled chain reaction and (Two)uncontrolled chain reaction.</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_14"><span class="bullet_1">(a) </span><span class="calibre52"><b class="calibre6">Controlled chain reaction</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">In the controlled chain reaction, the number of neutrons released is maintained to be one.  This is achieved by absorbing the extra neutrons with a neutron absorber leaving only one neutron to produce further fission. Thus, the reaction is sustained in a controlled manner. The energy released due to a controlled chain reaction can be utilized for constructive purposes. Controlled chain reaction is used in a nuclear reactor to produce energy in a sustained and controlled manner.</span></p>
	<p class="block_12"> (b) Uncontrolled chain reaction</p>
	<p class="block_">In the uncontrolled chain reaction, the number of neutrons multiplies indefinitely and causes fission in a large amount of the fissile material. This results in the release of a huge amount of energy within a fraction of a second. This kind of chain reaction is used in the atom bomb to produce an explosion. Figure 6.3 represents an uncontrolled chain reaction.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-77.png" alt="Uncontrolled chain reaction  Explained in the text book " class="calibre136"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 6.3 Uncontrolled chain reaction</p>
	<p class="block_12">6.3.4 Critical Mass</p>
	<p class="block_">During a nuclear fission process, about 2 to 3 neutrons are released. But all these neutrons may not be available to produce further fission. Some of them may escape from the system, which is termed as 'leakage of neutrons' and some may be absorbed by the non-fissionable materials present in the system. These two factors lead to the loss of neutrons. To sustain the chain reaction, the rate of production of neutrons due to nuclear fission must be more than the rate of its loss. This can be achieved only when the size (That is mass) of the fissionable material is equal to a certain optimum value. This is known as 'critical mass'.</p>
	<p class="block_">The minimum mass of a fissile material necessary to sustain the chain reaction is called' critical mass (mc)'. It depends on the nature, density and the size of the fissile material.</p>
	<p class="block_">If the mass of the fissile material is less than the critical mass, it is termed as 'subcritical'. If the mass of the fissile material is more than the critical mass, it is termed as 'supercritical'.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Activity 6.2</p>
	<p class="block_">Using beads make a chain reaction model</p>
	<p class="block_19">6.3.5 Atom bomb</p>
	<p class="block_9">The atom bomb is based on the principle of uncontrolled chain reaction. In an uncontrolled chain reaction, the number of neutrons and the number of fission reactions multiply almost in a geometrical progression. This releases a huge amount of energy in a very small-time interval and leads to an explosion.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Structure:</p>
	<p class="block_9">An atom bomb consists of a piece of fissile material whose mass is subcritical. This piece has a cylindrical void. It has a cylindrical fissile material which can fit into this void and its mass is also subcritical. When the bomb has to be exploded, this cylinder is injected into the void using a conventional explosive. Now, the two pieces of fissile material join to form the supercritical mass, which leads to an explosion. The structure of an atom bomb is shown in Figure 6.4</p>
	<p class="block_23"><img src="images/image1014.jpeg" alt="Atom bomb Explanation in the text book " class="calibre137"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 6.4 Atom bomb</p>
	<p class="block_">During this explosion tremendous amount of energy in the form of heat, light and radiation is released. A region of very high temperature and pressure is formed in a fraction of a second along with the emission of hazardous radiation like γ rays, which adversely affect the living creatures. This type of atom bombs was exploded in 1945 at Hiroshima and Nagasaki in Japan during the World War II.</p>
	<p class="block_">Do You Know?</p>
	<p class="block_">Electron Volt it read as eV is the unit used in nuclear physics to measure the energy of small particles. It is nothing but the energy of one electron when it is accelerated using an electric potential of one volt.</p>
	<p class="block_">1eV = 1.602 × 10 power -19 joule.</p>
	<p class="block_">1 million electron volt = 1 MeV = 10 power 6 eV</p>
	<p class="block_">(Mega electron volt)</p>
	<p class="block_">The energy released in a nuclear fission process is about 200 MeV.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_179">6.4 NUCLEAR FUSION</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-78.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of WHQY5" class="calibre71"/></p>
	<p class="block_">You have learnt that energy can be produced when a heavy nucleus is split up into two smaller nuclei. Similarly, energy can be produced when two lighter nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus. This phenomenon is known as nuclear fusion.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_180">6.4.1 Definition</h3>
	<p class="block_">The process in which two lighter nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus is termed as 'nuclear fusion'.</p>
	<p class="block_304"><b class="calibre6">Example<span class="calibre28">  </span></b><b class="calibre6">1 </b>Hydrogen<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>2 + 1 Hydrogen<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>2 <sub class="calibre25"> </sub>2 helium 4 + Q (Energy)</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image1017.jpeg" alt="Nuclear fusion Explained in the text book " class="calibre138"/></p>
	<p class="block_138"> Figure 6.5 Nuclear fusion</p>
	<p class="block_305">Here, 1H2 represents an isotope of hydrogen known as 'deuterium'. The average energy released in each fusion reaction is about 3.84 × 10 power -12 Joule. Figure 6.5 represents this.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">The mass of the daughter nucleus formed during a nuclear reaction (fission and fusion) is lesser than the sum of the masses of the   two parent nuclei. This difference in mass is called mass defect. This mass is converted into energy, according to the mass-energy equivalence. This concept of mass-energy equivalence was proposed by Einstein in 1905. It stated that mass can be converted into energy and vice versa. The relation between mass and energy proposed by Einstein is   </span></p>
	<p class="block_">E = mc power 2 where c is the velocity of light in vacuum and is equal to 3 × 10 power of 8 .</p>
	<p class="block_19">Do you Know </p>
	<p class="block_9">The nuclear bomb that was dropped in Hiroshima during World War II was called as</p>
	<p class="block_9">'Little boy'. It was a gun-type bomb which used a uranium core. The bomb, which was subsequently dropped over Nagasaki was called as 'Fat man'. It was an explosion type bomb, which used a plutonium core.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_181">6.4.2 Conditions necessary for nuclear fusion</h3>
	<p class="block_9">Earth’s atmosphere contains a small trace of hydrogen. If nuclear fusion is a spontaneous process at normal temperature and pressure, then a number of fusion processes would happen in the atmosphere which may lead to explosions. But we do not encounter any such explosions. Can you explain why?</p>
	<p class="block_9">The answer is that nuclear fusion can take place only under certain conditions.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Nuclear fusion is possible only at an extremely high temperature of the order of 10 power of  7 to </p>
	<p class="block_9">10 power of 9 Kelvin  and a high pressure to push the hydrogen nuclei closer to fuse with each other. Hence, it is named as 'Thermonuclear reaction'.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Do you know</p>
	<p class="block_9">Nuclear fusion is the combination of two lighter nuclei. The charge of both nuclei is positive. According to electrostatic theory, when they come closer, they tend to repel each other. This repulsive force will be overcome by the kinetic energy of the nuclei at higher temperature of the order of 10 power of  7 to 10 power of  9 Kelvin.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_182">6.4.3 Stellar Energy</h3>
	<p class="block_">The stars like our Sun emit a large amount of energy in the form of light and heat. This energy is termed as the stellar energy. Where does this high energy come from? All stars contain a large amount of hydrogen. The surface temperature of the stars is very high which is sufficient to induce fusion of the hydrogen nuclei.</p>
	<p class="block_">Fusion reaction that takes place in the cores of the Sun and other stars results in an enormous amount of energy, which is called as 'stellar energy. Thus, nuclear fusion or thermonuclear reaction is the source of light and heat energy in the Sun and other stars.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_183">6.4.4 Hydrogen Bomb</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Hydrogen bomb is based on the principle of nuclear fusion. A hydrogen bomb is always designed to have   an inbuilt atom bomb which creates the high temperature and pressure required for fusion when it explodes. Then, fusion takes place in the hydrogen core and leads to the release of a very large amount of energy in an uncontrolled manner. The energy released in a hydrogen bomb (or fusion bomb) is much higher than that released in an atom bomb (or fission bomb).</span></p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 6.3 Features of Nuclear fission and nuclear fusion</p>

	<p class="block_12">Do you know</p>
	<p class="block_">Sun fuses about 620 million metric tons of hydrogen each second and radiates about</p>
	<p class="block_">3.8 × 10 power of  26 joule  s energy per second. When this energy is radiated towards the Earth, it decreases in its intensity. When it reaches the Earth, its value is about 1.4 kilo joule per unit area in unit time.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_184">6.5 USES OF RADIOACTIVITY</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-79.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of IGJ4H" class="calibre42"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Many radio isotopes can be obtained from radioactivity. These radio isotopes have found wide variety of applications in the fields of medicine, agriculture, industry and archaeological research.</p>
	<p class="block_12">6.5.1 .Agriculture</p>
	<p class="block_">The radio isotope of phosphorous (Phosphorous -32) helps to increase the productivity of crops. </p>
	<p class="block_">The radiations from the radio isotopes can be used to kill the insects and parasites and prevent the wastage of agricultural products. Certain perishable cereals exposed to radiations remain fresh beyond their normal life, enhancing the storage time. Very small doses of radiation prevent sprouting and spoilage of onions, potatoes and gram.</p>
	<p class="block_12">6.5.2. Medicine</p>
	<p class="block_">Medical applications of radio isotopes can be divided into two parts:</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">First  </span>) Diagnosis <span class="calibre28">,  Second </span>) Therapy . </p>
	<p class="block_">Radio isotopes are used as tracers to diagnose the nature of circulatory disorders of blood, defects of bone metabolism, to locate tumours, etc. Some of the radio isotopes which are used as tracers are: hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen, sulphur, edcetera.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Radio sodium (sodium 24 ) is used for the effective functioning of heart.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Radio – Iodine (Iodine 131 ) is used to cure goitre.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Radio-iron is (Iron 59 ) is used to diagnose anaemia and also to provide treatment for the same.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Radio phosphorous (phosphorous 32 ) is used in the treatment of skin diseases.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Radio cobalt (Cobalt 60 ) and radio-gold (Gold<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>198 ) are used in the treatment of skin cancer.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Radiations are used to sterilize the surgical devices as they can kill the germs and microbes.</li>
</ol>
	<div class="calibre139">
	<div class="block_14"><span class="bullet_1">6.4.3. </span><span class="calibre52"><b class="calibre6">Industries</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_">In industries, radioactive isotopes are used as tracers to detect any manufacturing defects such as cracks and leaks. Packaging faults can also be identified through radio activity. Gauges, which have radioactive sources are used in many industries to check the level of gases, liquids and solids.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">An isotope of californium (californium<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>252 ) is used in the airlines to detect the explosives in the luggage.</li>
	<li class="block_8">An isotope of Americium (Americium 241 ) is used in many industries as a smoke detector.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">6.5.4 Archaeological research</p>
	<p class="block_">Using the technique of radio carbon dating, the age of the Earth, fossils, old paintings and monuments can be determined. In radio carbon dating, the existing amount of radiocarbon is determined, and this gives an estimate about the age of these things.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_185">6.6 SAFETY MEASURES</h2>
	<p class="block_">In day-to-day life, you do receive some natural radiation from the Sun. The radioactive elements present in the soil and rocks, the household appliances like television, microwave ovens, cell phones and the X-rays used in hospitals. These radiations do not produce any severe effects as they are very low in intensity.</p>
	<p class="block_">The second source of radiation exposure is man-made. These are due to nuclear reactors and during the testing of the nuclear devices in the atmosphere or in the ground.</p>
	<p class="block_">Improper and careless handling of radioactive materials release harmful radiations in our environment. These radiations are very harmful to the human body. A person who is exposed to radiations very closely or for a longer duration, is at a greater health risk and can be affected genetically.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do you Know</p>
	<p class="block_">How old is our mother Earth? Any guess?? It is nearly 4.54 × 10 power of 9 years (around 45 Crore 40 lakh years). Wow!!</p>
	<p class="block_12"> 6.6.1. Permitted range</p>
	<p class="block_">The International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) has recommended certain maximum permissible exposure limits to radiation that is believed to be safe without producing any appreciable injury to a person. Safe limit of overall exposure to radiation is given as 20 milli sievert per year. In terms of roentgen, the safe limit of receiving the radiation is about 100 milli Roentgen per week. If the exposure is 100 Roentgen,  it may cause fatal diseases like leukaemia (death of red blood corpuscle in the blood) or cancer. When the body is exposed to about 600 Roentgen, it leads to death.<span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_19">Do you Know</p>
	<p class="block_9">Dosimeter is a device used to detect the levels of exposure to an ionizing radiation. It is frequently used in the environments where exposure to radiation may occur such as nuclear power plants and medical imaging facilities. Pocket dosimeter is used to provide the wearer with an immediate reading of his/her exposure to X-rays and γ rays.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">Preventive measures</p>
	<p class="block_19"><img src="images/image1024.jpeg" alt="Lead coated aprons model. Explained in the text book " class="calibre140"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure. 6.6 Lead coated aprons model.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Radioactive materials should be kept in a thick-walled lead container.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Lead coated aprons and lead gloves should be used while working with hazardous radioactive materials.</li>
	<li class="block_7">You should avoid eating while handling radioactive materials.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The radioactive materials should be handled only by tongs or by a remote-control device.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Dosimeters should be worn by the users to check the level of radiation.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_186">6.7 NUCLEAR REACTOR</h2>
	<p class="block_">A Nuclear reactor is a device in which the nuclear fission reaction takes place in a self-sustained and controlled manner to produce electricity. The first nuclear reactor was built in 1942 at Chicago, USA.</p>
	<p class="block_12">6.7.1 Types of nuclear reactors</p>
	<p class="block_">Breeder reactor, fast breeder reactor, pressurized water reactor, pressurized heavy water reactor, boiling water reactor, water- cooled reactor, gas-cooled reactor, fusion reactor and thermal reactor are some types of nuclear reactors, which are used in different places world-wide.</p>
	<p class="block_12">6.7.2 Components of a nuclear reactors</p>
	<p class="block_">The essential components of a nuclear reactor are (1) fuel, (2) moderator, (3) control rod, (4) coolant and (5) protection wall.</p>
	<p class="block_74">First is . <b class="calibre6">Fuel:</b> A fissile material is used as the fuel. The commonly used fuel material is uranium.</p>
	<p class="block_">Second one is,  <b class="calibre6">Moderator:</b> A moderator is used to slow down the high energy neutrons to provide slow neutrons. Graphite and heavy water are the commonly used moderators.</p>
	<p class="block_74">Third one is ,  <b class="calibre6">Control rod: </b>Control rods are used to control the number of neutrons in order to have sustained chain reaction. Mostly boron or cadmium rods are used as control rods. They absorb the neutrons.</p>
	<p class="block_">Fourth one is ,  <b class="calibre6">Coolant: </b><span class="calibre28">A coolant is used to remove the heat produced in the reactor core, to produce steam. This steam is used to run   a turbine in order to produce electricity. Water, air and helium are some of the coolants.</span></p>
	<p class="block_74">Last one is ,  <b class="calibre6">Protection wall:</b><span class="calibre28">  A thick concrete lead wall is built around the nuclear reactor in order to prevent the harmful radiations from escaping into the environment.</span></p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-80.png" alt="schematic diagram of a nuclear reactor " class="calibre141"/></p>
	<p class="block_12"> 6.7.3. Uses of a nuclear reactor</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Nuclear reactors are widely used in power generation.</li>
	<li class="block_7">They are also used to produce radio isotopes, which are used in a variety of applications.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Some reactors help us to do research in the field of nuclear physics.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Breeder reactors are used to convert non- fissionable materials into fissionable materials.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">6.7.4. Nuclear power plants in India</p>
	<p class="block_">IndianAtomicEnergyCommission (AEC) was established in August 1948 by the Department of Indian Scientific Research committee at Bombay (now Mumbai) in Maharashtra. It is the nodal agency for all the research done in the field of atomic energy. Dr.Homi Jahangir Bhaba was the first chairman of Indian Atomic Energy Commission. Now, it is known as Bhaba Atomic Research Centre (BARC).</p>
	<p class="block_">Nuclear power is the fifth largest source of power in India. Tarapur Atomic Power Station is India’s first nuclear power station. Now, there are a total of seven power stations, one each in Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and two in Tamil Nadu. In Tamilnadan, we have nuclear power stations in Kalpakkam and Kudankulam. Apsara was the first nuclear reactor built in India and Asia. Now, there are 22 nuclear reactors which are operating in India. Some other operating reactors are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_321">Cirus</li>
	<li class="block_322">Dhuruva</li>
	<li class="block_323">Purnima</li>
</ol>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_187">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">This phenomenon of spontaneous emission of radiation from certain elements on its own is called 'natural radioactivity'.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Curie is defined as the quantity of a radioactive substance, which undergoes </li>
</ol>
	<div class="calibre146">
	<div class="block_14"><span class="bullet_1">2.7 </span><span class="calibre52">× 10 power10 disintegrations in one second. This is actually close to the activity of 1 gram  of <span class="calibre28">    </span>radium-226.</span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">   </span><img src="images/image-85.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of I302N" class="calibre42"/></p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="3" class="block_327">Rutherford (Rd) is defined as the quantity of a radioactive substance which produces</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_27">10 power 6 disintegrations in one second. 1 Rutherford<span class="calibre28">  </span>is 10 power 6 disintegrations per second.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="4" class="block_327">The System international  unit of radioactivity is Becquerel. It is defined as the quantity of one disintegration per second.</li>
	<li class="block_6">Helium nucleus <span class="calibre28"> ( helium 2  4 </span>) consisting of two protons and two neutrons is known as alpha particle.</li>
	<li class="block_6">Beta particles are electrons ( electrons), which are the basic elementary particles present in all atoms.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Gamma rays are electromagnetic waves consisting of photons.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A nuclear reaction in which an unstable parent nucleus emits an alpha particle and forms a stable daughter nucleus is called as 'alpha decay'.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A nuclear reaction in which an unstable parent nucleus emits a beta particle and forms a stable daughter nucleus is called as 'beta decay'.</li>
	<li class="block_7"><span class="calibre28">The process of breaking (splitting) up of   a heavier nucleus into two smaller nuclei with the release of a large amount of energy is called 'nuclear fission'.</span></li>
	<li class="block_7">The energy released in a nuclear fission process is about 200 MeV.</li>
	<li class="block_7">There are some radioactive elements which can be converted into a fissionable material. They are called as 'fertile materials'. Example: Uranium-238, Thorium-232, Plutonium-240.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Controlled chain reaction is used in a nuclear reactor to produce energy in a sustained and controlled manner.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The process in which two lighter nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus is termed as 'nuclear fusion'.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Nuclear fusion or thermonuclear reaction is the source of light and heat energy in the Sun and other stars.</li>
	<li class="block_8">The safe limit of receiving the radiation is about 100 milli Roentgen per week.</li>
</ol>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_192">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">You have learnt, in your lower classes that matter is around us everywhere. Matter is made of atoms. Curiously the idea of atom was first proposed by the Greek philosophers in the fifth century BC (BCE). But their theory was more philosophical than scientific.</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">The first scientific theory of the atom was proposed by John Dalton. Few of the postulates of Dalton’s theory about an atom were found incorrect by the later on studies made by J.J. Thomson, Rutherford, Neils   Bohr and Schrodinger. In the light of the result of the research most of the limitations of the Dalton’s theory were</span> removed and a new theory known as the modern atomic theory was put forward. ‘The main postulates of modern atomic theory’ are as follows:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_321">An atom is no longer indivisible (after the discovery of the electron, proton, and neutron).</li>
	<li class="block_322">Atoms of the same element may have different atomic mass. (Discovery of isotopes 17Cl35, 17Cl37).</li>
	<li class="block_322">Atoms of different elements may have same atomic masses (discovery of Isobars 18Ar40, 20Ca40).</li>
	<li class="block_322">Atoms of one element can be transmuted into atoms of other elements. In other words, atom is no longer indestructible (discovery of artificial transmutation).</li>
	<li class="block_322">Atoms may not always combine in a simple whole number ratio (Example Glucose C6H12O6 C is to H is to O = 6 is to 12 is to 6 or 1 is to 2 is to 1 and Sucrose C12H22O11 C is to H is to O = 12 is to 22 is to 11).</li>
	<li class="block_322">Atom is the smallest particle that takes part in a chemical reaction.</li>
	<li class="block_323">The mass of an atom can be converted into energy (E = mc power 2).</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_9">The modern atomic theory is the basis for all the studies of chemical and physical processes that involve atoms. You have studied the most fundamental ideas about an atom in your lower classes. Let us discuss some more concepts about atoms in this lesson.<br class="calibre26"/> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_193">7.1 ATOM AND ATOMIC MASS</h2>
	<p class="block_">As you know, anything that has mass and occupies space is called matter. Atoms are the building blocks of matter. Since matter has mass, it must be due to its atoms. According to the modern atomic theory, an atom contains subatomic particles such as protons, neutrons and electrons. Protons and neutrons have considerable mass, but electrons don't have such a considerable mass. Thus, the mass of an atom is mainly contributed by its protons and neutrons and hence the sum of the number of protons and neutrons of an atom is called its mass number.</p>
	<p class="block_">Individual atoms are very small, and it is difficult to measure their masses. You can measure the mass of macroscopic materials in gram or kilogram. The mass of an atom is measured in atomic mass unit (amu).</p>
	<p class="block_">Atomic mass unit is one-twelfth of the mass of a carbon-12 atom; an isotope of carbon, which contains 6 protons and 6 neutrons.</p>
	<p class="block_">(Note: The symbol ‘amu’ is no longer used in the modern system and instead, it uses the symbol ‘u’ to denote unified atomic mass. The mass of a proton or neutron is approximately 1 amu).</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_194">7.1.1 Relative Atomic Mass (RAM)</h3>
	<p class="block_">As an atom is very small, its absolute mass cannot be determined directly. The early pioneers of chemistry used to measure the atomic mass of an atom relative to an atom of another element. They measured the masses of equal number of atoms of two or more elements at a time, to determine their relative masses. They established one element as a standard, gave it an arbitrary value of atomic mass and using this value they measured the relative mass of other elements. The mass obtained by this way is called relative atomic mass. In the beginning, the mass of hydrogen atom was chosen as a standard and masses of other atoms were compared with it, because of the existence of isotopic character of hydrogen (1H1, 1H2, 1H3). Later hydrogen atom was replaced by oxygen atom as the standard. Now, the stable isotope of carbon (C-12) with atomic mass 12 is used as the standard for measuring the relative atomic mass of an element.</p>
	<p class="block_">Relative atomic mass of an element is the ratio between the average mass of its isotopes to </p>
	<p class="block_">1 by 12 th part of the mass of a carbon-12 atom. It is denoted as Ar. It is otherwise called “Standard Atomic Weight”.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Relative Atomic Mass</p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-89.png" alt="Relative Atomic Mass of an element is Average mass of the isotopes of the element divided by 1 by 12 th of the mass of one carbon 12 atom" class="calibre151"/></p>
	<p class="block_"> Modern methods of determination of atomic mass by Mass Spectrometry uses C-12 as standard. For most of the elements, the relative atomic mass is very closer to a whole number, and it is rounded off to a whole number, to make calculations easier. Table 7.1 lists some of the elements of periodic table and their Relative Atomic mass values.</p>
	<p class="block_138">Table 7.1 Relative atomic mass of elements (C-12 Scale)</p>

	<p class="block_19">Do you Know</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">Relative Atomic Mass is only a ratio, so it has no unit. If the atomic mass of an element is expressed in grams, it is called as Gram Atomic Mass</p>
	<p class="block_9">Gram Atomic Mass of hydrogen<span class="tab1">      </span>= 1 gram</p>
	<p class="block_9">Gram Atomic Mass of carbon<span class="tab1">      </span>= 12 gram</p>
	<p class="block_9">Gram Atomic Mass of nitrogen<span class="tab1">      </span>= 14 gram </p>
	<p class="block_9">Gram Atomic Mass of oxygen<span class="tab1">      </span>= 16 gram</p>
	<div class="calibre152">
	<div class="block_20" id="toc_id_195"><span class="bullet_">7.0.2 </span><span class="calibre18"><b class="calibre36">Average Atomic Mass (AAM)</b></span></div>
</div>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_196"><img src="images/image-90.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of 8ELKB" class="calibre153"/></h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_197">D78KWZ</h3>
	<h3 class="block_110" id="toc_id_198"> </h3>
	<p class="block_9">How can one measure the atomic mass of an element? It is somewhat more complicated because most of the naturally occurring elements exist as a mixture of isotopes, each of which has its own mass. Thus, it is essential to consider this isotopic mixture while calculating the atomic mass of an element.</p>
	<p class="block_">The average atomic mass of an element is the weighted average of the masses of its naturally occurring isotopes.</p>
	<p class="block_">But, the abundance of isotopes of each element may differ. So, the abundancy of all these isotopes is taken into consideration while calculating the atomic mass. Then, what do we mean by a weighted average? </p>
	<p class="block_">Let us consider an element which exists as a mixture of 50% of an isotope having a mass of 9 amu, and 50% of another isotope having a mass of 10 amu. Then, its average atomic mass is calculated by the following equation:</p>
	<p class="block_">Average atomic mass</p>
	<p class="block_">= (Mass of 1st isotope × % abundance of 1st isotope) + (Mass of 2nd isotope ×% abundance of 2nd isotope) Thus, for the given element the average</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-91.png" alt="Atomic mass is equal to  9 multiply 50 divided by 100 plus10 multiply 50 divided by 100 is 4.5 plus 5 is 9.5 atomic mass unit" class="calibre154"/></p>
	<p class="block_261"> </p>
	<p class="block_61"> </p>
	<p class="block_">(Note: In the calculations involving percentages, you need to convert percentage abundance into fractional abundance. For example, 50 percent is converted into 50 by 100 or 0.50 as shown in a foresaid calculation.)</p>
	<p class="block_">The atomic masses of elements, given in the periodic table, are average atomic masses. Sometimes, the term atomic weight is used to mean average atomic mass. It is observed, from the periodic table that atomic masses of most of the elements are not whole numbers. For instance, the atomic mass of carbon given in the periodic table is 12.01 amu, not 12.00 amu. The reason is that while calculating the atomic mass of carbon, both of its natural isotopes such as carbon-12. and carbon-13 are considered. The natural abundance of C-12 and C-13 are 98.90 % and 1.10 % respectively. The average of the atomic mass of carbon is calculated as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-92.png" alt="Average atomic mass of carbon is 12 multiply 98.9 divided by 100 plus 13 multiply 1.1 divided by 100 is  12 multiply 0.989 plus 13 multiply 0.011 is 11.868 plus 0.143 is 12.011 atomic mass unit" class="calibre155"/></p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_261"> </p>
	<p class="block_">So, it is important to understand that if it is mentioned that the atomic mass of carbon is 12 amu, it refers to the average atomic mass of the carbon isotopes, not the mass of the individual atoms of carbon.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 7.2 Atomic mass of some elements</p>

	<p class="block_12">Calculation of average atomic mass – Solved Examples</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Example 1:</b> Oxygen is the most abundant element in both the Earth’s crust and the human body. It exists as a mixture of three stable isotopes in nature as shown in Table 7.3:</p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 7.3 Isotopes of oxygen</p>
	<table class="table_16">

			<td class="td_228"><p class="block_368">% abundance</p></td>
		</tr>

			<td class="td_229"><p class="block_369"><span class="text_24">8</span><span class="text_25">O</span>16</p></td>

	<p class="block_375">The atomic mass of</p>
	<p class="block_376">Oxygen = (15.9949×0.99757) + (16.9991×</p>
	<p class="block_377">0.00038) + (17.9992×0.00205)</p>
	<p class="block_378">=15.999amu.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Example 2:</b> Boron naturally occurs as a mixture of boron-10 (5 protons + 5 neutrons) and boron-11 (5 protons + 6 neutrons) isotopes. The percentage abundance of B-10 is 20 and that of B-11 is 80. Then, the atomic mass of boron is calculated as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_61">Atomic mass <span class="calibre28">of boron is equal to  10*20 divided by 100 +11*80 divided by 100</span> <span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_61">= (10 × 0.20) + (11 × 0.80)</p>
	<p class="block_61">= 2 + 8.8 </p>
	<p class="block_61">= 10.8 amu</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_199">7.2 MOLECULE AND MOLECULAR MASS</h2>
	<p class="block_9">Except noble gases, atoms of most of the elements are found in the combined form with itself or atoms of other elements. It is called as a molecule. A molecule is a combination of two or more atoms held together by strong chemical forces of attraction,that is chemical bonds.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">Activity 7.1</p>
	<p class="block_9">Complete the following table by filling the appropriate values /terms </p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-93.png" alt="A comic representing MOLECULE AND MOLECULAR MASS " class="calibre156"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_200">7.2.1 Classification of molecules</h3>
	<p class="block_9">A molecule may contain atoms of the same element or may contain atoms of two or more elements joined in a fixed ratio, in accordance with the law of definite proportions. Thus, a molecule may be an element or a compound. If the molecule is made of similar kind of atoms, then it is called homoatomic molecule.</p>
	<p class="block_9">The molecule that consists of atoms of different elements is called heteroatomic molecule. A compound is a heteroatomic molecule. The number of atoms present in the molecule is called its ‘atomicity’.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Table 7.4 Classification of molecules</p>

	<p class="block_">Consider hydrogen chloride. It consists of two atoms, but of different elements,that is hydrogen and chlorine. So, its atomicity is two. It is a hetero diatomic molecule. Similarly, the water molecule contains two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. So, its atomicity is three. It is a hetero triatomic molecule.</p>

	<h3 class="block_110" id="toc_id_210"> </h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_211">7.2.2 Relative Molecular Mass (RMM)</h3>
	<p class="block_">As the molecules are made of atoms, they also have their own mass. The mass of the molecule of an element or compound is measured in the C-12 scale and hence called relative molecular mass. The Relative Molecular Mass of a molecule is the ratio between the mass of one molecule of the substance to 1 by 12 th mass of an atom of Carbon 12</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do you Know</p>
	<p class="block_419">Relative Molecular Mass is only a ratio. So, it has no unit. If the molecular mass of a compound is expressed in grams, it is called Gram Molecular Mass.</p>
	<p class="block_420">Gram Molecular Mass of water =18gram</p>
	<p class="block_420">Gram Molecular Mass of carbon dioxide = 44gram</p>
	<p class="block_421"><span class="text_27">Gram Molecular </span>Mass of ammonia=17gram</p>
	<p class="block_422">Gram Molecular Mass of HCl<span class="tab1">      </span>=36.5gram</p>
	<p class="block_422">The relative molecular mass is obtained by adding together the relative atomic masses of all the atoms present in a molecule.</p>
	<p class="block_422">Calculation of relative molecular mass – Solved examples:</p>
	<p class="block_422"><b class="calibre36">Example 1:</b> Relative molecular mass of sulphuric acid (H2SO4) is calculated as follows: Sulphuric acid contains 2 atoms of hydrogen, 1 atom of sulphur and 4 atoms of oxygen.</p>
	<p class="block_422">Therefore, Relative molecular mass of sulphuric acid = (2 × mass of hydrogen) + (1 × mass of sulphur) + (4 × mass of oxygen)</p>
	<p class="block_422">= (2 × 1) + (1 × 32) + (4 × 16)</p>
	<p class="block_422">= 98</p>
	<p class="block_422">That is one molecule of H2SO4 is 98 times as heavy as 1 by 12 the of the mass of a carbon 12.</p>
	<p class="block_423"> </p>
	<p class="block_422"><b class="calibre36">Example 2:</b> Relative molecular mass of water (H2O) is calculated as follows: A water molecule is made of 2 atoms of hydrogen and one atom of oxygen.</p>
	<p class="block_422">So, the relative molecular mass of water</p>
	<p class="block_422">= (2 × mass of hydrogen) + (1 × mass of oxygen)</p>
	<p class="block_422">= (2 × 1) + (1 × 16)</p>
	<p class="block_422">= 18</p>
	<p class="block_422">That is one molecule of H2O is 18 times as heavy as <span class="calibre15">1 by 12 th  </span> of the mass of a carbon 12.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_212">7.3 DIFFERENCE BETWEEN ATOMS AND MOLECULES</h2>
	<p class="block_422">Even though atoms are the basic components of molecules, they differ in many aspects when compared to the molecules. Table 7.5 consolidates the major difference between atoms and molecules.</p>
	<p class="block_424">Table 7.5 Difference between atoms and molecules</p>
	<table class="table_19">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_286"><p class="block_425">Atom</p></td>
			<td class="td_287"><p class="block_426">Molecule</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_288"><p class="block_427">An atom is the smallest particle of an element</p></td>
			<td class="td_288"><p class="block_428">A molecule is the smallest particle of an element or</p><p class="block_429">compound.</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_289"><p class="block_430"><b class="calibre36">Atom does not exist </b><span class="text_18">in free </span><b class="calibre36">state except in a noble gas</b></p></td>
			<td class="td_289"><p class="block_431"><span class="text_28">Molecule exists </span><b class="calibre6">in free state</b></p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_290"><p class="block_432"><b class="calibre36">Except some of noble </b><span class="text_26">gas, </span><span class="text_18">other atoms are </span><span class="text_26">highly reactive</span></p></td>
			<td class="td_290"><p class="block_433">Molecules are less reactive</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_289"><p class="block_434"><span class="text_28">Atom does not have </span><b class="calibre6">a chemical bond</b></p></td>
			<td class="td_289"><p class="block_435">Atoms in a molecule are held by chemical bonds</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>

	<h2 class="block_436" id="toc_id_218"> </h2>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_219">7.4 MOLE CONCEPT</h2>
	<p class="block_422">So far, we discussed about matters in terms of individual atoms and molecules. Atomic mass units provide a relative scale for the masses of the elements. Since the atoms have such small masses, no usable scale can be devised to weigh them in the calibrated units of atomic mass units. In any real situation, we deal with macroscopic samples containing enormous number of atoms. Therefore, it is convenient to have a special unit to describe a very large number of atoms. The idea of a ‘unit’ to denote a particular number of objects is not new. For example, the pair (2 items) and the dozen (12 items), are all familiar units. Chemists measure atoms and molecules in moles. So, you can now understand that ‘mole’ denotes a number of particles.</p>
	<p class="block_419">In the SI system, the mole (mol) is the amount of a substance that contains as many elementary entities (atoms, molecules, or other particles) as there are atoms in exactly 12 gram (or 0.012 kg) of the carbon 12 isotope. The actual number of atoms in 12 gram of carbon 12 is determined experimentally. This is called</p>
	<p class="block_419">Avogadro’s Number (NA), named after an Italian scientist Amedeo Avogadro who proposed its significance. Its value is 6.023 × 10 power 23. So, one mole of a substance contains 6.023 × 10 power 23 entities. Thus, 5 moles of oxygen molecules contain 5 × 6.023 ×10 power 23 molecules.</p>
	<p class="block_419">Mole Concept: The study of the collection of particles by using mole as the counting unit, in order to express the mass and volume of such unit particles in a bulk of matter is known as mole concept.</p>
	<p class="block_419">The number of moles of a substance can be calculated by various means depending on the data available, as follows:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_437">Number of moles of molecules.</li>
	<li class="block_438">Number of moles of atoms.</li>
	<li class="block_438">Number of moles of a gas (Standard molar volume at STP = 22.4 litre).</li>
	<li class="block_439">Number of moles of ions.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Note:</p>
	<p class="block_">STP-Standard<span class="tab">      </span>Temperature<span class="tab">      </span>and Pressure (273.15 Kelvin , 1.00  standard atmosphere pressure)</p>
	<p class="block_12">Mole of atoms:</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">One   mole    of   an    element   contains6.023 × 10</span> power 23 atoms and it is equal to its gram atomic mass.</p>
	<p class="block_">That is , one mole of oxygen contains 6.023 × 10 power 23 atoms of oxygen, and its gram atomic mass is 16 gram.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Mole of molecules:</p>
	<p class="block_">One mole of matter contains 6.023 × 10 power 23 molecules, and it is equal to its gram molecular mass.</p>
	<p class="block_">That is , one<span class="tab">      </span>mole of oxygen<span class="tab">      </span>contains 6.023 × 10 power 23 molecules of oxygen and its gram molecular mass is 32 gram.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Molar volume:</p>
	<p class="block_">One mole of any gas occupies 22.4 litre or 22400 ml at S.T.P. This volume is called as molar volume.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Calculation of number of moles by Different modes</p>
	<p class="block_">Number of moles</p>
	<p class="block_440">= Mass by Atomic Mass</p>
	<p class="block_440">= Mass by Molecular mass</p>
	<p class="block_440">= Number of Atoms by 6.023 × 10 power 23</p>
	<p class="block_440">= Number of Molecules by 6.023 × 10 power 23</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-95.png" alt="Mole concept Explained in the text book " class="calibre160"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 7.3 Mole concept</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_220">7.5 PERCENT COMPOSITION</h2>
	<p class="block_">So, for, we were dealing with the number of entities present in a given substance. But many times, the information regarding the percentage of a particular element present in a compound is required.</p>
	<p class="block_">The percentage composition of a compound represents the mass of each element present in 100 gram of the compound.</p>
	<p class="block_">Let us understand the percentage composition of oxygen and hydrogen by taking the example of H2O. It can be calculated using the formula</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-96.png" alt="Mass percentage of an element is mass of that element in the compound divided by molecular mass of the compound multiply by 100. Now molecular mass of water is 2 plus 16 = 18 gram. Mass percentage of Hydrogen is 2 divided by 18 multiply by 100 is 11.11 percentage. Mass of Oxygen is 16 divided by 18 multiply by 100 is 88.89 percentage." class="calibre161"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">This percentage composition is useful to determine the empirical formula and molecular formula.</p>
	<p class="block_441"><b class="calibre6">Example1: </b>Find the mass percentage composition of methane (C H 4).</p>
	<p class="block_441"><img src="images/image-97.png" alt="Molecular mass of methane is 12 plus 4 is 16 gram.  Mass percentage of carbon is 12 divided by 16 multply by  100  is 75 percentage. Mass percentage of hydrogen is 4 divided by 16 multiply by  100 is 25 percentage. " class="calibre162"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_221">7.6 AVOGADRO HYPOTHESIS</h2>
	<p class="block_">In 1811 Avogadro framed a hypothesis based on the relationship between the number of molecules present in equal volumes of gases in different conditions.</p>
	<p class="block_">The Avogadro’s law states that “equal volumes of all gases under similar conditions of temperature and pressure contain equal number of molecules”</p>
	<p class="block_">It follows that the volume of any given gas must be proportional to the number of molecules in it. If ‘V’ is the volume and ‘n’ is the number of molecules of a gas, then Avogadro law is represented, mathematically, as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_442">V<span class="calibre15">  is directly proportional to  </span> n</p>
	<p class="block_443"><span class="text_29">V equal to constant </span>multiply by  n</p>
	<p class="block_">Thus, one litre (1 dm power 3) of hydrogen contains the same number of molecules as in one litre of oxygen,  that is , the volume of the gas is directly proportional to the number of molecules of the gas.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image89.png" alt="Avogadro Hypothesis image" class="calibre163"/><img src="images/image90.png" alt="Avogadro Hypothesis image " class="calibre164"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 7.4 Avogadro Hypothesis</p>
	<p class="block_19">Explanation</p>
	<p class="block_9">Let us consider the reaction between hydrogen and chlorine to form hydrogen chloride gas</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-98.png" alt="hydrogen gas plus chlorine gas  gives 2 volumes of hydrogen chloride gas  1 volume plus 1 volume gives 2 volumes" class="calibre165"/><img src="images/image1.png" alt="Image" class="calibre102"/></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">According to Avogadro’s law 1 volume of any gas is occupied by “n” number of molecules. </p>
	<p class="block_9">n molecules + n molecules → 2n molecules</p>
	<p class="block_444">If n=1then</p>
	<p class="block_445">1 molecule<span class="calibre15">  </span>+1molecule<span class="calibre15">  </span>→2 molecules.</p>
	<p class="block_445">½ molecule + ½molecule → 1 molecule</p>
	<p class="block_9">1 molecule of hydrogen chloride gas is made up of ½ molecule of hydrogen and ½ molecule of chlorine. Hence, the molecules can be subdivided. This law is in agreement with Dalton’s atomic theory.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Activity 7.3</p>
	<p class="block_9">Under same conditions of temperature and pressure if you collect 3 litres of O2, 5 litres of Cl2 and 6 litres of H2,</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_231">Which has the highest number of molecules?</li>
	<li class="block_231">Which has the lowest number of molecules</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_19">7.7 APPLICATIONS OF AVOGADRO’S LAW</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_231">It explains Gay-Lussac’s law.</li>
	<li class="block_231">It helps in the determination of atomicity of gases.</li>
	<li class="block_231">Molecular formula of gases can be derived using Avogadro’s law</li>
	<li class="block_231">It determines the relation between molecular mass and vapour density.</li>
	<li class="block_231">It helps to determine gram molar volume of all gases (i.e., 22.4 litre at S.T.P)</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_222">7.8 RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN VAPOUR DENSITY AND RELATIVE MOLECULAR MASS</h2>
	<p class="block_19">1. Relative molecular mass: (Hydrogen scale)</p>
	<p class="block_9">The Relative Molecular Mass of a gas or vapour is the ratio between the mass of one molecule of the gas or vapour to mass of one atom of Hydrogen.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66"><b class="calibre36">Vapour Density:</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_9">Vapour density is the ratio of the mass of a certain volume of a gas or vapour, to the mass of an equal volume of hydrogen, measured under the same conditions of temperature and pressure.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Vapour Density (V.D.)</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-99.png" alt="Vapour density is Mass of given volume of gas or vapour at standard temperature and pressure divided by Mass of the same volume of hydrogen" class="calibre166"/></p>

	<div class="block_71" id="toc_id_223"><span class="bullet_1">7.9 </span><span class="calibre52">SOLVED PROBLEMS</span></div>
	<div class="block_460"><span class="bullet_1">7.10 </span><span class="calibre52"> </span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_9">I. Calculation of molecular mass</p>
	<p class="block_9">Calculate the gram molecular mass of the following.</p>
	<p class="block_9">1) H2 O<span class="tab1">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_9">2) C O2<span class="tab1">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_9">3) C a3 (P O4) twice</p>
	<p class="block_19">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_461">1) H2 O</p>
	<p class="block_60">Atomic masses of H = 1, O = 16</p>
	<p class="block_462">Gram molecular mass of H2 O</p>
	<p class="block_463">= (1×2) + (16×1)</p>
	<p class="block_463">=<span class="calibre15">  </span>2+16</p>
	<p class="block_464">Gram molecular mass of H2 O=18 gram</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_"> 2)C O2</p>
	<p class="block_465">Atomic masses of C=12, O=16</p>
	<p class="block_465">Gram molecular mass of C O2</p>
	<p class="block_466">= (12×1) + (16×2)</p>
	<p class="block_463">= 12+32</p>
	<p class="block_464">Gram molecular mass of C O2 = 44 gram</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">   3</span>)Ca3 (P O4) twice </p>
	<p class="block_467">Atomic masses of C a=40, P=30, O=16. </p>
	<p class="block_467"><span class="text_27">Gram </span>molecular<span class="text_27"> mass of Ca3(P O4) twice</span></p>
	<p class="block_468">= (40×3) + [30+(16×4)] × 2</p>
	<p class="block_469">=120+(94×2)</p>
	<p class="block_469">=120+188</p>
	<p class="block_464">Gram molecular mass of C a 3(P O4) twice = 308 gram</p>

	<p class="block_12">6. Calculation based on % composition</p>
	<p class="block_440">Calculate % of Sulpher  in H2S O4</p>
	<p class="block_440">Molecular mass of H2S O4</p>
	<p class="block_440">= (1 × 2) + (32 × 1) + (16 × 4)</p>
	<p class="block_440">= 2 + 32 + 64</p>
	<p class="block_440">= 98 gram</p>
	<p class="block_61">% of Sulphur  in H2S O4 = mass of sulphur divided by molecular mass of H2 S O4   100</p>
	<p class="block_566"><span class="calibre28">              </span>= 38 divided by 98 100 = 32.65%</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_224">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">Two or more forms of an element having the same atomic number, but different mass number are called Isotopes (17Cl35, 17Cl37).</li>
	<li class="block_66">Atoms of different elements having the same mass number, but different atomic numbers are called Isobars (18Ar40, 20Ca40).</li>
	<li class="block_66">Atoms of different elements having the same number of neutrons, but different atomic number and different mass number are called Isotones ( 6C13, 7N14 ).</li>
	<li class="block_66">Relative atomic mass of an element is the ratio between the mass of one atom of the element to 1 by 12th of the mass of the atom of carbon -12.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Average atomic mass of an element is calculated by adding the masses of its isotopes, each multiplied by their natural abundance on the Earth.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Relative molecular mass of a molecule is the ratio between the mass of one molecule of the substance to 1 by 12th of the mass of the atom of carbon – 12.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The Avogadro’s law states that “equal volumes of all gases under similar conditions of temperature and pressure contain equal number of molecules”.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The vapour density is defined as “the ratio between the masses of equal volumes of a gas (or a vapour) and hydrogen under the same condition”.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Atomicity of a monoatomic element = Molecular mass by Atomic Mass.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Molecular mass = 2 × Vapour density.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>

	<p class="block_12">IV. True or False: (If false give the correct statement)</p>
	<p class="block_">1. Two elements sometimes can form more than one compound.</p>

	<p class="block_12">five. Assertion and Reason:</p>
	<p class="block_12">Answer the following questions using the data given below:</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li class="block_6">A and R are correct, R explains A.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A is correct, R is wrong.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A is wrong, R is correct.</li>
	<li class="block_8">A and R are correct, R doesn’t explain A.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">1. <b class="calibre6">Assertion:</b> Atomic mass of aluminium is 27</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Reason: </b>An atom of aluminium is 27 times heavier than 1by12th of the mass of the C – 12 atoms.</p>
	<p class="block_">2. <b class="calibre6">Assertion:</b> The Relative Molecular Mass of Chlorine is 35.5 atomic mass unit</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Reason:</b> The natural abundance of Chlorine isotopes is not equal.</p>

	<p class="block_12">VII. Long answer questions</p>
	<p class="block_">1. Calculate the number of water molecule present in one drop of water which weighs</p>
	<p class="block_">0.18 g.</p>
	<p class="block_">2. N2 + 3 H2  gives 2 N H3</p>
	<p class="block_">(The atomic mass of nitrogen is 14, and that of hydrogen is 1)</p>
	<p class="block_">1 mole of nitrogen (dash gram) +3 moles of hydrogen (dash gram) gives 2 moles of ammonia (dash gram).</p>
	<p class="block_"> 3. Calculate the number of moles in</p>
	<p class="block_">i)27gram of A l<span class="tab">      </span>ii) 1.51 × 10 power 23 molecules of N H4 C l</p>
	<p class="block_">4. Give the salient features of “Modern atomic theory”.</p>
	<p class="block_">5. Derive the relationship between Relative molecular mass and Vapour density.</p>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_226">UNIT-8</h1>
	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_227">PERIODIC CLASSIFICATION OF ELEMENTS</h1>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-119.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of WVCQA" class="calibre80"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_228">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">After a thorough perusal of this unit, the students will be able to:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">recognize the basis of the modern periodic law and its development.</li>
	<li class="block_66">list the features of groups and periods of the modern periodic table.</li>
	<li class="block_66">explain the trend in periodic properties along the periods and groups.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Distinguish between ores and minerals.</li>
	<li class="block_66">list out the types of separation of impurities from the ores.</li>
	<li class="block_66">recall the various places of occurrences of minerals in the state of Tamil Nadu.</li>
	<li class="block_66">put forth the properties of metals.</li>
	<li class="block_66">identify the stages involved in metallurgical processes.</li>
	<li class="block_66">think scientifically on alloys and their types.</li>
	<li class="block_66">develop an idea on amalgam.</li>
	<li class="block_66">understand the reason for corrosion and the methods of its prevention.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_229">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">The eighteenth and nineteenth centuries witnessed a rapid development in chemistry in all spheres of scientific activities. By 1860, scientists had already discovered 60 elements and determined their atomic masses. They noticed that some elements had similar properties and hence arranged them into groups. During this period, several new elements were discovered. These elements were found to have different properties. It was realized that instead of studying the properties of all these elements individually, it would be more convenient to divide them into groups and periods in such a way that each group contained a certain number of elements (like an array of fruits and vegetables showing orderliness) with similar properties and periods showing a regular gradation. So, scientists made several attempts to arrange elements in a logical way. You have studied about all these early attempts of arrangement of elements in standard IX. In continuation of the knowledge gained in the topic periodic classification of elements in standard IX with earlier concepts and their subsequent deliberations, you get set to go ahead with the higher order of thinking to enhance your knowledge on the properties of elements.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_230">8.1 MODERN PERIODIC LAW</h2>
	<p class="block_9">Mendeleev’s periodic table had some discrepancies, which were difficult to overcome. For example, the atomic mass of argon (39.95 amu) is greater than that of potassium (39.10 amu), but argon comes before potassium in the periodic table. If elements were arranged solely according to increasing atomic mass, argon would appear in the position occupied by potassium in our modern periodic table (see in Figure 8.1). No chemist would place argon, a gas with no tendency to react, in the same group as lithium and sodium, which are two highly reactive metals. This kind of discrepancies suggested that some fundamental property other than atomic mass must be the basis of periodicity. The fundamental property turned out to be the number of protons in an atom’s nucleus, something that could not have been known by Mendeleev and his contemporaries.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Henry Moseley, a British scientist in 1912, discovered a new property of elements called atomic number, which provided a better basis for the periodic arrangement of the elements. It is a well-known fact that atomic number of an element is equal to the number of protons or the number of electrons present in the neutral atom of an element. The periodic law was, therefore, modified to frame a modern periodic law, which states that</p>
	<p class="block_9">“The physical and chemical properties of the elements are the periodic functions of</p>
	<p class="block_9">their atomic numbers”.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_231">8.2 MODERN PERIODIC TABLE</h2>
	<p class="block_">With reference to the modern periodic law, the elements were arranged in the increasing order of their atomic numbers to form the modern periodic table. The modern periodic table is a tabular arrangement of elements in rows and columns, highlighting the regular repetition of properties of the elements. Figure 8.1 shows the modern periodic table of 118 elements discovered so far.</p>
	<p class="block_">As you have studied the features of the modern periodic table in standard IX, here let us confine to the study of the features of periods and groups.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Features of Periods</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">The horizontal rows are called periods. There are seven periods in the periodic table.</li>
	<li class="block_7">First period (Atomic number 1 and 2): This is the shortest period. It contains only two elements (Hydrogen and Helium).</li>
	<li class="block_7">Second period (Atomic number 3 to 10): This is a short period. It contains eight elements (Lithium to Neon).</li>
	<li class="block_7">Third period (Atomic number 11 to 18): This is also a short period. It contains eight elements (Sodium to Argon).</li>
	<li class="block_7">Fourth period (Atomic number 19 to 36): This is a long period. It contains eighteen elements (Potassium to Krypton). This includes 8 representative elements and 10 transition elements.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Fifth period (Atomic number 37 to 54): This is also a long period. It contains 18 elements (Rubidium to Xenon). This includes 8 representative elements and 10 transition elements.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Sixth period (Atomic number 55 to 86): This is the longest period. It contains 32 elements (Caesium to Radon). This includes 8 representative elements, 10 transition elements and 14 inner transition elements (Lanthanides).</li>
	<li class="block_8">Seventh period (Atomic number 87 to 118): Like the sixth period, this period also accommodates 32 elements. Recently 4 elements have been included by IUPAC.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image124.jpeg" alt="figure 8.1 modern PERIODIC TABLE is given." class="calibre190"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Features of Groups</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">The vertical columns in the periodic table starting from top to bottom are called groups. There are 18 groups in the periodic table.</li>
	<li class="block_66"><span class="calibre15">Based on the   common   characteristics of elements in each group, they can be grouped as various families.</span></li>
</ol>

	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">The Lanthanides and Actinides, which form part of Group 3 are called inner transition elements.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Except 'group 18', all the elements present in each group have the same number of electrons in their valence shell and thus have the same valency. For example, all the elements of group 1 have one electron in their valence shells (1s1). So, the valency of all the alkali metals is ‘1’.</li>
	<li class="block_66">As the elements present in a group have identical valence shell electronic configurations, they possess similar chemical properties.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The physical properties of the elements in a group such as melting point, boiling point and density vary gradually.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The atoms of the 'group 18' elements have stable electronic configuration in their valence shells and hence they are unreactive.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_232">8.3 PERIODIC TRENDS IN PROPERTIES</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-120.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of SCFYQ" class="calibre191"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">The electronic configurations of elements help us to explain the periodic recurrence of physical and chemical properties. Anything which repeats itself after a regular interval is called periodic and this behaviour is called periodicity. Some of the atomic properties of the elements are periodic.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Properties such as atomic radius, ionic radius, ionisation energy, electronegativity, electron affinity, show a regular periodicity and hence they are called periodic properties. The main significance of the modern periodic table is that it gives a clear understanding of the general properties and trends within a group or a period to predict with considerable accuracy, the properties of any element, even though that element may be unfamiliar to us. Let us discuss the periodic trend of some of the properties.</p>
	<p class="block_19">8.3.1 Atomic Radius</p>
	<p class="block_9">Atomic radius of an atom is defined as the distance between the centre of its nucleus and the outermost shell containing the valence electron. Direct measurement of the radius of an isolated atom is not possible. Except for noble gases, usually the atomic radius is referred to as covalent radius or metallic radius depending on the nature of the</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-121.png" alt="figure 8.2 (A)Metallic Radius figure 8.2 (b)Covalent Radius are shown.  " class="calibre192"/></p>
	<p class="block_589">Figure 8.2</p>
	<p class="block_589">(a)Metallic Radius</p>
	<p class="block_589">(b)Covalent Radius</p>
	<p class="block_9">bonding between the concerned atoms. Atomic radius in metal atoms is known as metallic radius. It is defined as half the distance between the nuclei of adjacent metal atoms (Figure 8.2a)). </p>
	<p class="block_9">In non-metallic elements, their atomic radius is known as Covalent radius. It is defined as half the distance between the nuclei of two covalently bonded atoms of the same element in a molecule (Figure 8.2 (b)). For example, let us consider H2 molecule. The distance between the two hydrogen nuclei of the molecule is 0.74 Angstrom. So its covalent radius is 0.74 by 2 = 0.37 Angstrom. </p>
	<p class="block_9">When you look at the variation of the atomic radii in the periodic table, there are two distinct trends. Along the period, from left to right, the atomic radius of the elements decreases whereas along the groups, from the top to bottom, the atomic radius increases.<img src="images/image-122.png" alt="figure 8.3 Atomic radius of hydrogen is shown." class="calibre193"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 8.3 Atomic radius</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image138.jpeg" alt="figure 8.4 variation of atomic radiation is shown  with the help of boron atom which has five electrons. " class="calibre194"/></p>
	<p class="block_">The increase, down a group, is due to the increase in the valence shell number down the group. As the shell number increases, the distance between the valence shell and the nucleus increases. In contrast, when you observe along the period, the shell number remains the same but the number of protons (i.e. atomic number) increases. More and more positive charges impose a strong attraction over the electrons and thus the electron cloud shrinks towards the nucleus, which results in the decrease in the atomic size. Figure 8.4 shows how the atomic radius decreases from lithium to boron.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image137.jpeg" alt="figure 8.4 variation of atomic radiation is shown  with the help of lithium atom which has three electrons. " class="calibre195"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 8.4 Variation of atomic radius</p>
	<p class="block_12"><span class="calibre28">8.3.2   Ionic Radii</span></p>
	<p class="block_">It is defined as the distance from the centre of the nucleus of the ion up to the point where it exerts its influence on the electron cloud of the ion.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-123.png" alt="figure 8.5 Relative ionic radii of cation and anion  table. radii of lithium atom is 156 picometer radii of lithium anion 90 picometer. radii of sodium atom is 186 picometer radii of sodium anion is 116 picometer. radii of fluorine atom is 69 picometer radii of fluorine cation is 119 picometer. radii of chlorine atom is 91 picometer radii of chlorine cation is 167 picometer.   " class="calibre196"/></p>
	<p class="block_138">Figure 8.5 Relative ionic radii of cation and anion</p>
	<p class="block_9">You know that ions are formed when an atom loss or gain electrons. When a neutral atom loses an electron, it becomes a positively charged ion called cation, whereas the gain of an electron by a neutral atom forms a negatively charged ion called anion. The size of the ions is important to determine their behaviours in solutions and the structure of ionic solids. The size of a cation is always smaller than its corresponding neutral atom. But the anion is larger than its neutral atom.</p>
	<p class="block_9">For instance, lithium and sodium lose the single electron from their outermost energy level to form cations. The ions so formed are smaller because the remaining electrons are at inner cells and attracted more strongly by the nucleus. Fluorine and chlorine become negative ions by gaining an electron. When electrons are added, the charge on the nucleus is not great enough to hold the increased number of electrons as closely as it holds the electrons in the neutral atom. So, as seen in atomic radius, ionic radii also decrease along the period from left to right and increase down the group.</p>
	<p class="block_12">8.3.3 Ionisation Energy</p>
	<p class="block_">Ionisation energy is the minimum energy required to remove an electron from an isolated gaseous atom in its ground state to form a cation. It is otherwise called ionisation enthalpy. It is measured in kJ per mol. Higher the ionisation energy; it is more difficult to remove the electron.</p>
	<p class="block_">As the atomic size decreases from left to right in a period, more energy is required to remove the electrons. So, the ionisation energy increases along the period. But, down the group, the atomic size increases and hence the valence electrons are loosely bound. They require relatively less energy for the removal. Thus, ionisation energy decreases down the group in the periodic table.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Note:</b> As the positive charge increases the size of the cation decreases as the negative charge increases the size of the anion increases</p>
	<p class="block_19">8.3.4 Electron Affinity</p>
	<p class="block_9">Electron affinity is the amount of energy released when an isolated gaseous atom gains an electron to form its anion. It is also measured in kJ per mol and represented by the following equation:</p>
	<p class="block_590">A<span class="text_11">(g) </span>+ electron gives A<span class="text_11">(g) negative ion </span>+ Energy</p>
	<p class="block_590">Cl<span class="text_11">(g)</span>+electron gives C l negative ion gaseous state +energy</p>
	<p class="block_9">Like ionisation energy, electron affinity also increases from left to right in a period and decreases from top to bottom in a group.</p>
	<p class="block_19">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_9">Noble gases show no tendency to accept electrons because the outer s and p orbitals of noble gases are completely filled. No more electrons can be added to them and hence their electron affinities are zero.</p>
	<p class="block_12">8.3.5 Electronegativity</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Electronegativity of an element is the measure of the tendency of its atom to attract the shared pair of electrons towards itself in a covalent bond. Let us consider HCl molecule. Both the hydrogen and chlorine atoms share one electron each to form the covalent bond between them. chlorine atom has a  higher electronegativity and hence it pulls the shared electrons towards itself more strongly than hydrogen. Thus, when the bond breaks, the bonding electrons are left with chlorine forming H</span> positive ion and C l negative ions. It is represented, diagrammatically, as shown below:</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-124.png" alt="Relative electronegativity of H and Cl  diagram. hydrogen has weak pull for electron. so hydrogen losses electron and become positive ion. chlorine has strong pull for electron so chlorine gain electron and become negative ion. thus electron transferred from hydrogen to chlorine.  " class="calibre197"/></p>
	<p class="block_138">Figure 8.6 Relative electronegativity of H and Cl</p>
	<p class="block_9">Electronegativity is based on various experimental data such as bond energy, ionization potential, electron affinity, etc. Pauling scale is the widely used scale to determine the electronegativity, which in turn predicts the nature of bonding (ionic or covalent) between the atoms in a molecule. Electronegativity of some of the elements are given below</p>
	<p class="block_9">F = 4.0, Cl = 3.0, Br = 2.8, I = 2.5, H = 2.1, Na = 1</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">If the difference in electronegativity between two elements   is   1.7,   the   bond has 50% ionic character and 50% covalent character.</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">If the difference is less than 1.7, the bond is considered to be covalent.</p>
	<p class="block_9">If the difference is greater than 1.7, the bond is considered to be more ionic.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Along the period, from left to right in the periodic table, the electronegativity increases because of the increase in the nuclear charge which in turn attracts the electrons more strongly. On moving down a group, the electronegativity of the elements decreases because of the increased number of valence shells.</p>
