	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_233">8.4 METALLURGY</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-125.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of 6 A S F X" class="calibre198"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">Human life is associated with various metals. We use metals in our day-to-day activities. It is the utmost need to have some metals like sodium, potassium, calcium, iron, etc. in the human body. Deficiency of these metals affects the metabolic activities thereby causing diseases. So, metals play a vital role in our life. In this section, let us discuss how metals are obtained from various sources by the process of metallurgy.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Metallurgy is a science of extracting metals from their ores and modifying the metals into alloys for various uses, based on their physical and chemical properties and their structural arrangement of atoms. A metallurgical process involve three main steps as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_23">(i) <span class="calibre15">Concentration or Separation of the ore:   It is the process of removal of impurities from the ore.</span></p>
	<p class="block_23">(ii) <span class="calibre15">Production of the metal:   It is the conversion of the ore into metal.  </span></p>
	<p class="block_23"><span class="calibre15">(iii) Refining of the metal:   It is the process of purification of the metal.</span></p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_234">8.4.1 Terminology in metallurgy</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Minerals:   A mineral may be a single compound or a complex mixture of various compounds of metals found in the Earth.</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Ore: th</b><span class="calibre28">e mineral from which a metal can be readily and economically extracted on a large scale is said to be an ore.  </span></p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-126.png" alt="All ores are minerals; But all minerals are not ores. Why?" class="calibre199"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">For example</b>: Clay (A l2 O3. 2 Si O2. 2 H2 O) and bauxite (A l2 O3.2 H2 O) are the two minerals of aluminium, but aluminium can be profitably extracted only from bauxite. Hence, bauxite is an ore of aluminium and clay is its mineral.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Mining</b>: The process of extracting the ores from the Earth's crust is called mining.</p>
	<p class="block_">Gangue or Matrix: The rocky impurity associated with an ore is called gangue or matrix.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Flux:</b> It is the substance added to the ore to reduce the fusion temperature and to remove the impurities. E.g., Calcium oxide (basic), Silica (acidic). If the gangue is acidic, then basic flux is added and vice versa.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Slag:</b> It is the fusible product formed when a flux reacts with a gangue during the extraction of metals.</p>
	<p class="block_606"><span class="tab1">      </span><span class="tab1">      </span>Flux + Gangue gives Slag</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6"> Smelting:</b> Smelting is the process of reducing the roasted metallic oxide from the metal in its molten condition. In this process, impurities are removed as slag by the addition of flux.</p>
	<p class="block_12">8.4.2 Types of separation or concentration of an ore</p>
	<p class="block_">There are four major types of separation of ores based on the nature of the ore. The different kinds of ores of metals are given in Table 8.1</p>
	<p class="block_12">Concentration of the crushed ore is done mainly by the following methods: -</p>
	<p class="block_12">(i)Hydraulic (Gravity Separation) method</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Principle:</b> The difference in the densities or specific gravities of the ore and the gangue is the main principle behind this method. Oxide ores are purified by this method. example Haematite F e2 O3 the ore of iron.</p>
	<p class="block_">Note: When the ore is heavier than the impurity, this method can be used.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Method:</b> The ore is poured over a sloping, vibrating corrugated table with grooves and a jet of water is allowed to flow over it. The denser ore particles settle down in the grooves and lighter gangue particles are washed down by water.</p>
	<p class="block_12">(ii) Magnetic separation method</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Principle:</b> The magnetic properties of the ores form the basis of separation. When either the ore or the gangue is magnetic, this method is employed. e.g., Tinstone S n O2, the ore of tin.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-127.png" alt="Magnetic separation explanation diagram is given" class="calibre200"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 8.8 Magnetic separation</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Method:</b> The crushed ore is placed over a conveyer belt which rotates around two metal wheels, one of which is magnetic. The magnetic particles are attracted to the magnetic wheel and fall separately apart from the non- magnetic particles.</p>
	<p class="block_12">(iii)<span class="tab">      </span>Froth floatation</p>
	<p class="block_">Principle: This process depends on the preferential wettability of the ore with oil (pine oil) and the gangue particles by water. Lighter ores, such as sulphide ores, are concentrated by this method. </p>
	<p class="block_">e.g., Zinc blende (Z n S).</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-128.png" alt="Froth floatation  diagram given" class="calibre201"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 8.9 Froth floatation</p>
	<p class="block_">Note: When the impurity is heavier than the ore this method can be used.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Method:</b> The crushed ore is taken in a large tank containing pine oil and water and agitated with a current of compressed air. The ore is wetted by the oil and gets separated from the gangue in the form of froth. Since the ore is lighter, it comes on the surface with the froth and the impurities are left behind. e.g., Zinc blende (ZnS).</p>
	<p class="block_12">(iv) Chemical method or Leaching</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 8.1 Types of ores</p>

	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_">Extraction of metal from metal oxide can be categorized into three types</p>
	<table class="table_36">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_365"><p class="block_623">More reactive metals</p></td>
			<td class="td_366"><p class="block_623">Medium reactive metals</p></td>
			<td class="td_367"><p class="block_624">Less reactive metals</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_368"><p class="block_623">Na, K, Ca, Mg, A l</p></td>
			<td class="td_369"><p class="block_623">Z n, F e,Pb, Cu</p></td>
			<td class="td_370"><p class="block_624">Ag, Hg</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_371"><p class="block_623">Electrolytic reduction of</p><p class="block_625">Metal oxide into metal</p></td>
			<td class="td_372"><p class="block_624">Chemical reduction of metal</p><p class="block_626">Oxide into metal using coke</p></td>
			<td class="td_373"><p class="block_624">Thermal decomposition of</p><p class="block_626">Metal oxide into metal</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_">This method is employed when the ore is in a very pure form.</p>
	<p class="block_">The ore is treated with a suitable reagent such that the ore is soluble in it but the impurities are not. The impurities are removed by filtration. The solution of the ore, ie., the filtrate is treated with a suitable reagent which precipitates the ore. E.g. Bauxite Al2O3.2H2O, the ore of aluminium.</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_236">8.6 PROPERTIES OF METALS</h2>
	<p class="block_12">8.6.1 Physical properties</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">1.Physical state: </b>All metals are solids at room temperature except mercury and gallium.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">2.Lustre: </b>Metals possess a high lustre (called metallic lustre).</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">3.Hardness: </b>Most of the metals are hard and strong (exceptions: sodium and potassium can be cut with a knife)</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">4.Melting point and Boiling point: </b>Usually, metals possess high melting and boiling points and vaporize only at high temperatures (exceptions: gallium, mercury, sodium and potassium).</p>
	<p class="block_27">5. Density: Metals have a high density (exceptions: sodium and potassium are less dense than water).</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="6" class="block_6">Ductility: Metals are usually ductile. In other words, they can be drawn into thin wires without breaking.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Malleability: Metals are usually malleable, i.e., they can be beaten into thin sheets without cracking (except zinc and mercury).</li>
	<li class="block_7">Conduction of heat and electricity: Metals are good conductors of heat and electricity; silver and copper excel in this property (exception: tungsten)</li>
	<li class="block_8">Solubility: Usually, metals do not dissolve in liquid solvents.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">8.6.2 Chemical Properties</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Valence electrons: Atoms of metals usually have 1,2 or 3 electrons in their outermost shell.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Formation of ions: Metals form Positive ions by the loss of electrons and hence they are electro positive.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Discharge of ions: Metals are discharged at the cathode during the electrolysis of their compounds.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Atomicity: Molecules of metals in their vapour state are usually monoatomic.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Nature of oxides: Oxides of metals are usually basic.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_237">8.7 METALLURGY OF ALUMINIUM</h2>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Aluminium is the metal found most abundantly in the Earth’s crust. Since it is a reactive metal, it occurs in the combined state. The important ores of aluminium are as follows    </span></p>
	<p class="block_138"></p>
	<table class="table_2">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_374"><p class="block_19">Ores of Aluminium</p></td>
			<td class="td_375"><p class="block_19">Formula</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_376"><p class="block_9">Bauxite</p></td>
			<td class="td_377"><p class="block_9">A l2 O3.2H2O </p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_376"><p class="block_9">Cryolite</p></td>
			<td class="td_377"><p class="block_9"><sub class="calibre25"> </sub>Na3 A l F6 </p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_378"><p class="block_9">Corundum</p></td>
			<td class="td_379"><p class="block_9">A l2 O3 </p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_627">Bauxite is the chief ore of aluminium. The extraction of aluminium from bauxite involves two steps:</p>
	<p class="block_9">(i)Conversion of bauxite into alumina </p>
	<p class="block_9"> Baeyer’s Process:</p>
	<p class="block_9">The conversion of Bauxite into Alumina involves the following steps:</p>
	<p class="block_9">Bauxite ore is finely ground and heated under pressure with a solution of concentrated caustic soda solution at 150° C to obtain sodium meta-aluminate.</p>
	<p class="block_61">A l2 O3 + 2 NaOH gives 2 Na A l O2 + H2 O</p>
	<p class="block_9">On diluting sodium meta-aluminate with water, a precipitate of aluminium hydroxide is formed.</p>
	<p class="block_61"> Na A l O2 + 2 H2 O gives Al (O H) thrice + NaOH</p>
	<p class="block_9">The precipitate is filtered, washed, dried and ignited at 1000°C to get alumina.</p>
	<p class="block_61">2 A l (O H) thrice<span class="calibre28">   </span>under goes at 1000 degree Celsius gives A l 2 O3 + 3 H2 O </p>
	<p class="block_19">(ii) Electrolytic reduction of alumina </p>
	<p class="block_19"> Hall’s Process:</p>
	<p class="block_9">Aluminium is produced by the electrolytic reduction of fused alumina (A l 2 O3) in the electrolytic cell.</p>
	<p class="block_23"><b class="calibre36">Cathode:</b> Iron tank lined with graphite</p>
	<p class="block_23"><b class="calibre36">Anode</b>: A bunch of graphite rods suspended in molten electrolyte.</p>
	<p class="block_23"><b class="calibre36">Electrolyte:</b> Pure alumina+ molten cryolite+ fluorspar (fluorspar lowers the fusion temperature of electrolyte)</p>
	<p class="block_23">Temperature: 900 - 950 °C</p>
	<p class="block_23">Voltage used: 5-6 V</p>
	<p class="block_23">Overall reaction: 2 Al2O3 → 4 Al +3 O2↑</p>
	<p class="block_19">Electrolytic process of manufacturing aluminium</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-129.png" alt="figure 8.10 Hall's Process shown" class="calibre202"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 8.10 Hall's Process</p>
	<p class="block_9">Aluminium is deposited at the cathode and oxygen gas is liberated at the anode. Oxygen combines with graphite to form CO2.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Physical Properties of Aluminium</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">It is a silvery white metal</li>
	<li class="block_66">It has low density (2.7) and it is light</li>
	<li class="block_66">It is malleable and ductile</li>
	<li class="block_66">It is a good conductor of heat and electricity.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Its melting point is 660 °C.</li>
	<li class="block_66">It can be polished to produce a shiny attractive appearance.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Chemical Properties of Aluminium </p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li class="block_628"><b class="calibre6">Reaction with air:</b> It is not affected by dry air. On heating at 800 °C, aluminium burns very brightly forming its oxide and nitride.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_629">4 A l + 3 O2 gives 2 A l 2 O3 (Aluminium oxide)</p>
	<p class="block_629">2 A l+N2 gives 2 A l N (Aluminium nitride)</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li value="2" class="block_630"><b class="calibre36">Reaction with water:</b> Water does not react with aluminium due to the layer of oxide on it. When steam is passed over red-hot aluminium, hydrogen is produced.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_631">2A l+3H2 O (steam) gives A l 2 O3 (aluminium oxide) + 3H2 gas</p>
	<p class="block_74"></p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li value="3" class="block_628"><b class="calibre6">reaction with alkalis: </b>It reacts with strong <span class="text_33">caustic alkalis forming aluminates.</span></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">2 A l+2NaOH+2H2 O gives 2NaA l O2 (Sodium meta-aluminate) +3H2 gas</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li value="4" class="block_632"><span class="text_39">Reaction with acids: </span><span class="text_33">With dilute and </span><span class="text_27">con.</span> HCl, it liberates H<sub class="calibre25">2 </sub>gas.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">2A l+6 H C l gives 2 A l C l3 <span class="text_27">(Aluminium </span>chloride) + 3H2 gas</p>
	<p class="block_">Aluminium liberates hydrogen on reaction with dilute sulphuric acid. Sulphur dioxide is liberated with hot concentrated sulphuric acid</p>
	<p class="block_25">2A l+3H2 S O4 gives A l 2 (S O4) thrice + 3H2 gas</p>
	<p class="block_633">2A l+6H2 S O4 gives A l2 (S O4)thrice +6H2 O+3 S O2 gas</p>
	<p class="block_19">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_9">Dilute or concentrated nitric acid does not attack aluminium, but it renders aluminium passive due to the formation of an oxide film on its surface.</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li value="5" class="block_634"><b class="calibre6">As reducing agent: </b>Aluminium is a <span class="text_27">powerful reducing agent. When a mixture </span>of <span class="text_27">aluminium powder and iron oxide is ignited, </span>the latter is reduced to metal. This process is known as <b class="calibre6">aluminothermic process</b>.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_635">F e 2 O3 + 2 A l gives 2 F e + A l 2 O3 + heat</p>
	<p class="block_636">Uses</p>
	<p class="block_637">Aluminium is used in</p>
	<p class="block_637">household utensils</p>
	<p class="block_637">electrical cable industry</p>
	<p class="block_637">making aeroplanes and other industrial machine parts</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_238">8.8 EXTRACTIVE METALLURGY OF COPPER</h2>
	<p class="block_12">Occurrence:</p>
	<p class="block_">It was named as cuprum by the Romans because they got it from the Island of Cyprus. Copper is found in the native state as well as combined state.</p>
	<table class="table_37">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_380"><p class="block_638">Ores of copper</p></td>
			<td class="td_381"><p class="block_639">Formula</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_380"><p class="block_640"><span class="text_32">Copper </span><span class="text_29">pyrites</span></p></td>
			<td class="td_381"><p class="block_641">Cu F e S<span class="text_14">2</span></p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_380"><p class="block_642">Cuprite or ruby copper</p></td>
			<td class="td_381"><p class="block_643">Cu<span class="text_14">2</span>O</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_380"><p class="block_644">Copper glance</p></td>
			<td class="td_381"><p class="block_645">Cu<span class="text_14">2</span>S</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_">The chief ore of copper is copper pyrite. It yields nearly 76% of the world production of copper. Extraction of copper from copper pyrites involves the following steps</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">i. Concentration of ore:</b> The ore is crushed and concentrated by froth floatation process.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">ii. Roasting:</b> The concentrated ore is roasted in excess of air. During the process of roasting, the moisture and volatile impurities are removed. Sulphur, phosphorus, arsenic and antimony are removed as oxides. Copper pyrite is partly converted into sulphides of copper and iron.</p>
	<p class="block_61">2 CuF e S 2 + O2 gives Cu2S + 2 F e S + S O2 gas.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">iii. Smelting:</b> The roasted ore is mixed with powdered coke and sand and is heated in a blast furnace to obtain matte (Cu2 S + F e S) and slag. The slag is removed as waste.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">iv. Bessemerisation:</b> The molten matte is transferred to Bessemer converter in order to obtain blister copper. Ferrous sulphide from matte is oxidized to ferrous oxide, which is removed as slag using silica.</p>
	<p class="block_207">2 F e S + 3 O2 gives 2 F e O + 2 S O2 gas </p>
	<p class="block_207">F e O + S i O2 gives F e S I O 3 (slag) (Iron silicate) </p>
	<p class="block_207">2 Cu2 S + 3O2 gives 2 Cu2 O + 2 S O2 gas </p>
	<p class="block_207">2 Cu2 O + Cu2 S gives 6 Cu + S O2 gas (Blister copper) </p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">v. Refining:</b> Blister copper contains 98% of pure copper and 2% of impurities and is purified by electrolytic refining. This method is used to get metal of a high degree of purity. For electrolytic refining of copper, we use:</p>
	<p class="block_23"><b class="calibre36">Cathode:</b> A thin plate of pure copper metal.</p>
	<p class="block_23"><b class="calibre36">Anode:</b> A block of impure copper metal.</p>
	<p class="block_23"><b class="calibre36">Electrolyte:</b> Copper sulphate solution acidified with sulphuric acid.</p>
	<p class="block_9">When electric current is passed through the electrolytic solution, pure copper gets deposited at the cathode and the impurities settle at the bottom of the anode in the form of sludge called anode mud.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Physical Properties of Copper</p>
	<p class="block_9">Copper is a reddish-brown metal, with high lustre, high density and high melting point (1356°C).</p>
	<p class="block_19">Chemical Properties of Copper</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">1. Action of Air and Moisture:</b> Copper gets covered with a green layer of basic copper carbonate in the presence of C O2 and moisture.</p>
	<p class="block_60">2Cu+O<span class="text_14">2</span>+C O<span class="text_14">2</span>+H<span class="text_14">2</span>O gives Cu C O<span class="text_14">3</span>.Cu (O H)<span class="text_14"> twice.</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">2. Action of Heat:</b> On heating at different temperatures in the presence of oxygen, copper forms two types of oxides Cu O, Cu2 O</p>
	<p class="block_646">2 Cu + O2 <span id="id_Hlk168302572" class="calibre203">when heated below 1370 kelvin it gives<span class="calibre28">  2 Cu</span></span> O Copper II oxide (black) </p>
	<p class="block_61">4 Cu + O2 when heated above 1370 kelvin it gives 2Cu2 O Copper one oxide (red) </p>
	<p class="block_12">3. Action of Acids:</p>
	<p class="block_12">a) With dilute HCl and dilute H2 S O4:</p>
	<p class="block_">Dilute acids such as HCl and H2 S O4 have no action on these metals in the absence of air. Copper dissolves in these acids in the presence of air.</p>
	<p class="block_647">2Cu+4HCl+O<span class="text_14">2</span>(air) gives 2CuCl<span class="text_14">2</span>+2H<span class="text_14">2</span>O</p>
	<p class="block_19">b) With dil. HNO3:</p>
	<p class="block_9">Copper reacts with dil. HNO3 with the liberation of Nitric Oxide gas</p>
	<p class="block_648">3Cu+8HNO<span class="text_14">3 gives </span>Cu (N O<span class="text_14">3</span>)twice+2N O gas +4H<span class="text_14">2 </span>O</p>
	<p class="block_12">4.Action of Chlorine:</p>
	<p class="block_649"><span class="text_33">Chlorine reacts with copper, </span><span class="text_27">resulting in the </span>formation of copper (II) chloride.</p>
	<p class="block_650">Cu+Cl2 gives Cu Cl2</p>
	<p class="block_12">5.Action of Alkalis:</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="text_35">Copper is not attacked </span><span class="text_32">by alkalis.</span></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">Uses of Copper:</p>
	<p class="block_9">i. It is extensively used in manufacturing electric cables and other electric appliances.</p>
	<p class="block_9">ii. It is used for making utensils, containers, calorimeters and coins,</p>
	<p class="block_9">iii. It is used in electroplating.</p>
	<p class="block_9">iv. It is alloyed with gold and silver for making coins and jewels</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_239">8.9 METALLURGY OF IRON </h2>
	<p class="block_19">Occurrence:</p>
	<p class="block_9">Iron is the second most abundant metal available next to aluminium. It occurs in nature as oxides, sulphides and carbonates. The ores of iron are as follows:</p>
	<table class="table_38">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_382"><p class="block_651">Ores of iron</p></td>
			<td class="td_307"><p class="block_652">Formula</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_382"><p class="block_653">Hematite</p></td>
			<td class="td_307"><p class="block_654">F e<span class="text_40">2</span>O<span class="text_40">3</span></p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_382"><p class="block_655">Magnetite</p></td>
			<td class="td_307"><p class="block_656">F e<span class="text_40">3</span>O<span class="text_40">4</span></p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_382"><p class="block_655">Iron pyrite</p></td>
			<td class="td_307"><p class="block_656">F e S<span class="text_40">2</span></p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_9">Iron is chiefly extracted from haematite ore (F e2O3)</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">1. Concentration by Gravity Separation:</b> The powdered ore is washed with a steam of water. As a result, the lighter sand particles and other impurities are washed away and the heavier ore particles settle down.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">2. Roasting and Calcination:</b> The concentrated ore is strongly heated in a limited supply of air in a reverberatory furnace. As a result, moisture is driven out and sulphur, arsenic and phosphorus impurities are oxidized off.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">3. Smelting (in a Blast Furnace):</b> The charge consisting of roasted ore, coke and limestone in the ratio 8:4:1 is smelted in a blast furnace by introducing it through the hopper arrangement at the top. There are three important regions in the furnace.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-130.png" alt="C:\Users\ADMIN\Pictures\Screenshots\Screenshot (142).png" class="calibre204"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 8.11 Blast Furnace</p>
	<p class="block_">(a)The Lower Region (Combustion Zone)- The temperature is at 1500°C. In this region, coke burns with oxygen to form C O2 when the charge comes in contact with a hot blast of air.</p>
	<p class="block_61"><span class="calibre28">C+O2   </span><span id="id_Hlk168302697" class="calibre203">when heated at 1500 degree Celsius it gives C O2 + Heat</span></p>
	<p class="block_">It is an exothermic reaction since heat is liberated.</p>
	<p class="block_">(b) The Middle Region (Fusion Zone) – The temperature prevails at 1000°C. In this region, C O2 is reduced to C O.</p>
	<p class="block_207">CO<sub class="calibre25">2</sub> + C when heated at 1000 degree Celsius it gives<span class="calibre28">  2 C</span> O minus HEAT</p>
	<p class="block_">Limestone decomposes to calcium oxide and C O2.</p>
	<p class="block_">C a C O3<sub class="calibre25"> </sub> when heated at 1000 degree Celsius it gives C a O +C O2 minus HEAT</p>
	<p class="block_">These two reactions are endothermic due to absorption of heat. Calcium oxide combines with silica to form calcium silicate slag.</p>
	<p class="block_61">C a O<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>+ S I O2 gives C a S I O3</p>
	<p class="block_">(c) The Upper Region (Reduction Zone)- The temperature prevails at 400°C In this region carbon monoxide reduces ferric oxide to form a fairly pure spongy iron.</p>
	<p class="block_61">F e2 O3 + 3C O when heated at 400 degree Celsius it gives 2F e + 3C O2 gas </p>
	<p class="block_">The molten iron is collected at the bottom of the furnace after removing the slag.</p>
	<p class="block_">The iron thus formed is called pig iron. It is remelted and cast into different moulds. This iron is called cast iron.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Physical properties:</p>
	<p class="block_">1. It is a lustrous metal, greyish white in colour.</p>
	<p class="block_">ii. It has high tensility, malleability and ductility.</p>
	<p class="block_">iii. It can be magnetized.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Chemical properties:</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">1. Reaction with air or oxygen:</b> Only on <span class="text_33">heating in air, iron forms </span>magnetic oxide.</p>
	<p class="block_61">3 F e + 2 O2 gives F e 3 O4 BLACK</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">ii. Reaction with moist air:</b> When iron is exposed to moist air, it forms a layer of brown hydrated ferric oxide on its surface. This compound is known as rust and the phenomenon of formation of rust is known as rusting.</p>
	<p class="block_">4 F e+ 3 O2 + x H2 O gives 2 F e 2 O3.x H2 O (rust)</p>
	<p class="block_">iii. Reaction with steam: When steam is passed over red-hot iron, magnetic oxide is formed.</p>
	<p class="block_61">3 F e + 4 H2 O (STEAM) gives F e 3 O4 + 4 H2 gas</p>
	<p class="block_">iv. Reaction with chlorine: Iron combines with chlorine to form ferric chloride.</p>
	<p class="block_657">2 F e + 3 C l 2 gives 2 F e C l3<span class="text_34"> (ferric </span><span class="text_35">chloride)</span></p>
	<p class="block_">5. Reaction with acids: With dilute HCl and dilute H2 S O4 it liberates H2 gas.</p>
	<p class="block_61">F e + 2 HCl gives F e Cl2 + H2 gas </p>
	<p class="block_61">F e + H2 S O4 gives F e S O4 + H2 gas </p>
	<p class="block_">With dilute HNO3 in cold condition it gives ferrous nitrate and ammonium nitrate.</p>
	<p class="block_658">4F e+10HNO<span class="text_14">3 gives </span>4F e (N O<span class="text_14">3</span>) twice +NH<span class="text_14">4</span>N O<span class="text_14">3</span>+ 3 H<span class="text_14">2</span>O</p>
	<p class="block_">With con. H2 S O4 it forms ferric sulphate and liberates S O2.</p>
	<p class="block_659">2F e+6H<span class="text_11">2</span>S O<span class="text_11">4 gives </span>Fe<span class="text_11">2</span>(S O<span class="text_11">4</span>) thrice +3S O<span class="text_11">2</span>+6H<span class="text_11">2</span>O</p>
	<p class="block_">When iron is dipped in concentrated H N O3 it becomes chemically passive or inert due to the formation of a layer of iron oxide (F e 3 O4) on its surface.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Uses of iron</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Pig iron</b> (Iron with 2-4.5% of carbon): It is used in making pipes, stoves, radiators, railings, manhole covers and drain pipes.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Steel</b> (Iron with less than 0.25% of carbon): It is used in the construction of buildings, machinery, transmission cables and T.V towers and in making alloys.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Wrought iron</b> (Iron with 0.25-2% of wrought carbon): It is used in making springs, anchors and electromagnets.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_240">8.10 ALLOYS</h2>
	<p class="block_">An alloy is a homogeneous mixture of two or more metals or of one or more metals with certain non-metallic elements.</p>
	<p class="block_">The properties of alloys are often different from those of its components. Pure gold is brittle to be used. The addition of small percentage of copper enhances its strength and utility.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Amalgam</p>
	<p class="block_">An amalgam is an alloy of mercury with another metal. These alloys are formed through metallic bonding with the electrostatic force of attraction between the electrons and the positively charged metal ions. Silver tin amalgam is used for dental filling.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Reasons for alloying:</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li class="block_321">To modify appearance and colour</li>
	<li class="block_322">To modify chemical activity.</li>
	<li class="block_322">To lower the melting point.</li>
	<li class="block_322">To increase hardness and tensile strength.</li>
	<li class="block_323">To increase resistance to electricity.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Method of making alloys</p>
	<p class="block_">(a)By fusing the metals together. example Brass is made by melting zinc and copper.</p>
	<p class="block_">(b)By compressing finely divided metals.</p>
	<p class="block_">Example Wood metal: an alloy of lead, tin, bismuth and cadmium powder is a fusible alloy.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Alloys as solid solutions:</p>
	<p class="block_">Alloys can be considered solid solutions in which the metal with high concentration is solvent and other metals are solute.</p>
	<p class="block_">For example, brass is a solid solution of zinc (solute) in copper (solvent).</p>
	<p class="block_12">Types of Alloys</p>
	<p class="block_">Based on the presence or absence of Iron, alloys can be classified into:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_321">Ferrous alloys: Contain Iron as a major component. A few examples of ferrous alloys are Stainless Steel, Nickel Steel etc.</li>
	<li class="block_323">Non-ferrous alloys: These alloys do not contain Iron as a major component. For example, Aluminium alloy, Copper alloy etc.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">Copper Alloys (Non- ferrous)</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_241">8.11 CORROSION</h2>
	<p class="block_">It is the gradual destruction of metals by chemical or electrochemical reaction with the environment. It is a natural process which converts a metal into its oxide, hydroxide or sulphide so that it loses its metallic characteristics.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-131.png" alt="figure 8.12 Rusting  Explained as follows, equation for reactions at cathode  O2 + 2 H2 O + 4 electrons gives 40 Hydride ions. O2 + 4 H+ ions + 4 electrons gives 2 H2 O. reactions at anode F e become F e 2 plus ion + 2 electrons.  " class="calibre205"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 8.12 Rusting</p>
	<p class="block_">Rust is chemically known as hydrated ferric oxide (it is formulated as F e 2 O3.x H2O). Rusting results in the formation of scaling reddish brown hydrated ferric oxide on the surface of iron and iron containing materials.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_242">8.11.1 Types of Corrosion</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">i. Dry Corrosion or Chemical Corrosion: The corrosive action in the absence of moisture is called dry corrosion. It is the process of a chemical attack on a metal by   a corrosive liquids or gases such as O2 , N2, S</span> O2, H2S etc. It occurs at high temperature. Of all the gases mentioned above O2 is the most reactive gas to impart the chemical attack.</p>
	<p class="block_">ii. Wet Corrosion or Electrochemical Corrosion: The corrosive action in the presence of moisture is called wet corrosion. It occurs as a result of electrochemical reaction of metal with water or aqueous solution of salt or acids or bases.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_243">8.11.2 Methods of preventing corrosion</h3>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">i. Alloying:</b> The metals can be alloyed to prevent the process of corrosion. E.g.: Stainless Steel</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">ii. Surface Coating:</b> It involves application of a protective coating over the metal. It is of the following types:</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">a) Galvanization:</b> It is the process of coating zinc on iron sheets by using electric current.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">b) Electroplating:</b> It is a method of coating one metal over another metal by passing electric current.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">c) Anodizing:</b> It is an electrochemical process that converts the metal surface into a decorative, durable and corrosion resistant. Aluminium is widely used for anodizing process.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">d) Cathodic Protection:</b> It is the method of controlling corrosion of a metal surface protected is coated with the metal which is easily corrodible. The easily corrodible metal is called Sacrificial metal to act as anode ensuring cathodic protection.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_244">8.12 PAMBAN BRIDGE</h2>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image220.png" alt="figure 8.13 Pamban Bridge image " class="calibre206"/><b class="calibre6"> </b></p>
	<p class="block_138">Figure 8.13 Pamban Bridge</p>
	<p class="block_">It is a railway bridge which connects the town of Rameswaram on Pamban Island to mainland India. Opened on 1914, it was India’s first sea bridge in India until the opening of the Bandari Sea Link in 2010. We can control the corrosion and renovation of historical pamban bridge by a periodical protective coating which will be the strong example for applied chemistry to uphold our history.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_245">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">Modern periodic law states that, the physical and chemical properties of the elements are the periodic functions of their atomic numbers.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The table in which elements are arranged in rows and columns in regular gradation is called periodic table.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Smelting is the process of reducing the roasted metallic oxide into metal in molten condition.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Dilute or concentrated HNO3 does not attack aluminium metal, as it renders aluminium passive due to oxide film formation on its surface.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The charge used in the metallurgy of iron consists of roasted ore, coke and limestone in the ratio, 8 is to 4 is to 1.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Copper vessel on exposure to air and moisture forms a green layer on its surface due to basic copper carbonate.</li>
	<li class="block_66">An alloy is a homogeneous mixture of two or more metals.</li>
	<li class="block_66">An amalgam is an alloy of mercury with another metal. Example A g - S n amalgam is used for dental filling.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The chemical name of rust is hydrated ferric oxide and its formula is F e 2 O3.x H2 O.</li>
</ol>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_247">UNIT-9</h1>
	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_248">SOLUTIONS</h1>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-134.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of X L U 5 P" class="calibre209"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_249">Learning Objectives </h2>
	<p class="block_">After studying this lesson, students will BE able to</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Define solution.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Recognize the types of solutions.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Analyse the factors influencing solubility.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Explain the various modes of expression of concentration of solution.</li>
	<li class="block_7">calculate the solubility of solutes in solvents.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Correlate the hydrated salts and anhydrous salts.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Distinguish between deliquescent and hygroscopic substances.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_250">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">You have learnt about mixtures in your lower classes. Most of the substances that we encounter in our daily life are mixtures of two or more substances. The substances present in a mixture may exist in one or more physical state. For example, when we burn wood, the smoke released is a mixture of solid carbon and gases like C O2, C O, etc.</p>
	<p class="block_">In some cases of mixtures, their components can be separated easily whereas in some other cases they cannot be. Consider the two mixtures, one which contains salt and water, and the another which contains sand and water. Water is the one of the components in both the mixtures. In the first case salt dissolves in water. In the second case the sand does not dissolve in water. Sand in water can be separated by filtration but salt cannot be separated as it dissolves in water to form a homogeneous mixture. This kind of homogenous mixtures are termed as “solutions”.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-135.png" alt="SALT + WATER AND SAND =WATER IMAGE SHOWS DIFFERENCE BETWEEN  Homogeneous and heterogeneous mixtures" class="calibre210"/></p>
	<p class="block_138">Figure 9.1 Homogeneous and heterogeneous mixtures</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_251">9.1 SOLUTIONS IN DAY-TO-DAY LIFE</h2>
	<p class="block_9">One of the naturally existing solutions is sea water. We cannot imagine life on earth without sea water. It is a mixture of many dissolved salts. Another one is air. It is a mixture of gases like nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide and other gases.</p>
	<p class="block_9">All the life forms on the earth are associated with solutions. Plants take solutions of nutrients for their growth from the soil. Most of the liquids found in human body including blood, lymph and urine are solutions. Day to day human activities like washing, cooking, cleaning and few other activities involve the formation of solutions with water. Similarly, the drinks what we take, like fruit juice, aerated drinks, tea, coffee etc. are also solutions. Therefore, the ability of water to form solutions is responsible for sustenance of life </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_252">9.2 COMPONENTS OF SOLUTIONS</h2>
	<p class="block_">We know that, a solution is a homogeneous mixture of two or more substances. In a solution, the component which is present in lesser amount (by weight), is called solute and the component, which is present in a larger amount (by weight) is called solvent. The solute gets distributed uniformly throughout the solvent and thus forming the mixture homogeneous. So, the solvent acts as a dissolving medium in a solution. The process of uniform distribution of solute into solvent is called dissolution. Figure 9.2 shows the schematic representation of solution.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image-136.png" alt="Formation of solution -Explained. sOLUTE+SOLVENT GIVES SOLUTION" class="calibre211"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">A solution must at least be consisting of two components (a solute and a solvent). Such solutions which are made of one solute and one solvent (two components) are called binary solutions. e.g. On adding copper sulphate crystals to water, it dissolves in water forming a solution of copper sulphate as shown in Figure 9.3. It contains two components i.e. one solute- copper sulphate and one solvent-water So it is a binary solution. Similarly, a solution may contain more than two components. For example if salt and sugar are added to water, both dissolve in water forming a solution. Here two solutes are dissolved in one solvent. Such kind of solutions which contain three components are called ternary solutions.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-137.png" alt=" figure 9.3 Formation of Copper sulphate solution is as follows. copper is added with water and we can get solution of copper sulphate." class="calibre212"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 9.3 Formation of Copper sulphate solution</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_253">9.3 Types of Solutions</h2>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_254">9.3.1 Based on the physical state of the solute and the solvent</h3>
	<p class="block_">We know that substances normally exist in three physical states (phases) i.e., solid, liquid and gas. In binary solutions, both the solvent and solute may exist in any of these physical states. But the solvent constitutes the major part of the solution. Its physical state is the primary factor which determine the characteristics of the solution. Therefore, there are different types of binary solutions as listed in Table 9.1.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Table9.1Types of binary solutions</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-138.png" alt="Table9.1Types of binary solutions" class="calibre213"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_255">9.3.2 Based on the type of solvent</h3>
	<p class="block_">Most of the substances are soluble in water. That is why, water is called as ‘Universal solvent”. However some substances do not dissolve in water. Therefore, other solvents such as ethers, benzene, alcohols etc., are used to prepare a solution. On the basis of type of solvent, solutions are classified into two types. They are aqueous solutions and non-aqueous solutions.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">a) Aqueous solution</b>:</p>
	<p class="block_">The solution in which water acts as a solvent is called aqueous solution. Example Common salt in water, Sugar in water, Copper sulphate in water etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">b) Non–Aqueous solution</b>:</p>
	<p class="block_">The solution in which any liquid, other than water, acts as a solvent is called nonaqueous solution. Solvent other than water is referred to as non-aqueous solvent. Generally, alcohols, benzene, ethers, carbon disulphide, acetone, etcetera  are used as non-aqueous solvents. Examples for non-aqueous solutions: Sulphur dissolved in carbon disulphide; Iodine dissolved in carbon tetrachloride.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image307.jpeg" alt="Sulphur in carbon-di sulphide(Soluble), SulphurE in water(Insoluble) image " class="calibre214"/></p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">Figure9.4 Sulphur is soluble in carbon-di-sulphide , Sulphur  is Insoluble in water </span></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_256">9.3.3 Based on the amount of solute</h3>
	<p class="block_9">The amount of the solute that can be dissolved in the given amount of solvent is limited under any given conditions. Based on the amount of solute, in the given amount of solvent, solutions are classified into the following types:</p>
	<p class="block_9">(i) Saturated solution</p>
	<p class="block_9">(ii) Unsaturated solution</p>
	<p class="block_9">(iii) Supersaturated solution</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">(i) Saturated solution:</b> A solution in which no more solute can be dissolved in a definite amount of the solvent at a given temperature is called saturated solution. Example  36 gram of sodium chloride in 100 gram of water at 25 degree Celcius forms saturated solution. Further addition of sodium chloride, leave it undissolved.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">(ii) Unsaturated solution</b>: Unsaturated solution is one that contains less solute than that of the saturated solution at a given temperature. Example 10 gram or 20 gram or 30 gram of Sodium chloride in 100 gram of water at 25 degree Celcius forms an unsaturated solution.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">(iii) Super saturated solution:</b> Supersaturated solution is one that contains more solute than the saturated solution at a given temperature. Example  40 gram of sodium chloride in 100 gram of water at 25 degree Celcius forms super saturated solution. This state can be achieved by altering any other conditions like temperature, pressure. Super saturated solutions are unstable, and the solute is reappearing as crystals when the solution is disturbed.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-139.png" alt="Conceptual thoughts: You are given two samples if solutions of Nacl. Can you identify which one is saturated? and How?" class="calibre215"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_257">9.3.4 Concentrated and dilute solutions</h3>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">It is another kind of classification of unsaturated solutions. It expresses the relative concentration of two solutions with respect to their solutes present in the given amount of the solvent. For example, you are given two cups of tea. When you taste them, you feel that one is sweeter than the other. What do you infer from it? The tea which sweet more contains higher amount of sugar than the other. How can you express your observation? You can say that the tea is stronger. But a chemist would say that it is ‘concentrated’. When we compare two  solutions having same solute and solvent  the one which contains higher amount of solute per the given amount of solvent is said to be ‘concentrated </span>solution’ and the another is said to be ‘dilute solution’. They are schematically represented by Figure9.5.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-140.png" alt="Dilute and Concentrated Solution image given " class="calibre216"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure9.5 Dilute and Concentrated Solution</p>
	<p class="block_">Differentiating solutions as dilute and concentrated is a qualitative representation. It does not imply the quantity of the solute. This difference is observed by means of some physical characteristics such as colour, density, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Activity 1</p>
	<p class="block_">Look at the following pictures. Label them as dilute and concentrated solution and justify your answer.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-141.png" alt="Tea and Copper sulphate image are given" class="calibre217"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_258">9.4 Solubility</h2>
	<p class="block_">Usually, there is a limit to the amount of solute that can be dissolved in a given amount of solvent at a given temperature. When this limit is reached, we have a saturated solution and any excess solute that is added, simply resides at the bottom of the solution. The extent of dissolution of a solute in a solvent can be better explained by its solubility. Solubility is a measure of how much of a solute can be dissolved in a specified amount of a solvent.</p>
	<p class="block_"> Solubility is defined as the number of grams of a solute that can be dissolved in 100 gram of a solvent to form its saturated solution at a given temperature and pressure. For example, 36 gram of sodium chloride need to be dissolved in 100 gram of water to form its saturated solution at 25 degree Celcius Thus the solubility of sodium chloride in water is 36 gram at 25 degree Celcius .The solubility is mathematically expressed as</p>
	<p class="block_">Solubility = mass of the solute multiplied by 100 divided by mass of the solvent. </p>
	<p class="block_">Table 9.2 Solubility’s of some common substances in water at 25 degree Celcius</p>

	<h3 class="block_205" id="toc_id_259"> </h3>
	<h3 class="block_205" id="toc_id_260"> </h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_261">9.4.1Factors affecting solubility</h3>
	<p class="block_">There are three main factors which govern the solubility of a solute. They are:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-134.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of X L U 5 P" class="calibre209"/></p>
	<p class="block_">(i) Nature of the solute and solvent</p>
	<p class="block_">(ii) Temperature</p>
	<p class="block_">(iii) Pressure</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">(i)  Nature of the solute and solvent</span></p>
	<p class="block_">The nature of the solute and solvent plays an important role in solubility. Although water dissolves an enormous variety of substances, both ionic and covalent, it does not dissolve everything. The phrase that scientists often use when predicting solubility is “like dissolves like.” This expression means that dissolving occurs when similarities exist between the solvent and the solute. For example: Common salt is a polar compound and dissolves readily in polar solvent like water. Non-polar compounds are soluble in non-polar solvents. For example, Fat dissolved in ether. But non-polar compounds, do not dissolve in polar solvents; polar compounds do not dissolve in non-polar solvents.</p>
	<p class="block_">ii. Effect of Temperature</p>
	<p class="block_">Solubility of Solids in Liquid: Generally, solubility of a solid solute in a liquid solvent increase with increase in temperature. For example, a greater amount of sugar will dissolve in warm water than in cold water. In endothermic process, solubility increases with increase in temperature. In exothermic process, solubility decreases with increase in temperature.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Solubility of Gases in liquid Do you know why is it bubbling when water is boiled? Solubility of gases in liquid decrease with increase in temperature. Generally, water contains dissolved oxygen. When water is boiled, the solubility of oxygen in water decreases, so oxygen escapes in the form of bubbles. Aquatic animals live more in cold regions because, more amount of dissolved oxygen is present in the water of cold regions. This shows that the solubility of oxygen in water is more at low temperatures.</p>
	<p class="block_">Effect of Pressure</p>
	<p class="block_">Effect of pressure is observed only in the case of solubility of a gas in a liquid. When the pressure is increased, the solubility of a gas in liquid increases. The common examples for solubility of gases in liquids are carbonated beverages,  That is soft drinks, household cleaners containing aqueous solution of ammonia, formalin-aqueous solution of formaldehyde, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image344.jpeg" alt="Effect of pressure on solubility EXPLAINED" class="calibre218"/><img src="images/image345.jpeg" alt="Effect of pressure on solubility " class="calibre219"/></p>
	<p class="block_74">Figure9.6 Effect of pressure on solubility</p>
	<p class="block_19">More to know</p>
	<p class="block_9">The effect of pressure on the solubility of a gas in liquid is given by Henry’s law. It states that, the solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the pressure of the gas over the solution at a definite temperature.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_262">9.5 Concentration of a Solution</h2>
	<p class="block_23">So far, we discussed what is a solution? what does it consist of and its types. Most of the chemical reactions take place in solutions form So it is essential to quantify the solute in solvent to study the reactions. To quantify the solute in a solution, we can use the term</p>
	<p class="block_9">“concentration”.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Concentration of a solution may be defined as the amount of solute present in a given amount of solution or solvent.</p>
	<p class="block_">Quantitatively, concentration of a solution may be expressed in different methods. But here, we shall discuss percentage by mass ( percentage of  mass) and percentage by volume (percentage of  volume).</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_263">9.5.1 Mass percentage</h3>
	<p class="block_9">Mass percentage of a solution is defined as the percentage by mass of the solute present in the solution. It is mostly used when solute is solid and solvent is liquid.</p>
	<p id="id_Hlk168308285" class="block_9">Mass percentage = mass of the solute x 100 divided by mass of the solution.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Mass percentage = mass of the solute x 100 divided by open bracket mass of the solute + mass of the solvent close bracket.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">For example: 5% sugar solution (by mass) means 5 gram of sugar in 95 gram of water. Hence it is made of 100gram of solution.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Usually, mass percentage is expressed as w/w (weight / weight); mass percentage is independent of temperature.</p>
	<p class="block_154"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_264">9.5.2 Volume percentage</h3>
	<p class="block_9">Volume percentage is defined as the percentage by volume of solute (in ml) present in the given volume of the solution.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Volume percentage = Volume of the solute x 100 divided by Volume of the solution.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Volume percentage = Volume of the solute x 100 divided by open bracket Volume of the solute + Volume of the solvent close bracket.</p>
	<p class="block_">For example, 10% by volume of the solution of ethanol in water, means 10 ml of ethanol in100 ml of solution (or 90 ml of water)</p>
	<p class="block_">Usually volume percentage is expressed as v divided by v (volume by volume). It is used when both the solute and solvent are liquids. Volume percentage decreases with increases in temperature, because of expansion of liquid.</p>
	<p class="block_">You can notice that in the commercial products that we come across in our dailylife such as a solution of syrups, mouth wash,antiseptic solution, household disinfectants etc.,the concentration of the ingredients is expressed as v by v. Similarly, in ointments, antacid, soaps,etc., the concentration of solutions are expressed as w by w.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image.jpeg" alt="களிம்பு (w/w  சதவீதம்) விளக்கப்படம் கொடுக்கப்பட்டுள்ளது" class="calibre220"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure9.7Ointment (w by w percent)</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_265">9.6 Hydrated salts and Water of Crystallization</h2>
	<p class="block_">When ionic substances are dissolved in water to make their saturated aqueous solution, their ions attract water molecules which then attached chemically in certain ratio. This process is called hydration. These ionic substances crystallize out from their saturated aqueous solution with a definite number of molecules of water. The numberof water molecules found in the crystalline substance is called water of crystallization.Such salts are called hydrated salts.</p>
	<p class="block_">On heating these hydrated crystalline salts, they lose their water of crystallization and become amorphous or lose their colour(if they are coloured). Table 9.3 shows some common hydrated salts:</p>
	<p class="block_">Table 9.3 Hydrated salts</p>
	<table class="table_6">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_415"><p class="block_699">Common Name</p></td>
			<td class="td_86"><p class="block_700"><span class="calibre15">IUPAC  Name</span></p></td>
			<td class="td_416"><p class="block_701">Molecular Formula</p></td>
		</tr>

	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_266">9.6.1 Copper sulphatepentahydrate CuSO4. 5H2O (Blue vitriol)</h3>
	<p class="block_9">The number of water molecules in bluevitriol is five. So its water of crystallization is 5. When blue coloured copper sulphate crystals are gently heated, it loses its five water molecules and becomes colourless anhydrouscopper sulphate.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-142.png" alt="Cu S O4 dot 5 H2 O copper sulphate pentahydrate which is blue in colour while heating gives C u S O 4 + 5 H 2 O anhydrous copper sulphate which is colour less.  in reverse reaction C u S O 4 + 5 H2 O when cooling gives C u S O 4 dot 5 H2 O." class="calibre221"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 9.9 Copper sulphate heating before and after</p>
	<p class="block_">If you add few drops of water or allow it to cool, the colourless anhydrous salt again turns back into blue coloured hydrated salt.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image350.png" alt="Difference between Hydrated copper sulphate and anhydrous copper sulphate " class="calibre222"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 9.10 Anhydrous copper sulphate turns to blue when water is added</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_267">9.6.2 Magnesium sulphate heptahydrate MgSO4.7H2O (Epsom salt)</h3>
	<p class="block_">Its water of crystallization is 7. When magnesium sulphate heptahydrate crystals are gently heated, it loses seven water molecules,and becomes anhydrous magnesium sulphate.</p>
	<table class="table_42">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_426"><p class="block_714">MgSO<span class="text_14">4 dot </span>7H<span class="text_14">2</span>O</p><p class="block_714">(Magnesium sulphate heptahydrate)</p></td>
			<td class="td_427"><p class="block_715">Under goes reversible reaction. While heating right ward equation while cooling left ward reaction</p></td>
			<td class="td_428"><p class="block_716">MgSO4 +7H2 O</p><p class="block_716">(Anhydrous Magnesium sulphate)</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_">If you add few drops of water or allow it tocool, the colourless anhydrous salt again turnsback into hydrated salt.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_268">9.7 Hygroscopy</h2>
	<p class="block_9">Certain substances, when exposed to the atmospheric air at ordinary temperature,absorb moisture without changing their physical state. Such substances are called hygroscopic substances and this property is called hygroscopy.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Hygroscopic substances are used as drying agents.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Example: 1. Conc.Sulphuric acid (H2S O4).</p>
	<p class="block_9">2. Phosphorus Pentoxide (P2O5).</p>
	<p class="block_9">3. Quick lime (C aO).</p>
	<p class="block_9">4. Silica gel (S I O2).</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_269">9.8 Deliquescence</h2>
	<p class="block_9">Certain substances which are so hygroscopic, when exposed to the atmospheric air at ordinary temperatures, absorb enough water and get completely dissolved. Such substances are called deliquescent substances and this property is called deliquescence.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Deliquescent substances lose their crystalline shape and ultimately dissolve in the absorbed water forming a saturated solution.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Deliquescence is maximum when:</p>
	<p class="block_9">1)The temperature is low</p>
	<p class="block_9">2)The atmosphere is humid</p>
	<p class="block_9">Examples: Caustic soda (NaOH), Caustic potash(KOH) and Ferric chloride (FeCl3).</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">Table 9.3 Difference between hygroscopic substances and deliquescence.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-143.png" alt="C:\Users\ADMIN\Pictures\Screenshots\Screenshot (326).png" class="calibre223"/></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">Figure 9.11 Deliquescence in Sodium hydroxide</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<table class="table_43">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_429"><p class="block_717">Hygroscopic substances</p></td>
			<td class="td_430"><p class="block_718">Deliquescence substances</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_431"><p class="block_719">When exposed to the atmosphere at ordinary temperature, they absorb moisture and do not dissolve.</p></td>
			<td class="td_432"><p class="block_720">When exposed to the atmospheric air at ordinary temperature, they absorb moisture and dissolve.</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_433"><p class="block_719">Hygroscopic substances do not change its physical state on exposure to air.</p></td>
			<td class="td_434"><p class="block_720">Deliquescent substances change its physical state on exposure to air.</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_435"><p class="block_719">Hygroscopic substances may be amorphous solids or liquids.</p></td>
			<td class="td_436"><p class="block_721">Deliquescent substances are crystalline solids.</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_272">II. Problem based on mass percentage</h3>
	<p class="block_">1) A solution was prepared by dissolving 25 gtam of sugar in 100 gram of water. Calculate the mass percentage of solute.</p>
	<p class="block_">Mass of the solute = 25 gram</p>
	<p class="block_">Mass of the solvent=100gram</p>
	<p class="block_9">Mass percentage = mass of the solute x 100 divided by mass of the solution.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Mass percentage = mass of the solute x 100 divided by open bracket mass of the solute + mass of the solvent close bracket.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">                                     =</span> 25 x 100 divided by 25 + 100 = 25 x 100 divided by 125<span class="calibre28"> =  20%</span></p>
	<p class="block_">2) 16 grams of NaOH is dissolved in 100grams of water at 25°C to form a saturated solution.Find the mass percentage of solute and solvent.</p>
	<p class="block_">Mass of the solute (NaOH) = 16 gram<span class="calibre28">  </span></p>
	<p class="block_">Mass of the solvent H2O = 100 gram</p>
	<p class="block_"> (i) Mass percentage of the solute</p>
	<p class="block_">Mass percentage = mass of the solute x 100 divided by open bracket mass of the solute + mass of the solvent close bracket.</p>
	<p class="block_">= 16 x 100 divided by 16 + 100 = 1600 divided by 116 = 13.79</p>
	<p class="block_742">Mass percentage of the solute=13.79%</p>
	<p class="block_743">Mass percentage of solvent = 100 minus <span class="text_35">(Mass percentage of the </span><span class="text_32">solute)</span></p>
	<p class="block_744">=100 minus 13.79</p>
	<p class="block_745">= 86.21%</p>
	<p class="block_9">3) Find the amount of urea which is to be dissolved in water to get 500 gram<span class="calibre15"> of 10%  w </span>by w a<span class="calibre15">queous  solution?</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">Mass percentage w by w = mass of the solute x 100 divided by mass of the solution.</p>
	<p class="block_9">10 = mass of the urea x 100 divided by 500</p>
	<p class="block_746"> </p>
	<p class="block_">Mass of urea=50 gram</p>

	<h2 class="block_436" id="toc_id_274"> </h2>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_275"><span class="calibre28">                                </span></h2>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_276">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66"> A solution is a homogeneous mixture of two or more substances.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> An aqueous solution is a solution in which the solvent is water.</li>
	<li class="block_66">A non-aqueous solution is a solution in which the solvent is a liquid, other than water</li>
	<li class="block_66"> A solution in which no more solute can be dissolved in a definite amount of the solvent at a given temperature is called saturated solution.</li>
	<li class="block_66">An unsaturated solution is one that contains less solute than the saturated solution at a given temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> A supersaturated solution is one that contains more solute than the saturated solution at a given temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Polar compounds are soluble in polar solvents.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Non-polar compounds are soluble in non-polar solvents.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> In endothermic process, solubility of solid solute increases with increase in temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> In exothermic process, solubility of solid solute decreases with increase in temperature.</li>
</ol>

	<p class="block_">6. The aquatic animals live more in cold region Why?</p>

	<p class="block_">Conc.Sulphuric acid,Copper sulphate penta hydrate, Silica gel, Calcium chloride,and Gypsum salt.</p>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_278">UNIT-10</h1>
	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_279">TYPES OF CHEMICAL REACTIONS</h1>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6"><span class="calibre28">   </span></b><b class="calibre6"><img src="images/image-147.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of T 1 5 N B" class="calibre227"/></b></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_280">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_">After completing this lesson learners will be able to</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">infer different types of chemical reaction.</li>
	<li class="block_7">acquire knowledge about combination reaction and skill to perform a combination reaction using quick lime and water.</li>
	<li class="block_7">identify and differentiate between reversible and irreversible reactions.</li>
	<li class="block_7">explain the reversible reaction occurring at the equilibrium state.</li>
	<li class="block_7">list and explain characteristics of equilibrium state.</li>
	<li class="block_7">define rate of reaction.</li>
	<li class="block_7">discuss the dependence of rate of reactions on concentration, temperature and catalyst.</li>
	<li class="block_7">define pH.</li>
	<li class="block_7">correlate the concentration of hydrogen ions and pH with neutral, acidic and basic nature of aqueous solutions.</li>
	<li class="block_7">recognize the importance of pH in everyday life.</li>
	<li class="block_8">explain the term ionic product of water.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_281">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">As you know from your earlier studies, a chemical reaction involves breaking of old chemical bonds and formation of new chemical bonds. This change may happen spontaneously or it may be facilitated by external forces or energy. Chemistry is all about chemical reactions. In your day-to-day life, you could observe many chemical reactions. A clear understanding of these reactions is essential in order to manipulate them for the sake of human life and environment. So, chemistry mainly focuses on chemical reactions. Let us try to find the answer for the following questions:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">You need energy to play, walk, run or to perform various physical activities. Where do you get the energy from?</li>
	<li class="block_7">How do plants grow and get their food?</li>
	<li class="block_7">How does a car move use fuel?</li>
	<li class="block_8">Why does iron rust on its exposure to water or air?</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">You get energy from the digestion of the food you eat. Plants grow by absorbing nutrients from the Earth and get their food by photosynthesis. The combustion of a fuel makes the car to move. Oxidation of iron causes rusting. So, all these processes are chemical changes. the materials, which undergo changes are converted into some other new materials. For example, by burning petrol, the hydrocarbons present in it are converted into carbon dioxide and water. In this chapter, let us discuss the nature and types of chemical reactions.</p>
	<p class="block_12">What happens during a chemical reaction?</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_228">In a chemical reaction, the atoms of the reacting molecules or elements are rearranged to form new molecules.</li>
	<li class="block_758">Old chemical bonds between atoms are broken and new chemical bonds are formed.</li>
	<li class="block_759">Bond breaking absorbs energy whereas bond formation releases energy.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">How are chemical reactions represented?</p>
	<p class="block_">When methane reacts with oxygen, it forms carbon dioxide and water. How can you represent this reaction? It can be written as a word equation as shown below:</p>
	<p class="block_">Methane + Oxygen → Carbon dioxide + Water</p>
	<p class="block_">But this equation does not give the chemical composition of the reactants and products. So, to learn the characteristics of a chemical reaction, it is represented by a chemical equation. In the chemical equation, the chemicals of the reaction are represented by their chemical formulae. The compounds or elements, which undergo reactions (reactants) are shown to the left of an arrow and the compounds formed (products) are shown to the right of the arrow. The arrow indicates the direction of the reaction. Thus, the aforesaid reaction can be written as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_74">C H4 + O2 gives C O2 + H2O</p>
	<p class="block_">But this is also an incomplete chemical equation. Because, the law of conservation of matter states that matter cannot be created or destroyed. You cannot create new atoms by a chemical reaction. In contrast, they are rearranged in different ways by a chemical reaction to form a new compound. So, in a chemical equation, the number of atoms of the reactants and that of the products must be equal. The number of hydrogen and oxygen atoms in the reactants and the products are not equal in the given equation. On balancing the number of atoms, the following equation can be obtained:</p>
	<p class="block_760">CH<span class="text_11">4</span>+2O<span class="text_11">2gives</span>C O<span class="text_11">2</span>+2H<span class="text_11">2</span>O</p>
	<p class="block_">Further, the chemical equation provides information on the physical state of the substances and the conditions under which the reaction takes place.</p>
	<p class="block_761"><span class="text_46">CH</span><b class="calibre6">4</b>(gas)<span class="text_46">+2O</span><b class="calibre6">2</b>(gas) gives<span class="text_46"><span class="calibre28">  </span></span><span class="text_46">CO</span><b class="calibre6">2</b>(gas)<span class="text_46">+2H</span><b class="calibre6">2</b><span class="text_46">O</span>(gas)</p>
	<p class="block_762"><span class="calibre28">    </span>Methane +<span class="calibre28">  </span> Oxygen gives  Carbon-dioxide +<span class="calibre28">  </span>Water</p>
	<p class="block_763">A balanced chemical equation is the simplified representation of a chemical reaction which describes the Chemical composition, physical state of the reactants and the products, and the reaction conditions.</p>
	<p class="block_764">MORE TO KNOW</p>
	<p class="block_764">The phases or the physical state of the substances in a chemical reaction are denoted in short form within a bracket, as the subscript of the formula, of the respective substances. For example, when solid potassium reacts with liquid water, it produces hydrogen gas and potassium hydroxide solution. All these information of the reaction is given in the chemical equation as shown below:</p>
	<p class="block_764">2K(solid) + 2H2O (Liquid) gives 2KOH (aqueous) + H2(gas)</p>
	<table class="table_50">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_459"><p class="block_765">Symbol</p></td>

		</tr>

		</tr>
