	<p class="block_768"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_282"><img src="images/image-148.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of C D E M O" class="calibre228"/></h2>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_283"> 10.1 TYPES OF CHEMICAL REACTIONS</h2>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_284">10.1.1 Classification based on the nature of rearrangements of atoms</h3>
	<p class="block_9">So far you studied about a chemical reaction and how it can be described as a chemical equation. A large number of chemical reactions are taking place around us every day. Are they taking place in a similar way? No. Each reaction involves different kinds of atoms and hence the way they react also differs. Thus, based on the manner by which the atoms of the reactants are rearranged, chemical reactions are classified as follows.</p>
	<p class="block_9">a. Combination reactions</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">A combination reaction is a reaction in which two or more reactants combine to form a compound. It is otherwise called 'synthesis reaction' or   'composition   reaction'.   When a reactant ‘A’ combines with ‘B’, it forms the product ‘AB’. The generalised scheme of a combination reaction is given below:</span></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-149.png" alt="the image shows general formula for combination reaction A plus B gives A B" class="calibre229"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">Example: Hydrogen gas combines with chlorine gas to form hydrogen chloride gas.</p>
	<p class="block_9">H2(gas) + Cl2(gas<span class="calibre15">)  </span>gives 2HCl(gas)</p>
	<p class="block_9">Depending on the chemical nature of the reactants, there are three classes of combination reactions:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66"><b class="calibre36">Element + Element gives Compound</b></li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_9">In this type of combination reaction, two elements react with one other to form a compound. The reaction may take place between a metal and a non-metal or two non-metals.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Example 1:</b> When solid sulphur reacts with oxygen, it produces sulphur dioxide. Here both the reactants are non-metals.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-150.png" alt="element plus element gives compound" class="calibre230"/></p>
	<p class="block_769"><span class="text_46">S</span><b class="calibre6">(solid)</b><span class="text_46">+O</span><b class="calibre6">2(gas<span class="calibre28">)  </span></b>gives<span class="text_46"> S O</span><b class="calibre6">2(gas)</b></p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Example 2:</b> Sodium, a silvery-white metal, combines with chlorine, a pale-yellow green gas, to form sodium chloride, an edible compound. Here one of the reactants is a metal (sodium) and the other (chlorine) is a non- metal.</p>
	<p class="block_770">2Na<span class="text_11">(solid)</span>+Cl<span class="text_11">2(gas)</span> gives 2NaCl<span class="text_11">(solid)</span></p>
	<p class="block_19">Test Yourself:</p>
	<p class="block_9">Identify the possible combination reactions between the metals and non-metals given in the following table and write their balanced chemical equations:</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<table class="table_51">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_463"><p class="block_765">Metals</p></td>
			<td class="td_464"><p class="block_771">Non-metals</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_465"><p class="block_765">Na, K, Cs, Ca, Mg</p></td>
			<td class="td_466"><p class="block_772"><span class="text_29">F, Cl, Br, </span>I</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66"><b class="calibre36">Compound + Element gives Compound</b></li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_9">In this case, a compound reacts with an element to form a new compound. For instance, phosphorous trichloride reacts with chlorine gas and forms phosphorous pentachloride.</p>
	<p class="block_773"><span class="text_46">P Cl</span>3(Iiquid) <span class="text_46">+Cl</span>2(gas)<span class="text_46"> gives P Cl</span>5(solid)</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66"><b class="calibre36">Compound + Compound gives Compound</b></li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_9">It is a reaction between two compounds to form a new compound. In the following reaction, silicon dioxide reacts with calcium oxide to form calcium silicate.</p>
	<p class="block_23">Si O2(solid) + Ca O(solid) gives C a S i O3(solid)</p>
	<p class="block_9">Most of the combination reactions are exothermic in nature. Because, they involve the formation of new bonds, which releases a huge amount of energy in the form of heat.</p>
	<p class="block_19">(b) Decomposition reactions</p>
	<p class="block_23">In a decomposition reaction, a single compound splits into two or more simpler substances under suitable conditions. It is the opposite of the combination reaction. The generalised scheme of a decomposition reaction is given below:</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image384.jpeg" alt="the image shows Decomposition reactions as A B gives A + B " class="calibre231"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">Breaking of bonds is the major phenomenon in a decomposition reaction and hence it requires energy to break the bonds, depending on the nature of the energy used in the decomposition reaction.</p>
	<p class="block_9">There are three main classes of decomposition reactions. They are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">Thermal Decomposition Reactions</li>
	<li class="block_66">Electrolytic Decomposition Reactions</li>
	<li class="block_66">Photo Decomposition Reactions</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know?</p>
	<p class="block_74">A solution of slaked lime is used for white washing walls. Calcium hydroxide reacts slowly with the carbon di oxide in air to form a thin layer of calcium carbonate on the walls. Calcium carbonate is formed after two to three days of white washing and gives a shiny finish to the walls. It is interesting to note that the chemical formula for marble is also CaCO3.</p>
	<p class="block_">Ca (O H)twice(aqueous) + C O2(gas) gives C a C O3(solid) + H2O(Iiquid)</p>
	<p class="block_12">1. Thermal Decomposition Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_">In this type of reaction, the reactant is decomposed by applying heat. For example, on heating mercury (II) oxide is decomposed into mercury metal and oxygen gas. As the molecule is dissociated by the absorption of heat, it is otherwise called ‘Thermolysis’. It is a class of compound to element by element decomposition. i.e. a compound (Hg O) is decomposed into two elements (Hg and Oxygen).</p>
	<p class="block_74">2Hg O(solid) when heated gives 2Hg(liquid)+ O2(gas)</p>
	<p class="block_">Similarly, when calcium carbonate is heated, it breaks down in to calcium oxide and carbon dioxide. It is a type of compound to compound/compound decomposition.</p>
	<p class="block_">C a C O3(solid) <span id="id_Hlk134694698" class="calibre203"> when heated gives Ca O + C O2(gas)</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">In   thermal   decomposition   reaction, heat is supplied to break the bonds. Such reactions, in which heat is absorbed, are called ‘Endothermic reactions.</span></p>
	<p class="block_12">(ii)Electrolytic Decomposition Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_">In some of the decomposition reactions, electrical energy is used to bring about the reaction. For example, decomposition of sodium chloride occurs on passing electric current through its aqueous solution. Sodium chloride decomposes in to metallic sodium and chlorine gas. This process is termed as ‘Electrolysis’.</p>
	<p class="block_74">2NaCI (aqueous)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>undergoes electrolytic decomposition gives 2Na(solid)+CI2(gas)</p>
	<p class="block_">Here, a compound (NaCl) is converted into elements (sodium and chlorine).So it is a type of compound to element by element decomposition.</p>
	<p class="block_12">(iii)Photo Decomposition Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_">Light is another form of energy, which facilitates some of the decomposition reactions. For example, when silver bromide is exposed to light, it breaks down into silver metal and bromine gas. As the decomposition is caused by light, this kind of reaction is also called ‘Photolysis’.</p>
	<p class="block_23"> <b class="calibre36">2</b>AgBr <b class="calibre36">(solid)<span class="calibre15">   </span></b><b class="calibre36">undergoes photo decomposition and gives 2</b>Ag <b class="calibre36">(solid) </b>+ Br<b class="calibre36">2(gas)</b></p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image386.jpeg" alt="figure 10.1 Photo decomposition of silver bromide is sown." class="calibre232"/></p>
	<p class="block_138">Figure 10.1 Photo decomposition of silver bromide</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">The yellow-coloured silver bromide turns into   grey   coloured   silver   metal.   It is also a compound to element/element decomposition.</span></p>
	<div class="calibre139">
	<div class="block_14"><span class="bullet_1">(a) </span><span class="calibre52"><b class="calibre6">Single Displacement Reactions</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">It is a reaction between an   element and a compound. When they react, one of the elements of the compound-reactant is replaced by   the   element-reactant   to   form a new compound and an element. The general schematic representation of a single displacement reaction is given as:</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image387.jpeg" alt="image shows general formule for Single Displacement Reactions as A + B C gives A C + B" class="calibre233"/></p>
	<p class="block_">‘A’ displaces element ‘B’ from the compound ‘B C’ and hence a single displacement reaction occurs. If zinc metal is placed in hydrochloric acid, hydrogen gas is evolved. Here, hydrogen is displaced by zinc metal and zinc chloride is formed.</p>
	<p class="block_61">Z n(Solid) + 2HCl(aqueous) gives Z n Cl2(aqueous) + H2(gas) </p>
	<p class="block_61">F e(Solid) + Cu S O4(aqueous) → F e S O4(aqueous) + Cu(Solid) </p>
	<p class="block_">If an iron nail is placed in an aqueous solution of copper (II) sulphate as shown in Fig. 10.2, the iron displaces copper from its aqueous solution and the so formed copper deposits over the iron nail.</p>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image389.jpeg" alt="figure 10.2 Displacement of copper Solutions is shown." class="calibre234"/></p>
	<p class="block_138">Figure 10.2 Displacement of copper</p>
	<p class="block_61">It is easy to propose so many reactions of this kind with different combinations of reactants. Will they all occur in practice? No. This is most easily demonstrated with halogens. Let us consider the following two reactions: 2NaCl <b class="calibre6">(aqueous) </b>+ F<b class="calibre6">2(gas) gives</b> 2Na F<b class="calibre6">(aqueous) </b>+ Cl<b class="calibre6">2(gas) </b></p>
	<p class="block_61">2Na F<b class="calibre6">(aqueous) </b>+ Cl<b class="calibre6">2(gas)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>gives</b> 2Na Cl<b class="calibre6">(aqueous) </b>+ F<b class="calibre6">2(gas)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub></b></p>
	<p class="block_">The first reaction involves the displacement of chlorine from NaCl, by fluorine. In the second reaction, chlorine displaces fluorine from NaF. Out of these two, the second reaction will not occur. Because, fluorine is more active than chlorine and occupies the upper position in the periodic table. So, in displacement reactions, the activity of the elements and their relative position in the periodic table are the key factors to determine the feasibility of the reactions. More active elements readily displace fewer active elements from their aqueous solution. The activity series of some elements is given below:</p>
	<table class="table_2">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_467"><div class="calibre235">

</div><p class="block_9">Penguin</p></td>

	<p class="block_9">By referring the activity series, try to answer the following questions:</p>
	<p class="block_9">Which of the metals displaces hydrogen gas from hydrochloric acid? Silver or Zinc. Give the chemical equation of the reaction and justify your answer.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Activity 10.1</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">Take about 50 ml of toilet cleaning acid in a beaker</li>
	<li class="block_66">Place a small iron nail in it</li>
	<li class="block_66">Wait for about 10 minutes</li>
	<li class="block_66">Observe what happen in the beaker</li>
	<li class="block_66">Do you recognize any change?</li>
	<li class="block_66">Report your observations with the chemical equation.</li>
</ul>
	<div class="calibre139">
	<div class="block_14"><span class="bullet_1">(b) </span><span class="calibre52"><b class="calibre6">Double Displacement Reactions</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_">When two compounds react, if their ions are interchanged, then the reaction is called double displacement reaction. The ion of one compound is replaced by the ion of another compound. Ions of identical charges are only interchanged, i.e., a cation can be replaced by other cations. This reaction is also called ‘Metathesis Reaction’. The schematic representation of a double displacement reaction is given below.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-151.png" alt="the image shows Double Displacement Reactions as A B + C D gives A D + C B" class="calibre236"/></p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">For a double   displacement   reaction to take place, one of the products must be a precipitate or water. By this way, there are major classes of double displacement reactions. They are:</span></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">(1)<span class="tab1">      </span>Precipitation Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_9">(ii)<span class="tab1">      </span>Neutralization Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">(1) Precipitation Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_">When aqueous solutions of two compounds are mixed, if they react to form an insoluble compound and a soluble compound, then it is called precipitation reaction. Because the insoluble compound, formed as one of the products, is a precipitate and hence the reaction is so called.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Table 10.1 Differences between combination and decomposition reactions</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<table class="table_52">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_470"><p class="block_780">COMBINATION</p><p class="block_780">REACTIONS</p></td>
			<td class="td_471"><p class="block_781">DECOMPOSITIONREACTIONS</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_472"><p class="block_782">One or more reactants combine to form a single product</p></td>
			<td class="td_473"><p class="block_783">A single reactant is decomposed to form one or more products</p></td>
		</tr>

			<td class="td_474"><p class="block_82"><span class="text_29">Energy </span>is released</p></td>

	<p class="block_12">(ii) Neutralization Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_">In your lower classes, you have learnt the reaction between an acid and a base. It is another type of displacement reaction in which the acid reacts with the base to form a salt and water. It is called 'neutralization reaction' as both acid and base neutralize each other.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-152.png" alt="Neutralization Reactions is as follows acid + base give salt + water." class="calibre238"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Reaction of sodium hydroxide with hydrochloric acid is a typical neutralization reaction. Here, sodium replaces hydrogen from hydrochloric acid forming sodium chloride, a neutral soluble salt.</p>
	<p class="block_207"><span class="tab">      </span>NaOH<b class="calibre6">(aqueous) </b>+ HCl<b class="calibre6">(aqueous) gives</b> NaCl <b class="calibre6">(aqueous) </b>+ H<b class="calibre6">2</b>O<b class="calibre6">(liquid)</b></p>
	<p class="block_">Similarly, when ammonium hydroxide reacts with nitric acid, it forms ammonium nitrate and water.</p>
	<p class="block_207"><span class="tab">      </span>NH4O H<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>(aqueous) + H N O3(aqueous) gives NH4N O3(aqueous)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>+ H2O (liquid)</p>
	<p class="block_12">(d.)Combustion Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_">A combustion reaction is one in which the reactant rapidly combines with oxygen to form one or more oxides and energy (heat). So in combustion reactions, one of the reactants must be oxygen. Combustion reactions are majorly used as heat energy sources in many of our day-to-day activities. For instance, we use LPG gas for domestic cooking purposes. We get heat and flame from LPG gas by its combustion reaction of its constituent gases. LPG is a mixture of hydrocarbon gases like propane, butane, propylene, etc. All these hydrocarbons burn with oxygen to form carbon dioxide and water.</p>
	<p class="block_786"><img src="images/image400.jpeg" alt="the image shows conceptual thoughts. all combustion reactions are oxidations but all oxidations are not combustions. why?" class="calibre239"/><span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_786">C<span class="text_47">3</span>H<span class="text_47">8(gas)</span>+5O<span class="text_47">2(gas) gives </span>3C O<span class="text_47">2(gas)</span>+4H<span class="text_47">2</span>O<span class="text_47">(gas)</span>+ Heat</p>
	<p class="block_9">Since heat is evolved, it is an exothermic reaction. As oxygen is added, it is also an oxidation. So, combustion may be called as an exothermic oxidation. If a flame is formed (as shown in Figure 10.4), then it is called burning.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image399.png" alt="figure 10.4 Combustion of LPG gas is shown. " class="calibre240"/></p>
	<p class="block_12"><span class="calibre28">   Figure 10.4 Combustion of LPG gas</span></p>
	<p class="block_12">Which of the following is a combustion?</p>
	<p class="block_">(i) Digestion of Food</p>
	<p class="block_">(ii) Rusting of iron</p>
	<p class="block_">Many thousands of reactions fall under these five categories and further you will learn in detail about these reactions in your higher classes.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_285">10.1.2 Classification based on the direction of the reaction</h3>
	<p class="block_74"><img src="images/image402.jpeg" alt="figure 10.5 Recharging of mobile battery is shown" class="calibre241"/><img src="images/image401.jpeg" alt="figure 10.5 Burning of wood is shown.  " class="calibre242"/></p>
	<p class="block_138">Figure 10.5 Burning of wood and recharging of mobile battery</p>
	<p class="block_">You know that innumerable changes occur every day around us. Are all they permanent? For example, liquid water freezes into ice, but then ice melts into liquid water. In other words, freezing is reversed. So, it is not a permanent change. Moreover, it is a physical change. Physical changes can be reversed easily. Can chemical changes be reversed? Can the products be converted into reactants? Let us consider the burning of a wood. The carbon compounds present in the wood are burnt into carbon dioxide gas and water. Can we get back the wood immediately from carbon dioxide and water? We cannot. So, it is a permanent change. In most of the cases, we cannot. But some chemical reactions can be reversed. Our mobile phone gets energy from its lithium-ion battery by chemical reactions. It is called discharging. On recharging the mobile, these chemical reactions are reversed. Thus, chemical reactions may be reversed under suitable conditions. Hence, they are grouped into two categories such as reversible and irreversible reactions.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Reversible Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_9">A reversible reaction is a reaction that can be reversed, i.e., the products can be converted back to the reactants. A reversible reaction is represented by a double arrow with their heads in the direction opposite to each other. Thus, a reversible reaction can be represented by the following equation:</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image403.jpeg" alt="the image shows general formula for Reversible Reactions as follows  forward reaction A B gives A + B reverse reaction A + B gives A B thus the reaction can take place in two directions so it is called as reversible reaction." class="calibre243"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">Explanation: Here, the compound ‘A B’ undergoes decomposition to form the products ‘A’ and ‘B’. It is the forward reaction. As soon as the products are formed, they combine together to form ‘A B’. It is the backward reaction. So, the reaction takes place in both the directions. Do you think then that no products are formed in the aforesaid reaction? If you think so, you are wrong. Because, even though the reaction takes place in both the directions, at the initial stage the rates (speed) of these reactions are not equal. Consider the following decomposition reaction of phosphorous pentachloride into phosphorous trichloride and chlorine.</p>
	<p class="block_61">P Cl<b class="calibre6">5(gas)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>undergoes reversible reaction and gives </b>P Cl<b class="calibre6">3(gas)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub></b>+ Cl<b class="calibre6">2(gas)</b></p>
	<p class="block_9">The forward reaction is the decomposition of PCl5 and the backward reaction is the combination of PCl3 and Cl2. Initially, the forward reaction proceeds faster than the backward reaction. After sometimes, the speed of both the reactions become equal. So, PCl5 cannot be completely converted into the products as the reaction is reversed. It is a reversible reaction. The actual measurements of the given reaction show that the reaction is at equilibrium, but the amount of PCl5 is more than that of P Cl3 and Cl2.</p>
	<p class="block_12">MORE TO KNOW</p>
	<p class="block_">If hydrogen peroxide is poured on a wound, it decomposes into water and oxygen. The gaseous oxygen bubbles away as it is formed and thus prevent the formation of H2O2.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-153.png" alt="the image shows Hydrogen Peroxide on a wound " class="calibre244"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Thus, more amount   of   products   can be obtained in a reversible reaction by the periodical removal of one of the products or the periodical addition of the reactants.</span></p>
	<p class="block_61">2H<b class="calibre6">2</b>O<b class="calibre6">2(aqueous)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub></b> under goes reversible reaction and gives 2H2O <b class="calibre6">(liquid) </b>+ O<b class="calibre6">2(gas)</b></p>
	<p class="block_19">Irreversible Reactions</p>
	<p class="block_23">The reaction that cannot be reversed is called irreversible reaction. The irreversible reactions are unidirectional, i.e., they take place only in the forward direction. Consider the combustion of coal into carbon dioxide and water.</p>
	<p class="block_61">C<b class="calibre6">(solid) </b>+ O<b class="calibre6">2(gas)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub><sub class="calibre25"> </sub>gives</b> CO<b class="calibre6">2(gas)<sub class="calibre25"> </sub></b>+ Heat</p>
	<p class="block_61">Coal + Oxygen gives <i class="calibre33">Carbon dioxide + heat.</i></p>
	<p class="block_9">In this reaction, solid coal burns with oxygen and gets converted into carbon dioxide gas and water. As the product is a gas, as soon as it is formed it escapes out of the reaction container. It is extremely hard to decompose a gas into a solid. Thus, the backward reaction is not possible in this case. So, it is an irreversible reaction. Table 10.2 provides the main differences between a reversible and an irreversible reaction:</p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 10.2 Differences between reversible and irreversible reactions</p>
	<table class="table_53">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_478"><p class="block_787">REVERSIBLE REACTION</p></td>
			<td class="td_479"><p class="block_788">IRREVERSIBLE REACTION</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_480"><p class="block_789">It can be reversed under suitable conditions.</p></td>
			<td class="td_481"><p class="block_790">It cannot be reversed.</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_482"><p class="block_791">Both forward and backward</p><p class="block_792">reactions take place</p><p class="block_793">simultaneously.</p></td>
			<td class="td_483"><p class="block_794">It is unidirectional. It proceeds only in forward direction.</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_480"><p class="block_795">It attains equilibrium.</p></td>
			<td class="td_481"><p class="block_796">Equilibrium is not attained.</p></td>

	<p class="block_23">You will learn more about these reactions in your higher classes.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_286">10.2 RATE OF A CHEMICAL REACTION</h2>
	<p class="block_">So far, we discussed various types of chemical reactions and the nature of the reactants and products. Let us consider the following reactions:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Rusting of iron</li>
	<li class="block_7">Digestion of food</li>
	<li class="block_7">Burning of petrol</li>
	<li class="block_8">Weathering of rock</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_">How fast is each reaction? Rank them from the slowest to fastest. How will you determine, which is the fastest and which is the slowest? One of the ways to find out how fast a reaction is as follows: Measure the number of reactants or products before and after a specific period of time. For example, let us assume that 100 gram of a substance ‘A’ undergoes a reaction and after an hour 50 gram of ‘A’ is left.</p>
	<p class="block_">A gives<span class="calibre28">  Product</span></p>
	<p class="block_">In another instance, 100 gram of substance ‘C’ undergoes a reaction and after an hour, 20 g of ‘C’ is left.</p>
	<p class="block_800">C gives<span class="calibre28">  Product</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Can you say which is the faster reaction? In the first reaction, 50 gram of the reactant (A) is converted into products whereas in the second reaction 80 gram of the reactant is converted into products in one hour. So, the second reaction is faster. This measurement is called ‘the reaction rate’.</p>
	<p class="block_">“Rate of a reaction is the change in the amount or concentration of any one of the reactants or products per unit time”.</p>
	<p class="block_">Consider the following reaction <i class="calibre33">A </i>gives B</p>
	<p class="block_">The rate of the reaction is given by</p>
	<p class="block_"> </p>
	<p class="block_61">rate = minus d square bracket A divided by d t = + d square bracket of B divided by d t<span class="tab">      </span><span class="calibre28">   </span><span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_">square bracket of A is concentration of A</p>
	<p class="block_">square bracket of B is concentration of B</p>
	<p class="block_">d t is change in time</p>
	<p class="block_">The negative sign indicates the decrease in the concentration of A with time.</p>
	<p class="block_">The positive sign indicates the increase in the concentration of B with time.</p>
	<p class="block_">Note: square bracket represents the concentration, ‘d’ represents the infinitesimal change in the concentration.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Why is reaction rate important?</p>
	<p class="block_">Faster the reaction, more will be the amount of the product in a specified time. So, the rate of a reaction is important for a chemist for designing a process to get a good yield of a product. Rate of reaction is also important for a food processor who hopes to slow down the reactions that cause food to spoil.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_287">10.2.1 Factors influencing the rate of a reaction</h3>
	<p class="block_">Can the rate of a reaction be changed? The rate of a reaction can be changed. For example, iron gets rusted faster in an acid than in water. Important factors that affect rate of a reaction are</p>
	<p class="block_">1. Nature of the reactants</p>
	<p class="block_">2. Concentration of the reactants</p>
	<p class="block_">3. Temperature</p>
	<p class="block_">4. Catalyst</p>
	<p class="block_">5.Pressure</p>
	<p class="block_">6. Surface area of the reactants</p>
	<p class="block_12">(1) Nature of the reactants</p>
	<p class="block_">The reaction of sodium with hydrochloric acid is faster than that with acetic acid. Do you know why? Hydrochloric acid is a stronger acid than acetic acid and thus more reactive. So, the nature of the reactants influences the reaction rate.</p>
	<p class="block_801">2Na<span class="text_48">(solid)</span>+2HCl<span class="text_48">(aquoes) gives </span>2NaCl<span class="text_48">(aqueous)</span>+H<span class="text_48">2(g)</span>(fast)</p>
	<p class="block_802">2Na<span class="text_48">(solid)</span>+2CH<span class="text_48">3</span>COOH<span class="text_48">(aqueous) </span>gives 2CH<span class="text_48">3</span>COONa<span class="text_48">(aqueous)</span>+H<span class="text_48">2(gas)</span>(slow)</p>
	<p class="block_19">(ii) Concentration of the reactants</p>
	<p class="block_9">Changing the amount of the reactants also increases the reaction rate. The amount of the substance present in a certain volume of the solution is called ‘concentration’. More the concentration, more particles per volume exist in it and hence faster the reaction. Granulated zinc reacts faster with </p>
	<p class="block_9">2M hydrochloric acid than 1M hydrochloric acid.</p>
	<p class="block_19">(iii) Temperature</p>
	<p class="block_9">Most of the reactions go faster at higher temperature. Because adding heat to the reactants provides energy to break more bonds and thus speed up the reaction. Calcium carbonate reacts slowly with hydrochloric acid at room temperature. When the reaction mixture is heated the reaction rate increases.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know?</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Food kept at room temperature spoils faster  than  that  kept in the refrigerator. In the refrigerator, the temperature is lower than the room temperature and hence the reaction rate is less.</span></p>
	<p class="block_12">(iv) Pressure</p>
	<p class="block_">If the reactants are gases, increasing their pressure increases the reaction rate. This is because, on increasing the pressure the reacting particles come closer and collide frequently.</p>
	<p class="block_12">(5) Catalyst</p>
	<p class="block_">A catalyst is a substance which increases the reaction rate without being consumed in the reaction. In certain reactions, adding a substance as catalyst speeds up the reaction. For example, on heating potassium chlorate, it decomposes into potassium chloride and oxygen gas, but at a slower rate. If manganese dioxide is added, it increases the reaction rate.</p>
	<p class="block_12">(vi) Surface area of the reactants</p>
	<p class="block_">When solid reactants are involved in a reaction, their powdered form reacts more readily. For example, powdered calcium carbonate reacts more readily with hydrochloric acid than marble chips. Because, powdering of the reactants increases the surface area and more energy is available on collision of the reactant particles. Thus, the reaction rate is increased.</p>
	<p class="block_">You will study more about reaction rate in you higher classes.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_288">10.3 STATE OF EQUILIBRIUM</h2>
	<p class="block_">In a reversible reaction, both forward and backward reactions take place simultaneously. When the rate of the forward reaction becomes equal to the rate of backward reaction, then no more product is formed. This stage of the reaction is called ‘equilibrium state’. After this stage, no net change in the reaction can occur and hence in the amount of the reactants and products. Since this equilibrium is attained in a chemical reaction, it is called ‘Chemical Equilibrium’. </p>
	<p class="block_">Chemical Equilibrium: It is state of a reversible chemical reaction in which no change in the amount of the reactants and products takes place. At equilibrium,</p>
	<p class="block_">Rate of forward reaction = Rate of backward reaction.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Explanation:</b><span class="calibre28"> Initially the rate of the forward reaction is greater than the rate of the backward reaction. However, during the course of reaction, the concentration of the reactants decreases   and   the   concentration of the products increases. Since the rate of a reaction is directly proportional to the concentration, the rate of the forward reaction decreases with time, whereas the rate of the backward reaction increases.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">At a certain stage, both the rates become equal. From this point onwards, there will be no change in the concentrations of both the reactants and the products with time. This state is called as equilibrium state.</p>
	<p class="block_">Let us consider the decomposition of calcium carbonate into lime and carbon dioxide. It is a reversible reaction. The speed of each reaction can be determined by how quickly the reactant disappears. If the reaction is carried out in a closed vessel, it reaches a chemical equilibrium. At this stage,</p>
	<p class="block_803">C a C O<b class="calibre6">3(solid) undergoes reversible reaction and gives </b>C<span class="calibre28">  </span>aO<b class="calibre6">(solid) </b>+ C O<b class="calibre6">2(gas)</b></p>
	<p class="block_803">The rate of decomposition of C a C O3 = The rate of combination of C a O and C O2</p>
	<p class="block_803">Not only chemical changes, physical changes also may attain equilibrium. When water kept in a closed vessel evaporates, it forms water vapour. No water vapour escapes out of the container as the process takes place in a closed vessel. So, it builds up the vapour pressure in the container. At one time, the water vapour condenses back into liquid water and when the rate of this condensation becomes equal to that of vaporisation, the process attains equilibrium.</p>
	<p class="block_803">At this stage, the volume of the liquid and gaseous phases remains constant. Since it is a physical change, the equilibrium attained is called ‘Physical Equilibrium’. Physical equilibrium is a state of a physical change at which the volume of all the phases remains unchanged.</p>
	<p class="block_803"><span class="calibre28">                   </span></p>
	<p class="block_61">H<b class="calibre6">2</b>O<b class="calibre6">(liquid) undergoes condensation which is reversible and gives </b>H<b class="calibre6">2</b>O(gas) <sub class="calibre25"><span class="calibre15">   </span></sub></p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image408.jpeg" alt="figure 10.6 shows State of physical equilibrium  Solutions. it contains three images. in first image water pressure is high and vapour pressure is very low. in second image vapour pressure increase as water undergoes evaporation. in third image water pressure and vapour pressure becomes equal thus physical equilibrium is attained. " class="calibre245"/></p>
	<p class="block_12"><span class="calibre28">  Figure 10.6 State of physical equilibrium</span></p>
	<p class="block_12">Characteristics of equilibrium</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">In a chemical equilibrium, the rates of the forward and backward reactions are equal.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The observable properties such as pressure, concentration, colour, density, viscosity etc., of the system remain unchanged with time.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The chemical equilibrium is a dynamic equilibrium, because both the forward and backward reactions continue to occur even though it appears static externally.</li>
	<li class="block_8">In physical equilibrium, the volume of all the phases remain constant.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know?</p>
	<p class="block_">Aerated soft drinks contain dissolved carbon dioxide in a pop bottle (Soda). When the bottle is sealed,the dissolved carbon dioxide (in the form of carbonic acid) and gaseous C O2 are in equilibrium with each other. When you open the bottle, the gaseous C O2 can escape. So, the dissolved C O2 begins to undissolve back to the gas phase trying to replace the gas that was lost, <span class="calibre28">when you opened the bottle. That’s why if you leave it open long enough, it  goes ‘flat’. All the C</span> O2 will be gone, blown away in the air.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_289">10.4 IONIC PRODUCT OF WATER</h2>
	<p class="block_">Although pure water is often considered as a non-conductor of electricity, precise measurements show that it conducts electricity to a little extent. This conductivity of water has resulted from the self-ionisation of water. Self- ionisation or auto ionisation is a reaction in which two like molecules react to give ions. In the process of ionisation of water, a proton from one water molecule is transferred to another water molecule leaving behind an O H negative ion. The proton gets dissolved in water forming the hydronium ion as shown in the following equation:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-154.png" alt="the image shows IONIC PRODUCT OF WATER 2 water molecules combine to give H3O positive ion and one O H negative ion. H2O (Liquid) + H2O (liquid) gives H 3 O positive ion (aqueous) + O H minus ion (aqueous)." class="calibre246"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">The hydronium ion formed is a strong acid and the hydroxyl ion is a strong base. So as fast as they are formed, they react again to produce water. Thus, it is a reversible reaction and attains equilibrium very quickly.   So, the extent of ionisation is very little and the concentration of the ions produced is also very less. The product of the concentration of the hydronium ion and the hydroxyl ion is called‘ionic product of water’. It is denoted as ‘K</span> w’. It is mathematically expressed as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_804">K w = concentration of H3O+ ion into concentration of O H negative ion. </p>
	<p class="block_">Concentrarion of H3O + ion  may be simply written as concentration of H +ion. Thus the ionic product of water may also be expressed as</p>
	<p class="block_805">K w = concentration of H + ion in to concentration of O H negative ion.</p>
	<p class="block_">Its unit is mol square deci meter power minus 6. At 25° C, its value is 1.00 × 10power minus 14.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_290">10.5 pH SCALE</h2>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">All the aqueous solutions may contain hydrogen and hydroxyl ions due to self- ionisation of water. In addition to this ionisation, substances dissolved in   water also may produce hydrogen ions or hydroxyl ions. The concentration of these ions decides whether the solution is acidic or basic. pH scale is a scale for measuring the hydrogen ion concentration in a solution. The 'p' in pH stands for ‘Potenz’ in German meaning 'power'. pH notation was devised by the Danish biochemist Sorensen in 1909. pH scale is a set of numbers from 0 to 14 which is used to indicate whether a solution is acidic, basic or neutral.</span></p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Acids have pH less than 7</li>
	<li class="block_7">Bases have pH greater than 7</li>
	<li class="block_8">A neutral solution has pH equal to 7</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_">The pH is the negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration</p>
	<p class="block_">That is  pH = minus log base 10 concentration of H+ ion</p>

	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_">How can we measure the pH of a given solution using pH Paper</p>
	<p class="block_">The pH of a solution can be determined by using a universal indicator. It contains a mixture of dyes. It comes in the form of a solution or a pH paper.</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-155.png" alt="figure 10.7 pH indication with different pH level for acid neutral and base is shown." class="calibre247"/></p>
	<p class="block_138">Figure 10.7 pH Indicator</p>
	<p class="block_9">A more common method of measuring pH in a school laboratory is by using the pH paper. A pH paper contains a mixture of indicators. It shows a specific colour at a given pH. A colour guide is provided with the bottle of the indicator or the strips of paper impregnated with it, which are called pH paper strips. The test solution is tested with a drop of the universal indicator, or a drop of the test solution is put on the pH paper. The colour of the solution on the pH paper is compared with the colour chart and the pH value is read from it. The pH values thus obtained are only approximate values.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_291">10.6 ROLE OF pH IN EVERYDAY LIFE</h2>
	<p class="block_12">Are plants and animals pH sensitive?</p>
	<p class="block_">Our body works within the pH range of 7.0 to 7.8. Living organisms can survive only in a narrow range of pH change. Different body fluids have different pH values. For example, pH of blood is ranging from 7.35 to 7.45. Any increase or decrease in this value leads to diseases. The ideal pH for blood is 7.4.</p>
	<p class="block_19">pH in our digestive system</p>
	<p class="block_23">It is very interesting to note that our stomach produces hydrochloric acid. It helps in the digestion of food without harming the stomach. During indigestion the stomach produces too much acid and this causes pain and irritation. pH of the stomach fluid is approximately 2.0.</p>
	<p class="block_19">pH changes as the cause of tooth decay</p>
	<p class="block_23">pH of the saliva normally ranges between6.5 to 7.5. White enamel coating of our teeth is calcium phosphate, the hardest substance in our body. When the pH of the mouth saliva falls below 5.5, the enamel gets weathered. Toothpastes, which are generally basic are used for cleaning the teeth that can neutralise the excess acid and prevent tooth decay.</p>
	<p class="block_19">pH of soil</p>
	<p class="block_9">In agriculture, the pH of the soil is very important. Citrus fruits require slightly alkaline soil, while rice requires acidic soil and sugarcane requires neutral soil.</p>
	<p class="block_19">pH of rain water</p>
	<p class="block_23">The pH of rain water is approximately 7, which means that it is neutral and also represents its high purity. If the atmospheric air is polluted with oxide gases of sulphur and nitrogen, they get dissolved in the rain water and make its pH less than 7. Thus, if the pH of rain water is less than 7, then it is called acid rain. When acid rain flows into the rivers it lowers the pH of the river water also.</p>
	<p class="block_23"><img src="images/image-156.png" alt="image shows conceptual thoughts Why is pure water has ph 7 at room temperature" class="calibre248"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">The survival of aquatic life in such rivers becomes difficult.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_292">10.7 pH CALCULATION</h2>
	<p class="block_813">The pH is the negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">pH= minus log base</b><span class="text_47">10 concentration of </span><b class="calibre6">H+ ion</b></p>
	<p class="block_814"><b class="calibre6">Example: </b>Calculate the pH of 0.01MHNO3?</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_815">Concentration of H+ ion = 0.01</p>
	<p class="block_816">pH = minus log base<span class="text_11">10 concentration of </span>H+ ion</p>
	<p class="block_816">pH = minus log base10 [0.01]</p>
	<p class="block_817">pH= minus log [1×10<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>power minus 2]</p>
	<p class="block_818">pH= minus (log base<span class="text_11">10</span>1 minus 2log base<span class="text_11">10 </span>10)</p>
	<p class="block_818">pH = 0 + 2×log base 10 10</p>
	<p class="block_819">pH = 0 + 2×1 = 2</p>
	<p class="block_820">pH= 2</p>
	<p class="block_821"><b class="calibre6">pOH: </b>The pOH of an aqueous solution is related to the pH.</p>
	<p class="block_822">The pOH is the negative logarithm of the hydroxyl ion concentration</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">pOH = minus log10 concentration of OH </b>negative ion</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Example:</b> The hydroxyl ion concentration of a solution is 1 × 10 power minus 9 M. What is the p O H of the solution?</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solution</p>
	<p class="block_74">p O H = minus log base 10 concentration of O H<sup class="calibre27"> </sup>negative ion</p>
	<p class="block_74">p O H = minus log base10 [1x10 power minus 9]</p>
	<p class="block_74">p O H = minus (log base10<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>1 + log base10 10 power minus 9 ) </p>
	<p class="block_74">p O H = minus (0 minus 9 log base10 10)</p>
	<p class="block_74">p O H = minus(0 minus 9)</p>
	<p class="block_74">p O H = 9</p>
	<p class="block_12">Relationship between pH and p O H</p>
	<p class="block_821">The pH and p O H of a water solution at 25<sup class="calibre27">o</sup>C are related by the following equation.</p>
	<p class="block_12">pH + p O H = 14</p>
	<p class="block_823">If either the pH or the p O H of a solution is known, the other value can be calculated.</p>
	<p class="block_822"><b class="calibre6">Example: </b>A solution has a p O H of 11.76.What is the pH of this solution?</p>
	<p class="block_824">pH=14 minus p O H</p>
	<p class="block_825">pH=14 minus 11.76 = 2.24</p>
	<p class="block_826">10.8 Problems</p>
	<p class="block_826">Example 1: Calculate the pH of 0.001 molar solution of HCl.</p>
	<p class="block_826">Solution: HCl is a strong acid and is completely dissociated in its solutions according to the</p>
	<p class="block_826">process: </p>
	<p class="block_826">HCl(aqueous) gives H+ ion(aqueous) + Cl negative ion (aqueous)</p>
	<p class="block_826">From this process it is clear that one mole of HCl would give one mole of H+ions.</p>
	<p class="block_826">Therefore, the concentration of H+ ions would be equal to that of HCl, that is 0.001 molar or</p>
	<p class="block_826">1.0 × 10 power minus 3  mol litre power minus 1.</p>
	<p class="block_826">Thus, concentration of H+ ion = 1 × 10 power minus3 mol litre power minus 1</p>
	<p class="block_826">pH = minus log base 10 concentration of H+ ion = minus log base10 10 power minus3</p>
	<p class="block_826">= minus into (minus3 × log base10 10) = (3 × 1) = 3</p>
	<p class="block_826">Thus, pH = 3</p>
	<p class="block_826">Example 2: What would be the pH of an aqueous solution of sulphuricacid which is 5 × 10 power minus 5 mol litre power minus 1 in concentration.</p>
	<p class="block_826">Solution: Sulphuric acid dissociates in water as:</p>
	<p class="block_826">H2 S O 4(aqueous) gives 2 H+(aqueous) + S O4 2miuns ion (aqueous)</p>
	<p class="block_826">Each mole of sulphuric acid gives two mole of H+ ions in the solution. One litre of H2</p>
	<p class="block_826">S O4 solution contains 5 × 10 power minus 5 moles of H2 S O4 which would give 2 × 5 × 10 power minus 5 = 10 × 10 power minus 5 or 1.0 × 10 power minus 4 moles of H+ ion in one litre of the solution.</p>
	<p class="block_826">Therefore,</p>
	<p class="block_826">Concentration H+ ion = 1.0 × 10 power minus 4 mol litre power minus 1</p>
	<p class="block_826">pH = minus log base10 concentration of H+ ion</p>
	<p class="block_826"> = minus log base 10 10 power minus 4 </p>
	<p class="block_826">= minus into (minus4 × log base10 10)</p>
	<p class="block_826">= minus into(minus4 × 1) = 4</p>
	<p class="block_826">Example 3: Calculate the pH of 1 × 10 power minus 4  molar solution of NaOH.</p>
	<p class="block_826">Solution: NaOH is a strong base and dissociates in its solution as:</p>
	<p class="block_826">Na O H(aqueous) gives Na +ion (aqueous) + O H minus ion (aqueous)</p>
	<p class="block_826">One mole of NaOH would give one mole ofO H negative ion. Therefore</p>
	<p class="block_826">Concentration of O H negative ion = 1 × 10 power minus 4 mol litre power minus 1</p>
	<p class="block_826">p O H = minus log base10 concentration of O H negative ion</p>
	<p class="block_826"> = minus log base10 × [10power minus 4]</p>
	<p class="block_826">= minus into (minus 4 × log base10 10)</p>
	<p class="block_826">= minus into (minus 4) = 4</p>
	<p class="block_827"> </p>
	<p class="block_826">Since, pH + p O H = 14</p>
	<p class="block_826">pH = 14 minus p O H = 14 minus 4 </p>
	<p class="block_826">= 10.</p>
	<p class="block_826">Example 4: Calculate the pH of a solution in which the concentration of the hydrogen ions is 1.0 × 10 power minus 8 mol litre power minus 1.</p>
	<p class="block_826">Solution: Here, although the solution is extremely dilute, the concentration given is not of an acid or a base but that of H+ ions. Hence, the pH can be calculated from the relation:</p>
	<p class="block_826">pH = minus log base10 concentration of H+ ion</p>
	<p class="block_826">given concentration of H+ ion = 1.0 × 10 power minus 8 mol litre power minus 1</p>
	<p class="block_826">pH = minus log base 10 10 power minus8 </p>
	<p class="block_826">= minus into (minus 8 × log base10 10)</p>
	<p class="block_826">= minus into (minus8 × 1) </p>
	<p class="block_826">= 8</p>
	<p class="block_826">Example 5: If the pH of a solution is 4.5, what is its p O H?</p>
	<p class="block_826">Solution:</p>
	<p class="block_826">pH + p O H = 14</p>
	<p class="block_826">p O H = 14 minus 4.5 = 9.5</p>
	<p class="block_826">pOH = 9.5</p>
	<p class="block_826">points to remember</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_828">A chemical change is a change in which one or more new substances are formed.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Most combination reactions are exothermic</li>
	<li class="block_828">All photo decomposition reaction are endothermic reactions.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Double displacement reaction or metathesis may occur by the mutal exchange of ions.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Precipitation reaction gives an insoluble salt as the product.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Neutralisation reactions are reactions between an acid and a base that forms salt and water.</li>
	<li class="block_828"> Neutralisation prevents tooth decay.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Most reactions in chemistry are irreversible reactions.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Chemical equilibrium-the rate of the forward reaction is equal to rate of the back ward reactions.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Equilibrium is possible in a closed system.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Temperature increases the reaction rate.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Pressure increases the reaction rate.</li>
	<li class="block_828">The term pH means power of hydrogen.</li>
	<li class="block_828">pH plays a vital role in everyday life.</li>
	<li class="block_828">In humans all bio chemical reactions take place between the pH value of 7.0 to 7.8.</li>
	<li class="block_828">If pH of rain water is below 5.6 its called acid rain.</li>
	<li class="block_828">Pure water is a weak electrolyte.</li>
</ul>

	<p class="block_25">a. A(solid) + B(solid) gives C(solid) + D(solid)</p>

	<p class="block_25">d. A(aqueous) + B(solid) gives C(aqueous) + D(liquid)</p>
	<p class="block_25">9. The pH of a solution is 3. Its [OH<sup class="calibre27">–]</sup> concentration is</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_296">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_9">After studying this lesson, the student will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">know the importance of organic compounds.</li>

</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_297">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">You have studied, in your lower classes, that carbon is an inseparable element in human life as we use innumerable number of carbon compounds in our day-to-day life. Because, the food we eat, medicines we take when ill, clothes we wear; domestic and automobile fuels, paint, cosmetics, automobile parts, etc., that we use contain   carbon   compounds.   The   number of carbon compounds found in nature and man-made, is much higher than that of any other element in the periodic table. In fact there are more than 5 million compounds of carbon. The unique nature of carbon, such as catenation, tetravalency and multiple bonding, enables it to combine with itself or other elements like hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, sulphur etc., and hence form large number of compounds. All these compounds are made of covalent bonds. These compounds are called organic compounds. In this lesson, you will learn about carbon compounds.</span></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_298">11.1 GENERAL CHARACTERISTICS OF ORGANIC COMPOUNDS</h2>
	<p class="block_23">Everything in this world has unique character, similarly organic compounds are unique in their characteristics. Some of them are given below:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">Organic compounds have a high molecular weight and a complex structure.</li>
	<li class="block_66">They are mostly insoluble in water, but soluble in organic solvents such as ether, carbon tetrachloride, toluene, etc.</li>
	<li class="block_66">They are highly inflammable in nature</li>
	<li class="block_66">Organic compounds are less reactive compared to inorganic compounds. Hence, the reactions involving organic compounds proceed at slower rates.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Mostly organic compounds form covalent bonds in nature.</li>
	<li class="block_66">They have lower melting point and boiling point when compared to inorganic compounds</li>
	<li class="block_66">They exhibit the phenomenon of isomerism, in which a single molecular formula represents several organic compounds that differ in their physical and chemical properties</li>
	<li class="block_66">They are volatile in nature.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Organic compounds can be prepared in the laboratory</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_299">11.2 CLASSIFICATION OF ORGANIC COMPOUNDS BASED ON THE PATTERN OF CARBON CHAIN</h2>
	<p class="block_">What is the significance of classification? There are millions of organic compounds known and many new organic compounds are discovered every year in nature or synthesized in laboratory. This may mystify organic chemistry to a large extent. However, a unique molecular structure can be assigned to each compound and it can be listed by using systematic methods of classification and eventually named on the basis of its structural arrangements. In early days, chemists recognised that compounds having similar structural features have identical chemical properties. So they began to classify compounds based on the common structural arrangements found among them.</p>
	<p class="block_">Organic chemistry is the chemistry of catenated carbon compounds. The carbon atoms present in organic compounds are linked with each other through covalent bonds and thus exist as chains. By this way, organic compounds are classified into two types as follows: </p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">1. Acyclic or Open chain compounds:</b> These are the compounds in which the carbon atoms are linked in a linear pattern to form the chain. If all the carbon atoms in the chain are connected by single bonds, the compound is called as saturated. If one or more double bonds or triple bonds exist between the carbon atoms, then the compound is said to unsaturated.</p>
	<h5 class="block_832"><b class="calibre36">CH3-CH2-CH3<span class="tab1">      </span>CH</b><b class="calibre36">3-CH double bond CH2</b></h5>
	<p class="block_833">Propane<span class="tab1">      </span>Propene</p>
	<p class="block_834">Saturated compound<span class="tab">      </span>Unsaturated compound</p>
	<p class="block_">2. Cyclic Compounds: Organic compounds in which the chain of carbon atoms is closed or cyclic are called cyclic compounds. If the chain contains only carbon atoms, such compounds are called carbocyclic (homocyclic)compounds. If the chain contains carbon and other atoms like oxygen, nitrogen, sulphur, etc., these compounds are called heterocyclic compounds. Carbocyclic compounds are further subdivided into alicyclic and aromatic compounds. Alicyclic compounds contain one or more carbocyclic rings which may be saturated or unsaturated whereas aromatic compounds contain one or more benzene rings (ring containing alternate double bonds between carbon atoms). E.g.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-160.png" alt="image shows Carbo cyclic compounds difference image as follows  alicyclic compound example cyclobutane square shape aromatic compound example benzene hexagonal shape. hetrocyclic compounds example furan pentagon shape." class="calibre252"/></p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_"></p>
	<p class="block_835">Organic compounds</p>
	<p class="block_836">Acyclic or Open chain compounds</p>
	<p class="block_837">Cyclic or Closed chain compounds</p>
	<p class="block_838">Saturated</p>
	<p class="block_838">(Compounds <span class="text_33">containing </span></p>
	<p class="block_838"><span class="text_27">C-C</span> (single bond)</p>
	<p class="block_838">Example EthaneC2 H6</p>
	<p class="block_839">Unsaturated</p>
	<p class="block_840">(double Or Triple bond)</p>
	<p class="block_841"> Ethene CH2 double bond CH2 </p>
	<p class="block_841">Ethyne </p>
	<p class="block_842"><span class="text_49"> CH</span><span class="text_50"> triple bond </span><span class="text_49">CH</span></p>
	<p class="block_843">CarbocyclicCompounds</p>
	<p class="block_843"><span class="text_27">(Only </span>cabon ring)</p>

	<p class="block_845">Alicyclic</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_300">11.3 CLASSES OF ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (BASED ON THE KIND OF ATOMS)</h2>
	<p class="block_">Other than carbon, organic compounds contain atoms like hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, etc., bonded to the carbon. Combination of these kinds of atoms with carbon gives different classes of organic compounds. In the following section, let us discuss various classes of organic compounds.</p>
	<h4 class="block_103"><span class="calibre28">11.3.1  Hydrocarbons</span></h4>
	<p class="block_9">The organic compounds that are composed of only carbon and hydrogen atoms are called hydrocarbons. The carbon atoms join together to form the framework of the compounds. These are regarded as the parent organic compounds and all other compounds are considered to be derived from hydrocarbons by replacing one or more hydrogen atoms with other atoms or group of atoms. Hydrocarbons are, further, sub divided into three classes such as:</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">(a)Alkanes:</b> These are hydrocarbons, which contain only single bonds. They are represented by the general formula Cn H 2n + 2 (where n = 1,2, 3, ……). The simplest alkane (for n=1) is methane (C H4). Since, all are single bonds in alkanes, they are saturated compounds.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">(b)Alkenes:</b> The hydrocarbons, which contain one or more C=C bonds are called alkenes. These are unsaturated compounds. They are represented by the general formula CnH2n. The simplest alkene contains two carbon atoms (n=2) and is called ethylene (C2 H4).</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">(c)Alkynes:</b> The hydrocarbons containing carbon to carbon triple bond are called alkynes. They are also unsaturated as they contain triple bond between carbon atoms. They have the general formula Cn H 2n – 2. Acetylene (C2 H2) is the simplest alkyne, which contains two carbon atoms. Table 11.1 lists the first five hydrocarbons of each class:</p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 11.1 Hydrocarbons containing 1to 5 carbon atoms</p>

	<h4 class="block_5">11.3.2 Characteristics of hydrocarbons<b class="calibre6">:</b></h4>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Lower hydrocarbons are gases at room temperature E.g. methane, ethane are gases.</li>
	<li class="block_7">They are colorless and odorless.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The boiling point of hydrocarbons increases with an increase in the number of carbon atoms.</li>
	<li class="block_7">They undergo combustion reaction with oxygen to form C O2 and water.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Alkanes are least reactive when compared to other classes of hydrocarbons.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Alkynes are the most reactive due to the presence of the triple bond.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Alkanes are saturated whereas alkenes and alkynes are unsaturated.</li>
	<li class="block_8">They are insoluble in water.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">Test to identify saturated and unsaturated compounds:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Take the given sample solution in a test tube.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Add a few drops of bromine water and observe any characteristic change in colour.</li>
	<li class="block_7">If the given compound is unsaturated, it will decolourise bromine water.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Saturated compounds do not decolourise bromine.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-161.png" alt=" ADDITION OF BROMINE WATER TO ALKANES AND ALKENES. alkane does not react with bromine water and does not decolourise bromine water. alkene will react with bromine water and as such as so decolourises bromine water." class="calibre253"/></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">ADDITION OF BROMINE WATER TO ALKANES AND ALKENES</p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 11.2 Test to identify unsaturated compounds.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">11.3.3   Classification of organic compounds based on functional groups</span></p>
	<p class="block_9">The structural frameworks of organic compounds are made of carbon and hydrogen, which are relatively less reactive. But, the presence of some other atoms or group of atoms makes the compounds more reactive and thus determines the chemical properties of the compound. These groups are called functional groups.</p>
	<p class="block_">A functional group is an atom or group of atoms in a molecule, which gives its characteristic chemical properties.</p>
	<p class="block_">The chemical properties of an organic compound depend on its functional group whereas its physical properties rely on remaining part of the structure. Carbon to carbon multiple bonds </p>
	<p class="block_">(C double bond C, C triple bond C) also are considered as functional groups as many of the properties are influenced by these bonds. Other functional groups include atoms of halogens, –O H, –C H O, –COOH, etc.</p>
	<p class="block_">For example, ethane is a hydrocarbon having molecular formula C2H6. If one of its hydrogens is replaced by –O H group, you will get an alcohol. Leaving the functional group, the rest of the structure is represented by ‘R’. Thus an alcohol is represented by ‘R-O H’</p>
	<h5 class="block_870"><span class="text_53">CH3 - CH3 </span><span class="text_54">Ethane is a hydrocarbon</span><span class="text_53"><sub class="calibre25"><span class="calibre15">                 </span></sub></span></h5>
	<h5 class="block_870"><span class="text_53">CH3 - CH2 - O H (O H - Functional Group) </span><span class="text_54">Ethanol is an Alcohol</span></h5>
	<p class="block_">A series of compounds containing the same functional group is called a class of organic compounds. Table 11.2 shows various classes or families of organic compounds and their functional groups:</p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 11.2 Classes of organic compounds based on functional group</p>

			<td class="td_535"><p class="block_892">Ether</p></td>
			<td class="td_536"><p class="block_893">–O–R</p></td>
			<td class="td_537"><p class="block_894">R-O-R</p></td>
			<td class="td_538"><p class="block_895">Dimethyl ether,CH3 O CH3</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_301">11.4 HOMOLOGOUS SERIES</h2>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Homologous series is a group or a class of organic compounds having same general formula and    </span></p>
	<p class="block_">similar chemical properties in which the successive members differ by a - CH2 group.</p>
	<p class="block_">Let us consider members of alkanes given in Table 11.1. Their condensed structural formulas are given below:</p>
	<table class="table_57">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_539"><p class="block_677">Methane</p></td>
			<td class="td_540"><p class="block_896">-</p></td>
			<td class="td_541"><p class="block_897">CH4</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_542"><p class="block_898">Ethane</p></td>
			<td class="td_543"><p class="block_899">-</p></td>
			<td class="td_544"><p class="block_900">CH3 CH3</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_542"><p class="block_898">Propane</p></td>
			<td class="td_543"><p class="block_899">-</p></td>
			<td class="td_544"><p class="block_900">CH3 CH2 CH3</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_542"><p class="block_898">Butane</p></td>
			<td class="td_543"><p class="block_899">-</p></td>
			<td class="td_544"><p class="block_900">CH3 (CH2) twice CH3</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_545"><p class="block_898">Pentane</p></td>
			<td class="td_546"><p class="block_899">-</p></td>
			<td class="td_547"><p class="block_900">CH3 (CH2) thrice CH3</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_">If you observe the above series. you can notice that each successive member has one methylene group more than the precedent member of the series and hence they are called homologs.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_302">11.4.1 Characteristics of homologous series</h3>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Each member of the series differs from the preceding or succeeding member by one methylene group (–CH2) and hence by a molecular mass of 14 amu.</li>
	<li class="block_7">All members of a homologous series contain the same elements and functional group.</li>
	<li class="block_7">They are represented by a general molecular formula. example Alkanes, Cn H2n + 2.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The members in each homologous series show a regular gradation in their physical properties with respect to their increase in molecular mass.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Chemical properties of the members of a homologous series are similar.</li>
	<li class="block_8">All the members can be prepared by a common method.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_303">11.5 NOMENCLATURE OF ORGANIC COMPOUNDS</h2>
	<h4 class="block_103">11.5.1 Why do we need nomenclature?</h4>
	<p class="block_">In ancient days, the names of organic compounds were related to the natural things from which they were obtained. For example, the formic acid was initially obtained by distillation of ‘red ants. Latin name of the red ant is ‘Formica’. So, the name of the formic acid was derived from the Latin name of its source Later, the organic compounds were synthesized from sources other than the natural sources. So scientists framed a systematic method for naming the organic compounds based on their structures. Hence, a set of rules was formulated by IUPAC (International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry) for the nomenclature of chemical compounds.</p>
	<p class="block_12">11.5.2 Components of an IUPAC name</p>
	<p class="block_">The IUPAC name of the any organic compound consists of three parts:</p>
	<p class="block_">1. Root word</p>
	<p class="block_">ii. Prefix</p>
	<p class="block_">iii. Suffix</p>
	<p class="block_">These parts are combined as per the following sequence to get the IUPAC name of the compound:</p>
	<p class="block_901"><span class="text_56">Prefix</span><span class="text_57"> + </span><span class="text_58">Root</span><span class="text_59"> Word </span><span class="text_57">+</span><span class="text_60"> Suffix gives</span> <span class="text_60">IUPAC Name</span></p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">(1)Root word:</b> It is the basic unit, which describes the carbon skeleton. It gives the number of carbon atoms present in the parent chain of the compound and the pattern of their arrangement. Based on the number of carbon atoms present in the carbon skeleton, most of the names are derived from Greek numerals (except the first four). Table 11.3 shows the root words for the parent chain of hydrocarbons containing 1to10 carbon atoms:</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>

	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">(ii)Prefix:</p>
	<p class="block_9"> The prefix represents the substituents or branch present in the parent chain. Atoms or group of atoms, other than hydrogen, attached to carbon of the parent chain are called substituents. Table 11.4 presents the major substituents of organic compounds and respective prefix used for them</p>
	<p class="block_12">(iii)Suffix</p>
	<p class="block_">The suffix forms the end of the name. It is divided into two parts such as (a) Primary suffix and (b) Secondary suffix. The primary suffix comes after the root word. It represents the nature in carbon-to-carbon bonding of the parent chain. If all the bonds between the carbon atoms of the parent chain are single, then suffix ‘ane’ has to be used. Suffix ‘ene’ and ‘yne’ are used for the compounds containing double and triple bonds respectively. The secondary suffix describes the functional group of the compound.</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_">Table 11.5 Suffix for IUPAC Name</p>
	<table class="table_60">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">

	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_12">IUPAC rules for naming organic compounds:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Rule1: Identify the longest chain of carbon atoms to get the parent’s name (root word).</li>
	<li class="block_7">Rule 2: Number the carbon atoms of the parent chain, beginning at the closest end of the substituent or functional group. These are called locant numbers. If both functional group and substituent are present, then the priority will be given to the functional group.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Rule 3: In case of alkenes and alkynes, locate the double bond or triple bond and use its locant number followed by a dash and a primary suffix. The carbon chain is numbered in such a way that the multiple bonds have the lowest possible locant number.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Rule 4: If the compound contains functional group, locate it and use its locant number followed by a dash and a secondary suffix.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Rule 5: When the primary and secondary suffixes are joined, the terminal ‘e’ of the primary suffix is removed.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Rule 6: Identify the substituent and use a number followed by a dash and a prefix to specify its location and identity.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12"><span class="calibre28">11.5.4   IUPAC Nomenclature of hydrocarbons – Solved examples</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Let us try to name, systematically, some of the linear and substituted hydrocarbons by following IUPAC rules:</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Example 1:</b> CH3-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH3</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 1: It is a five- carbon chain and hence the root word is ‘Pent’. (Rule 1)</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 2: All the bonds between carbon atoms are single bonds, and thus the suffix is ‘ane’.</p>
	<p class="block_">So, its name is Pent + ane = Pentane</p>
	<p class="block_12">Example2:</p>
	<p class="block_930">CH3−CH−CH2−CH2−CH3<span class="calibre15"> and  methyl group CH3 is located with second carbon atom of the chain.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Step 1: The longest chain contains five carbon atoms and hence the root word is ‘Pent’.</p>
	<p class="block_"> Step 2: There is a substituent. So, the carbon chain is numbered from the left end, which is</p>
	<p class="block_">closest to the substituent. (Rule 2)<span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_61">CH3 – CH − CH2 − CH2 − CH3 and substituent methyl group is located at second carbon atom.</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_">Step 3: All are single bonds between the carbon atoms and thus the suffix is ‘ane’.</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 4: The substituent is a methyl group and it is located at second carbon atom. So, its locant number is 2. Thus the prefix is ‘2-Methyl’. (Rule 6).</p>
	<p class="block_">The name of the compound is</p>
	<p class="block_">2-Methyl + pent +ane = 2-Methylpentane</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Example3</b>:</p>
	<p class="block_">CH<span class="text_11">3</span> −CH2-CH − CH<span class="text_11">2 </span>− CH<span class="text_11">2 </span>− CH<span class="text_11">2 </span>− CH<span class="text_11">3<span class="calibre28">  and substituent methyl group is located at third carbon atom.</span></span></p>
	<p class="block_">Step 1: The longest chain contains seven carbon atoms and hence the root word is ‘Hept’. </p>
	<p class="block_">Step 2: There is a substituent. So, the carbon chain is numbered from the end, which is closest to substituent. (Rule 2)</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-162.png" alt="CORRECT representation is CH3 −CH2-CH − CH2 − CH2 − CH2 − CH3  and substituent methyl group is located at third carbon atom.  wrong representation is CH3 CH CH2 CH2 CH2 CH3 and substituent ethyl group is located at second carbon atom" class="calibre254"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Step 3: All are single bonds between the carbon atoms and thus the suffix is ‘ane’.</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 4: The substituent is a methyl group and it is located at third carbon. So, its locant number is 3. Thus the prefix is ‘3-Methyl’. (Rule 6)</p>
	<p class="block_">Hence the name of the compound is</p>
	<p class="block_">3-Methyl + hept + ane = 3 –Methylheptane</p>
	<p class="block_">Example 4: CH3-CH2-CH2-CH double bond CH2</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 1: It is a ‘five- carbon atoms chain’ and hence the root word is ‘Pent’. (Rule 1)</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 2: There is a carbon-to-carbon double bond. The suffix is ‘ene’.</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 3: The carbon chain is numbered from the end such that double bond has the lowest locant number as shown below: (Rule 3):</p>
	<p class="block_931">CH<span class="text_61">3</span>− CH<span class="text_61">2</span>−CH<span class="text_61">2</span>− CH double bond CH<span class="text_61">2 number 1 2 3 4 5 given from right to left.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Step 4: The locant number of the double bond is 1 and thus the suffix is ‘-1-ene’.</p>
	<p class="block_">So, the<span class="tab">      </span>name of the compound is</p>
	<p class="block_">Pent + (-1-ene) = Pent-1-ene</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">11.5.5   IUPAC Nomenclature of other classes – Solved examples</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Example1:</b> CH<span class="text_61">3</span>− CH<span class="text_61">2</span>−CH<span class="text_61">2</span>− O H</p>
	<p class="block_">Step1: The parent chain consists of 3 carbon atoms. The root word is ‘Prop’.</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 2: There are single bonds between the carbon atoms of the chain. So, the primary suffix is ‘ane’.</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 3: Since, the compound contains – OH group, it is an alcohol. The carbon chain is numbered from the end which is closest to –OH group. (Rule 3)</p>
	<p class="block_">CH<span class="text_62">3</span>−CH<span class="text_62">2</span>−CH<span class="text_62">2</span>−O H here number 1, 2, 3, is given from right to left for carbon atom.</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 4: The locant number of –OH group is 1 and thus the secondary suffix is ‘1-ol’.</p>
	<p class="block_">The name of the compound is</p>
	<p class="block_">Prop + ane + (1-ol) = Propan-1-ol</p>
	<p class="block_">Note: Terminal ‘e’ of ‘ane’ is removed as per Rule 5</p>
	<p class="block_">Example 2: CH3 C O O H</p>
	<p class="block_">Step1: The parent chain consists of 2 carbon atoms. The root word is ‘Eth’.</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 2: All are single bonds between the carbon atoms of the chain. So the primary suffix is ‘ane’.</p>
	<p class="block_">Step 3: Since the compound contains the–COOH group, it is a carboxylic acid. The secondary suffix is ‘oic acid’</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">The    name     of     the     compound     is</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Eth + ane + oic acid) = Ethanoic acid</p>
	<p class="block_">Table 11.6 lists IUPAC names homologs of various classes of organic compounds</p>
	<p class="block_12">Test yourself:</p>
