	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_304">11.6 ETHANOL (CH3CH2OH)</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-163.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of I U 9 4 8" class="calibre256"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Ethanol is commonly known as alcohol. All alcoholic beverages and some cough syrups contain ethanol. Its molecular formula is C2H5OH. Its structural formula is</p>
	<p class="block_61"><img src="images/image-164.png" alt="image shows structural formula for ethanol. one hydroxyl group and two Hydrogen atoms located at first carbon atom. three hydrogen atom located at second carbon atom." class="calibre257"/></p>
	<p class="block_207"><span class="calibre28">     </span><span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_305">11.6.1 Manufacture of ethanol</h3>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Ethanol is manufactured in industries by the fermentation of molasses, which is a by-product obtained during the manufacture of sugar from sugarcane. Molasses is   a dark coloured syrupy liquid left after the crystallization of sugar from the concentrated sugarcane juice. Molasses contains about 30% of sucrose, which cannot be separated by crystallization. It is converted into ethanol by the following steps:</span></p>
	<p class="block_19">(i) Dilution of molasses</p>
	<p class="block_9">Molasses is first diluted with water to bring down the concentration of sugar to about 8 to 10 percent.</p>
	<p class="block_19">(ii) Addition of Nitrogen source</p>
	<p class="block_9">Molasses usually contains enough nitrogenous matter to act as food for yeast during the fermentation process. If the nitrogen content of the molasses is poor, it may be fortified by the addition of ammonium sulphate or ammonium phosphate.</p>
	<p class="block_19">(iii) Addition of Yeast</p>
	<p class="block_9">The solution obtained in step (ii) is collected in large ‘fermentation tanks and yeast are added to it. The mixture is kept at about 303 Kelvin for a few days. During this period, the enzymes invertase and zymase present in yeast, bring about the conversion of sucrose into ethanol.</p>
	<p class="block_61">C12 H22 O11 (sugar) + H2O (water) in the presence of invertase gives C<span class="text_63">6</span> H12 O6 (glucose) + C6 H12 O6<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>(fructose)</p>
	<p class="block_61"> C6 H12 O6 (glucose or fructose) in the presence of zymase gives 2C2 H5 O H ethanol + 2 C O2</p>
	<p class="block_12">The fermented liquid is technically called wash.</p>
	<p class="block_19">(iv) Distillation of 'Wash'</p>
	<p class="block_9">The fermented liquid (i.e. wash), containing 15 to 18 percent alcohol, is now subjected to fractional distillation. The main fraction drawn is an aqueous solution of ethanol which contains 95.5% of ethanol and 4.5% of water. This is called rectified spirit. This mixture is then refluxed over quicklime for about 5 to 6 hours and then allowed to stand for 12 hours. On distillation of this mixture, pure alcohol (100%) is obtained. This is called absolute alcohol.</p>
	<p class="block_19">More to know</p>
	<p class="block_9">Yeast and Fermentation: Yeasts are single–celled microorganisms, belonging to the class of fungi. The enzymes present in yeasts catalyse many complex organic reactions. Fermentation is conversion of complex organic molecules into simpler molecules by the action of enzymes. Example Curdling of milk</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_306">11.6.2 Physical properties</h3>
	<p class="block_">i) Ethanol is a colourless liquid, having a pleasant smell and a burning taste.</p>
	<p class="block_">ii) It is a volatile liquid. Its boiling point is 78<sup class="calibre27">0</sup> C (351Kelvin), which is much higher than that of its corresponding alkane, that is ethane (Boiling Point = 184 Kelvin).</p>
	<p class="block_">iii) It is completely miscible with water in all proportions.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_307">11.6.3 Chemical Properties</h3>
	<p class="block_">(1) Dehydration (Loss of water)</p>
	<p class="block_">When ethanol is heated with con H2 S O4 at 443Kelvin, it loses a water molecule that is dehydrated to form ethene.</p>
	<p class="block_9">CH3 CH2 O <span class="calibre15">H Ethanol   </span>when heated with concentrated H2 S O 4 at 443 kelvin gives CH2 double bond  CH2 ethene + H2O</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">      </span><span class="tab1">      </span><span class="tab1">      </span><span class="tab1">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_">(ii) Reaction with sodium:</p>
	<p class="block_">Ethanol reacts with sodium metal to form sodium ethoxide and hydrogen gas.</p>
	<p class="block_551">2C2 H5 O <span class="calibre28">H + 2Na   </span>gives  2 C2 H5 O N a (sodium ethoxide) + H2 gas<span class="calibre28">  </span></p>
	<p class="block_551"><span class="calibre28">          </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="calibre28">                                                                           </span></p>
	<p class="block_">(iii) Oxidation:</p>
	<p class="block_">Ethanol is oxidized to ethanoic acid with alkaline K M n O4 or acidified K2 C r2 O7</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">                      </span></p>
	<p class="block_">CH3 CH2 O <span class="calibre28">H   </span>oxidized in the presence of acidified potassium di chromate gives<span class="calibre28">  CH</span>3 CH O O H (ethanoic acid)+ H2O </p>
	<p class="block_">During this reaction, the orange colour of K2 C r2 O7 changes to green. Therefore, this reaction can be used for the identification of alcohols.</p>
	<p class="block_">(iv) Esterification:</p>
	<p class="block_">The reaction of an alcohol with a carboxylic acid gives a compound having fruity odour. This compound is called an ester and the reaction is called esterification. Ethanol reacts with ethanoic acid in the presence of conc. H2 S O4 to form ethyl ethanoate, an ester.</p>
	<p class="block_">C2 H5 O H (ethanol) + CH3 C O O H (ethanoic acid) in the presence of concentrated sulphuric acid gives CH3 C O O C2 H5<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>(ETHYL<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>ETHANOATE) + H2O </p>
	<p class="block_">(v) Dehydrogenation:</p>
	<p class="block_">When the vapour of ethanol is passed over heated copper, used as a catalyst at 573 Kelvin, it is dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde</p>
	<p class="block_">CH3 CH2 O H ethanol heated with copper at the temperature of 573 kelvin gives CH3 CH O ACETALDEHYDE + H2 gas</p>
	<p class="block_74"><span class="calibre28">                </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_">(vi) Combustion:</p>
	<p class="block_">Ethanol is highly inflammable liquid. It burns with oxygen to form carbon dioxide and water.</p>
	<p class="block_61">C2 H5 O H ETHANOL + 3O2<span class="calibre28">  </span>gives  2C O2 Carbon dioxide + 3H2<span class="calibre28">O                                                  </span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_308">11.6.4 Uses of ethanol</h3>
	<p class="block_">Ethanol is used</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_969">in medical wipes, as an antiseptic.</li>
	<li class="block_970">as an anti-freeze in automobile radiators.</li>
	<li class="block_970">for effectively killing microorganisms like bacteria, fungi, etc., by including it in many hand sanitizers.</li>
	<li class="block_970">as an antiseptic to sterilize wounds in hospitals.</li>
	<li class="block_970">as a solvent for drugs, oils, fats, perfumes, dyes, etc.</li>
	<li class="block_970">in the preparation of methylated spirit (mixture of 95% of ethanol and 5% of methanol) rectified spirit (mixture of 95.5% of ethanol and 4.5% of water), power alcohol (mixture of petrol and ethanol) and denatured spirit (ethanol mixed with pyridine).</li>
	<li class="block_971">to enhance the flavour of food extracts, for example vanilla extract; a common food flavour, which is made by processing vanilla beans in a solution of ethanol and water.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_309">11.7 ETHANOIC ACID (CH3 C O O H)</h2>
	<p class="block_">Ethanoic acid or acetic acid is one of the most important members of the carboxylic acid family. Its molecular formula is C2 H4 O2. Its structural formula is </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-165.png" alt="the image shows structural formula for ethanoic acid. one hydroxyl group and oxygen atom with double bond is located at first carbon atom. three hydrogen atoms located at second hydrogen atom." class="calibre258"/></p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_310">11.7.1 Manufacture of ethanoic acid</h3>
	<p class="block_">Ethanoic acid is prepared in large scale, by the oxidation of ethanol in the presence of alkaline potassium permanganate or acidified potassium dichromate.</p>
	<p class="block_61">CH3 CH2 OH ETHANOL oxidized with alkaline K M n O4 gives CH3 C O O H ETHANOIC ACID+ H2O</p>
	<p class="block_207"><span class="tab">      </span><span class="calibre28">                                 </span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_311">11.7.2 Physical Properties</h3>
	<p class="block_">(1) Ethanoic acid is a colourless liquid having an unpleasant odour.</p>
	<p class="block_">(ii) It is sour in taste.</p>
	<p class="block_">(iii) It is miscible with water in all proportions.</p>
	<p class="block_">(iv) Its boiling point is higher than the corresponding alcohols, aldehydes and ketones.</p>
	<p class="block_">(v) On cooling, pure ethanoic acid is frozen to form ice like flakes. They look like glaciers, so it is called glacial acetic acid.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_312">11.7.3 Chemical Properties</h3>
	<p class="block_">1. Reaction with metal: Ethanoic acid reacts with active metals like N a, Z n, etcetera to liberate hydrogen and form ethanoate.</p>
	<p class="block_972"><span class="calibre15">             2CH</span>3 C O O H +Z n gives (CH3 C O O) twice Z n +H2 gas</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="text_27"><span class="calibre28">             2CH</span></span><span class="text_27">3 C O O H + 2 N a gives </span>2CH3 C O O N a +H2 gas</p>
	<p class="block_">2. Reaction with carbonates and bicarbonates: Ethanoic acid reacts with sodium carbonate and sodium bicarbonate, which are weaker bases and liberates C O2, with brisk effervescence.</p>
	<p class="block_61"><span class="calibre28">               2CH</span>3 C O O H + N a2 C O3 gives 2CH3 C O O N a + C O2 gas + H2O </p>
	<p class="block_61"><span class="calibre28">                 CH</span>3 C O O H + N a H C O3 gives CH3 C O O N a + CO2 gas + H2O</p>
	<p class="block_">(iii) Reaction with base: Ethanoic acid reacts with sodium hydroxide to form sodium ethanoate and water.</p>
	<p class="block_973"><span class="text_29">CH3 C O O H + N a O H gives </span>CH3 C O O N a +H2O</p>
	<p class="block_973">(iv) Decarboxylation (Removal of C O2):</p>
	<p class="block_973">When a sodium salt of ethanoic acid is heated with soda lime (solid mixture of 3 parts of NaOH and 1 part of C a O), methane gas is formed.</p>
	<p class="block_973"><span class="calibre15">                         </span></p>
	<p class="block_61">CH3 C O O N a when heated with soda lime gives CH4<sub class="calibre25"> </sub>gas + Na2 C O3</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_313">11.7.4 Uses of ethanoic acid</h3>
	<p class="block_">Acetic acid, in lower concentration (vinegar), is used as a food additive, a flavoring agent and a preservative.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Ethanoic acid is used</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">in the manufacture of plastic.</li>
	<li class="block_7">in making dyes, pigments and paint.</li>
	<li class="block_7">in printing on fabrics.</li>
	<li class="block_7">as a laboratory reagent.</li>
	<li class="block_7">for coagulating rubber from latex.</li>
	<li class="block_8">in the production of pharmaceuticals.</li>
</ul>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_315">11.9 SOAPS AND DETERGENTS</h2>
	<p class="block_">Soaps and the Detergents are materials that are used by us for cleaning purposes because pure water alone cannot remove all types of dirt or any oily substance from our body or clothes. They contain ‘surfactants’, which are compounds with molecules that line up around water to break the ‘surface tension’. Both of them having a different chemical nature. Soap is a cleaning agent that is composed of one or more salts of fatty acids. Detergent is a chemical compound or a mixture of chemical compounds, which is used as a cleaning agent, also. They perform their cleaning actions in certain specific conditions. You will learn more about this in detail, in the following units.</p>
	<p class="block_12"><span class="calibre28">11.9.1   Soap</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Soaps are sodium or potassium salts of some long chain carboxylic acids, called fatty acids. Soap requires two major raw materials: i) fat and ii) alkali. The alkali, most commonly used in the preparation of soap is sodium hydroxide. Potassium hydroxide can also be used. A potassium-based soap creates a more water- soluble product than a sodium-based soap. Based on these features, there are two types of soaps:</p>
	<p class="block_12">A. HARD SOAP</p>
	<p class="block_">Soaps, which are prepared by the saponification of oils or fats with caustic soda (sodium hydroxide), are known as hard soaps. They are usually used for washing purposes.</p>
	<p class="block_12">B. SOFT SOAP</p>
	<p class="block_">Soaps, which are prepared by the saponification of oils or fats with potassium salts, are known as soft soaps. They are used for cleansing the body.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Manufacture of soap</p>
	<p class="block_12">KETTLE PROCESS:</p>
	<p class="block_">This is the oldest method. But, it is still widely used in the small scale preparation ofsoap. There are mainly, two steps to be followed in this process.</p>
	<p class="block_12">1) Saponification of oil:</p>
	<p class="block_">The oil, which is used in this process, is taken in an iron tank (kettle). The alkaline solution (10%) is added into the kettle, a little in excess. The mixture is boiled by passing steam through it. The oil gets hydrolysed after several hours of boiling. This process is called Saponification</p>
	<p class="block_12">ii) Salting out of soap:</p>
	<p class="block_">Common salt is then added to the boiling mixture. Soap is finally precipitated in the tank. After several hours the soap rises to the top of the liquid as a ‘curdy mass’. The neat soap is taken off from the top. It is then allowed to cool down.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Effect of hard water on soap</p>
	<p class="block_">Hard water contains calcium and magnesium ions (C a2 + and M g2+) that limit the cleaning action of soap. When combined with soap, hard water develops a thin layer (precipitates of the metal ions) called ‘scum’, which leaves a deposit on the clothes or skin and does not easily rinse away. Over time, this can lead to the deterioration of the fabric and eventually ruin the clothes. On the other hand, detergents are made with chemicals that are not affected by hard water.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know?</p>
	<p class="block_">Why ordinary soap is not suitable for using with hard water?</p>
	<p class="block_">Ordinary soaps when treated with hard water, precipitate as salts of calcium and magnesium. They appearat the surface of the cloth as sticky grey scum. Thus, the soaps cannot be used conveniently in hard water.</p>
	<p class="block_12"><span class="calibre28">11.9.2    Detergents</span></p>
	<p class="block_">Development of synthetic detergents is a big achievement in the field of cleansing. These soaps possess the desirable properties of ordinary soaps and also can be used with hard water and in acidic solutions. These are salts of sulphonic acids or alkyl hydrogen sulphates in comparison to soap, which are salts of carboxylic acids. The detergents do not form precipitates with C a 2+ and M g 2+ present in hard water. So, the cleansing action of detergents is better than that of soaps.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Preparation of detergents</p>
	<p class="block_">Detergents are prepared by adding sulphuric acid to the processed hydrocarbon obtained from petroleum. This chemical reaction result in the formation of molecules similar to the fatty acid in soap. Then, an alkali is added to the mixture to produce the ‘surfactant molecules’, which do not bond with the minerals present in the hard water, thus preventing the formation of their precipitates.</p>
	<p class="block_">In addition to a ‘surfactant’, the modern detergent contains several other ingredients. They are listed as follows:</p>
	<p class="block_">1) Sodium silicate, which prevents the corrosion and ensures that the detergent does not damage the washing machine.</p>
	<p class="block_">ii) Fluorescent whitening agents that give a glow to the clothes.</p>
	<p class="block_">iii) Oxygen bleaches, such as ‘sodium perborate’, enable the removal of certain stains from the cloth.</p>
	<p class="block_">iv) Sodium sulphate is added to prevent the caking of the detergent powder.</p>
	<p class="block_">5) Enzymes are added to break down some stains caused by biological substances like blood and vegetable juice.</p>
	<p class="block_">vi) Certain chemicals that give out a pleasant smell are also added to make the clothes fragrant after they are washed with detergents.</p>
	<div class="calibre259">
	<div class="block_14"><span class="bullet_1">11.8.3 </span><span class="calibre52"><b class="calibre6"><span class="calibre28">Cleansing action of soap      </span></b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_27"><img src="images/image-166.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of E B S K 6" class="calibre260"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">A soap molecule contains two chemically distinct parts that interact differently with water. It has one polar end, which is a short head with a carboxylate group (–COONa) and one non-polar   end   having the long tail made of the hydrocarbon chain.</span></p>
	<p class="block_">The polar end is hydrophilic (Water loving) in nature and this end is attracted towards water. The non-polar end is hydrophobic (Water hating) in nature and it is attracted towards dirt or oil on the cloth, but not attracted towards water. Thus, the hydrophobic part of the soap molecule traps the dirt and the hydrophilic part makes the entire molecule soluble in water.</p>
	<p class="block_">When a soap or detergent is dissolved in water, the molecules join together as clusters called ‘micelles’. Their long hydrocarbon chains attach themselves to the oil and dirt. The dirt is thus surrounded by the non-polar end of the soap molecules (Figure 11.3). The charged carboxylate end of the soap molecules makes the micelles soluble in water. Thus, the dirt is washed away with the soap.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Advantages of detergents over soaps</p>
	<p class="block_">Detergents are better than soaps because they:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">can be used in both hard and soft water and can clean more effectively in hard water than soap.</li>
	<li class="block_7">can also be used in saline and acidic water.</li>
	<li class="block_7">do not leave any soap scum on the tub or clothes.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> dissolve freely even in cool water and rinse freely in hard water.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> can be used for washing woollen garments, where as soap cannot be used.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> have a linear hydrocarbon chain, which is biodegradable.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> are active emulsifiers of motor grease.</li>
	<li class="block_8">do an effective and safe cleansing, keeping even synthetic fabrics brighter and whiter.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">Biodegradable and Non-biodegradable detergents:</p>
	<p class="block_12">a) Biodegradable detergents:</p>
	<p class="block_">They have straight hydrocarbon chains, which can be easily degraded by bacteria.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-167.png" alt="C:\Users\ADMIN\Pictures\Screenshots\Screenshot (281).png" class="calibre261"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-168.png" alt="figure 11.3 3 Cleansing action of soap is shown" class="calibre262"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 11.3 Cleansing action of soap<span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_12">b) Non-biodegradable detergents:</p>
	<p class="block_">They have highly branched hydrocarbon chains, which cannot be degraded by bacteria.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Disadvantages of Detergents</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Some detergents having a branched hydro- carbon chain are not fully biodegradable by </li>
	<li class="block_8">micro-organisms present in water. So, they cause water pollution.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">2. They are relatively more expensive than soap.</p>

	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">TFM means TOTAL FATTY MATTER.</b>It is the one of the important factors to be considered to assess the quality of soap. A soap, which has higher TFM, is a good bathing soap.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_316">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">A group or class of organic compounds related to each other by a general molecular formula constitutes homologous series.</li>
	<li class="block_7"><span class="calibre28">The IUPAC name of the any organic compound consist of three parts. ROOTWORD, PREFIX and  or SUFFIX.</span></li>
	<li class="block_7">Functional group may be defined as an atom or group of atom or reactive part which is responsible for the characteristic properties of the compounds</li>
	<li class="block_7">Ethanoic acid is most commonly known as acetic acid and belongs to a group of acids called carboxylic acids.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Ethanol or ethyl alcohol or simply alcohol is one of the most important members of the family of alcohols.</li>
	<li class="block_7"><span class="calibre28">The slow chemical change that takes place in complex organic   compounds by the action of enzymes leading to the formation of simple molecules is called fermentation.</span></li>
	<li class="block_7">Soaps are sodium or potassium salts of some long chain carboxylic acids.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Detergents are sodium salts of sulphonic acids. Thus instead of –COOH group in soaps, detergents contain –SO3H group</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12"> <img src="images/image-170.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of 7LXS2" class="calibre264"/></p>

	<p class="block_12">IV. Assertion and Reason:</p>
	<p class="block_">Answer the following questions using the data given below:</p>
	<p class="block_">i) A and R are correct, R explains the A.</p>
	<p class="block_">ii) A is correct, R is wrong.</p>
	<p class="block_">iii) A is wrong, R is correct.</p>
	<p class="block_">iv) A and R are correct, R doesn’t explains A.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">1. Assertion:</b> Detergents are more effective cleansing agents than soaps in hard water.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Reason</b>: Calcium and magnesium salts of detergents are water soluble.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">2. Assertion</b>: Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Reason:</b> Hydrocarbons consist of covalent bonds.</p>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_318">UNIT-12 <b class="calibre6">PLANT ANATOMY AND PLANT PHYSIOLOGY</b></h1>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6"><span class="calibre28">  </span></b><b class="calibre6"><img src="images/image-173.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of UMX9V" class="calibre267"/></b></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_319">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand vascular tissue system- their types and functions.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Know the structure of dicot root, stem, leaf and monocot root, stem, leaf.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Differentiate the internal structure of dicot root, stem, leaf with that of monocot root, stem, leaf.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Name the different pigments found in chloroplast.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Elaborate on the structure and functions of plastids.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Enumerate the steps involved in photosynthesis.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the structure of mitochondria</li>
	<li class="block_66">List the basic events of aerobic and anaerobic respiration.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_320">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_985"><span class="calibre28">Plants exhibits varying degrees of organization. Atoms are organized into molecules, molecules into organelles, organelles into cells, cells into tissues and tissues into organs. The first account of internal structure of plants was published by English Physician Nehemiah Grew. He is known as Father of Plant Anatomy. Plant anatomy (Gk Ana  =  as under; Temnein  =  to cut) is the study of internal structure of plants. You have already studied the different kinds of tissues in IX standard. In this lesson, you will study about the internal structure of plant tissues, process of photosynthesis and respiration.</span></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_321">12.1 Tissues</h2>
	<p class="block_9">Tissues are the group of cells that are similar or dissimilar in structure and origin but perform similar function. Plant tissues can be broadly classified into two, based on their ability to divide. They are</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_66">Meristematic tissue</li>
	<li class="block_66">Permanent tissue.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_322">12.2 Tissue system</h2>
	<p class="block_9">Sachs (1875) classified tissue system in plants into three types</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_66">Dermal or Epidermal tissue system</li>
	<li class="block_66">Ground tissue system</li>
	<li class="block_66">Vascular tissue system</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_9">The functions of these tissues are given in Table 12.1.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_323">12.2.1</h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_324"> Dermal or Epidermal Tissue System</h3>
	<p class="block_9">It consists of epidermis, stomata and epidermal outgrowths. Epidermis is the outer most layer. </p>
	<p class="block_9">Minute pores called stomata are present in the epidermis of leaf and stem.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Table 12.1 </p>
	<p class="block_19">Tissue system and its functions</p>
	<table class="table_64">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_608"><p class="block_986">Tissue System</p></td>
			<td class="td_609"><p class="block_987">Components</p></td>
			<td class="td_610"><p class="block_988">Functions</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_611"><p class="block_989"><span class="text_29">Dermal Tissue </span>System</p></td>
			<td class="td_612"><p class="block_990">Epidermis and Periderm (in older stems and roots)</p></td>
			<td class="td_613"><div class="calibre268">
	<div class="block_991"><span class="bullet_6">• </span><span class="calibre18">Protection</span></div>
	<div class="block_992"><span class="bullet_6">• </span><span class="calibre18">Prevention of water loss</span></div>
</div></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_611"><p class="block_18"> </p><p class="block_252"> </p><p class="block_993">Ground Tissue System</p></td>
			<td class="td_612"><p class="block_195">Parenchyma tissue</p><p class="block_195">Chlorenchyma</p><p class="block_285">Collenchyma tissue</p><p class="block_994"> </p><p class="block_285"> <span class="text_64">Sclerenchyma </span><span class="text_33">tissue</span></p></td>
			<td class="td_613"><div class="calibre268">
	<div class="block_992"><span class="bullet_6">• </span><span class="calibre18">Food storage</span></div>
	<div class="block_991"><span class="bullet_6">• </span><span class="calibre18">Photosynthesis</span></div>
	<div class="block_992"><span class="bullet_6">• </span><span class="calibre18">Support ,Protection</span></div>
	<div class="block_992"><span class="bullet_6">• </span><span class="calibre18">Support ,rigidity</span></div>
</div></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_614"><p class="block_961"> </p><p class="block_995">Vascular Tissue System</p></td>
			<td class="td_615"><p class="block_996">Vascular tissues</p><p class="block_997">Xylem tissue</p><p class="block_998">Phloem tissue</p></td>
			<td class="td_616"><div class="calibre268">
	<div class="block_999"><span class="bullet_5">• </span><span class="calibre52">Transport of water and minerals</span></div>
	<div class="block_1000"><span class="bullet_5">• </span><span class="calibre18">Transport of food</span></div>
</div></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_">Cuticle is present on the outer wall of epidermis to check evaporation of water. Trichomes and root hairs are the epidermal outgrowths.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Functions:</p>
	<p class="block_">1 Epidermis protects the inner tissues.</p>
	<p class="block_">2 Stomata helps in transpiration.</p>
	<p class="block_">3 Root hairs help in absorption of water and minerals.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_325">12.2.2 </h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_326">Ground Tissue System</h3>
	<p class="block_">It includes all the tissues of the plant body except epidermal and vascular tissues like</p>
	<p class="block_">1 Cortex</p>
	<p class="block_">2 Endodermis </p>
	<p class="block_">3 ericycle</p>
	<p class="block_">4 Pith</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_327">12.2.3 </h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_328">Vascular Tissue System</h3>
	<p class="block_">It consists of xylem and phloem tissues. They are present in the form of bundles called vascular bundles. Xylem conducts water and minerals to different parts of the plant. Phloem conducts food materials to different parts of the plant.</p>
	<p class="block_">There are three different types of vascular bundles namely </p>
	<p class="block_">1 Radial</p>
	<p class="block_">2 Conjoint</p>
	<p class="block_">3 Concentric</p>
	<h4 class="block_103">Radial Bundles</h4>
	<p class="block_">Xylem and phloem are present in different radii alternating with each other. Example:roots</p>
	<h4 class="block_103"><span class="calibre28">Con  joint bundles</span></h4>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Xylem and phloem lie on the same radius. There are two types of con  joint bundles.</span></p>
	<h5 class="block_15">a) Collateral</h5>
	<p class="block_">Xylem lies towards the centre and phloem lies towards the periphery.</p>
	<p class="block_">When cambium is present in collateral bundles, it is called open. Example:dicot stem </p>
	<p class="block_">and collateral bundle without cambium is called closed. Example:monocot stem.</p>
	<h5 class="block_15"><span class="calibre15">b)  Bicollateral</span></h5>
	<p class="block_">In this type of bundle, the phloem is present on both outer and inner side of xylem.</p>
	<p class="block_">Example:Cucurbita</p>
	<h4 class="block_103">3.Concentric Bundles</h4>
	<p class="block_">Vascular bundle in which xylem completely surrounds the phloem or vice versa is called concentric vascular bundle. It is of two types:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6"><b class="calibre6">Amphivasal :</b> Xylem surrounds phloem. Example: Dracaena</li>
	<li class="block_8"><b class="calibre6">Amphicribral :</b> Phloem surrounds xylem. Example:Ferns</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Endarch:</b> Protoxylem lies towards the centre and metaxylem lies towards the periphery. Example:stem.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Exarch:</b> Protoxylem lies towards the periphery and metaxylem lies towards the centre. Example:roots.</p>
	<p class="block_12"><span class="calibre28">                                                    Figure 12.1 Types of vascular bundle</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-174.png" alt="Image shows Types of vascular bundle " class="calibre269"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_329">12.3 Internal Structure of Dicot Root (Bean)</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">A thin transverse section of dicot root shows the following structures.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">1 </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Epiblema:</b> It is the outermost layer. Cuticle and stomata are absent. Unicellular root hairs are present. It is also known as Rhizodermis or Piliferous layer.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">2 </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Cortex:</b> It is a multi-layered large zone made of thin-walled parenchymatous cells with intercellular spaces. It stores food and water.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">3</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Endodermis:</b> It is the innermost layer of cortex. The cells are barrel shaped, closely packed, and show band like thickenings on their radial and inner tangential walls called casparian strips. But these</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><span class="calibre15">casparian strips are absent in the endodermis cells which are located opposite to the protoxylem. These thin-walled cells without  casparian strips are called passage cell. It helps in the movement of water and dissolved salts from cortex into xylem.</span></p>
	<p class="block_1002">4</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Stele:</b> All tissues inner to endodermis constitute stele. It includes pericycle and vascular bundle.</p>
	<p class="block_1003"><b class="calibre36">1 Pericycle:</b> Inner to endodermis lies a single layer of pericycle. It is the site of origin of lateral roots.</p>
	<p class="block_1003"><b class="calibre36">2 Vascular bundle:</b> It is radial. Xylem is exarch and tetrach. The tissue present between xylem and phloem is called conjunctive tissue. In dicot root, it is made up of parenchyma.</p>
	<p class="block_1003"><b class="calibre36">3 Pith:</b> Young root contains pith whereas in old root pith is absent.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_330">12.4 Internal Structure of Monocot Root (Maize)</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">A thin transverse section of monocot root shows the following characteristic features.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">1</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36"> Epiblema or Rhizotomies:</b> It is the outermost layer of the root and is made up of single layer of thin walled, parenchymatous cell. Stomata and cuticle are absent. The root hair helps in absorption of water and minerals from the soil. This layer also protects the inner tissues.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 12.2 Transverse section of Dicot root</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-175.png" alt="Image shows the Transverse section of Dicot root " class="calibre270"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 12.3 Transverse section of Monocot root</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-176.png" alt="Image shows the Transverse section of Monocot root" class="calibre271"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">2 Cortex:</b> It is multi-layered large zone, composed of parenchymatous cells with intercellular spaces. It stores water and food material.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">3</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36"> Endodermis:</b> It is the innermost layer of cortex with characteristic casparian strips and passage cells. Casparian strips are band like thickening made of suberin.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">4</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36"> Stele:</b> All the tissues inner to endodermis constitute stele. It includes pericycle, vascular tissues and pith.</p>
	<p class="block_1004"><b class="calibre36">1 Pericycle</b>: It is a single layer of thin-walled cells. The lateral roots originate from this layer.</p>
	<p class="block_1004"><b class="calibre36">2 Vascular tissues:</b> It consists of many patches of xylem and phloem arranged radially. The xylem is exarch and polyarch. The conjunctive tissue is made up of sclerenchyma.</p>
	<p class="block_1005"><b class="calibre36">3 Pith:</b> It is present at the center. It is made up of parenchyma cells with intercellular spaces. It contains abundant amount of starch grains. It stores food.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_331">12.5 Internal Structure of Dicot Stem (Sunflower)</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">The transverse section of a dicot stem reveals the following structures.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">1 </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Epidermis:</b> It is the outermost layer. It is made up of single layer of parenchyma cells, its outer wall is covered with cuticle. It is protective in function.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">2</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Cortex: -</b> It is divided into three regions:</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36"> 1 Hypodermis</b>: It consists of 3 - 6 layers of collenchyma cells. It gives mechanical support.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Table 12.2 Differences between Dicot and Monocot root</p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>

		</tr>

	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">2 Middle cortex:</b> It is made up of few layers of chlorenchyma cells. It is involved in photosynthesis due to the presence of chloroplast.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">3 Inner cortex:</b> It is made up of few layers of parenchyma cells. It helps in gaseous exchange and stores food materials.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Endodermis</b> is the inner most layer of cortex. It consists of a single layer of barrel shaped cells; these cells contain starch grains. So, it is also called starch sheath.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">3 Stele: </b>The central part of the stem inner to endodermis is known as stele. It consists of pericycle, vascular bundle and pith.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">1 Pericycle:</b> It occurs between vascular bundle and endodermis. It is multi-layered, parenchymatous with alternating patches of sclerenchyma.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">2 Bundle cap: There is a patch of hard Sclerenchyma tissue outside the phloem of vascular bundle is called Bundle cap.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">3 Vascular bundle:</b> Vascular bundles are con joint, collateral, end arch and open. They are arranged in the form of a ring around the pith.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">4 Pith:</b> The large central parenchymatous zone with intercellular spaces is called pith. It helps in the storage of food materials.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_332">12.6 Internal Structure of Monocot Stem (Maize)</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">A transverse section of monocot stem reveals the following structures.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(1). Epidermis:</b> It is the outermost layer. It is made up of single layer of parenchyma cells. It is covered with thick cuticle. Multicellular hairs are absent, and stomata are also less in number.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(2). Hypodermis:</b> It is made up of few layers of sclerenchyma cells interrupted by chlorenchyma. Sclerenchyma provides mechanical support to plant.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-177.png" alt="C:\Users\ADMIN\Pictures\Screenshots\Screenshot (166).png" class="calibre272"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-178.png" alt="C:\Users\ADMIN\Pictures\Screenshots\Screenshot (168).png" class="calibre273"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 12.4 Transverse section of Dicot stem</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(3). Ground tissue:</b> The entire mass of parenchyma cells next to hypodermis and extending to the centre is called ground tissue. It is not differentiated into endodermis, cortex, pericycle and pith.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 12.5 Transverse section of Monocot stem</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-179.png" alt="Image shows Transverse section of Monocot stem" class="calibre274"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(4). Vascular Bundle:</b> Vascular bundles are skull shaped and scattered in the ground tissue. Vascular bundles are con joint, collateral, end arch and closed. Each vascular bundle is surrounded by few layers of sclerenchyma cells called bundle sheath.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(a) Xylem:</b> It consists of metaxylem and protoxylem. Xylem vessels are arranged in V or Y shape. In mature vascular bundle, the lower most protoxylem disintegrates and form a cavity. This is called protoxylem lacuna.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(b) Phloem:</b> It consists of sieve tube elements and companion cells. Phloem parenchyma, and phloem Fibres are absent.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(5). Pith:</b> Pith is not differentiated in monocot stems.</p>

	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_333">12.7 Internal Structure of Dicot or Dorsiventral Leaf (Mango leaf)</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">The transverse section of leaf shows the following structures.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">1 Upper epidermis</b>: This is the outermost layer made of single layered parenchymatous cells without intercellular spaces. The outer wall of the cells is cuticularized. Stomata are less in number.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><span class="calibre15">                                   Figure 12.6 Transverse section of Dicot leaf</span></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-180.png" alt="Image shows Transverse section of Dicot leaf " class="calibre275"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">2 Lower epidermis:</b> It is a single layer of parenchymatous cells with a thin cuticle. It contains numerous stomata. Chloroplasts are present only in guard cells. The lower epidermis helps in the exchange of gases. The loss of water vapour is facilitated through this chamber.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">3 Mesophyll</b>: The tissue present between the upper and lower epidermis is called mesophyll. It is differentiated into Palisade parenchyma and Spongy parenchyma.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">a) Palisade parenchyma</b>: It is found just below the upper epidermis. The cells are elongated. These cells have more number of chloroplasts. The cells do not have intercellular spaces and they take part in photosynthesis.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">b) Spongy parenchyma</b>: It is found below the palisade parenchyma tissue. Cells are almost spherical or oval and are irregularly arranged. Cells have intercellular spaces. It helps in gaseous exchange.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(4Vascular bundles</b>: Vascular bundle are present in mid-rib and lateral veins. Vascular bundles are con joint, collateral and closed. Each vascular bundle is surrounded by a sheath of parenchymatous cells called bundle sheath. Each vascular bundle consists of xylem lying towards the upper epidermis and phloem towards the lower epidermis.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_334">12.8 Internal Structure of Monocot or Isobilateral Leaf  Example.Grass leaf</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">The transverse section of a monocot leaf reveals the following structures.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(1) Epidermis:</b> Monocot leaf has upper and lower epidermis. Epidermis is made up of parenchyma cells. Cuticle is present on the outer wall stomata are present on both upper and lower epidermis. Some cells of upper epidermis are large and thin walled they are known as bulliform cells.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(2) Mesophyll</b>: It is the ground tissue that is present between both epidermal layers. Mesophyll is not differentiated into palisade and spongy parenchyma. The cells are irregularly arranged with inter-cellular spaces. These cells contain chloroplasts.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(3) Vascular bundles</b>: large number of vascular bundles are present, some of which are small, and some are large. Each vascular bundle is surrounded by parenchymatous bundle sheath. Vascular bundles are con joint, collateral and closed. Xylem is present towards upper epidermis and phloem towards lower epidermis.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><span class="calibre15">                              Figure 12.7 Transverse section of Monocot Leaf</span></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-181.png" alt="Image shows Transverse section of Monocot Leaf  " class="calibre276"/></p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_335">12.9 Plant Physiology</h2>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_336">12.9.1 Plastids</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Plastids are double membrane bound organelles found in plants and some algae. They are responsible for preparation and storage of food. There are three types of plastids.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Chloroplast - green coloured plastids </p>
	<p class="block_1001">Chromoplast - yellow, red, orange-coloured plastids </p>
	<p class="block_1001">Leucoplast - colourless plastids</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_337">12.9.2 Structure of Chloroplast</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Chloroplasts are green plastids containing green pigment called chlorophyll. Chloroplasts are oval shaped organelles having a diameter of 2-10 micrometre and a thickness of 1-2 micrometre.</p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-182.png" alt="Image of Ultrastructure of Chloroplast " class="calibre277"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><span class="calibre15">                           Figure 12.8 Ultrastructure of Chloroplast</span></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">(1). Envelope:</b> Chloroplast envelope has outer and inner membranes which is separated by intermembrane space.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36"><span class="calibre15">(2).  Stroma</span></b><b class="calibre36">:</b> Matrix present inside to the membrane is called stroma. It contains DNA, 70 S ribosomes and other molecules required for protein synthesis.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36"><span class="calibre15">(3).  Thylakoids</span></b><b class="calibre36">:</b> It consists of thylakoid membrane that encloses thylakoid lumen. Photosynthetic pigments are present in Thylakoids. Thylakoids forms a stack of disc like structures called a granum (singular-granum).</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36"><span class="calibre15">(4).  Grana</span></b><b class="calibre36">:</b> Thylakoids are arranged in the form of discs stacked one above the other called granum Grana, are interconnected by stroma lamellae.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_338">12.9.3 Functions of Chloroplast</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">Photosynthesis </li>
	<li class="block_1049">Storage of starch</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Synthesis of fatty acids </li>
	<li class="block_1049">Storage of lipids</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Formation of chloroplasts</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_339">12.9.4 Photosynthesis</h3>
	<p class="block_1002"> <img src="images/image-183.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of OASPVL" class="calibre278"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Photosynthesis (Photo = light; synthesis = to build) is a process by which autotrophic organisms like green plants, algae and chlorophyll containing bacteria utilize the energy from sunlight to synthesize their own food. In this process, carbon dioxide combines with water in the presence of sunlight and chlorophyll to form carbohydrates. During this process oxygen is released as a by-product.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-184.png" alt="6CO2 PLUS 12 H2O GIVES WITH LIGHT AND CHOLOROPHYLE C6H12O6 PLUS 6 H2O PLUS 6O2 GAS" class="calibre279"/></p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001">Carbon dioxide + Water gives Glucose + water + Oxygen (In the presence of light and chlorophyll)</p>
	<p class="block_254"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_340">12.9.5 Where does photosynthesis occur?</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Photosynthesis occurs in all green parts of the plant especially in green leaves. </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_341">12.9.6 Photosynthetic Pigments</h3>
	<p class="block_1001"><span class="calibre15">Pigments involved   in   photosynthesis are called Photosynthetic pigments. Photosynthetic pigments are of two classes namely, the primary pigments and accessory pigments. chlorophyll (a )is the primary pigment that traps solar energy and converts it into electrical and chemical energy. Thus, it is called the reaction centre. Other pigments such as chlorophyll b and carotenoids are called accessory pigments as they pass on the absorbed energy to chlorophyll a (Chl.a) molecule. Reaction centres (primary pigments and harvesting centre) (accessory pigments) together form photo systems.</span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_342">12.9.7 Role of Sunlight in Photosynthesis</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The entire process of photosynthesis takes place inside the chloroplast. The structure of chloroplast is such that the light dependent (Light reaction) and light independent (Dark reaction) take place at different sites in the organelle</p>
	<h4 class="block_103">(1). Light dependent Reaction (Hill reaction or Light reaction)</h4>
	<p class="block_1001">This was discovered by Robin Hill (1939). This reaction takes place in the presence of light energy in thylakoid membranes (grana) of the chloroplasts. Photosynthetic pigments absorb the light energy and convert it into chemical energy ATP and NADPH+H<sup class="calibre27">+</sup>. These products of light reaction move out from the thylakoid to the stroma of the chloroplast.</p>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<table class="table_6">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_648"><p class="block_1050">ATP</p></td>
			<td class="td_649"><p class="block_1050">Adenosine Triphosphate</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_650"><p class="block_195">ADP</p></td>
			<td class="td_651"><p class="block_195">Adenosine Diphosphate</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_652"><p class="block_1051">N A D</p></td>
			<td class="td_653"><p class="block_1052">Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_654"><p class="block_1051">N A D P</p></td>
			<td class="td_655"><p class="block_1053">Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide Phosphate</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_12">Do you Know?</p>
	<p class="block_">A cell cannot get its energy directly from glucose. So, in respiration the energy released from glucose is used to make ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate)</p>
	<h4 class="block_103">(2). Light independent reactions (Dark reaction) (Biosynthetic phase)</h4>
	<p class="block_985">Dark reaction or biosynthetic pathway takes place in stroma. During this reaction C O2 is reduced into carbohydrates with the help of light generated ATP and N A DPH+H<sup class="calibre27">+</sup>. This is also called as Calvin cycle and is carried out in the absence of light. It is called dark reaction.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In Calvin cycle the inputs are CO2 from the atmosphere and the ATP and NADPH+H<sup class="calibre27">+</sup> produced from light reaction.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 12.9 Overview of Hill and Calvin cycle</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-185.png" alt="Image of Overview of Hill and Calvin cycle" class="calibre280"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-186.png" alt="Image of Melvin Calvin" class="calibre281"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Melvin Calvin, an American biochemist, discovered chemical pathway for photosynthesis. The cycle is named as Calvin cycle. He was awarded with Nobel Prize in the year 1961 for his discovery.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_343">12.9.8 Factors Affecting Photosynthesis</h3>
	<h4 class="block_103">a) Internal Factors:</h4>
	<p class="block_9">1 Pigments</p>
	<p class="block_9">2 Leaf age</p>
	<p class="block_9">3 Accumulation of carbohydrates</p>
	<p class="block_9">4 Hormones</p>
	<h4 class="block_103">b) External Factors:</h4>
	<p class="block_9">1 Light</p>
	<p class="block_9">2 Carbon dioxide</p>
	<p class="block_9">3 Temperature</p>
	<p class="block_9">4 Water</p>
	<p class="block_9">5 Mineral elements</p>
	<p class="block_12">Info bit</p>
	<p class="block_">Artificial photosynthesis is a method for producing renewable energy by the use of sunlight. Indian scientist C.N.R. Rao who was conferred the Bharat Ratna (2013) is also working on similar technology of artificial photosynthesis to produce - Hydrogen fuel (renewable energy).</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-187.png" alt="Image of C.N.R.Rao" class="calibre282"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_344">12.10 Mitochondria</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Mitochondria are filamentous or granular cytoplasmic organelles present in cells. The mitochondria were first discovered by Kolliker in 1857 as granular structures in striated muscles. Mitochondria (singular: mitochondrion) are organelles within eukaryotic cells that produce adenosine triphosphate (ATP) which form the energy currency of the cell, for this reason, the mitochondria is referred to as the “Powerhouse of the cell”. Mitochondria vary in size from 0.5 mew m to 2.0 mew m. </p>
	<p class="block_1001">Mitochondria contain 60-70% protein, 25-30% lipids, 5-7% RNA and small amount of DNA and minerals.</p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_345">12.10.1 Structure of Mitochondria</h3>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Mitochondrial Membranes</b>: It consists of two membranes called inner and outer membrane. Each membrane is 60 to 70  Angstrom  thick. Outer mitochondrial membrane is smooth and freely permeable to most small molecules. It contains enzymes, proteins and lipids. It has porin molecules (proteins) which form channels for passage of molecules through it.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Inner mitochondrial membrane is semi permeable membrane and regulates the passage of materials into and out of the mitochondria. It is rich in enzymes and carrier proteins. It consists of 80% proteins and lipids.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 12.10 Structure of Mitochondria</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-188.png" alt="This picture shows the image of mitochondria" class="calibre283"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Cristae:</b> The inner mitochondrial membrane gives rise to finger like projections called cristae. These cristae increase the inner surface area (fold in inner membrane) of the mitochondria to hold variety of enzymes.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Oxysomes:</b> The inner mitochondrial membrane bear minute regularly spaced tennis racket shaped particles known as oxysomes (F1particle). They involve in ATP synthesis.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 12.11 Structure of Oxysomes</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-189.png" alt="Image of Structure of Oxysomes " class="calibre284"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Mitochondrial matrix</b> - It is a complex mixture of proteins and lipids. Matrix contains enzymes for Krebs cycle, mitochondrial ribosomes (70 S), tRNAs and mitochondrial DNA.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_346">12.10.2 Functions of Mitochondria</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Mitochondria is the main organelle of cell respiration. They produce a large number of ATP molecules. </p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">So, they are called as power houses of the cell or ATP factory of the cell.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It helps the cells to maintain normal concentration of calcium ions.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It regulates the metabolic activity of the cell.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_347">12.11 TYPES OF RESPIRATION</h2>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image789.jpeg" alt="Image which shows the Tree intake oxygen and expels carbon dioxide in the night and vice verse in the Day " class="calibre285"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Respiration involves exchange of gases between the organism and the external environment. The plants obtain oxygen from their environment and release carbon dioxide and water vapour. This exchange of gases is known as external respiration. It is a physical process. Biochemical process occurs within cells where the food is oxidized to obtain energy, this is known as cellular respiration.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_348">12.11.1 Aerobic respiration</h3>
	<p class="block_985"><span class="text_4">Aerobic respiration is the type of cellular respiration in which organic food is completely oxidized with the help of oxygen into carbon dioxide, water and energy. It occurs in most plants and animals.</span> </p>
	<p class="block_985"><img src="images/image-190.png" alt="CLUCOSE PLUS 6 OXYGEN GIVES 6 CARBON DI OXIDE PLUS 6 WATER MOLECULESPLUS ENERGYU" class="calibre286"/></p>
	<p class="block_1056"> </p>
	<p class="block_1057"> </p>
	<h4 class="block_103">Stages of Aerobic respiration</h4>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_12">a. </p>
	<p class="block_12">Glycolysis (Glucose splitting):</p>
	<p class="block_"> It is the breakdown of one molecule of glucose (6 carbon) into two molecules of pyruvic acid (3 carbon). Glycolysis takes place in cytoplasm of the cell. It is the first step of both aerobic and anaerobic respiration.</p>
	<p class="block_12">b.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6"> Krebs Cycle:</b> This cycle occurs in mitochondria matrix. At the end of glycolysis, 2 molecules of pyruvic acid enter into mitochondria. The oxidation of pyruvic acid into C O2 and water takes place through this cycle. It is also called Tricarboxylic Acid Cycle (TCA).</p>
	<p class="block_12">c.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6"> Electron Transport Chain:</b> This is accomplished through a system of electron carrier complex called electron transport chain (E T C) located on the inner membrane of the mitochondria. NADH+H+ and FADH2 molecules formed during glycolysis and Krebs cycle are oxidised to N A D+ and F A D to release the energy via electrons. The electrons, as they move through the system, release energy which is trapped by ADP to synthesize ATP. This is called oxidative phosphorylation. In this process, O2 the ultimate acceptor of electrons gets reduced to water.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_349">12.11.2 </h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_350">Anaerobic respiration</h3>
	<p class="block_">Anaerobic respiration takes place without oxygen. Glucose is converted into ethanol </p>
	<p class="block_">(Ethanol fermentation by yeast) or lactic acid (lactic acid fermentation by bacteria).</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-191.png" alt="CLUCOSE GIVES 2 CARBON DI OXIDE PLUS 2 ETHANAL PLUS ENERGY (ATP)" class="calibre287"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_351">12.11.3 </h3>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_352">Respiratory quotient (R.Q)</h3>
	<p class="block_">Respiratory quotient is the ratio of volume of carbon dioxide liberated and the volume of oxygen consumed during respiration. It is expressed as</p>
	<p class="block_">RQ = Volume of CO2 liberated by Volume of O2 consumed.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_353">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Tissue is a group of similar or dissimilar cells, having a common origin and performing similar functions.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Plants are capable of synthesizing glucose from C O2 and H2O in the presence of light, by the process of photosynthesis.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Light reaction takes place in grana of chloroplast.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Dark reaction takes place in stroma of chloroplast.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Respiration involves both external and cellular respiration.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Aerobic respiration takes place in the presence of oxygen.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Aerobic respiration occurs in three major steps like Glycolysis, Krebs cycle and Electron transport chain.</li>
</ul>

	<h1 class="block_99" id="toc_id_370">UNIT-13 <b class="calibre6">STRUCTURAL ORGANISATION OF ANIMALS</b></h1>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-195.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of YDUIH" class="calibre291"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_371">Learning Objectives<span class="tab">      </span></h2>
	<p class="block_9">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">Understand the external morphology of the leech and rabbit.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Recognise the structural features of different organ systems.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Will be able to understand the physiology of various organ systems of leech and rabbit.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Learn the parasitic adaptations of leech.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Identify the type of dentition and its significance in rabbit.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Perceive the differences between the structural organisation of an invertebrate (leech) and vertebrate (rabbit).</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_372">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">The variety in nature and habits of animals in the biosphere are quite amazing and interesting. What we see around us may be just few, but there are innumerable species living in this world. You have learnt in lower classes about the classification of animal kingdom. We will recall here that ‘Kingdom Animalia’ is divided into two groups, Invertebrates and Chordates.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">There occurs a great diversity in the habit, habitat, structural organisation and mode of reproduction between the animals existing on earth. In this chapter, you will understand the structural morphology and anatomy of an Invertebrate (Leech) and a Vertebrate (Rabbit).</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The scientific name of the Indian cattle leech is Hirudinaria granulosa which belongs to Phylum Annelida. Annelids are metamerically segmented worms with well-developed organ systems.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The scientific name of the common rabbit is Oryctolagus cuniculus. It is representing Phylum Chordata and Class Mammalia. Mammals occupy the highest group in the animal kingdom and show advancement over the other groups of animals. They are warm blooded and possess covering of hair on the body. Mammary gland in females is the most striking feature of a mammal. Let us now study about the morphology of leech and rabbit in detail.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_373">13.1 The Indian Cattle Leech (Hirudinaria granulosa)</h2>
	<table class="table_67">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td colspan="2" class="td_656"><p class="block_1064">Taxonomic Position</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_657"><p class="block_1065">Phylum</p></td>
			<td class="td_483"><p class="block_43">Annelida</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_658"><p class="block_1065">Class</p></td>
			<td class="td_481"><p class="block_43">Hirudinea</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_657"><p class="block_1065">Order</p></td>
			<td class="td_483"><p class="block_43">Gnathobdellida</p></td>

		<tr class="calibre12">

		</tr>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_374">13.1.1Habit and Habitat</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Hirudinaria granulosa (Indian Cattle Leech) is found in India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Myanmar and Sri Lanka. It lives in freshwater ponds, lakes, swamps and slow streams. They are ectoparasitic and feed on the blood of fishes, frogs, cattle and human. It is sanguivorous (blood sucking) in nature.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_375">13.1.2External Morphology</h3>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Shape and Size:</b> The body of a leech is soft, vermiform, elongated and segmented. It becomes ribbon shaped when extended and almost cylindrical when contracted. Leeches may grow to a length of 35cm.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Colouration:</b> Dorsal surface is olive green in colour and the ventral surface is orange yellow or orange red in colour.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Segmentation:</b> Metamerism is the segmentation of the body. The body of leech is metamerically divided into 33 segments. The segments are arranged one behind the other. Each segment is further superficially subdivided into rings or annuli. A temporary clitellum is formed on segments 9-11, which is meant to produce a cocoon during the breeding season.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Receptors:</b> On the dorsal side there are five pairs of eyes on the first five segments. Each segment bears a number of sensory projections called receptors. Annular receptors are located in each annulus and segmental receptors are located on the first annulus of each segment.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-196.png" alt="1 External morphology of Leech   A. Dorsal View                      B. Ventral view. parts of dorsal view eyes anus posterior sucker. segmental receptor organs. parts of ventral view mouth first nephridiopore male genital aperture female genital aperture nephridiopores." class="calibre292"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 13.1 External morphology of Leech</p>
	<p class="block_1067">1 Dorsal View</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">                                        2 </span>Ventral view</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Suckers:</b> Leech has two suckers. The sucker located at the anterior end is called anterior sucker or oral sucker which is ventral in position occupying the first five segments. The posterior sucker is formed by the fusion of the last seven segments. The anterior sucker helps in feeding, while both the suckers help in attachment and locomotion.</p>
	<p class="block_12">External apertures</p>
	<p class="block_1068"> </p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_1069"><b class="calibre6">Mouth:</b> It is located in the middle of anterior sucker.</li>
	<li class="block_1070"><b class="calibre6">Anus:</b> Anus is a small aperture that opens on the mid-dorsal side of 26th segment.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_533"><b class="calibre6">3 Nephridiopores:</b> Nephridia open to the exterior by 17 pairs of nephridiopores. They lie ventrally on the last annulus of each segment from 6 to 22.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="4" class="block_7"><b class="calibre6">Male genital pore:</b> It is a mid-ventral opening, situated between second and third annuli of 10<sup class="calibre27">th</sup> segment.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Female genital pore: It lies mid-ventrally between second and third annuli of 11th segment.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Activity 1</p>
	<p class="block_">Observe the external morphology of leech specimen in your biology laboratory.</p>
	<p class="block_">Can you find leeches in your locality?</p>
	<p class="block_">In which geographical areas are leeches found more predominantly in India?</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_376">13.1.3Divisions of the Body</h3>
	<p class="block_">The body of leech is divided into six regions.</p>
	<table class="table_55">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">

			<td class="td_480"><p class="block_1073">Middle region</p></td>
			<td class="td_481"><p class="block_1073">Twelfth to twenty second</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_482"><p class="block_1076">Caudal region</p></td>
			<td class="td_483"><p class="block_1077"><span class="calibre15">Twenty  third  </span></p><p class="block_1077">to </p><p class="block_1077">Twenty sixth</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_484"><p class="block_1076">Posterior sucker</p></td>
			<td class="td_485"><p class="block_1077">Twenty seventh to 33</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_377">13.1.4Body wall</h3>
	<p class="block_63">Body wall of leech includes five layers:</p>
	<p class="block_1054">1 cuticle (outermost layer) 2 epidermis which lies below the cuticle 3<span class="calibre28"> dermis which lies below the   epidermis   formed of connective tissue </span>4 muscular layer formed of circular and longitudinal muscles 5 botryoidal tissue lies beneath longitudinal muscles and fills the entire coelom around the gut.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_378">13.1.5Locomotion</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Locomotion in leech takes place by 1 looping or crawling movement 2 Swimming movement.</p>
	<div class="calibre139">
	<div class="block_1078"><span class="bullet_">1 </span><span class="calibre18"><b class="calibre36">Looping or Crawling movement</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_1079">This type of movement is brought about by the contraction and relaxation of muscles. The two suckers serve for attachment during movement on a substratum.</p>
	<div class="calibre139">
	<div class="block_1078"><span class="bullet_">2 </span><span class="calibre18"><b class="calibre36">Swimming movement</b></span></div>
</div>
	<p class="block_1079">Leeches swim very actively and perform undulating movements in water.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_379">13.1.6Digestive System</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The digestive system includes the long alimentary canal and the digestive glands.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Alimentary Canal</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The alimentary canal of leech is a straight tube running from the mouth to the anus. Mouth is a triradiate aperture situated in the middle of the anterior sucker that leads into the small buccal cavity. The wall of the buccal cavity bears three jaws with single row of minute teeth. The jaws are provided with papillae which bear the openings of salivary glands. Mouth and buccal cavity occupy the first five segments.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The buccal cavity leads into muscular pharynx. It is surrounded by salivary glands. The secretion of saliva contains hirudin which prevents the coagulation of blood. Pharynx leads into crop through a short and narrow oesophagus.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Crop is the largest portion of the alimentary canal. It is divided into a series of 10 chambers. The chambers communicate with one another through circular apertures surrounded by sphincters. A pair of laterals, backwardly directed caecae arises as blind outgrowth from each chamber known as caeca or diverticula. Crop and its diverticula can store large amount of blood which can be slowly digested.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The last chamber of crop opens into stomach. The stomach leads into intestine which is a small straight tube that opens into rectum. The rectum opens to the exterior by anus.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Food, Feeding and Digestion</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The leech feeds by sucking the blood of cattle and other domestic animals. During feeding the leech attaches itself to its victim strongly by the posterior sucker. The leech makes a triradiate or Y shaped incision in the skin of the host by the jaws protruded through the mouth. The blood is sucked by muscular pharynx and the salivary secretion is poured.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The ingested blood is stored in crop chambers and its diverticulum. The blood passes from the crop into the stomach. Digestion takes place in stomach by the action of proteolytic enzyme. The digested blood is then absorbed slowly by the intestine. Undigested food is stored in rectum and egested through anus.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Leeches prevent blood clotting by secreting a protein called hirudin. They also inject an anaesthetic substance that prevents the host from feeling their bite.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-197.png" alt="Digestive system of Leech. parts of digestive system of leech jaw pharynx oesophagus crop chambers crop diverticulla stomach intestine rectum anus." class="calibre293"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 13.2 Digestive system of Leech</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">More to Know</b><span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Leeches do not have ear, hence can sense vibrations through their skin.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Leeches have 2 to 10 tiny eyes, which helps them to locate their food.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Leeches can suck blood five times more than their body weight. It may take more than a year for the complete digestion and absorption of a full meal.</li>
</ul>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_380">13.1.7Respiratory System</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Respiration takes place through the skin in leech. Dense network of tiny blood vessels called as capillaries containing the haemocoelic fluid extend in between the cells of the epidermis. The exchange of respiratory gases takes place by diffusion. Oxygen dissolved in water diffuses through the skin into haemocoelic fluid, while carbon dioxide diffuses out. The skin is kept moist and slimy due to secretion of mucus which also prevents it from drying.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_381">13.1.8Circulatory System</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">In leech, circulation is brought about by haemocoelic system. There are no true blood vessels. The blood vessels are replaced by channels called haemocoelic channels or canals filled with blood like fluid. The coelomic fluid contains haemoglobin.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">There are four longitudinal channels. One channel lies above (dorsal) the alimentary canal, one below (ventral) the alimentary canal. The other two channels lie on either (lateral) side of the alimentary canal which serve as heart and have inner valves. All the four channels are connected together posteriorly in the 26th segment.</p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_382">13.1.9Nervous System</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The central nervous system of leech consists of a nerve ring and a paired ventral nerve cord. The nerve ring surrounds the pharynx and is formed of suprapharyngeal ganglion (brain), circumpharyngeal connective and subpharyngeal ganglion. The subpharyngeal ganglion lies below the pharynx and is formed by the fusion of four pairs of ganglia.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-198.png" alt="Nervous system of Leech. parts of nervous system of leech brain ventral nerve card ganglion." class="calibre294"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 13.3 Nervous system of Leech</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_383">13.1.10Excretory System</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">In leech, excretion takes place by segmentally arranged paired tubules called nephridia. There are 17 pairs of nephridia which open out by nephridiopores from 6th to 22nd segments.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_384">13.1.11Reproductive System</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Leech is hermaphrodite because both the male and female reproductive organs are present in the same animal.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Male Reproductive System</p>
	<p class="block_1054">There are eleven pairs of testes, one pair in each segment from 12 to 22 segments. They are in the form of spherical sacs called testes sacs. From each testis arises a short duct called vas deferens, which join with the vas deferens. The vas deferens becomes convoluted to form the epididymis or sperm vesicle, to store spermatozoa.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The epididymis leads to a short duct called ejaculatory duct. The ejaculatory ducts on both sides join to form the genital atrium. The atrium consists of two regions, the coiled prostate glands and the penial sac consisting of penis that opens through the male genital pore.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Female Reproductive System</p>
	<p class="block_1054">It consists of ovaries, oviducts and vagina. There is a single pair of ovaries in the 11th segment on the ventral side. Each ovary is a coiled ribbon-shaped structure.</p>
	<p class="block_">The ova are budded off from the ovary. From each ovary runs a short oviduct. The oviducts of the two sides joins together, to form a common oviduct. The common oviduct opens into a pear-shaped vagina which lies mid-ventrally in the posterior part of the 11th segment.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Development</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li class="block_1088">Internal fertilization takes place. This is followed by cocoon formation. Cocoon is also known as egg case which is formed around the 9th, 10th and 11th segments.</li>
	<li class="block_1089">Development is direct and proceeds in cocoon which contain one to 24 embryos.</li>
	<li class="block_1090">Young leech resembling the adult emerges.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-199.png" alt="Reproductive system of Leech. parts of reproductive system of leech eyes first nephridum atrium epidiymis ovary testis sac vagina vas deferens 17th nephridum anus posterior sucker." class="calibre295"/></p>
	<p class="block_12"> Figure 13.4 Reproductive system of Leech</p>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_12">Medicinal value of Leech</p>
	<p class="block_">Leeches are effective in increasing blood circulation and breaking up blood clots. It is surprising that they can be used to treat cardiovascular diseases. Biochemical substances derived from leech saliva are used for preparation of pharmaceutical drugs that can treat hypertension.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_385">13.1.12Parasitic Adaptations of Leech</h3>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-200.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of C U 7 D B" class="calibre296"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Leeches lead a parasitic mode of life by sucking the blood of vertebrates and show several important adaptations in their structure.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Blood is sucked by pharynx.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Anterior and posterior ends of the body are provided with suckers by which the animal attaches itself to the body of the host.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The three jaws inside the mouth, causes a painless Y-shaped wound in the skin of the host.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The salivary glands produce hirudin which does not allow the blood to coagulate. Thus, a continuous supply of the blood is maintained.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Parapodia and setae are completely absent</li>
	<li class="block_8">Blood is stored in the crop. It gives nourishment to the leech for several months. Due to this reason, there is no elaborate secretion of the digestive juices and enzymes.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Do you Know?</p>
	<p class="block_">Bloodletting is a technique of bleeding in a patient to remove toxic impurities from the body.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_386">13.2 Rabbit (Oryctolagus cuniculus)</h2>
	<p class="block_">Taxonomic - Position</p>
