	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_387">13.2.1 Habit and Habitat</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Rabbits are gentle and timid animals. They show leaping movement and live in burrows. They are distributed throughout the world. They are herbivorous animals feeding on grass and vegetables like turnips, carrots and lettuce. Rabbits are gregarious (moving in groups) animals.</p>
	<p class="block_1092"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">Do you Know?</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The pygmy rabbit was listed as a threatened species in Washington in 1990, because of decline in its population size and distribution due to habitat loss. In March 2003, the Columbia Basin Pygmy Rabbit was federally listed as an endangered species.</p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_388">13.2.2External Morphology</h3>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-201.png" alt=" Rabbit- External features. external feature of rabbit has following parts. eye ear neck trunk mouth upper arm fore arm digits foot thigh tail. " class="calibre297"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 13.5 Rabbit- External features</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Shape, Size and Colouration: It has an elongated and cylindrical body. Males and females are of the same size. They grow about 45 cm in length and weigh about 2.25 kg as adult. The colour varies from white to black and white. Body is covered with fur which serves to keep it warm.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Body-division:</b> The body of the rabbit is divisible into the head, neck, trunk and tail.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Head:</b> Head is ovoid, flattened and bears a truncate snout. It contains mouth, external nares, eyes, ears and vibrissae. The mouth is a transverse slit-like bounded by upper lip and lower lip. Just above the mouth are two oblique openings called nostrils. From each side of the upper lip tactile hairs or vibrissae (whiskers) project outwards. A pair of large, movable external ear or pinnae is situated at the top of the head.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Neck:</b> The neck connects the head with the trunk. It helps to turn the head.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Trunk:</b> The trunk is divisible into an anterior thorax and a posterior abdomen. In females, four or five teats or nipples are present on the ventral surface between the thorax and abdomen.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The trunk bears two pairs of pentadactyl limbs. The forelimbs are shorter than the hind limbs. All the digits bear claws.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The anus is present at the posterior end of the abdomen at the base of tail. In females on the ventral side a slit like vulva is present. In male’s penis is present in the ventral side of anus. The male has a pair of testes enclosed by scrotal sacs.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Tail:</b> The tail is short. It is used to give signals to other rabbits in the event of danger.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">In tegument (Skin): The in tegument forms the outer covering of the body. The structures which are derived from it are hairs, claws, nails and glands like sweat glands, sebaceous glands and </p>
	<p class="block_1001">mammary glands.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Mammary glands are modified glands of the skin. They secrete milk and help in nourishing young ones. The sweat glands and sebaceous glands embedded in the skin regulate the body temperature.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_389">13.2.3Coelom (Body cavity)</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Rabbit is a coelomate animal. The body is divisible into thoracic cavity and abdominal cavity separated by transverse partition called diaphragm. Diaphragm is the characteristic feature of mammals. Breathing movements are brought by the movement of the diaphragm.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Lungs and heart lie in the thoracic cavity, whereas abdominal cavity encloses digestive and urinogenital system.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_390">13.2.4Digestive System</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The digestive system includes the alimentary canal and the associated digestive glands. The alimentary canal consists of mouth, buccal cavity, pharynx, oesophagus, stomach, small intestine, caecum, large intestine and anus.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Mouth is a transverse slit bounded by upper and lower lips. It leads into the buccal cavity. The floor of the buccal cavity is occupied by a muscular tongue. Jaws bear teeth.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The buccal cavity leads into the oesophagus through the pharynx. Oesophagus opens into the stomach followed by small intestine. Caecum is a thin-walled sac present at the junction of small intestine and large intestine. It contains bacteria that helps in digestion of cellulose. The small intestine opens into the large intestine which has colon and rectum. The rectum finally opens outside by the anus.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Digestive glands</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The digestive glands are salivary glands, gastric glands, liver, pancreas and intestinal glands. The secretions of digestive glands help in digestion of food in the alimentary canal.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Dentition in Rabbit</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Teeth are hard bone-like structures used to cut, tear and grind the food materials. The rabbit has two sets of teeth. The existence of two sets of teeth in the life of an animal is called diphyodont dentition. The two types of teeth are milk teeth (young ones) and permanent teeth (in adults).</p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-202.png" alt="figure 13.6 Digestive System of Rabbit has following parts liver gall bladder oesophagus stomach pancreas small intestine caecum colon rectum anus. " class="calibre298"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 13.6 Digestive System of Rabbit</p>
	<p class="block_1001">In rabbit the teeth are of different types. Hence, the dentition is called heterodont. There are four kinds of teeth in mammals namely. the incisors (I), canines (C), premolars (PM) and molars (M). This is expressed in the form of a dental formula.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-203.png" alt="figure 13.7 Dentition of Rabbit (Arrangement of teeth in jaws) has following parts. upper jaw diastema premolars molars incisors lower jaw." class="calibre299"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 13.7 Dentition of Rabbit (Arrangement of teeth in jaws)</p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001">Dental formula is the simple method of representing the teeth of a mammal. The number of each kind of tooth in the upper and the lower jaws on one side is counted.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Dental formula is: I(2 by 1), C (0 by 0), PM (3 by 2), M (3 by 3).</p>
	<p class="block_1001">in rabbit which is written as2033 by 1023. Canines are absent. The gap between the incisors and premolar is called diastema. It helps inmastication and chewing of food in herbivorous animals.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_391">13.2.5Respiratory System</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Respiration takes place by a pair of lungs, which are light spongy tissues enclosed in the thoracic cavity. The thoracic cavity is bound dorsally by the vertebral column and ventrally by the sternum, laterally by the ribs. On the lower side of the thoracic cavity is the dome shaped diaphragm.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-204.png" alt="figure 13.8 Lungs of Rabbit has folllowing parts larynx trachea bronchi right anterior lobe left anterior lobe lobules right posterior lobe left posterior lobe." class="calibre300"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure. 13.8 Lungs of Rabbit</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Each lung is enclosed by a double membranous pleura. Atmospheric air passes through the external nostril and nasal passages into the pharynx. From the pharynx it passes through the glottis into the windpipe.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The anterior part of the windpipe is enlarged to form the larynx or voice box with its wall supported by four cartilaginous plates. Inside the larynx lies the vocal cord and its vibrations result in the production of sound. The larynx leads into trachea or windpipe.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Tracheal walls are supported by rings of cartilage which help in the free passage of air. The epiglottis prevents the entry of food into the trachea through the glottis. The trachea divides into two branches called the bronchi one entering into each lung and dividing into further branches called bronchioles which end in alveoli.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The respiratory events consist of inspiration (breathing in) and expiration (breathing out) allowing exchange of gases (oxygen and carbon dioxide). Inspiration is an active process while expiration is a passive process.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-205.png" alt="figure 13.9 heart of Rabbit having following parts left precaval vein right precaval vein systemic arch right auricle left auricle right ventricle left ventricle pulmonary artery dorsal aorta." class="calibre301"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure. 13.9 Heart of Rabbit – Ventral View</p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_392">13.2.6Circulatory System</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The circulatory system is formed of blood, blood vessels and heart. The heart is pear shaped and lies in the thoracic cavity in between the lungs. It is enclosed by pericardium, a double layered membrane.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The heart is four chambered with two auricles and two ventricles. The right and left auricles are separated by interarticular septum, similarly right and left ventricles are separated by interventricular septum.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The right auricle opens into the right ventricle by right auriculoventricular aperture, guarded by a tricuspid valve. The left auricle opens into the left ventricle by left auriculoventricular aperture guarded by a bicuspid valve or mitral valve. The opening of the pulmonary artery and aorta are guarded by three semilunar valves.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The right auricle receives deoxygenated blood through two precaval (superior vena cava) and one postcaval (inferior vena cava) veins from all parts of the body. The left auricle receives oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins from the lungs. From the right ventricle arises pulmonary trunk which carries the deoxygenated blood to the lungs and from the left ventricle arises the systemic arch (aorta) which supplies oxygenated blood to all parts of the body.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_393">13.2.7 Nervous System</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The nervous system in rabbit is formed of the central nervous system (CNS), peripheral nervous system (P N S) and autonomic nervous system (A N S).</p>
	<p class="block_1054">CNS consists of brain and spinal cord. PN S is formed of 12 pairs of cranial nerves and 37 pairs of spinal nerves. A N S comprises sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Brain is situated in the cranial cavity and covered by three membranes called an outer durometer, an inner piamater and a middle arachnoid membrane. The brain is divided into forebrain (prosencephalon), (mesencephalon) and midbrain (rhombencephalon).</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Forebrain consists of a pair of olfactory lobes, cerebral hemispheres and diencephalon. The right and left cerebral hemispheres are connected by transverse band of nerve tissue called corpus callosum.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-206.png" alt="figure 13.10 Brain of Rabbit (Dorsal view) having following parts olfactory lobe cerebral hemisphere diencephalom optic lobs cerebellum medulla oblongata." class="calibre302"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure. 13.10 Brain of Rabbit (Dorsal view)</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001">The midbrain includes the optic lobes. The hindbrain consists of the cerebellum, pons varolii and medulla oblongata. You will study about the details of mammalian brain in the chapter on nervous system.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_394">13.2.8Urinogenital System</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">It comprises the urinary or excretory system and the genital or reproductive system. Therefore, they are usually described as urinogenital system in vertebrates.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Excretory system</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Each kidney is made of several nephrons. It separates the nitrogenous wastes from blood and excretes it in the form of urea. Kidneys are dark red, bean shaped organs situated in the abdominal cavity. From each kidney arises the ureters which open posteriorly into the urinary bladder and leads into a thick-walled muscular duct called urethra.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Reproductive System</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Sexual dimorphism is exhibited in rabbits. The male and female sexes are separate and are morphologically different.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Male Reproductive system</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The male reproductive system of rabbit consists of a pair of testes which are ovoid in shape. Testes are enclosed by scrotal sacs in the abdominal cavity. Each testis consists of numerous fine tubules called seminiferous tubules. This network of tubules leads into a coiled tubule called epididymis, which lead into the sperm duct called vas deferens. The vas deferens join in the urethra just below the urinary bladder. The urethra runs backward and passes into the penis.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">There are three accessory glands namely prostate gland, Cowper’s gland and perineal gland. Their secretions are involved in reproduction.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-207.png" alt="figure 13.11 Male reproductive system of Rabbit has following parts right kidney left kidney ureter urinary bladder prostate glands cowper's glands perileal glands vas deferens epididymis testis scrotal sac urethra.  " class="calibre303"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Fig. 13.11 Male reproductive system of Rabbit</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Female reproductive system</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The female reproductive system of rabbit consists of a pair of ovaries which are small ovoid structures. They are located behind the kidneys in the abdominal cavity.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">A pair of oviducts opens into the body cavity by a funnel shaped opening from each side of the ovary. The anterior part of the oviduct is the fallopian tube. It leads into a wider tube called the uterus. The uterus joins together to form a median tube called vagina. The common tube is formed by the union of urinary bladder and the vagina and is called the urinogenital canal or vestibule. It runs backwards and opens to the exterior by a slit- like aperture called vulva.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">A pair of Cowper’s gland and perineal gland are the accessory glands present in the female reproductive system.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-208.png" alt="figure 13.12 reproductive system  of Rabbit  has following parts ovary kidney ureter vagina fallopian tube uterus urinary bladder perineal gland urethra. " class="calibre304"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure. 13.12 Female reproductive system of Rabbit</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Points to Remember</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1093">Leech is metamerically segmented and has 33 segments.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">It has two suckers which are used to attach to the body of the host. It is also involved in locomotion.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">The salivary glands of leech produce an anticoagulating substance called hirudin.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">Leech is a hermaphrodite.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">Rabbits are warm blooded vertebrates.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">Canine teeth are absent in rabbit.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">Respiration takes place through a pair of lungs in rabbit.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">The heart is four chambered consisting of two auricles and two ventricles.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">Urinogenital system comprises the urinary (or) excretory system and the genital (or) reproductive system.</li>
	<li class="block_1093">Mammary glands are modified glands of the skin and help in nourishing the young ones.</li>
</ol>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_405">UNIT-14 <b class="calibre6">TRANSPORTATION IN PLANTS AND CIRCULATION IN ANIMALS</b></h1>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-211.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of DLS6X" class="calibre307"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_406">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">Learn how the water and minerals move from soil to the plant.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Learn how prepared food by the leaf is translocated to various parts of the plant.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the role of osmosis and transpiration.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the composition of blood.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Identify and explain the structure of heart and associated blood vessels.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand systemic, pulmonary and coronary circulation.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Differentiate the events of the cardiac cycle.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Know about blood pressure and heartbeat.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the use of stethoscope and sphygmomanometer.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Identify the different blood groups.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the role of lymphatic system.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_407">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Multicellular organisms possess millions of cells in their body. Every cell needs a constant supply of essential substances like nutrients and oxygen to maintain life and survival. Food is the only source of energy, and every cell gets its energy by the breakdown of glucose. The cells utilise this energy and govern various vital activities of life.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Have you ever wondered how water and nutrients absorbed by the root are transported to the leaves? How is the food prepared by the leaves carried to the other parts of the plant? Do you know how water reaches the top of tall plants in spite of not having a circulatory system like animals? Water absorbed by the roots have to reach entire plant and the food synthesised by the leaves have to be distributed to all the parts of the plant. To understand this, we need to recall the anatomy of the plants. Water and mineral salts absorbed by the roots reach all parts of the plant through the xylem. The food synthesised by the leaves are translocated to all parts of the plant through the phloem. The bulk movement of substances through the vascular tissue is called Translocation.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">‘Transport’ means to carry things from one place to another. Have you ever wondered how in animals the useful substances are transported to other cells and toxic substances are removed? In larger organism's transport of nutrients, salts, oxygen, hormones and waste products around the body are performed by the ‘Circulatory system’. The circulatory system consists of the circulating fluids, the blood and lymph and the heart and blood vessels which form the collecting and transporting system.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_408">14.1 Means of Transport in Plants</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">The transport of materials in and out of the cells is carried out by diffusion and active transport in plants.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_409">14.1.1 Diffusion</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The movement of solid, liquid and gaseous molecules from a region of higher concentration to a region of their lower concentration without the utilization of energy is called diffusion. This is a passive process</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 14.1 Diffusion across cell membrane</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-212.png" alt="C:\Users\ADMIN\Pictures\Screenshots\Screenshot (231).png" class="calibre308"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_410">14.1.2 Active Transport</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Active transport utilizes energy to pump molecules against a concentration gradient. Active transport is carried out by membrane bound proteins. These proteins use energy to carry substances across the cell membrane hence they are often referred to as pumps. These pumps can transport substances from a low concentration to a high concentration (‘uphill’ transport).</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_411">14.1.3 Osmosis</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Osmosis is the movement of solvent or water molecules from the region of higher concentration to the region of lower concentration through a semi-permeable membrane. This process is carried out till an equilibrium is reached. Osmosis is the passive movement of water or any other solvent molecules.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Plasmolysis</p>
	<p class="block_1054">It occurs when a living plant cell is placed in a hypertonic solution water molecule moves out of the cell and resulting in the shrinkage of protoplasm away from the cell wall.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 14.2 Plasmolysis </p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-213.png" alt="In this image you could see both the Normal Plant cell and Plasmolysed Plant cell." class="calibre309"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">Activity 1</p>
	<p class="block_63">Demonstration of Osmosis</p>
	<p class="block_1054">A thistle funnel whose mouth is covered with a semipermeable membrane, is filled with sucrose solution. It is kept inverted in a beaker containing water. The water will diffuse across the membrane due to osmosis and raise the level of the solution in the funnel.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-214.png" alt="This picture shows the Demonstration of osmosis where you can see the Sugar solution in the funnel covered with parchment paper is kept inverted in a beaker containing water" class="calibre310"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">Imbibition</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Imbibition is a type of diffusion in which a solid plant material absorbs water and gets swelled up. </p>
	<p class="block_1054">Example absorption of water by dry seeds and grapes. If it were not for imbibition, seedlings would not have been able to emerge out of the soil.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_412">14.2 Root Hair-Water Absorbing Unit</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">There are millions of root hairs on the tip of the root which absorb water and minerals by diffusion. Root hairs are thin walled, slender extension of epidermal cell that increase the surface area of absorption.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 14.3 Root Tip with Root Hairs</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-215.png" alt="figure 14.3 h Root Hairs - has following parts  region of maturation root hair region of elongation region of meristematic activity root cap. " class="calibre311"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_413">14.3 Pathway of Water Absorbed by Roots</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Once the water enters the root hairs, the concentration of water molecules in the root hair cells become more than that of the cortex. Thus, water from the root hair moves to the cortical cells by osmosis and then reaches the xylem. From there the water is transported to the stem and leaves.</p>
	<p class="block_63"> Figure 14.4 T. S. of the root showing movement of water from soil to xylem</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-216.png" alt="figure 14.4 T. S. of the root showing movement of water from soil to xylem is as follows  water enter root hair cell then passes through root cortex cell and finally reaches xylem vessels." class="calibre312"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_414">14.4 Types of Movement of Water into the Root Cells</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Once water is absorbed by the root hairs, it can move deeper into root layers by two distinct pathways:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Apoplast pathway</li>
	<li class="block_65">Symplast pathway</li>
</ul>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_415">14.4.1 Apoplast Pathway</h3>
	<p class="block_">The apo plastic movement of water occurs exclusively through the intercellular spaces and the walls of the cells. Apo plastic movement does not involve crossing the cell membrane. This movement is dependent on the gradient.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_416">14.4.2 Symplast Pathway</h3>
	<p class="block_">In this method, the water molecules moves to the adjacent cells through the plasma membrane, cytoplasm and </p>
	<p class="block_">Plasmodesmata. This method of transport is slow as water moves through plasma membrane.</p>
	<p class="block_">It is in accordance to the concentration gradient. </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-217.png" alt="figure 14.5 Symplastic and Apoplastic pathways of Water - important parts are cell wall plasma membrane casparian strip apoplast symplast plasmodesmata endoderm pericycle cells." class="calibre313"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 14.5 Symplastic and Apo plastic pathways of Water</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_417">14.5 Transpiration</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Transpiration is the evaporation of water from the aerial parts of the plant through stomata in leaves. Stomata are open in the day and closed at night. The opening and closing of the stomata is due to the change in turgidity of the guard cells. When water enters into the guard cells, they become turgid and the stoma open. When the guard cells lose water, it becomes flaccid and the stoma closes.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Figure. 14.6 Process of Transpiration</p>
	<p class="block_985"><img src="images/image-218.png" alt="Process of Transpiration image where you can see a Small plant in a pot in which the leaves are enclosed in plastic bag. " class="calibre314"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Water evaporates from mesophyll cells of leaves through the open stomata, this lowers water concentration in mesophyll cells. As a result, more water is drawn into these cells from the xylem present in the veins through the process of osmosis. As water is lost from the leaves, pressure is created at the top to pull more water from the xylem to the mesophyll cells, this process is called transpiration pull. This extends up to the roots causing the roots to absorb more water from the soil to ensure continuous flow of water from the roots to the leaves.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_418">14.5.1 Factors affecting Transpiration</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Transpiration is affected by several external factors such as temperature, light, humidity, and wind speed. Internal factors that affect transpiration include number and distribution of stomata, percentage of open stomata, water status of the plant, canopy structure etc.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure. 14.7 Guard cell in turgid and flaccid condition</p>
	<p class="block_985"><img src="images/image-219.png" alt="figure 14.7 Guard cell in turgid and flaccid condition. the important parts for guard cell swollen position (stoma open) and guard cells shrunken position (stoma closed) are vacuole nucleus stoma cell wall chloroplast. " class="calibre315"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_419">Significance of Transpiration</h3>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Creates transpirational pull for transport of water</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Supplies water for photosynthesis</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Transports minerals from soil to all parts of the plant</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Cools the surface of the<span class="tab">      </span>leaves by evaporation.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Keeps the cells turgid; hence, maintains their shape</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_420">14.6 Root Pressure</h2>
	<p class="block_9">As mineral ions from the soil are actively transported into the xylem tissue of the root, water moves along and increases the pressure inside the xylem. This pressure is called root pressure and is responsible for pushing water upward to some extent</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_421">14.7 Uptake of Minerals</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Plants depend on minerals from soil for its nutritional requirements. All minerals cannot be passively absorbed by the roots. Two factors account for this: 1 minerals are present in the soil as charged particles (ions) that cannot move across cell membranes and 2 the concentration of minerals in the soil is usually lower than the concentration of minerals in the root. Therefore, most minerals enter the root by active absorption through the cytoplasm of epidermal cells. This needs energy in the form of ATP. Then it is transported to all parts by transpiration pull.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_422">14.8 Translocation of Mineral Ions</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Minerals are remobilised from older dying leaves to younger leaves. This phenomenon can be seen in deciduous plants. Elements like phosphorus, sulphur, nitrogen and potassium are easily mobilised, while elements like calcium are not remobilised. Small amounts of material exchange take place between xylem and phloem.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_423">14.9 Phloem Transport</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">The food synthesised by the leaves are transported by the phloem either to the area of requirement or stored. Phloem tissue is composed of sieve tubes which have sieve plates. Cytoplasmic strands pass through the pores in the sieve plates.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Phloem transports food (sucrose) from a source to a sink. The source is part of the plant that synthesize food, that is the leaf, and sink, is the part that needs or stores the food. But the source and sink may be reversed depending on the season, or the plant’s need.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Since the source-sink relationship is variable, the direction of movement in the phloem can be upwards or downwards, that is, bidirectional. In contrast, the movement is always unidirectional in xylem that is upwards.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_424">14.10 Translocation of Sugars</h2>
	<p class="block_9">The mechanism of translocation of sugars from source to sink is through pressure flow hypothesis Glucose prepared at source (by photosynthesis) is converted to sucrose. Sucrose moves into the companion cells, then into the living phloem sieve tube cells by active transport. This process produces a hypertonic condition in the phloem. Water in the adjacent xylem moves into the phloem by osmosis. As osmotic pressure builds up, the phloem sap moves to areas of lower pressure. By active transport sucrose moves into the cells where it is utilised or stored. As sugars are removed, the osmotic pressure decreases, and water moves out of the phloem.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_425">14.11 Ascent of Sap and its Events – An Overview</h2>
	<p class="block_">The upward movement of water and minerals from roots to different plant parts is called ascent of sap. A number of factors play a role in ascent of sap, and it takes places in following steps</p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 14.8 Ascent of Sap</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-220.png" alt="figure 14.8 Ascent of Sap -Explained as follows.  osmosis pushes water to root hairs. root pressure pushes water to stem. capillary action results in rise of water at the base of stem. adhesion cohesion makes column of water molecules . transpiration creates transpiration pull." class="calibre316"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">1 Root Pressure:</b> Water from soil enters the root hairs due to osmosis. Root pressure is responsible for movement of water up to the base of the stem.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">2 Capillary Action:</b> Water or any liquid rises in a capillary tube because of physical forces, this phenomenon is called capillary action. In the same way, in stem water rises up to certain height because of capillary action.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">3 Adhesion-cohesion of Water Molecules: </b>Water molecules form a continuous column in the xylem because of forces of adhesion and cohesion among the molecules.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">4 Cohesion:</b> The force of attraction between molecules of water is called cohesion.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">5 Adhesion:</b> The force of attraction between molecules of different substances is called adhesion. Water molecules stick to a xylem because of force of adhesion.</p>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Dews are water droplets on the leaves of grass seen in the early mornings, when the climate is humid and excess of water is present in the plants, the excess water is exudated in the form of liquid. This is due to root pressure. This phenomenon is called Guttation which takes place through specialized cells called Hydathodes.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Transpiration Pull:</b> Transpiration through stomata creates vacuum which creates a suction. called transpiration pull. The transpiration pull sucks the water column from the xylem tubes and thus water is able to rise to great heights even in the tallest plants.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Activity 2</p>
	<p class="block_63">Demonstration of Root Pressure</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Choose a small soft stemmed plant. Cut the stem horizontally near the base with a blade in the morning. You will see drops of solution oozing out of the cut stem due to root pressure.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_426">14.12 Blood</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Blood is the main circulatory medium in the human body. It is a red coloured fluid connective tissue.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Components of Blood:</b> The blood consists of two main components. The fluid plasma and the formed elements (blood cells) which are found suspended in the plasma.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Plasma:</b> It is slightly alkaline, containing non-cellular substance which constitutes about 55% of the blood. Organic substances like proteins, glucose, urea, enzymes, hormones, vitamins and minerals are present in the plasma.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Formed Elements of Blood</b>: Blood corpuscles are of three types</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">(1). Red blood corpuscles</b> (RBC) or Erythrocytes</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6"><span class="calibre28">(2).  White blood corpuscles</span></b> (WBC) or Leucocytes</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6"><span class="calibre28">(3).  Blood platelets</span></b> or Thrombocytes.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Red blood corpuscles (Erythrocytes)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">They are the most abundant cells in the human body. RBCs are formed in the bone marrow. The RBCs impart<span class="tab">      </span>red colour to the blood due to presence of respiratory pigment haemoglobin. Matured mammalian RBCs do not have cell organelles and nucleus. They are biconcave and disc shaped. Their life span is about 120 days. RBC is involved in the transport of oxygen from lungs to tissues.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Erythrocytes</p>
	<p class="block_985"><img src="images/image-221.png" alt="Image displays Erythrocytes" class="calibre317"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Why does mammalian RBC lack cell organelles and nucleus?</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Mammalian RBC lack nucleus and makes the cells biconcave and increase surface area for oxygen binding, loss of mitochondria allows the RBC to transport all the oxygen to tissues, and loss of endoplasmic reticulum allows more flexibility for RBC to move through the narrow capillaries.</p>
	<p class="block_63">White blood corpuscles (Leucocytes)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">WBCs are colourless. They do not have haemoglobin and are nucleated cells. It is found in the bone marrow, spleen, thymus and lymph nodes. They are capable of amoeboid movement</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image197.jpeg" alt="In this image you could see the images of Neutrophil, Eosinophil, Basophil, lymphocyte, monocyte" class="calibre318"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 14.9 Leucocytes</p>
	<p class="block_63">The white blood corpuscles can be grouped into two categories:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64"><b class="calibre6">Granulocytes<span class="tab">      </span></b></li>
	<li class="block_65"><b class="calibre6">Agranulocytes.</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Granulocytes</p>
	<p class="block_1054">They contain granules in their cytoplasm. Their nucleus is irregular or lobed. The granulocytes are of three types</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_64">Neutrophils </li>
	<li class="block_1055">Eosinophils</li>
	<li class="block_65">Basophils</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1002">1 Neutrophils</p>
	<p class="block_1001">They are large in size and have a 2 to 7 lobed nucleus. These corpuscles from 60% to 65% of the total leucocytes. Their numbers are increased during infection and inflammation.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">2 Eosinophils</p>
	<p class="block_1001">It has a bilobed nucleus and constitute 2% to 3% of the total leucocytes. Their number increases during conditions of allergy and parasitic infections. It brings about detoxification of toxins.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">3 Basophils</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Basophils have lobed nucleus. They from 0.5 to 1.0% of the total leucocytes. They release chemicals during the process of inflammation.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Agranulocytes</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Granules are not found in the cytoplasm of these cells. The agranulocytes are of two types:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1049">Lymphocytes</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Monocytes</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1002">1 Lymphocytes</p>
	<p class="block_1001">These are about 20 to 25% of the total leucocytes. They produce antibodies during bacterial and viral infections.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">2 Monocytes</p>
	<p class="block_1001">They are the largest of the leucocytes and are amoeboid in shape. These cells from 5 to 6 % of the total leucocytes. They are phagocytic and can engulf bacteria.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Blood Platelets or Thrombocytes</p>
	<p class="block_1001">These are small and colourless. They do not have nucleus. There are about 2 lakh 50 thousand </p>
	<p class="block_1001">to 4 lakh platelets per cubic mm of blood. Life span of Thrombocytes platelets is 8 to 10 days. They play an important role in clotting of blood. Platelets form clot at the site of injury and prevent blood loss</p>
	<p class="block_1003"><img src="images/image-222.png" alt="Image shows the picture of Thrombocytes" class="calibre319"/></p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<p class="block_1002">Thrombocytes</p>
	<p class="block_1002">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Anaemia:</b> Decrease in number of erythrocytes. </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Leucocytosis:</b> Increase in the number of leukocytes.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Leukopenia:</b> Decrease in number of leukocytes.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Thrombocytopenia:</b> Decrease in the number of thrombocytes.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Functions of blood</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1108"><span class="text_33">Transport </span><span class="text_27">of respiratory gases (Oxygen</span> and C O<sub class="calibre25">2</sub>).</li>
	<li class="block_7"><span class="text_27">Transport of digested </span>food materials to the different body cells.</li>
	<li class="block_102">Transport of hormones.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Transport of <span class="text_33">nitrogenous </span>excretory <span class="text_27">products like ammonia, </span>urea and uric acid.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is involved in protection of the body and defense against diseases.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It acts as buffer and also helps in regulation of pH and body temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_7"><span class="text_27">It maintains proper </span>water balance in the body.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_427">14.13 Blood Vessels - Arteries and Veins</h2>
	<p class="block_">Blood vessels are a network of branched tubes that transport blood. There are three types of blood vessels namely arteries, veins and capillaries</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Arteries:</b> They are thick and elastic vessels that carry blood away from the heart to various organs of the body. All arteries carry oxygenated blood except the pulmonary artery which carry deoxygenated blood to the lungs.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Veins:</b> Veins are thin and non-elastic vessels that transport blood to the heart from the different organs. All veins carry deoxygenated blood except the pulmonary vein which carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Capillaries:</b> Capillaries are narrow tubes formed by branching of arterioles which then unite to form the venules and veins. They are about 8 mew m in diameter. Capillaries are formed of single layer of endothelial cells.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Table 14.1 Differences between Artery and Vein</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_428">14.14 Types of Circulatory System</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Animals possess two types of circulatory system. They are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">Open type</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Closed type</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1002">Open type</p>
	<p class="block_1001">In open type the blood is pumped by heart into blood vessels that open into blood spaces called as sinuses. These sinuses are the body cavities which are called haemocoel. Capillary system is absent. Example  Arthropods, Molluscs and Ascidians.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Closed type</p>
	<p class="block_1001">In closed type the blood flows in a complete circuit around the body through specific blood vessels. The blood flows from arteries to veins through small blood vessels called capillaries.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Example Vertebrates.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Closed circulatory system was discovered by William Harvey (1628) who is regarded the Father of Modern Physiology.</p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_429">14.15 Structure of Human Heart</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Heart is a muscular pumping organ that pumps out the blood into the blood vessels. Human heart is situated between the lungs, slightly tilted toward the left and above the diaphragm in the thoracic cavity. The heart is made of specialized type of muscle called the cardiac muscle.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The heart is enclosed in a double walled sac called pericardium. It contains lubricating pericardial fluid which reduces friction during heartbeat and protects it from mechanical injuries.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 14.11 External structure of human heart</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-224.png" alt="Image displays the External structure of human heart  where you can see Superior vernacava, Right attrium, Right Ventricle, Inferior Vernacava, Aorta, Pulmonary trunk, Left attrium, Pulmonary veins and Left Ventricle." class="calibre321"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">The human heart is four chambered. The two upper thin-walled chambers of the heart are called auricle or atria (sing: atrium) and two lower thick-walled chambers are called ventricles. The chambers are separated by partition called septum. The septum between auricles and ventricles prevents the mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The two auricles are separated from each other by interatrial septum. The left atrium is smaller than the right atrium. The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from different parts of the body through the main vein’s superior vena cava, inferior vena cava and coronary sinus. Pulmonary veins bring oxygenated blood to the left atrium from the lungs. The right and left auricles pump blood into the right and left ventricles respectively.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The ventricles form the lower part of the heart. The two ventricles are separated from each other by an interventricular septum. The left and right ventricles have thick walls because the ventricles have to pump out blood with force away from the heart. From the right ventricle arises the pulmonary trunk which bifurcates to form right and left pulmonary arteries. The right and left pulmonary arteries supply deoxygenated blood to the lungs of the respective side. The left ventricle is longer and narrower than the right ventricle. The walls are about three times thicker than the right ventricle. The left ventricle gives rise to aorta. The oxygenated blood is supplied by the aorta to various organs of the body. The coronary arteries supply blood to the heart.</p>
	<p class="block_985"><img src="images/image-225.png" alt="figure 14.12 Internal structure of human heart- Explained with following parts superior vena cava aorta pulmonary trunk right atrium left atrium pulmonary valve pulmonary vein tricuspid valve bicuspid valve aortic valve right ventricle left ventricle inferior vena cava cardiac muscle. " class="calibre322"/></p>
	<p class="block_985">Figure 14.12 INTERNAL STRUCTURE OF HUMAN HEART</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Valves</b>: The valves are the muscular flaps that regulate the flow of blood in a single direction and prevent back flow of blood. The heart contains three types of valves.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Right atrioventricular valve:</b> It is located between the right auricle and right ventricle. It has three thin triangular leaf like flaps and therefore called tricuspid valve. The apices of the flaps are held in position by chordae tendinea arising from the muscular projection of the ventricle wall known as papillary muscles.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Left atrioventricular valve:</b> It is located between the left auricle and left ventricle. It has two cusps and therefore called bicuspid or mitral valve.</p>
	<p class="block_19">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_9">Heart chambers in vertebrate animals </p>
	<p class="block_9">Two chambered: Fishes</p>
	<p class="block_9">Three chambered: Amphibians</p>
	<p class="block_9">Incomplete Four chambered: Reptiles</p>
	<p class="block_9">Four chambered: Aves, Mammals and Crocodiles (Reptile)</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Semilunar valves</b>: The major arteries (pulmonary artery and aorta) which leave the heart have semilunar valves which prevent backward flow of blood into the ventricles. They are the pulmonary and aortic semilunar valves.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_430">14.15.1 Types of Blood Circulation</h3>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-226.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of EPLYK" class="calibre323"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">The blood circulates in our body as oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. </p>
	<p class="block_1001">The types of circulation are:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Systemic circulation:</b> Circulation of oxygenated blood from the left ventricle of the heart to various organs of the body and return of deoxygenated blood to the right atrium. Aorta carries oxygenated blood to all the organs of the body.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Pulmonary circulation:</b> The path of pulmonary circulation starts in the right ventricle. Pulmonary artery arises from the right ventricle and reaches the lungs with deoxygenated blood. Pulmonary veins collect the oxygenated blood from the lungs and supplies it to the left atrium of the heart.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Coronary circulation:</b> The supply of blood to the heart muscles (cardiac muscles) is called as coronary circulation. Cardiac muscles receive oxygenated blood from coronary arteries that originate from the aortic arch. Deoxygenated blood from the cardiac muscles drains into the right atrium by the coronary sinuses.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1001">When the blood circulates twice through the heart in one complete cycle it is called double circulation. In double circulation the oxygenated blood do not mix with the deoxygenated blood.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">However, in some animals the oxygenated and deoxygenated blood are mixed and pass through the heart only once. This type of circulation is called single circulation. Example  fishes, amphibians and certain reptiles.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-227.png" alt="Image displays the Systemic and Pulmonary circulation where you can see the Vessels transporting Oxygenated Blood and deoxygenated blood and Vessels involved in gas exchange. " class="calibre324"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 14.13 Systemic and Pulmonary circulation</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_431">14.15.2 Heartbeat</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">One complete contraction (systole) and relaxation (diastole) of the atrium and ventricles of the heart constitute heartbeat. The heart normally beats 72 – 75 times per minute.</p>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Neurogenic and Myogenic Heartbeat</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Neurogenic heartbeat is initiated by a nerve impulse caused from a nerve ganglion situated near the heart. Example Annelids, most arthropods</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Myogenic heartbeat is initiated by a specialized group of modified heart muscle fibres. example Mollusca and Vertebrates</p>
	<p class="block_63">Initiation and conduction of Heartbeat</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The human heart is myogenic in nature. Contraction is initiated by a specialized portion of the heart muscle, the Sino-atrial (S A) node which is situated in the wall of the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava. The S A node is broader at the top and tapering below. It is made up of thin fibres.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Sino-atrial node acts as the ‘pacemaker’ of the heart because it is capable of initiating impulse which can stimulate the heart muscles to contract. The impulse from the sinoatrial node spreads as a wave of contraction over the right and left atrial wall pushing the blood through the atrioventricular valves into the ventricles. The wave of contraction from S A node reaches the atrioventricular (AV) node which is stimulated to emit an impulse of contraction spreading to the ventricular muscle via the atrioventricular bundle and the Purkinje fibres.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know</p>
	<p class="block_">Atrioventricular bundle was discovered by His (1893). So is called Bundle of His.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Pulse:</b> When the heart beats the blood is forced into the arteries. The expansion of the artery every time the blood is forced into it is called pulse. It can be felt by placing the fingertip on the artery near the wrist. Normal pulse rate ranges from 70 – 90 PER minute.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Activity 3 </b>Determining Heart Rate</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Materials:</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Stopwatch or Stop clock.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Procedure:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Have your partner to find the pulse in your wrist and count your heartbeats for 15 seconds while you are seated. Calculate your resting heart rate in beats per minute.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Have your partner to count your heart beats for 15 seconds after you jog or run for 5 minutes. Calculate your heart rate in beats per minute.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Analyse:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">What causes your pulse?</li>
	<li class="block_65">What causes the change in your heartbeat rate in each situation?</li>
</ul>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_432">14.15.3 Cardiac Cycle</h3>
	<p class="block_">The sequence of events occurring from the beginning to the completion of one heartbeat is called cardiac cycle. During cardiac cycle blood flows through the chambers of the heart in a specific direction. Each cardiac cycle lasts about 0.8 second. The event during a single cardiac cycle involves</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_6"><b class="calibre6">Atrial systole:</b> Contraction of auricles (0.1 second).</li>
	<li class="block_7"><b class="calibre6">Ventricular systole:</b><span class="calibre28">  Contraction of ventricles (0.3 </span>second).</li>
	<li class="block_8"><b class="calibre6">Ventricular diastole:</b> Relaxation of ventricles (0.4 second).</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-228.png" alt="Image shows the Pie chart of Cardiac Cycle " class="calibre325"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_433">14.15.4 Heart Sound</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The rhythmic closure and opening of the valves cause the sound of the heart. </p>
	<p class="block_1054">The first sound L U B B is of longer duration and is produced by the closure of the tricuspid and bicuspid valves after the beginning of ventricular systole. The second sound D U P P is of a shorter duration and produced by the closure of semilunar valves at the end of ventricular systole.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_434">14.16 Blood pressure</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Blood pressure is the force exerted during the flow of blood against the lateral walls of arteries. The blood pressure is high in the arteries gradually drops in the arterioles and capillaries and become very low in the veins.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Blood pressure is usually expressed in terms of the systolic pressure and diastolic pressure.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Systolic pressure:</b> During ventricular systole, the left ventricle contracts and forces blood into the aorta. The pressure rises to a peak which is referred as systolic pressure.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Diastolic pressure:</b> During diastole, the ventricles relax, and the pressure falls to the lowest value which is referred as diastolic pressure.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In a healthy adult during normal resting condition systolic and diastolic blood pressure is expressed as 120mm by 80mm Hg. Blood pressure varies during conditions of physical exercise, anxiety, emotions, stress and sleep.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">A prolonged or constant elevation of blood pressure is a condition known as hypertension (High blood pressure) can increase the risk of heart attack and stroke. Decrease in blood pressure is termed hypotension (Low blood pressure).</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_435">Stethoscope</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">A stethoscope is used to detect the sound produced by the internal organs of human body. The heart sound is heard by placing the stethoscope on the chest. It is a useful diagnostic tool to identify and localize health problems and diagnose disease. The modern electronic stethoscopes are high previsioned instruments.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-229.png" alt="Image shows the picture of Stethoscope" class="calibre326"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">Figure 14.14 Stethoscope</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_436">Sphygmomanometer</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Sphygmomanometer is a clinical instrument used to measure blood pressure when a person is in a relaxed and resting condition. The pressure of the brachial artery is measured. It helps to estimate the state of blood circulation and the working of the heart. It helps to diagnose conditions such as increased or decreased blood pressure. Manometric and modern digital types are the apparatus used to measure blood pressure.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-230.png" alt="Image shows the picture of Monometric and Digital type blood pressure " class="calibre327"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">Figure 14.15 Monometric (A) and Digital (B) type blood pressure apparatus</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_437">14.17 Blood Groups</h2>
	<p class="block_1054"><span class="calibre28">The concept of blood grouping was developed by Karl Landsteiner (1900). He identified blood groups A, B and O. AB blood group was recognized by Decastello and Steini (19 02).Human blood contains certain specific substances called agglutinogens or antigens (Ag) and agglutinins or antibodies (A b). Antigens are found on the membrane surface of RBC. Antibodies are present in blood plasma. Based on the presence or absence of antigen and antibodies human blood group is classified into four groups called,  A, B, A B and O. An individual has one of the four blood groups.</span></p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_64">‘A’group individuals: Antigen A is present on the surface of RBC and antibody b (anti-b) is present in the plasma.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">‘B’group individuals: Antigen B is present on the surface of RBC and antibody a (anti - a) is present in the plasma.</li>
	<li class="block_1055"><span class="calibre28">‘A  B’  group individuals: Antigens A and B are present on the surface of RBC and both the antibodies are absent in the plasma.</span></li>
	<li class="block_65">‘O’group individuals: Antigen A or B are absent on the surface of RBC. However, the plasma contains both the antibodies a and b (anti a and b).</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_438">Blood donation</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">In blood transfusion one must consider the antigen and antibody compatibility (matching) between the donor and the person receiving blood (recipient). When an individual receives a mismatched blood group from the donor agglutination (clumping) of blood occurs in the body which leads to death.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><span class="calibre28"> Persons with ‘A B’  blood group are called ‘Universal Recipient’ as they can receive blood from persons with any blood group.</span></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><span class="calibre28">Persons with ‘O’  blood group are called ‘Universal Donor’ as they can donate blood to persons with any blood group.</span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_439">Rh factor</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Rh factor was discovered by Landsteiner and Wiener in 1940 in Rhesus monkey. The surface of RBC contains the antigen for Rh factor. Rh+ ( positive) persons have Rh antigen on the surface of RBC while, Rh minus (negative)persons do not have Rh antigen on the surface of RBC. Antibodies developed against this Rh antigen is called Rh antibodies.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Table 14.2 Distribution of Antigen (RBC) and Antibody (Plasma) in different Blood Groups</p>
	<table class="table_68">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_697"><p class="block_1110">Blood</p><p class="block_1111">Group</p></td>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_440">14.18 Lymphatic System</h2>
	<p class="block_">The lymphatic system comprises of lymphatic capillaries, lymphatic vessels, lymph nodes and lymphatic ducts. Lymph is the fluid that flows through the lymphatic system.</p>
	<p class="block_">The lymphatic capillaries unite to form large lymphatic vessels. Lymph nodes are small oval or pear-shaped structures located along the length of lymphatic vessels.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-231.png" alt="Image displays the Lymphatic System in Man where you can see the lymph node in our body and lymphatic and thoractic duct present in our body." class="calibre328"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 14.16 Lymphatic System in Man</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_441">Lymph</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Lymph from the intercellular spaces drains into lymphatic capillaries. Lymph is a colourless fluid formed when plasma, proteins and blood cells escape into intercellular spaces in the tissues through the pores present in the walls of capillaries. It is similar to blood plasma but is colourless and contains less proteins. The lymph contains very small amount of nutrients, oxygen, C O2, water and WBC.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Functions of Lymph</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Supplies nutrients and oxygen to those parts where blood cannot reach</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It drains away excess tissue fluid and metabolites and returns proteins to the blood from tissue spaces.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The lymph also carries absorbed fats from small intestine to the blood. The lymphatic capillaries of intestinal villi (lacteals) absorb digested fats.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Lymphocytes in the lymph defend the body from infections.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_442">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">The movement of molecules from a region of higher concentration to a region of their lower concentration without the utilization of energy is called diffusion.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Osmosis is the movement of solvent or water molecules from the region of higher concentration to the region of lower concentration through a semi-permeable membrane.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Transpiration is the evaporation of water in plants through stomata in the leaves.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The circulatory system consists of the circulating fluids, the blood and lymph and the heart and its blood vessels.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The blood consists of two main components. The fluid plasma and the formed elements (blood cells) which are found suspended in the plasma.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">A muscular pumping organ that pumps out the blood into the blood vessels is called heart.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The blood circulates in our body as oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The supply of blood to the heart muscles (cardiac muscles) is called as coronary circulation.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">One complete contraction (systole) and relaxation (diastole) of atrium and ventricles of heart is called a heartbeat.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The sequence of events which occur during the beginning and completion of one heartbeat is called cardiac cycle.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Blood pressure is usually expressed as systolic pressure and diastolic pressure (120mm by 80 mm Hg)</li>
	<li class="block_1055">An individual has one of the four blood groups A, B, A B and O.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Rh factor was discovered by Landsteiner and Wiener in 1940.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Lymph is a colourless fluid formed when plasma, proteins and blood cells escape into intercellular spaces in the tissues through the pores present in the walls of capillaries.</li>
</ul>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_459">9 Assertion and Reasoning</h3>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Direction:</b> In each of the following questions a statement of assertion (A) is given, and a corresponding statement of reason (R) is given just below it. Mark the correct statement as.</p>
	<p class="block_">a). If both A and R are true and R is correct explanation of A</p>
	<p class="block_">b). If both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A</p>
	<p class="block_">c). A is true, but R is false</p>
	<p class="block_">d). Both A and R are false</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">1). Assertion:</b> RBC plays an important role in the transport of respiratory gases.</p>
	<p class="block_">Reason: RBC do not have cell organelles and nucleus.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">2). Assertion:</b> Persons with A B blood group are called a universal recipient because they can receive blood from all groups. </p>
	<p class="block_">Reason: Antibodies are absent in persons with A B blood group.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_460">10. </h3>

	<div class="block_13">1) When any dry plant material is kept in water, they swell up. Name and define the phenomenon involved in this change.</div>
	<div class="block_13">2) Why are the walls of the left ventricle thicker than the other chambers of the heart?</div>
	<div class="block_13">3) Doctors use stethoscope to hear the sound of the heart. Why?</div>
	<div class="block_13">4) How does the pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein differ in their function when compared to a normal artery and vein?</div>
	<div class="block_14">5) Transpiration is a necessary evil in plants. Explain.</div>
</div>
