	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_462">UNIT 15 <b class="calibre6">NERVOUS SYSTEM</b></h1>
	<p class="block_1135"><img src="images/image-236.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of SRG60" class="calibre334"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_463">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_9">At the end of the lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">Admire nervous system as the control and coordinating centre of the body.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Learn the components of the nervous system.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Analyse the transmission of nerve impulses.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the divisions of human nervous system.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Interpret the different sections of brain which handle different functions.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Know the significance of reflex action and its operative pathway.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_464">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">One of the characteristic features of all living organisms is responding to stimuli. Stimulus refers to the changes in the environmental condition, that are detected by receptors present in the body. Relevant changes in the activities of organisms to particular stimuli are called their reactions or responses. Living organisms show their response to different kinds of stimuli like light, heat, cold, sound, smell, taste, touch, pressure, pain or the force of gravity etc. For example, withdrawal of hand when we touch hot objects or closing the eyes when flashed with bright light, in this condition heat or light is the stimulus to which the body shows its response. Thus, on receiving a stimulus, the body responds in a manner that is most appropriate for its survival and functioning. </p>
	<p class="block_1054">To provide the correct response to a stimulus, it is necessary that all the organs work together in a proper coordinated manner. This working together of various organs in a systematic, controlled and efficient way to produce proper response to various stimuli is called coordination. In animals including human the coordination between the various cells and organs is essential for their diverse activities to maintain physiological balance called homeostasis. In this unit we shall learn about one of the major regulatory systems the nervous system and its control over the body activities</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_465">15.1 Nervous System</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">The nervous system is made up of nervous tissues. It is formed of three distinct components namely the neurons, neuroglia and nerve fibres.</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Neuron or nerve cell:</b> A neuron or nerve cell is the structural and functional unit of the nervous system. It is the longest cell of the human body with a length of over 100 mew m. These cells are highly specialised to detect, receive and transmit different kinds of stimuli. Information is conducted through neurons in the form of electrical impulses from one part of the body to another.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Neuroglia:</b> Neuroglia are also called as glial cells. They are non-exciting, supporting cell of the nervous system. They do not initiate or conduct nerve impulses.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Nerve fibres:</b> The nerve fibres are the long slender processes of neurons. A number of nerve fibres are bundled up together to form nerves.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_466">15.1.1 Structure of Neuron</h3>
	<p class="block_">A neuron typically consists of three basic parts: Cyton, Dendrites and Axon.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Fig. 15.1 Structure of Neuron</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-237.png" alt="Image displays the Picture of Neuro where ther following items are highlighted.  1. Dendrites 2. Nucleus 3. Axon 4. Cyton 5. Nodes of Ranvier 6. Myelin sheath 7. Axon terminal" class="calibre335"/></p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_64"><b class="calibre6">Cyton: </b>Cyton is also called cell body or perikaryon. It has a central nucleus with abundant cytoplasm called neoplasm. The cytoplasm has large granular body called Nissl’s granules and the other cell organelles like mitochondria, ribosomes, lysosomes, and endoplasmic reticulum. Neurons do not have the ability to divide. Several neurofibrils are present in the cytoplasm that help in transmission of nerve impulses to and from the cell body.</li>
	<li class="block_1055"><b class="calibre6">Dendrites</b>: These are the numerous branched cytoplasmic processes that project from the surface of the cell body. They conduct nerve impulses towards the cyton. The branched projections increase the surface area for receiving the signals from other nerve cells.</li>
	<li class="block_65"><b class="calibre6">Axon:</b> The axon is a single, elongated, slender projection. The end of axon terminates as fine branches which terminate into knob like swellings called synaptic knob. The plasma membrane of axon is called axolemma, while the cytoplasm is called axoplasm. It carries impulses away from the cyton. The axons may be covered by a protective sheath called myelin sheath which is further covered by a layer of Schwann cells called neurilemma. Myelin sheath breaks at intervals by depressions called Nodes of Ranvier. The region between the nodes is called as internode. Myelin sheath acts as insulator and ensures rapid transmission of nerve impulses.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Synapse:</b> A junction between synaptic knob of axon of one neuron and dendron of next neuron is called synaptic junction. Information from one neuron can pass to another neuron through these junctions with the release of chemicals known as neurotransmitters from the synaptic knob.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Activity 1</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Create a model of a neuron using clay or beads.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_467">15.1.2 Types of Neurons</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The neurons may be of different types based on their structure and functions.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-238.png" alt="Picture shows the image of Unipolar, Bipolar and multipolar neurons." class="calibre336"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">Fig. 15.2 Unipolar (A), Bipolar (B) and multipolar (C) neurons</p>
	<p class="block_9">Structurally the neurons may be of the following types:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_66"><b class="calibre36">Unipolar neurons:</b> Only one nerve process arises from the cyton which acts as both axon and dendron.</li>
	<li class="block_66"><b class="calibre36">Bipolar neurons:</b> The cyton gives rise to two nerve processes of which one acts as an axon while another as a dendron.</li>
	<li class="block_66"><b class="calibre36">Multipolar neurons:</b> The cyton gives rise to many dendrons and an axon.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<table class="table_59">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_715"><p class="block_1136">Unipolar Neurons</p></td>
			<td class="td_716"><p class="block_1137">Found in early embryos but not in adult</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_717"><p class="block_1138">Bipolar Neurons</p></td>
			<td class="td_718"><p class="block_1139">Found in retina of eye and olfactory epithelium of nasal chambers</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_719"><p class="block_1140">Multipolar Neurons</p></td>
			<td class="td_720"><p class="block_1141">Found in cerebral cortex of brain</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_1054">On the basis of functions neurons are categorised as: -</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_64"><b class="calibre6">Sensory or afferent neurons</b> which carry impulses from the sense organ to the central nervous system.</li>
	<li class="block_1055"><b class="calibre6">Motor or efferent neurons</b> which carry impulses from the central nervous system to effector organ such as the muscle fibre or the gland.</li>
	<li class="block_65"><b class="calibre6">Association neurons</b> conduct impulses between sensory and motor neurons.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_468">15.1.3 Types of Nerve Fibres</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Nerve fibres are of two types based on the presence or absence of myelin sheath.</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_64"><b class="calibre6">Myelinated nerve fibre:</b> The axon is covered with myelin sheath</li>
	<li class="block_65"><b class="calibre6">Non-myelinated nerve fibre:</b> The axon is not covered by myelin sheath.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054">Myelinated and non-myelinated nerve fibres form the white matter and grey matter of the brain.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_469">15.2 Transmission of Nerve Impulse</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">All the information from the environment is detected by the receptors located in our sense organs such as the eyes, the nose, the skin etcetera. Information from the receptors is transmitted as electrical impulse and is received by the dendritic tips of the neuron. This impulse travels from the dendrite to the cell body and then along the axon to its terminal end. On reaching the axonal end, it causes the nerve endings to release a chemical (neurotransmitter) which diffuses across a synapse and starts a similar electrical impulse in the dendrites of the next neuron, then to their cell body to be carried along the axon.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In this way, the electrical signal reaches the brain or spinal cord. The response from brain (or spinal cord) is similarly passed on to the effector organs such as the muscle or gland cell, that undergoes the desired response.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image255.jpeg" alt="Nerve impulse transmission in Explained " class="calibre337"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Fig. 15.3 Nerve impulse transmission</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The flow of nerve impulses from axonal end of one neuron to dendrite of another neuron through a synapse is called synaptic transmission.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know?</p>
	<p class="block_">Each neuron can transmit 1,000 nerve impulses per second and make as many as ten thousand of synaptic contacts with other neurons.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_470">15.2.1 Neurotransmitters</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Neurotransmitters are the chemicals which allow the transmission of nerve impulse from the axon terminal of one neuron to the dendron of another neuron or to an effector organ. The important neurotransmitter released by neurons is called Acetylcholine.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_471">15.3 Human Nervous System</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">The complexity of nervous system can be observed during the course of evolution. We the human beings differ from other animals in our ability to think and take actions, which is due to the well-developed nervous system. Human nervous system is differentiated into central nervous system (CNS), peripheral nervous system (PN S) and autonomic nervous system (A N S).</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001">The CNS acts as centre for information processing and control. It consists of the brain and the spinal cord. The PN S is made up of the nerves which connect the brain and spinal cord to all parts of the body. The A N S is formed of sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_472">15.3.1 Central Nervous System</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The brain and the spinal cord being delicate vital structures are well protected in bony cavities of the skull and the vertebral column respectively. CNS is formed of two types of matter such as white matter or grey matter with respect to the presence or absence of myelin sheath which we have discussed earlier.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-239.png" alt="Image displays Meninges of Brain" class="calibre338"/></p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">Figure 15.4 Meninges of brain</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001">The brain is the controlling centre of all the body activities. It is covered by three connectives </p>
	<p class="block_1001">tissue membrane or meninges:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1142"><b class="calibre36">Durometer</b> (dura: tough; mater: membrane) is the outermost thick fibrous membrane</li>
	<li class="block_1142"><b class="calibre36">Arachnoid membrane</b> (arachnoid: spider) is the middle, thin vascular membrane providing web like cushion</li>
	<li class="block_1142"><b class="calibre36">Piamater</b> (Pia: soft or tender) is the innermost, thin delicate membrane richly supplied with blood.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1001">Meningeal membranes protect the brain from mechanical injury.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Do You Know?</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Meningitis is an inflammation of the meninges. It can occur when fluid surrounding the meninges becomes infected. The most common causes of meningitis are viral and bacterial infections.</p>
	<p class="block_9">A human brain is formed of three main parts: (a) forebrain (b) midbrain and (c) hindbrain.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-240.png" alt="Image displays Structure of Brain " class="calibre339"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Forebrai</b>n: The forebrain is formed of cerebrum and diencephalon. The latter consists of dorsal thalamus and ventral hypothalamus.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Cerebrum</p>
	<p class="block_1001">It is the largest portion forming nearly two- third of the brain. The cerebrum is longitudinally divided into two halves as right and left cerebral hemispheres by a deep cleft called median cleft. Two cerebral hemispheres are interconnected by thick band of nerve fibres called corpus callosum. The outer portion of each cerebral hemisphere is formed of grey matter and is called cerebral cortex. The inner or deeper part is formed of white matter and is called cerebral medulla. The cortex is extremely folded forming elevations called gyri with depressions between them termed as sulci that increase its surface area.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Each cerebral hemisphere is divisible into a frontal lobe, a parietal lobe, a temporal lobe and an occipital lobe. These lobes are also known as cerebral lobes and are associated with specific functions. Any damage in specific lobe intern affects its function.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The cerebrum is responsible for the thinking, intelligence, consciousness, memory, imagination, reasoning and willpower.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Thalamus</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Thalamus present in cerebral medulla is a major conducting centre for sensory and motor signalling. It acts as a relay centre.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Hypothalamus</p>
	<p class="block_1054">It lies at the base of the thalamus. It controls involuntary functions like hunger, thirst, sleep, sweating, sexual desire, anger, fear, water balance, blood pressure etcetera. It acts as a thermoregulatory (temperature control) center of the body. It controls the secretion of hormones from anterior pituitary gland and is an important link between nervous system and endocrine system.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Midbrain</p>
	<p class="block_1001">It is located between thalamus and hind brain. The dorsal portion of the mid brain consists of four rounded bodies called corpora quadrigemina that control visual and auditory (hearing) reflexes.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Hindbrain</p>
	<p class="block_1001">It is formed of three parts cerebellum, pons and medulla oblongata.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know?</p>
	<p class="block_1054">That human brain constitutes nearly 60 percent of fat. The most crucial molecules that determine our brain’s integrity and the ability are Essential Fatty Acids (EFA s). EFA s cannot be synthesised and must be obtained from food. Fish, green leafy vegetables, almond, walnut are rich sources of EFA s.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Cerebellum</p>
	<p class="block_1054">It is second largest part of the brain formed of two large sized hemispheres and middle vermis. It coordinates voluntary movements and also maintains body balance.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Pons</p>
	<p class="block_1054">‘Pons’ a Latin word meaning bridge. It is a bridge of nerve fibre that connects the lobes of cerebellum. It relays signals between the cerebellum, spinal cord, midbrain and cerebrum. It controls respiration and sleep cycle.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Medulla Oblongata</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Medulla oblongata is the posterior most part of the brain that connects spinal cord and various parts of brain. It has cardiac centres, respiratory centres, vasomotor centres to control heartbeat, respiration and contractions of blood vessels respectively. It also regulates vomiting and salivation.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Table 15.1 Overview of brain functions</p>

		</tr>

		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">

		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_63">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><span class="calibre28">Electroencephalogram (E E G) is an instrument which records the electrical impulses of   brain. </span></p>
	<p class="block_1054">An E E G can detect abnormalities in the brain waves and help in diagnoses of seizures, epilepsy, brain tumours, head injuries, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Spinal Cord</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Spinal cord is a cylindrical structure lying in the neural canal of the vertebral column. It is also covered by meninges. It extends from the lower end of medulla oblongata to the first lumbar vertebra. The posterior most region of spinal cord tapers into a thin fibrous thread like structure called filum terminal.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Internally, the spinal cord contains a cerebrospinal fluid filled cavity known as the central canal. The grey matter of spinal cord is ‘H’ shaped. The upper end of letter ‘H” forms posterior horns and lower end forms anterior horns. A bundle of fibres passes into the posterior horn forming dorsal or afferent root. Fibres pass outward from the anterior horn forming ventral or efferent root. These two <span id="id_Int_xz99chIq">roots join to form spinal nerves. The white matter is external and have bundle of nerve tracts. Spinal cord conducts sensory and motor impulses to and from the brain. It controls reflex actions of the body.</span></p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-241.png" alt="Image displays the Structure of spinal cord " class="calibre340"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Fig. 15.6 Structure of spinal cord</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_473">15.4 Cerebrospinal Fluid</h2>
	<p class="block_">The brain is suspended in a special fluid environment called cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). It is lymph like, watery fluid that surrounds and protects the brain within the skull. It also fills the central canal of the spinal cord.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Functions:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">It acts as shock absorbing fluid and protects the brain from damage when it is subjected to sudden jerk.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It supplies nutrients to the brain.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It collects and removes wastes from the brain.</li>
	<li class="block_8">It is also responsible for maintaining a constant pressure inside the cranium.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_474">15.5 Reflex Action</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">A reflex is any response that occurs automatically without consciousness. There are two types of reflexes.</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_64"><b class="calibre6">Simple or basic reflexes:</b> These reflexes are inbuilt and unlearned responses. Many of the actions we perform in our day-to-day life are simple reflexes. e.g., winking of eyes when any dust particles enter, sneezing, coughing, yawning, etc. We perform these actions without thinking.</li>
	<li class="block_65"><b class="calibre6">Acquired or conditioned reflexes: These</b> reflexes are the result of practice and learning. Playing harmonium by striking a particular key on seeing a music note is an example of conditioned reflexes which required conscious training effort. Can you think of some more examples of conditioned reflexes?</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054">Most of the reflex actions are monitored and controlled by the spinal cord, hence also known as spinal reflexes.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The pathway taken by nerve impulse to accomplish reflex action is called reflex arc. Now, let us understand how the body executes reflex action when we touch a hot plate.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-242.png" alt="Picture shows the image of Reflex action and its pathway" class="calibre341"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Fig. 15.7 Reflex action and its pathway</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1150">When we touch a very hot pan, the stimulus is the heat which is sensed by receptor called as heat receptors or thermoreceptors in our hand. This stimulus (heat) intern triggers an impulse in sensory neuron.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">The sensory neuron transmits or conveys the message to the spinal cord.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Spinal cord interprets the stimulus, and the impulse is passed on to the relay neuron which intern transmits it to a motor neuron.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Motor neurons carry command from spinal cord to our arm.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Muscle in our arm contracts and we withdraw our hand immediately from the pan.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1001">In this example, muscle is an effector organ which has responded to the heat. You will study in higher classes how the neuronal impulse triggers the muscular movement.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_475">15.6 Peripheral Nervous System</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Peripheral nervous system is formed by the nerves arising from the brain and the spinal cord. The nerves arising from the brain are called cranial nerves. Nerves arising from spinal cord are called spinal nerves.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Activity 2</p>
	<p class="block_">You must say the colour of the word but not the name of the word.</p>
	<table class="table_69">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_729"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1152">BLUE</p></td>
			<td class="td_730"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1153">RED</p></td>
			<td class="td_730"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1153">YELLOW</p></td>
			<td class="td_731"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1154">ORANGE</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_732"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1155">GREEN</p></td>
			<td class="td_733"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1153">BLUE</p></td>
			<td class="td_733"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1154">PURPLE</p></td>

		</tr>

			<td class="td_735"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1156">PURPLE</p></td>

			<td class="td_737"><p class="block_1151"> </p><p class="block_1154">BLUE</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_63">Cranial Nerves</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In man, there are 12 pairs of cranial nerves. Some of the cranial nerves are sensory example optic nerve which innervates the eye. Some are motor nerves which helps in rotation of eyeball. It also innervates the eye muscles, muscles of iris and tear gland.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Spinal Nerves</p>
	<p class="block_1054">There are 31 pairs of spinal nerves. Each spinal nerve has a dorsal sensory root and the ventral motor root. The direction of impulses in dorsal spinal root is towards the spinal cord and in ventral spinal root away from the spinal cord.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_476">15.7 Autonomic Nervous System</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Autonomic nervous system (A N S) is also called as visceral nervous system as it regulates the function of internal visceral organs of our body through its two antagonistic (opposite) components sympathetic and parasympathetic systems. They enable the body to perform rapid and specific visceral activities in order to maintain steady state. It controls the involuntary functions of the visceral organs.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure. 15.8 Sympathetic and Parasympathetic nervous system</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-243.png" alt="Image shows the picture of Sympathetic and Parasympathetic nervous system" class="calibre342"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-244.png" alt="This image shows the activity 3 where you are asked to Use the letter and number code to decode the given information" class="calibre213"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_477">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Nervous system controls and coordinates the activities of our body.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Neuron is the structural and functional unit of the cell and has three parts- cyton, dendrites and axon.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">A receptor is a cell or group of cells that receives the stimuli. An effector is a part of the body which can respond to a stimulus according to the instructions from the brain or the spinal cord.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">C N S is formed of brain and spinal cord. P N S consists of all nerves which connect brain and spinal cord to all parts of the body. A N S operates automatically and formed of sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves</li>
	<li class="block_65">A reflex action is a rapid, automatic response to a stimulus which is not under the voluntary control of the brain.</li>
</ul>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_488">UNIT-16 <b class="calibre6">PLANT AND ANIMAL HORMONES</b></h1>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-247.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of ZXTVA" class="calibre346"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_489">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Define hormone.</li>
	<li class="block_7">List out plant hormones.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Classify plant hormones into growth promoters and growth inhibitors.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Differentiate the physiological effects of various plant hormones.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Understand how plant hormones control and coordinate various physiological activities in plants.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Know the various endocrine glands in the human body.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Identify the location and structure of the endocrine glands in the human body.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Differentiate exocrine and endocrine glands.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Know the specific site of action and their functions.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Identify the disorders which occur due to decreased or increased hormone secretion.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_490">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">The word hormone is derived from the Greek word “hormon” meaning “to excite”. The function of control and coordination in plants is performed by chemical substances produced by the plants called plant hormones. In plants several cells are capable of producing hormones. These phytohormones are transported to different parts of the plants to perform various physiological functions.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Endocrine glands</b> in vertebrate animals possess a diversified communication system to co-ordinate physiological and metabolic functions by chemical integration. The endocrine system acts through chemical messengers known as hormones which are produced by specialized glands. Physiological processes such as digestion, metabolism, growth, development and reproduction are controlled by hormones. </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_491">16.1 Plant Hormones</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Plant hormones are organic molecules that are produced at extremely low concentration in plants. These molecules control morphological, physiological and biochemical responses.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Types of Plant Hormones </p>
	<p class="block_1001">There are five major classes of plant hormones.</p>
	<p class="block_19"><img src="images/image-248.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of OWJBT" class="calibre347"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">They are:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1164">Auxins</li>
	<li class="block_1164">Cytokinin’s</li>
	<li class="block_1164">Gibberellins</li>
	<li class="block_1164">Abscisic Acid (A B A)</li>
	<li class="block_1164">Ethylene</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_9">Among all these plant hormones auxins, cytokinin’s and gibberellins promote plant growth while abscisic acid and ethylene inhibit plant growth.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-249.png" alt="This picture shows the image of the Hormonal interaction in plant growth and development" class="calibre348"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 16.1 Hormonal interaction in plant growth and development</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_492">16.1.1 Auxins</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Auxins (G k. auxin = to grow) were the first plant hormones discovered. The term auxin was introduced by Kogl and Haagen- Smith (1931). Auxins are produced at the tip of stems and roots from where they migrate to the zone of elongation. Charles Darwin in 1880 observed unilateral growth and curvature of canary grass (Phalariscanariensis) coleoptiles. He came to the conclusion that some ‘influence’ was transmitted from the tip of the coleoptile to the basal region. This ‘influence’ was later identified as Auxin by Went.</p>
	<h4 class="block_103">16.1.1.1 Went’s Experiment</h4>
	<p class="block_1054">Frits Warmolt Went (1903 to 1990), a Dutch biologist demonstrated the existence and effect of auxin in plants. He did a series of experiments in Avena coleoptiles.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In his first experiment he removed the tips of Avena coleoptiles. The cut tips did not grow indicating that the tips produced something essential for growth. In his second experiment he placed the agar blocks on the decapitated coleoptile tips. The coleoptile tips did not show any response. In his next experiment he placed the detached coleoptile tips on agar blocks. After an hour, he discarded the tips and placed this agar block on the decapitated coleoptile. It grew straight up indicating that some chemical had diffused from the cut coleoptile tips into the agar block which stimulated the growth.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">From his experiments Went concluded that a chemical diffusing from the tip of coleoptiles was responsible for growth, and he named it as “Auxin” meaning ‘to grow”.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-250.png" alt="Image displays the Wents experiment, where you can see,  a) Germination of an Oat seed, b) Decapitate tip of coleoptile and place on agar block  c) Agar block is placed on top of the decapitated tip of the seeding. " class="calibre349"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 16.2 Went’s Experiment</p>
	<p class="block_12">Types of Auxins: Auxins are classified into two types, namely natural auxins and synthetic auxins.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1165">Natural Auxins: Auxins produced by the plants are called natural auxins. Example: IAA (Indole – 3 - Acetic Acid)</li>
	<li class="block_1166">Synthetic Auxins: Artificially synthesized auxins that have properties like auxins are called as synthetic auxins. Example: 2, 4 D (2,4 Dichloro phenoxy Acetic Acid).</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Physiological effects of auxins</b>: Auxins bring about a variety of physiological effects in different parts of the plant body.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-251.png" alt="Cell Elongation in Explained " class="calibre350"/></p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1165">Auxins promote the elongation of stems and coleoptiles which makes them to grow.</li>
	<li class="block_1167">Auxins induce root formation at low concentration and inhibit it at higher concentration.</li>
	<li class="block_1167">The auxins produced by the apical buds suppress growth of lateral buds. This is called apical dominance.</li>
	<li class="block_1167">Seedless fruits without fertilization are induced by the external application of auxins. (Parthenocarpy). Examples: Watermelon, Grapes, Lime etcetera.</li>
	<li class="block_1166">Auxins prevent the formation of abscission layer.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">Do You Know </p>
	<p class="block_">Phenyl Acetic Acid (P A A) and Indole 3 Acetonitrile (I A N) are natural auxins. Indole 3 Butyric Acid (I B A), Indole-3- Propionic Acid, α-Naphthalene Acetic Acid (N A A), 2, 4, 5-T (2,4,5 Trichloro phenoxy Acetic Acid) are some of the synthetic auxins.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_493">16.1.2 Cytokinin’s</h3>
	<p class="block_">Cytokinin’s (Cyrtos - cell; kinesis - division) are the plant hormones that promote cell division or cytokinesis in plant cells. It was first isolated from Herring fish sperm. Zeatin was the cytokinin isolated from Zea mays. Cytokinin is found abundantly in liquid endosperm of coconut.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Physiological effects of cytokinin’s</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">Cytokinin induces cell division(cytokinesis) in the presence of auxins.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Cytokinin also causes cell enlargement.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Both auxins and cytokinin’s are essential for the formation of new organs from the callus in tissue culture (Morphogenesis).</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Cytokinin’s promote the growth of lateral buds even in the presence of apical bud.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Application of cytokinin delays the process of ageing in plants. This is called Richmond Lang effect.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_494">16.1.3 Gibberellins</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Gibberellins are the most abundantly found plant hormones. Kurosawa (1926) observed Bakanae disease or foolish seedling disease in rice crops. This internodal elongation in rice was caused by fungus Gibberellafujikuroi. The active substance was identified as Gibberellic acid.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Physiological effects of gibberellins</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1168">Application of gibberellins on plants stimulate extraordinary elongation of internode. e.g., Corn and Pea.</li>
	<li class="block_1165">Treatment of rosette plants with gibberellin induces sudden shoot elongation followed by flowering. This is called bolting.</li>
	<li class="block_1167">Gibberellins promote the production of male flowers in monoecious plants (Cucurbits).</li>
	<li class="block_1167">Gibberellins break dormancy of potato tubers.</li>
	<li class="block_1166">Gibberellins are efficient than auxins in inducing the formation of seedless fruit - Parthenocarpic fruits (Development of fruits without fertilization) e.g., Tomato.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-252.png" alt="This image shows one of Physiological effects of gibberellins called Bolting" class="calibre351"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 16.4 Bolting</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_495">16.1.4 Abscisic Acid</h3>
	<p class="block_9">Abscisic acid (A B A) is a growth inhibitor which regulates abscission and dormancy. It increases tolerance of plants to various kinds of stress. So, it is also called as stress hormone. It is found in the chloroplast of plants.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Physiological effects of abscisic acid</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">A B A promotes the process of abscission (separation of leaves, flowers and fruits from the branch).</li>
	<li class="block_66">During water stress and drought conditions A B A causes stomatal closure.</li>
	<li class="block_6">A B A promotes senescence in leaves by causing loss of chlorophyll.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A B A induces bud dormancy towards the approach of winter in trees like birch.</li>
	<li class="block_8">A B A is a powerful inhibitor of lateral bud growth in tomato.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-253.png" alt="This Picture Shows the Image of Healthy Green Plant, Senescence yellow plant and abscised Plant Leaf. " class="calibre352"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Activity</p>
	<p class="block_">Place two or three unripe tomatoes in a brown paper bag with a ripe banana and roll the top closed. In another bag place two or three unripe tomatoes only and roll the top closed, observe what happens to the tomatoes? Why?</p>
	<p class="block_">As the banana continues to ripen in the first bag, it produces ethylene gas. The gas trapped in the bag will cause tomatoes to ripen. The tomatoes remain unripe in the second bag.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_496">16.1.5 Ethylene</h3>
	<p class="block_">Ethylene is a gaseous plant hormone. It is a growth inhibitor. It is mainly concerned with maturation and ripening of fruits. Maximum synthesis of ethylene occurs during ripening of fruits like apples, bananas and melons.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Physiological effects of ethylene</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Ethylene promotes the ripening of fruits. Example. Tomato, Apple, Mango, Banana, etcetera.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Ethylene inhibits the elongation of stem and root in dicots.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Ethylene hastens the senescence of leaves and flowers.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Ethylene stimulates formation of abscission zone in leaves, flowers and fruits. This leads to premature shedding.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Ethylene breaks the dormancy of buds, seeds and storage organs.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-254.png" alt="This picture shows the Tomato plant " class="calibre353"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 16.6 Ethylene</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_497">16.2 Human Endocrine Glands</h2>
	<p class="block_">Endocrine glands in animals possess a versatile communication system to coordinate biological functions. Exocrine glands and endocrine glands are two kinds of glands found in animals. Endocrine glands are found in different regions of the body of animals as well as human beings. These glands are called ductless glands. Their secretions are called hormones which are produced in minute quantities. The secretions diffuse into the blood stream and are carried to the distant parts of the body. They act on specific organs which are referred as target organs. </p>
	<p class="block_">Do you Know </p>
	<p class="block_">The branch of biology which deals with the study of the endocrine glands and its physiology is known as ‘Endocrinology’. Thomas Addison is known as Father of Endocrinology. English physiologists W. M. Bayliss and E. H. Starling introduced the term hormone in 1909. They first discovered the hormone secretin.</p>
	<p class="block_">Exocrine glands have specific ducts to carry their secretions example.salivary glands, mammary glands, sweat glands.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Endocrine glands present in human and other vertebrates are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Pituitary gland</li>
	<li class="block_7">Thyroid gland</li>
	<li class="block_7">Parathyroid gland</li>
	<li class="block_7">Pancreas (Islets of Langerhans)</li>
	<li class="block_7">Adrenal gland (Adrenal cortex and Adrenal medulla)</li>
	<li class="block_7">Gonads (Testes and Ovary)</li>
	<li class="block_8">Thymus gland</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_498">16.2.1Pituitary Gland</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The pituitary gland or hypophysis is a pea shaped compact mass of cells located at the base of the midbrain attached to the hypothalamus by a pituitary stalk. The pituitary gland is anatomically composed of two lobes and perform different functions. They are the anterior lobe (adenohypophysis) and the posterior lobe (neurohypophysis). The intermediate lobe is non-existent in humans.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-255.png" alt="This Picture Shows the Image of the Pituitary Gland present in the Human Brain and also other parts near the Pituitary Gland are highlighted.  " class="calibre354"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 16.7 Pituitary Gland</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The pituitary gland forms the major endocrine gland in most vertebrates. It regulates and controls other endocrine glands and so is called as the “Master gland”.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Hormones secreted by the anterior lobe (Adenohypophysis) of pituitary</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The anterior pituitary is composed of different types of cells and secrete hormones which stimulates the production of hormones by other endocrine glands. The hormones secreted by anterior pituitary are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Growth Hormone</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Thyroid stimulating Hormone</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Adrenocorticotropic Hormone</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Gonadotropic Hormone which comprises the Follicle Stimulating Hormone and Luteinizing Hormone</li>
	<li class="block_65">Prolactin</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Growth hormone (GH)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">GH promotes the development and enlargement of all tissues of the body. It stimulates the growth of muscles, cartilage and long bones. It controls the cell metabolism.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The improper secretion of this hormone leads to the following conditions.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Dwarfism:</b> It is caused by decreased secretion of growth hormone in children. The characteristic features are stunted growth, delayed skeletal formation and mental disability.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Gigantism: </b>Over secretion of growth hormone leads to gigantism in children. It is characterised by overgrowth of all body tissues and organs. Individuals attain abnormal increase in height.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Acromegaly:</b> Excess secretion of growth hormone in adults may lead to abnormal enlargement of head, face, hands and feet.</p>
	<p class="block_63">2 Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">TSH controls the growth of thyroid gland, coordinates its activities and hormone secretion.</p>
	<p class="block_63">3 Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">ACTH stimulates adrenal cortex of the adrenal gland for the production of its hormones. It also influences protein synthesis in the adrenal cortex.</p>
	<p class="block_63">4 Gonadotropic hormones (GTH)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The gonadotropic hormones are follicle stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone which are essential for the normal development of gonads.</p>
	<p class="block_63">5 Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In male, it stimulates the germinal epithelium of testes for formation of sperms. In female it initiates the growth of ovarian follicles and its development in ovary.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Luteinizing hormone (LH)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In male, it promotes the Leydig cells of the testes to secrete male sex hormone testosterone. In female, it causes ovulation (rupture of mature graafian follicle), responsible for the development of corpus luteum and production of female sex hormones oestrogen and progesterone.</p>
	<p class="block_63">6 Prolactin (PRL)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">PRL is also called lactogenic hormone. This hormone initiates development of mammary glands during pregnancy and stimulates the production of milk after childbirth.</p>
	<p class="block_63">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Melatonin is a hormone produced by the pineal gland. It is known as a ‘time messenger’. It signals nighttime information throughout the body. Exposure to light at night, especially short-wavelength light, can decrease melatonin production interrupting sleep. Suppression of melatonin has been implicated in sleep disturbances and related metabolic disorders.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Hormones secreted by the posterior lobe (Neurohypophysis) of pituitary</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The hormones secreted by the posterior pituitary are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Vasopressin or Antidiuretic hormone</li>
	<li class="block_65">Oxytocin</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">1 Vasopressin or Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In kidney tubules it increases reabsorption of water. It reduces loss of water through urine and hence the name antidiuretic hormone. Deficiency of ADH reduces reabsorption of water and causes an increase in urine output (polyuria). This deficiency disorder is called Diabetes insipidus.</p>
	<p class="block_63">2 Oxytocin</p>
	<p class="block_1054">It helps in the contraction of the smooth muscles of uterus at the time of childbirth and milk ejection from the mammary gland after childbirth.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_499">16.2.2Thyroid Gland</h3>
	<p class="block_">The thyroid gland is composed of two distinct lobes lying one on either side of the trachea. The two lobes are connected by means of a narrow band of tissue known as the isthmus. This gland is composed of glandular follicles and lined by cuboidal epithelium. The follicles are filled with colloid material called thyroglobulin. </p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image457.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Thyroid Gland." class="calibre355"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure16.8ThyroidGland</p>
	<p class="block_">An amino acid tyrosine and iodine are involved in the formation of thyroid hormone. The hormones secreted by the thyroid gland are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Triiodothyronine (T3)</li>
	<li class="block_8">Tetraiodothyronine or Thyroxine (T4)</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Functions of thyroid hormones</p>
	<p class="block_">The functions of thyroid hormones are</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Production of energy by maintaining the Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) of the body.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Helps to maintain normal body temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Influences the activity of central nervous system.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Controls growth of the body and bone formation.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Essential for normal physical, mental and personality development.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is also known as personality hormone.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Regulates cell metabolism.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_">Edward C. Kendal in 1914 first crystallised thyroxine hormone. Charles Harrington and George Barger identified the molecular structure of thyroxine in 1927. Thyroid gland requires “120 μg” of iodine every day for the production of thyroxine.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Thyroid Dysfunction</p>
	<p class="block_">When the thyroid gland fails to secrete the normal level of hormones, the condition is called thyroid dysfunction. It leads to the following conditions</p>
	<p class="block_12">Hypothyroidism</p>
	<p class="block_">It is caused due to the decreased secretion of the thyroid hormones. The abnormal conditions are simple goitre, cretinism and myxoedema.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Goitre</p>
	<p class="block_">It is caused due to the inadequate supply of iodine in our diet. This is commonly prevalent in Himalayan regions due to low level of iodine content in the soil. It leads to the enlargement of thyroid gland which protrudes as a marked swelling in the neck and is called as goitre.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-256.png" alt="This picture shows the image of the Goitre in the neck" class="calibre356"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Cretinism</p>
	<p class="block_">It is caused due to decreased secretion of the thyroid hormones in children. The conditions are stunted growth, mental defect, lack of skeletal development and deformed bones. They are called as cretins.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Myxoedema</p>
	<p class="block_">It is caused by deficiency of thyroid hormones in adults. They are mentally sluggish, increase in body weight, puffiness of the face and hand, oedematous appearance.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Hyperthyroidism</p>
	<p class="block_">It is caused due to the excess secretion of the thyroid hormones which leads to Grave’s disease. The symptoms are protrusion of the eyeballs (Exophthalmia), increased metabolic rate, high body temperature, profuse sweating, loss of body weight and nervousness.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_500">16.2.3Parathyroid Gland</h3>
	<p class="block_">The parathyroid glands are four small oval bodies that are situated on the posterior surface of the thyroid lobes. The chief cells of the gland are mainly concerned with secretion of parathormone.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-257.png" alt="figure 16.9 Parathyroid Gland has following parts thyroid gland parathyroid gland trachea. " class="calibre357"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 16.9 Parathyroid Gland </p>
	<p class="block_12">Functions of Parathormone</p>
	<p class="block_">The parathormone regulates calcium and phosphorus metabolism in the body. They act on bone, kidney and intestine to maintain blood calcium levels.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Parathyroid Dysfunction</p>
	<p class="block_">The secretion of parathyroid hormone can be altered due to the following conditions.</p>
	<p class="block_">Removal of parathyroid glands during thyroidectomy (removal of thyroid) causes decreased secretion of parathormone. The conditions are</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Muscle spasm known as Tetany (sustained contraction of muscles in face, larynx, hands and feet).</li>
	<li class="block_8">Painful cramps of the limb muscles.</li>
</ul>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_501">16.2.4Pancreas (Islets of Langerhans)</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Pancreas is an elongated, yellowish gland situated in the loop of stomach and duodenum. It is exocrine and endocrine in nature. The exocrine pancreas secretes pancreatic juice which plays a role in digestion while, the endocrine portion is made up of Islets of Langerhans.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-258.png" alt="Pancreas in Explained " class="calibre358"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 16.10 Pancreas</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Do you Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Human insulin was first discovered by Fredrick Banting, Charles Best and MacLeod in 1921. Insulin was first used in treatment of diabetes on 11th January 1922. </p>
	<p class="block_1054">The Islets of Langerhans consists of two types of cells namely alpha cells and beta cells. The alpha cells secrete glucagon and beta cells secrete insulin.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Functions of Pancreatic hormones</p>
	<p class="block_1054">A balance between insulin and glucagon production is necessary to maintain blood glucose concentration.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Insulin</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Insulin helps in the conversion of glucose into glycogen which is stored in liver and skeletal muscles.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It promotes the transport of glucose into the cells.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It decreases the concentration of glucose in blood.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_63">Glucagon</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Glucagon helps in the breakdown of glycogen to glucose in the liver.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It increases blood glucose levels.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_63">Diabetes mellitus</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The deficiency of insulin causes Diabetes mellitus. It is characterised by</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Increase in blood sugar level (Hyperglycaemia).</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Excretion of excess glucose in the urine (Glycosuria).</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Frequent urination (Polyuria).</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Increased thirst (Polydipsia).</li>
	<li class="block_65">Increase in appetite (Polyphagia).</li>
</ul>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_502">16.2.5Adrenal Gland</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The adrenal glands are located above each kidney. They are also called supra renal glands.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The outer part is the adrenal cortex, and the inner part is the adrenal medulla. The two distinct parts are structurally and functionally different.</p>
	<p class="block_1092"> </p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-259.png" alt="This picture shows the image of the Adrenal Glan over the Kidney" class="calibre359"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">Figure 16.11 Adrenal Gland</p>
	<p class="block_63">Adrenal Cortex</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The adrenal cortex consists of three layers of cells. They are zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata and zona reticularis</p>
	<p class="block_63">Hormones of Adrenal Cortex</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The hormones secreted by the adrenal cortex are corticosteroids. They are classified into</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Glucocorticoids</li>
	<li class="block_65">Mineralocorticoids</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Functions of adrenocortical hormones </p>
	<p class="block_63">Glucocorticoids</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The glucocorticoids secreted by the zona fasciculata are cortisol and corticosterone</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">They regulate cell metabolism.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It stimulates the formation of glucose from glycogen in the liver.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It is an anti-inflammatory and anti-allergic agent.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_63">Mineralocorticoids</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The mineralocorticoids secreted by zona glomerulosa is aldosterone</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">It helps to reabsorb sodium ions from the renal tubules.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It causes increased excretion of potassium ions.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It regulates electrolyte balance, body fluid volume, osmotic pressure and blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_1054">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The cortisol hormones of adrenal cortex serve to maintain the body in living condition and recover it from the severe effects of stress reactions. Thus, an increased output of cortisol is “lifesaving” in “shock conditions”. It is also known as life-saving hormone.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Adrenal Medulla</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The adrenal medulla is composed of chromaffin cells. They are richly supplied with sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Hormones of Adrenal Medulla</p>
	<p class="block_1054">It secretes two hormones namely</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Epinephrine (Adrenaline)</li>
	<li class="block_65">Norepinephrine (Noradrenaline)</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054">They are together called as “Emergency hormones”. It is produced during conditions of stress and emotion. Hence it is also referred as “flight, fright and fight hormone”.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Functions of adrenal medullary hormones </p>
	<p class="block_12">Epinephrine (Adrenaline)</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">It promotes the conversion of glycogen to glucose in liver and muscles.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It increases heartbeat and blood pressure.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It increases the rate of respiration by dilation of bronchi and trachea.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It causes dilation of the pupil in eye.</li>
	<li class="block_8">It decreases blood flow through the skin.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">Norepinephrine (Noradrenalin)</p>
	<p class="block_">Most of its actions are similar to those of epinephrine.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_503">16.2.6Reproductive Glands (Gonads)</h3>
	<p class="block_">The sex glands are of two types of the testes and the ovaries. The testes are present in male, while the ovaries are present in female.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Testes</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Testes are the reproductive glands of the males. They are composed of seminiferous tubules, Leydig cells and Sertoli cells. Leydig cells form the endocrine part of the testes. They secrete the male sex hormone called testosterone.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Functions of testosterone</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">It influences the process of spermatogenesis.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It stimulates protein synthesis and controls muscular growth.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It is responsible for the development of secondary sexual characters (distribution of hair on body and face, deep voice pattern, etc).</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_63">Ovary</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The ovaries are the female gonads located in the pelvic cavity of the abdomen. They secrete the female sex hormones</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Estrogen</li>
	<li class="block_65">Progesterone</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054">Estrogen is produced by the Graafian follicles of the ovary and progesterone from the corpus luteum that is formed in the ovary from the ruptured follicle during ovulation.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Functions of estrogens</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">It brings about the changes that occur during puberty.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It initiates the process of oogenesis.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It stimulates the maturation of ovarian follicles in the ovary.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It promotes the development of secondary sexual characters (breast development, high pitched voice etc).</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">Functions of progesterone</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">It is responsible for the premenstrual changes of the uterus.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It prepares the uterus for the implantation of the embryo.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It maintains pregnancy.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It is essential for the formation of placenta</li>
</ul>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_504">16.2.7Thymus Gland</h3>
	<p class="block_">Thymus is partly an endocrine gland and partly a lymphoid gland. It is located in the upper part of the chest covering the lower end of trachea. Thymosin is the hormone secreted by thymus.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-260.png" alt="Thymus Gland in Explained " class="calibre360"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Functions of Thymosin</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">It has a stimulatory effect on the immune function.</li>
	<li class="block_8">It stimulates the<span class="tab">      </span>production and differentiation of lymphocytes.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_505">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Auxins are produced at the tip of stems and roots from where they migrate to the zone of elongation.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Cytokinin’s are the plant hormones that promote cell division or cytokinesis in plant cells.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Gibberellins induce the formation of seedless fruit and parthenocarpic fruits.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Abscisic acid is a growth inhibitor which regulates abscission and dormancy. It increases tolerance of plants to various kinds of stress.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Ethylene is a gaseous plant hormone mainly concerned with maturation and ripening of fruits.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The pituitary gland regulates and controls other endocrine glands and so is called as the “Master gland”.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The hormones secreted by the thyroid gland are triiodothyronine (T3), and tetraiodothyronine or thyroxine (T4)</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The parathormone act on bone, kidney and intestine to maintain blood calcium levels.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Pancreas secretes insulin and glucagon. They maintain blood glucose level.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Adrenal <span id="id_Int_JnaxwYrv" class="calibre203">cortex secrete cortisol and aldosterone and adrenal medulla secretes epinephrine and norepinephrine.</span></li>
	<li class="block_65">The sex glands are of two <span id="id_Int_wPvwYb3I" class="calibre203">types the testes and the ovaries which secrete testosterone and estrogens respectively.</span></li>
</ul>
	<div class="calibre68" id="calibre_pb_21"></div>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_511">5 Assertion and Reasoning</h3>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Direction:</b> In each of the following questions a statement of assertion (A) is given, and a corresponding statement of reason (R) is given just below it. Mark the correct statement as.</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_64">If both A and R are true and R is correct explanation of A</li>
	<li class="block_1055">If both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A</li>
	<li class="block_1055">A is true but R is false</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Both A and R are false</li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1177"><b class="calibre6">Assertion:</b> Application of cytokinin to marketed vegetables can keep them fresh for several days.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1178"><b class="calibre6">Reason: </b>Cytokinin’s delay senescence of leaves and other organs by mobilisation of nutrients.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="2" class="block_1177"><b class="calibre6">Assertion (A):</b> Pituitary gland is referred as “Master gland”.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1178"><b class="calibre6">Reason (R):</b> It controls the functioning of other endocrine glands.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="3" class="block_1177"><b class="calibre6">Assertion (A):</b> Diabetes mellitus increases the blood sugar levels.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1179"><b class="calibre6">Reason (R): Insulin</b> decreases the blood sugar levels.</p>
