	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_516">UNIT-17 <b class="calibre6">REPRODUCTION IN PLANTS AND ANIMALS</b></h1>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-264.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of W16EC" class="calibre364"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_517">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Differentiate vegetative, asexual and sexual reproduction.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Describe parts of flower and their functions.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Understand the types and modes of pollination and their significance.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Understand the process of double fertilization, steps involved in fertilization (syngamy and triple fusion), embryo development, endosperm development and formation of seed.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Understand the process of sexual reproduction in human beings.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Know the structure of testicular and ovarian cells.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Know the structural details of human sperm and ovum.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Realize the events of menstrual cycle and fertilization.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Gain awareness on reproductive health and strategies.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Gain knowledge on personal and social hygiene.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_518">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">“Living organisms cannot survive for an indefinite period on earth. All living organisms have the ability to produce more of its own kind by the process called reproduction. Reproduction is the unfolding of life forms where new individuals are formed. It ensures continuity and survival of the species. This process is to preserve individual species and it is called as self-perpetuation. The time required to reproduce also varies from organism to organism. You may find great variations in period of reproduction in yeast, bacteria, rat, cow, elephant and humans. In sexual reproduction off springs are produced by the union of male and female gametes (sperm and egg). The male and female gametes contain the genetic material or genes present on the chromosomes which transmit the characteristic traits to the next generation. There are three types of reproduction in plants namely </p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1049">Vegetative</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Asexual</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Sexual reproduction. </li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_519">17.1 Vegetative Reproduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">In this type, new plantlets are formed from vegetative (somatic) cells, buds or organs of plant. The vegetative part of plant (root, stem, leaf or bud) gets detached from the parent body and grows into an independent daughter plant. It has only mitotic division, no gametic fusion and daughter plants are</p>
	<p class="block_1001">genetically similar to the parent plant. Vegetative reproduction may take place through</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Leaves:</b> In Bryophyllum ,small plants grow at the leaf notches</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1079"><img src="images/image-265.png" alt="Image displays the Vegetative reproduction by leaf " class="calibre365"/></p>
	<p class="block_1079">Figure 17.1 Vegetative reproduction by leaf</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="2" class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Stems:</b> In strawberry aerial weak stems touch the ground and give off adventitious roots and buds. When the connections with the parent plant is broken, the offspring becomes independent.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1079"><img src="images/image-266.png" alt="Image displays the Vegetative reproduction by Stem " class="calibre366"/></p>
	<p class="block_1079">Figure 17.2 Vegetative reproduction by stem</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="3" class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Root:</b> Tuberous roots (Asparagus and Sweet potato) can be used for vegetative propagation.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Bulbils:</b> In some plants the flower bud modifies into globose bulb which are called as bulbils, when these falls on the ground they grow into new plants. Example  Agave.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"><b class="calibre36">Other types of Vegetative Reproduction</b></li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_1181"><b class="calibre36">Fragmentation:</b> In filamentous algae, breaking of the filament into many fragments is called fragmentation. Each fragment having at least one cell, may give rise to a new filament of the algae by cell division example Spirogyra.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1002"><img src="images/image-267.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Fragmentation in Spirogyra" class="calibre367"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 17.3 Fragmentation in Spirogyra</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li value="2" class="block_1181"><b class="calibre36">Fission:</b> In this <span id="id_Int_bxWQ67AZ">type the parent cell divides into two daughter cells and each cell develops into a new adult organism example Amoeba.</span></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-268.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Fission in Amoeba" class="calibre368"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 17.4 Fission in Amoeba</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li value="3" class="block_1181"><b class="calibre36">Budding:</b> Formation of a daughter individual from a small projection, the bud, arising on the parent body is called budding. Example  Yeast.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-269.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Budding in Yeast" class="calibre369"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 17.5 Budding in Yeast</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li value="4" class="block_1181"><b class="calibre36">Regeneration:</b> The ability of the lost body parts of an individual organism to give rise to a whole new organism is called regeneration. It takes place by specialized mass of cells example Hydra and Planaria.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_520">17.2 Asexual Reproduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Production of an offspring by a single parent without the formation and fusion of gametes is called asexual reproduction. It involves only mitotic cell divisions and meiosis does not occur. Offspring produced by asexual reproduction are not only identical to parents but are also exact copies of their parent.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Asexual reproduction occurs by spore formation. This is the most common method of asexual reproduction in fungi and bacteria.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">During spore formation a structure called sporangium develops from the fungal hypha. The nucleus divides several times within the sporangium and each nucleus with small amount of cytoplasm develops into a spore. The spores are liberated, and they develop into new hypha after reaching the ground or substratum.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image526.jpeg" alt="Spore formation in Rhizopus in Explained in the text book " class="calibre370"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 17.6 Spore formation in Rhizopus</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Activity 1</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_1049">Wet a slice of bread, and keep it in a cool, moist and dark place.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Observe the surface of the slice with a magnifying glass.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Record your observations for a week.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_521">17.3 Sexual Reproduction in Plants</h2>
	<p class="block_">Sexual reproduction is the process in which two gametes (male and female) are fused to produce offspring of their own kind. In such cases both sexes, male and female sex organs are needed to produce gametes. You have already learnt that the flower is a reproductive organ of a flowering plant. To understand this further we need to study the structure of a flower.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_522">17.3.1 Parts of a Typical Flower</h3>
	<p class="block_">A flower is a modified shoot with limited growth to carry out sexual reproduction. A flower consists of four whorls borne on a thalamus. These whorls are from outside</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">Calyx – consisting of sepals</li>
	<li class="block_7">Corolla – consisting of petals</li>
	<li class="block_7">Androecium – consisting of stamens</li>
	<li class="block_8">Gynoecium or pistil – consisting of carpels</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-270.png" alt="This picture Shows the Parts of a flower." class="calibre371"/> </p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 17.7 Parts of a flower</p>
	<p class="block_12">Activity 2</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Take a shoe flower from a growing plant.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Observe the floral parts Calyx, Corolla, Androecium and Gynoecium.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Separate the stamens and carpels and observe the parts.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Dust the pollen grains on a slide and observe under a microscope.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_1001">The two outermost whorls calyx and corolla are non-essential or accessory whorls as they do not directly take part in the reproduction. The other two whorls androecium and gynoecium are known as the essential whorls, because both take part directly in reproduction.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Androecium:</b> Androecium, the male part of flower is composed of stamens. Each stamen consists of a stalk called the filament and a small bag like structure called anther at the tip. The pollen grains are produced in the anther within the pollen sac.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-271.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Anther  and image of pollen grain " class="calibre372"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Pollen grain:</b> Pollen grains are usually spherical in shape. It has two layered walls. The hard- outer layer is known as exine. It has prominent apertures called germ pore. The inner thin layer is known as intine. It is a thin and continuous layer made up of cellulose and pectin. Mature pollen grains contain two cells, the vegetative and the generative cell. Vegetative cell contains a large nucleus. The generative cell divides mitotically to form two male gametes.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Gynoecium:</b> Gynoecium is the female part of the flower and is made up of carpels. It has three parts:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1049">Ovary</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Style</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Stigma</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1001">The ovary contains the ovules.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-272.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Gynoecium " class="calibre373"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_523">17.3.2 Structure of the Ovule</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The main part of the ovule is the nucellus which is enclosed by two integuments leaving an opening called as micropyle. The ovule is attached to the ovary wall by a stalk known as funiculus. Chalaza is the basal part.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-273.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Structure of Ovule " class="calibre374"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 17.10 Structure of the Ovule</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The embryo sac contains seven cells and the eighth nuclei located within the nucellus. Three cells at the micropylar end form the egg apparatus and the three cells at the chalaza end are the antipodal cells. The remaining two nuclei are called polar nuclei found in the centre. In the egg apparatus one is the egg cell (female gamete), and the remaining two cells are the synergids.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Process of sexual reproduction in flowering plants. It involves:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1049">Pollination</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Fertilization</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_524">17.4 Pollination</h2>
	<p class="block_">The transfer of pollen grains from anther to stigma of a flower is called as pollination</p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-274.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of 8NKYJ" class="calibre375"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Importance of Pollination</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">It results in fertilization which leads to the formation of fruits and seed.</li>
	<li class="block_66"> New varieties of plants are formed through new combination of genes in case of cross pollination.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_525">17.4.1 Types of Pollination</h3>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">Self-pollination</li>
	<li class="block_8">Cross pollination</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Self-pollination (Autogamy)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Self-pollination is also known as autogamy. The transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of same flower or another flower borne on the same plant is known as self- pollination. Example  Hibiscus.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Advantages of self-pollination</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Self-pollination is possible in certain bisexual flowers.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Flowers do not depend on agents for pollination.</li>
	<li class="block_8">There is no wastage of pollen grains.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Disadvantages of self-pollination</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">The seeds are less in numbers.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The endosperm is minute. Therefore, the seeds produce weak plants.</li>
	<li class="block_8">New varieties of plants cannot be produced</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Cross pollination</p>
	<p class="block_">Cross-pollination is the transfer of pollen from the anthers of a flower to the stigma of a flower on another plant of the same species e.g., apples, grapes, plum, etc.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Advantages of cross pollination</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">The seeds produced as a result of cross pollination, develop and germinate properly and grow into better plants, that is, cross pollination leads to the production of new varieties.</li>
	<li class="block_8">More viable seeds are produced.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Disadvantages of cross-pollination</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Pollination may fail due to distance barrier.</li>
	<li class="block_7">More wastage of pollen grains</li>
	<li class="block_7">It may introduce some unwanted characters</li>
	<li class="block_8">Flowers depend on the external agencies for pollination</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Activity 3</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Observe the flowers in a garden. Identify the insects and birds that act as pollinating agents.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Maintain a record of pollinating agents and the plants.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_526">17.5 Agents of Cross Pollination</h2>
	<p class="block_">In order to bring about cross pollination, it is necessary that the pollen should be carried from one flower to another of a different plant. This takes place through the agency of animals, insects, wind and water.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6"><b class="calibre6">Pollination by wind</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_533">The pollination with the help of wind is called anemophily. The anemophilous flowers produce enormous amount of pollen grains. The pollen grains are small, smooth, dry and light in weight. Pollen of such plants are blown off at a distance of more than 1,000 km. The stigmas are comparatively large, protruding and sometimes hairy to trap the pollen grains. Example  Grasses and some cacti.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="2" class="block_7"><b class="calibre6">Pollination by insects</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_533">Pollination with the help of insects like honeybees, flies are called entomophily. To attract insects these flowers are brightly coloured, have smell and nectar. The pollen grains are larger in size, the exine is pitted, spiny etcetera. so they can be adhered firmly on the sticky stigma. Approximately, 80% of the pollination done by the insects is carried by honeybees.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="3" class="block_7"><b class="calibre6">Pollination by water</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_533">The pollination with the help of water is called hydrophily. This takes place in aquatic plants.</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_7">Pollen grains are produced in large numbers.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Pollen grains float on surface of water till they land on the stigma of female flowers example  Hydrilla, Vallisneria.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-275.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Hydrophily" class="calibre376"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 17.11 Hydrophily</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="4" class="block_6"><b class="calibre6">Pollination by Animals</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_114">When pollination takes place with the help of animals, it is called Zoophily. Flowers of such plants attract animals by their bright colour, size, scent etc. example.sun bird pollinates flowers of Canna, Gladioli etcetera. Squirrels pollinate flowers of silk cotton tree.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_527">17.6 Fertilization in Plants</h2>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-276.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Process of Fertilization." class="calibre377"/></p>
	<p class="block_19">Figure 17.12 Process of Fertilization</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_1049">Pollen grains reach the right stigma and begin to germinate.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Pollen grain forms a small tube-like structure called pollen tube which emerges through the germ pore. The contents of the pollen grain move into the tube.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Pollen tube grows through the tissues of the stigma and style and finally reaches the ovule through the micropyle.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Vegetative cell degenerates and the generative cell divides to form two sperms (or male gametes).</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Tip of pollen tube bursts and the two sperms enter the embryo sac.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">One sperm fuse with the egg (syngamy) and forms a diploid zygote. The other sperm fuses with the secondary nucleus (Triple fusion) to form the primary endosperm nucleus which is triploid in nature. Since two types of fusion syngamy and triple fusion take place in an embryo sac the process is termed as double fertilization.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"> After triple fusion, primary endosperm nucleus develops into an endosperm.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"> Endosperm provides food to the developing embryo.</li>
	<li class="block_1049"> Later the synergids and antipodal cells degenerate.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">Significance of Fertilization</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">It stimulates the ovary to develop into fruit.</li>
	<li class="block_8">It helps in development of new characters from two different individuals.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Post fertilization changes:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">The ovule develops into a seed.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The in teguments of the ovule develop into the seed coat.</li>
	<li class="block_8">The ovary enlarges and develops into a fruit.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">The seed contains the future plant or embryo which develops into a seedling under appropriate conditions.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_528">17.7 Sexual Reproduction in Human</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">You have studied the structural details of the male and female reproductive system in 9th standard. In human beings the male and female reproductive organs differ anatomically and physiologically. New individuals develop by the fusion of gametes. Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of two haploid gametes (male and the female gametes) to form a diploid individual (zygote).</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Organs of the reproductive system are divided into primary and secondary (accessory) sex organs.</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Primary reproductive organs include the gonads (Testes in male and Ovaries in female).</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Accessory sex organs</li>
</ul>
	<ul class="list_5">
	<li class="block_1169">Male: Vas deferens, epididymis, seminal vesicle, prostate gland and penis.</li>
	<li class="block_1170">Female: Fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and vagina.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_">The secondary (accessory) sex organs include those structures which are involved in the</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Process of ovulation</li>
	<li class="block_7">Fusion of the male and female gametes (fertilization)</li>
	<li class="block_7">Division of the fertilized egg up to the formation of embryo</li>
	<li class="block_7">Pregnancy</li>
	<li class="block_7">Development of foetus</li>
	<li class="block_8">Childbirth.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_">Now let’s see the cells of the primary reproductive organs in human male and female and their role in reproduction.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_529">17.7.1 Male Reproductive Organ - Structure of Testes</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Testes are the reproductive glands of the male that are oval shaped organs which lie outside the abdominal cavity of a man in a sac like structure called scrotum. Now we shall study the various cells which are present in the testes.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Each testis is covered with a layer of fibrous tissue called tunica albuginea. Many septa from this layer divide the testes into pyramidal lobules, in which lie seminiferous tubules, cells of Sertoli, and the Leydig cells (interstitial cells).</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The process of spermatogenesis takes place in the seminiferous tubules. The Sertoli cells are the supporting cells and provide nutrients to the developing sperms. The Leydig cells are polyhedral in shape and lie between the seminiferous tubules and secrete testosterone. It initiates the process of spermatogenesis.</p>
	<p class="block_985"><img src="images/image-277.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Cross section of human testes " class="calibre378"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 17.13 L.S. of human testes</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_530">17.7.2. Female Reproductive Organ - Structure of Ovary</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The ovaries are located on either side of the lower abdomen composed of two almond shaped bodies, each lying near the lateral end of fallopian tube. Each ovary is a compact structure consisting of an outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex is composed of a network of connective tissue called as stroma and is lined by the germinal epithelium. The epithelial cells called the granulosa cells surround each ovum in the ovary together forming the primary follicle. As the egg grows larger, the follicle also enlarges and gets filled with the fluid and is called the Graafian follicle.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Info bits</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The number of primordial follicles in newborn female child ranges over 7 million and during reproductive period (at puberty) the number is around 60,000 to 70,000. During a woman’s lifetime, she will only ovulate 300 to 400 of the 1-2 million eggs, she was initially born with. On the other side, men will produce over 500 billion sperms in their lifetime.</p>
	<p class="block_1092"> </p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image541.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Cross section of human ovary " class="calibre379"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 17.14 Cross section of human ovary</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_531">17.8 Gametogenesis</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">The formation of the sperm in male and the ovum in female is called gametogenesis. It involves spermatogenesis (formation of spermatozoa) and oogenesis (the formation of ova). Gametes with haploid cells are produced through gametogenesis.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_532">17.8.1Structure of Human Sperm</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The spermatozoan consists of head, a middle piece and tail. The sperm head is elongated and formed by the condensation of nucleus. The anterior portion has a cap like structure called acrosome. It contains hyaluronidase an enzyme that helps the sperm to enter the ovum during fertilization. A short neck connects the head and middle piece which comprises the centrioles. The middle piece contains the mitochondria which provides energy for the movement of tail. It brings about sperm motility which is essential for fertilization.</p>
	<p class="block_1092"> </p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-278.png" alt="This image shows the Structure of sperm" class="calibre380"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 17.15 Structure of sperm</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_533">17.8.2Structure of Human Ovum</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The mature ovum or egg is spherical in shape. The ovum is almost free of yolk. It contains abundant cytoplasm and the nucleus. The ovum is surrounded by three membranes. The plasma membrane is surrounded by inner thin zona pellucida and an outer thick corona radiata. The corona radiata is formed of follicle cells. The membrane forming the surface layer of the ovum is called vitelline membrane. The fluid-filled space between zona pellucida and the surface of the egg is called perivitelline space.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-279.png" alt="This image shows Structure of ovum " class="calibre381"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Puberty</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The reproductive system in both males and females becomes functional and an increase in sex hormone production resulting in puberty. This phenomenon tends to start earlier in females than in males. Generally, boys attain puberty between the age of 13 to 14 years, while girls reach puberty between 11 to 13 years. In male, the onset of puberty is triggered by the secretion of the hormone testosterone in the testes, in female the secretion of estrogens and progesterone from the ovary. The secretion of both male and female hormones is under the control of the pituitary gonadotropins luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH).</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_534">17.9 Menstrual Cycle-Process of Ovulation</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">The cyclic events that take place in a rhythmic fashion during the reproductive period of a woman’s life is called menstrual cycle. In human females the menstrual cycle starts at the age of 11-13 years which marks the onset of puberty and is called menarche and ceases around 48-50 years of age and this stage is termed menopause. The reproductive period is marked by characteristic events repeated almost every month in physiologically normal women (28 days with minor variation) in the form of a menstrual flow. The menstrual cycle consists of 4 phases</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">Menstrual or Destructive Phase</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Follicular or Proliferative Phase</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Ovulatory Phase</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Luteal or Secretory Phase</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-280.png" alt="figure 17.17 Menstrual cycle in Explained as follows menstrual phase follicular phase ovulatory phase luteal phase. " class="calibre382"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 17.17 Menstrual cycle</p>
	<p class="block_1001">These phases show simultaneous synchrony of events in both ovary and uterus. Changes in the ovary and the uterus are induced by the pituitary hormones (LH and FSH) and ovarian hormones (estrogen and progesterone).</p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1002">Table 17.1 Events of Menstrual Cycle and the Role of Hormones</p>

	<p class="block_1002">Info bit</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Menstruation is a periodical phenomenon that continues from puberty to menopause. This will happen if the released ovum is not fertilized by the sperm. Lack of menstruation generally indicates pregnancy.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_535">17.10 Fertilization to Foetal Development</h2>
	<p class="block_1002">Fertilization</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Fertilization in human is internal and occurs in the oviduct of the female genital tract. It takes place usually in the ampulla of the fallopian tube. An oocyte is alive for about 24 hours after it is released from the follicle. Fertilisation must take place within 24 hours. The sperm enters into the ovum and fuses with it, resulting in the formation of a ‘zygote’. This process is called fertilization. The zygote is a fertilized ovum.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Cleavage and Formation of Blastula</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The first cleavage takes place about 30 hours after fertilization. Cleavage is a series of rapid mitotic divisions of the zygote to form many celled <span id="id_Int_znkokk8k">blastula (Blastocyst) which comprises an outer layer of smaller cells and inner mass of larger cells.</span></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Implantation</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The blastocyst (fertilized egg) reaches the uterus and gets implanted in the uterus. The process of attachment of the blastocyst to the uterine wall (endometrium) is called implantation. The fertilized egg becomes implanted in about 6 to 7 days after fertilization.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Gastrulation</p>
	<p class="block_">The transformation of blastula into gastrula and the formation of primary germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm) by rearrangement of the cells is called gastrulation. This takes place after the process of implantation.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Info bits</p>
	<p class="block_">Normally one egg matures in the ovary each month. Ovulation is the rupture of the follicle releasing the egg or <span id="id_Int_sEIfylPs" class="calibre203">ovum . The uterus prepares itself to receive the fertilized egg every month. The uterine lining becomes thick and spongy for implantation of the fertilized egg. </span></p>
	<p class="block_">Events leading to when fertilization occurs and does not occur </p>
	<p class="block_">If fertilization takes place the corpus luteum persists, continues to secrete progesterone maintains the thickened state of uterine wall and prevents maturation of another follicle till the end of pregnancy. </p>
	<p class="block_">If fertilization does not occur, corpus luteum degenerates, the egg disintegrates and the uterine lining slowly breaks, discharged as blood and mucus leading to menstrual events.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-281.png" alt="This image shows the Developmental stages of zygote from cleavage to blastocyst formation" class="calibre383"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 17.18 Developmental stages of zygote from cleavage to blastocyst formation</p>
	<p class="block_12">Organogenesis</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The establishment of the germ layers namely ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm initiate the final phase of embryonic development. During organogenesis the various organs of the foetus are established from the different germ layers attaining a functional state.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Formation of Placenta</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The placenta is a disc shaped structure attached to the uterine wall and is a temporary association between the developing embryo and maternal tissues. It allows the exchange of food materials, diffusion of oxygen, excretion of nitrogenous wastes and elimination of carbon dioxide. A cord containing blood vessels that connects the placenta with the foetus is called the umbilical cord.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Pregnancy (Gestation)</p>
	<p class="block_1001">It is the time period during which the embryo attains its development in the uterus. Normally gestation period of human last for about 280 days. During pregnancy the uterus expands up to 500 times of its normal size.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Parturition (Childbirth)</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Parturition is the expulsion of young one from the mother’s uterus at the end of gestation. Oxytocin from the posterior pituitary stimulates the uterine contractions and provides force to expel the baby from the uterus, causing birth.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Do You Know</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Sometimes ovaries release two eggs and each is fertilised by a different sperm, resulting in Non-Identical Twins (Fraternal Twins). If single egg is fertilised and then divides into two foetus, Identical Twins develop.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Lactation</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The process of milk production after childbirth from mammary glands of the mother is called lactation. The first fluid which is released from the mammary gland after childbirth is called as colostrum. Milk production from alveoli of mammary glands is stimulated by prolactin secreted from the anterior pituitary. The ejection of milk is stimulated by posterior pituitary hormone oxytocin.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Info bits</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The milk produced from the breast during the first 2 to 3 days after childbirth is called colostrum. It contains immune substances and provides immunity to the newborn which is essential for the body.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_536">17.11 Reproductive Health</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">According to World Health Organization (W H O) reproductive health means a total wellbeing in all aspects of reproduction, ability to reproduce and regulate fertility, women's ability to undergo pregnancy and safe childbirth, maternal and infant survival and well-being.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Several measures were undertaken by the government to improve the reproductive health of the people by launching National Health Programmes such as the</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Family Welfare Programme</li>
	<li class="block_65">Reproductive and Child Health Care (RCH) Programme</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Family welfare programme:</b> The National Family Welfare Programme is a comprehensive scheme which includes:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Maternal and child health care (MCH)</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Immunization of mothers, infants and children.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Nutritional supplement to pregnant women and children.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Contraception with health education, to motivate couples to accept contraceptive methods and to have small family norms, which improve economic status, living status and the quality of life.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Reproductive and Child Health Care (RCH) Programme:</b> It has integrated all services which include</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Pregnancy and childbirth</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Postnatal care of the mother and child</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Importance of breast feeding</li>
	<li class="block_65">Prevention of reproductive tract infections and sexually transmitted diseases.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_537">17.12 Population Explosion and Family Planning</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Population explosion defined as the sudden and rapid rise in the size of population, especially human population. Realizing the dangers inherent in population growth, the Government of India has taken several measures to check population growth and introduced family planning. India has been one of the first country in the world to launch the nationwide family planning programme in 1952.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Family planning is a way of living that is adopted voluntarily by couples on the basis of knowledge and responsible decisions to promote the health and welfare of the family group and society. The W H O (World Health Organisation) has also stressed the importance of family planning as global strategy health for all.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Do You Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The inverted red triangle is a symbol of family planning in India for family welfare. It is displayed prominently at all hospitals, primary health clinics and family welfare centres where any help or advice about family planning is available free of cost. The symbol is displayed along with a slogan Small Family, Happy Family.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_538">17.12.1. Contraception </h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Contraception is one of the best birth control measures. A number of techniques or methods have been developed to prevent pregnancies in women. The devices used for contraception are called contraceptive devices. Common contraceptive methods used to prevent pregnancy are discussed here. </p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1182">Barrier methods</li>
	<li class="block_1183">Hormonal methods</li>
	<li class="block_1183">Intra-Uterine Devices (IUD s)</li>
	<li class="block_1184">Surgical methods</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Barrier Methods</p>
	<p class="block_1054">This method prevents sperms from meeting the ovum. Its entry into the female reproductive tract is prevented by barrier.</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_64"><b class="calibre6">Condom:</b> Condom prevents deposition of sperms in the vagina. Condoms are made of thin rubber or latex sheath. Condom also protect against sexually transmitted diseases (STD) like syphilis, AIDS.</li>
	<li class="block_65"><b class="calibre6">Diaphragm (Cervical cap):</b> Vaginal diaphragm fitting into the vagina or a cervical cap fitting over the cervix. This prevents the entry of sperms into the uterus.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Hormonal Methods</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Hormonal preparations are in the form of pills or tablets (contraceptive pills). These hormones stop (interfere with ovulation) the release of egg from the ovary.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Intra-Uterine Devices (IUD s)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The intrauterine device (IUD) are contraceptive devices inserted into the uterus. There are two synthetic devices commonly used in India are</p>
	<p class="block_1054"> Lippe’s Loop and Copper-T made of copper and plastic (non-irritant). This can remain for a period of 3 years. This reduces the sperm fertilizing capacity and prevents implantation. This also helps to give adequate time interval between pregnancies.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-282.png" alt="This picture shows the image of Copper-T" class="calibre384"/></p>
	<p class="block_9">Figure 17.19 Copper-T</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">Surgical Methods</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Surgical contraception or sterilization techniques are terminal methods to prevent any pregnancy. This procedure in males is vasectomy (ligation of vas deferens) and in females it is tubectomy (ligation of fallopian tube). These are methods of permanent birth control.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_539">17.13 Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Many diseases affect both women and men, but a few diseases occur at a higher frequency in woman. Women are susceptible to U T I from the bacteria that are present on skin, rectum or vagina. This will enter the urethra, before moving upwards. The types of <span id="id_Int_EvNET3cD" class="calibre203">U T I are:</span></p>
	<p class="block_63">1 Cystitis or Bladder infection</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Bacteria lodged in the urinary bladder thrive and multiply leading to inflammation. It is most common in the age group of 20 to 50.</p>
	<p class="block_63">2 Kidney Infection</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The bacteria can travel from the urinary bladder and upward to ureter and affect one or both the kidneys. It also infects the blood stream and leads to serious life-threatening complications.</p>
	<p class="block_63">3 Asymptomatic Bacteriuria</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The bacteria present in the urinary bladder which may not show any symptoms.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_540">17.14 Personal Hygiene</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Hygiene is the practice of healthy living and personal cleanliness. Personal hygiene is caring of one’s own body and health. Social hygiene is proper care of the surrounding environment. The main aspect of hygiene is body hygiene, food hygiene, sanitary hygiene and hygienic environment.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_541">17.14.1Body Hygiene</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Washing is vital to all age group of people which maintains our personal hygiene. A daily bath regularly keeps skin clean and free of germs. Hair should be kept clean by frequent washing. Mouth wash should be done after every meal. We should wash our hands many times during the day. Cloth towels used to dry our hands or body should be dried after each use and laundered regularly. Clothes, handkerchief, undergarments and socks should be washed daily. Washing prevents body odour, infections and skin irritation.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_542">17.14.2Toilet Hygiene</h3>
	<p class="block_9">The toilet has a lot to do with personal hygiene and general health as it is a place that cannot be avoided and used regularly. Parents should guide and practice their children on how to use the toilets at home, in schools and other public places so that it will protect the children from various contagious infections and diseases. The following measures can ensure toilet hygiene</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_66">The floors of the toilet should be maintained clean and dry. This helps to reduce the bad odour and also infection.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Toilet flush handles, doorknobs, faucets, paper towel dispensers, light switches and walls should be cleaned with disinfectants to kill harmful germs and bacteria.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Hands should be washed thoroughly with soap before and after toilet use.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_543">17.14.3Menstrual and Napkin Hygiene</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Women’s health depends upon the level of cleanliness to keep them free from skin and genitourinary tract infection.</p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<p class="block_1002">Menstrual hygiene</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Maintaining menstrual hygiene is important for the overall health of women. The basic menstrual hygiene ways are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">Sanitary pads should be changed regularly, to avoid infections due to microbes from vagina and sweat from genitals.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Use of warm water to clean genitals helps to get rid of menstrual cramps</li>
	<li class="block_66">Wearing loose clothing rather than tight fitting clothes will ensure the airflow around the genitals and prevent sweating.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Every year May 28 is observed as Menstrual Hygiene Day to make girls and women aware of maintaining menstrual hygiene and importance of menstrual hygiene for good health. By way of awareness through films, discussions and campaigns menstrual hygiene has taken quite the centre stage in recent days.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Napkin hygiene</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The parents and teachers are to create awareness among the schoolgirls about the use of napkins and their proper disposal. Girls should be educated in the following ways</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">The sanitary pad and tampons should be wrapped properly and discarded because they can spread infections.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Sanitary pad or tampon should not be flushed down the toilet.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Napkin incinerators are to be used properly for disposal of used napkins.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1002">Info bits</p>
	<p class="block_1003">The menstrual hygiene scheme to provide subsidized sanitary napkins was launched by the health ministry in 2011In Tamil Nadu, UNICEF has developed an affordable incinerator that uses firewood to handle sanitary napkin waste at schools and special wells are equipped where sanitary napkins are composted.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_544">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_1185">Many bacteria and protozoa simply divide into two or more daughter cells by fission.</li>
	<li class="block_1186">Organisms such as hydra can regenerate if they are broken into pieces. They can also give out buds which mature into new individuals.</li>
	<li class="block_1186">Reproduction in flowering plants involves transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma which is referred to as pollination. This is followed by fertilization.</li>
	<li class="block_1186">Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of two haploid gametes (male and the female gametes) to form a diploid individual (zygote).</li>
	<li class="block_1186">The formation of the sperm in male and the ovum in female is called gametogenesis. It involves spermatogenesis (formation of spermatozoa) and oogenesis (the formation of ova).</li>
	<li class="block_1186">The cyclic events that take place in a rhythmic manner during the reproductive period of a woman’s life is called menstrual cycle.</li>
	<li class="block_1186">The process of attachment of the blastocyst to the uterine wall (endometrium) is called implantation.</li>
	<li class="block_1186"> The placenta is a temporary association between the developing embryo and maternal tissues.</li>
	<li class="block_1186"> Parturition is the expulsion of young one from the mother’s uterus.</li>
	<li class="block_1187"> Contraception is one of the best birth control measures. The devices used for contraception are called contraceptive devices.</li>
</ul>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_560">UNIT-18 <b class="calibre6">GENETICS</b></h1>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-288.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of 2BK7U" class="calibre390"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_561">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_9">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">Know about Mendelian laws.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Differentiate between phenotype and genotype.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the process of monohybrid and dihybrid cross.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Differentiate between a chromosome, DNA and gene.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the structure of chromosome.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Classify the chromosomes based on the position of centromere.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand the structure and replication of DNA.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Define mutation and classify the chromosomal and gene mutation.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Identify the chromosomal abnormality of Down’s syndrome.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_562">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">“Like Begets Like” is an important and universal phenomenon of life as the living beings produce offspring of their own kind. Colour of eye, colour of hair, shape of nose, type of earlobe, etcetera, are inheritable traits. Have you ever wondered, how do we inherit traits and characteristics from our father and mother? Some of our characteristics might have been inherited from our grandparents. How do we inherit characters from one generation to another? It is because of the genes we inherit from our parents. These genes are responsible for the physical outlook and biological functions. The branch of biology that deals with the genes, genetic variation and heredity of living organisms is called genetics.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Heredity is transmission of characters, from one generation to the next generation, while variation refers to the differences shown by the individuals of the same species and also by the offspring of the same parents. All these can happen only due to chromosomes. Now let’s see what chromosomes are and how they are composed with DNA, that form the genetic material.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_563">18.1Gregor Johann Mendel - Father of Genetics</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Mendel (1822-1884) was an Austrian monk who discovered the basic principles of heredity through his experiments. His experiments are the foundation for modern genetics. He was born in 1822 to a family of farmers in Silesian of Czechoslovakia. After finishing his high school at the age of 18, he entered the Augustinian Monastery at Brunn as a priest. From there he went to the University of Vienna for training in physics, mathematics and natural science. Mendel returned to the monastery in 1854 and continued to work as a priest and teach in high school. In his leisure time he started his famous experiments on the garden pea plant. He conducted his experiments in the monastery for about seven years from 1856 to 1863. He had worked on nearly 10000 pea plants of 34 different varieties. Mendel noted that they differ from one another in many ways.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Thus, Mendel had chosen 7 pairs of contrasting characters for his study as shown in the table.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Table 18.1 contrasting characters of pea plant used by Mendel</p>

	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<p class="block_63">Reasons for Mendel’s success</p>
	<p class="block_1054">He chose the pea plant as it was advantageous for experimental work in many aspects</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">It is naturally self-pollinating and so is very easy to raise pure breeding individuals.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It has a short life span as it is an annual and so it was possible to follow several generations.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It is easy to cross-pollinate.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">It has deeply defined contrasting characters.</li>
	<li class="block_65">The flowers are bisexual.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_564">18.2Monohybrid Cross – Inheritance of One Gene</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Crosses involving inheritance of only one pair of contrasting characters are called monohybrid crosses. For example, it is a cross between two forms of a single trait like a cross between tall and dwarf plant.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Mendel’s Explanation of Monohybrid Cross </p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Parental generation:</b> Pure breeding tall plant and a pure breeding dwarf plant.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">F1 generation:</b> Plants raised from the seeds of pure breeding parental cross in F1 generation were tall and monohybrids.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">F2 generation: </b>Selling of the F1 monohybrids resulted in tall and dwarf plants respectively in the ratio of 3 is to1. The actual number of tall and dwarf plants obtained by Mendel was 787 tall and 277 dwarf. External expression of a particular trait is known as phenotype. So, the phenotypic ratio is 3 is to1.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In the F2 generation 3 different types were obtained:</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Tall Homozygous – T T (Pure) – 1 </p>
	<p class="block_1054">Tall Heterozygous – T t – 2</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Dwarf Homozygous – t t – 1</p>
	<p class="block_1054">So, the genotypic ratio 1 is to 2 is to1. A genotype is the genetic expression of an organism</p>
	<p class="block_63">Mendel’s Interpretation on Monohybrid cross</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Based on these observations it was confirmed by Mendel that ‘factors’ are passed on from one generation to another, now referred to as genes. Tallness and Dwarfness are determined by a pair of contrasting factors, tall plant possess a pair of factors (represented by capital T- taking the first letter of the dominant character) and a plant is dwarf because it possesses factors for dwarfness (represented as small t- recessive character). These factors occur</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-289.png" alt="Monohybrid cross explained in the image as follows parental generation gametes capital T small t. f 1 generation genotype all are capital T small t phenotype all are tall. f 2 generation genotype capital T capital T is to capital T small t is to small t small t = 1 is to 2 is to 1 phenotype tall is to dwarf = 3 is to 1. " class="calibre391"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 18.1 Monohybrid cross</p>
	<p class="block_1054">in pairs and may be alike as in pure breeding tall plants (capital TT) and dwarf plants (small tt). This is referred to as homozygous. If they are unlike (capital T small t) they are referred to as heterozygous.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Two factors making up a pair of contrasting characters are called alleles or allelomorphs. One member of each pair is contributed by one parent.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">When two factors for alternative expression of a trait are brought together by fertilization. </li>
	<li class="block_1055">The character which expresses itself is called dominant (Tallness) condition and that which is masked is called recessive condition (dwarfness).</li>
	<li class="block_65">The factors are always pure and when gametes are formed, the unit factors segregate so that each gamete gets one of the two alternative factors. It means that factors for tallness(capital T) and dwarfness(small t) are separate entities and in a gamete either capital T or small t is present. When F1 hybrids are self crossed the two entities separate and then unite independently, forming tall and dwarf plants.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Info Bits </p>
	<p class="block_">Punnett square is a checkerboard form devised by a British geneticist R C Punnett for study of genetics. It is a graphical representation to calculate the probability of all possible genotypes of offsprings in a genetic cross.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_565">18.3Dihybrid Cross- </h2>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_566">Inheritance Two Genes and Law of Independent Assortment</h2>
	<p class="block_">Dihybrid cross involves the inheritance of two pairs of contrasting characteristics (or contrasting traits) at the same time. The two pairs of contrasting characteristics chosen by Mendel were shape and colour of seeds: round-yellow seeds and wrinkled-green seeds.</p>
	<p class="block_">Mendel crossed pea plants having round- yellow seeds with pea plants having wrinkled- green seeds. Mendel made the following observations:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Mendel first crossed pure breeding pea plants having round-yellow seeds with pure breeding pea plants having wrinkled- green seeds and found that only round- yellow seeds were produced in the first generation (F1). No wrinkled-green seeds were obtained in the F1 generation. From this it was concluded that round shape and yellow colour of the seeds were dominant traits over the wrinkled shape and green colour of the seeds.</li>
	<li class="block_65">When the hybrids of F1 generation pea plants having round-yellow seeds were cross-bred by self-pollination, then four types of seeds having different combinations of shape and colour were obtained in second generation or F2 generation. They were round yellow, round-green, wrinkled yellow and wrinkled-green seeds.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-290.png" alt="Dihybrid Cross Explained as follows parental generation pure breeding round yellow seeds and pure breeding wrinkled seeds. first generation round yellow seeds undergoes self pollination. phenotype ratio of F 2 generation 9 is to 3 is to 3 is to 1 round yellow 9 wrinkled yellow 3 round green 3 wrinkled green 1. " class="calibre392"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 18.2 Dihybrid Cross</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The ratio of each phenotype (or appearance) of seeds in the F2 generation is 9 is to3 is to 3 is to 1. This is known as the Dihybrid ratio.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">From the above results it can be concluded that the factors for each character or trait remain independent and maintain their identity in the gametes. The factors are independent to each other and pass to the offsprings (through gametes).</p>
	<p class="block_63">Results of a Dihybrid Cross:</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Mendel got the following results from his dihybrid cross</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Four Types of Plants: A dihybrid cross produced four types of F2 offsprings in the ratio of 9 with two dominant traits, 3 with one dominant trait and one recessive trait, 3 with another dominant trait and another recessive trait and 1 with two recessive traits.</li>
	<li class="block_65">New Combination: Two new combinations of traits with round green and wrinkled yellow had appeared in the dihybrid cross (F2 generation).</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_567">18.4 Mendel’s Laws</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Based on his experiments of monohybrid and dihybrid cross, Mendel proposed three important laws which are now called as Mendel’s Laws of Heredity.</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_1193">Law of Dominance: “When two homozygous individuals with one or more sets of contrasting characters are crossed, the characters that appear in the F1 hybrid are dominant and those that do not appear in F1 are recessive characters".</li>
</ul>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_1194">Law of Segregation or Law of purity of gametes: “When a pair of contrasting factors or are brought together in a F1 hybrid the two factors of the allelic pair remain together without mixing and when gametes are formed, the two separate out, so that only one enters each gamete.”</li>
</ul>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_1195">Law of independent assortment: “In case of inheritance of two or more pairs of characters simultaneously, the factors or genes of one pair assort out independently of the other pair.”</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_1054">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">T.H. Morgan was awarded Nobel Prize in 1993 for determining the role of chromosomes in heredity.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_568">18.5 Chromosomes, DNA and Genes</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">The human body is made up of million cells. The nucleus of each cell contains thin thread like structures called chromosomes. The term ‘chromosomes’ was first coined by Waldeyer in 1888. The chromosomes are the carrier of genetic material which contain the heredity information.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The chromosomes are highly condensed coiled chromatin fibres packed with the DNA (Deoxyribonucleic acid) that forms the genetic material. Genes are segments of DNA, which are responsible for the inheritance of a particular phenotypic character. Each gene is present at a specific position on a chromosome called its locus. During cell division, the genetic information present in the genes is passed from one generation to another.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_569">18.5.1Structure of a Chromosome</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The chromosomes are thin, long and thread like structures consisting of two identical strands called sister chromatids. They are held together by the centromere. Each chromatid is made up of spirally coiled thin structure called chromonema. The chromonema has number of bead-like structures along its length which are called chromomeres. The chromosomes are made up of DNA, RNA, chromosomal proteins (histones and non-histones) and certain metallic ions. These proteins provide structural support to the chromosome.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-291.png" alt="This image displays the Structure of chromosome. " class="calibre393"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">Figure 18.3 Structure of chromosome</p>
	<p class="block_1054">A chromosome consists of the following regions</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Primary constriction:</b> The two arms of a chromosome meet at a point called primary constriction or centromere. The centromere is the region where spindle fibres attach to the chromosomes during cell division.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Secondary constriction:</b> Some chromosomes possess secondary constriction at any point of the chromosome. They are known as the nuclear zone or nucleolar organizer (formation of nucleolus in the nucleus).</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Telomere:</b> The end of the chromosome is called telomere. Each extremity of the chromosome has a polarity and prevents it from joining the adjacent chromosome. It maintains and provides stability to the chromosomes.</p>
	<p class="block_9"><b class="calibre36">Satellite:</b> Some of the chromosomes have an elongated knob-like appendage at one end of the chromosome known as satellite. The chromosomes with satellites are called as the sat-chromosomes.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do you Know </p>
	<p class="block_12">Telomeres act as aging clock in every cell.</p>
	<p class="block_">Telomeres are protective sequences of nucleotides found in chromosomes. As a cell divides every time, they become shorter. Telomeres get too short to do their job, causing our cells to age.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_570">18.5.2Types of Chromosomes based on the position of Centromere</h3>
	<p class="block_">Based on the position of centromere, the chromosomes are classified as Telocentric, Acrocentric, Submetacentric and Metacentric</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-292.png" alt="Types of chromosomes based on position of centromere in explained " class="calibre394"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002"> Figure 18.4 Types of chromosomes based on position of centromere</p>
	<p class="block_1006"> </p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">Telocentric– </li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1004">The centromere is found on the proximal end. They are rod shaped chromosomes.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="2" class="block_1049">Acrocentric – </li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1004">The centromere is found at the one end with a short arm and a long arm. They are also rod- shaped chromosomes.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="3" class="block_1049">Submetacentric – </li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1079">The centromere is found near the centre of the chromosome. Thus forming two unequal arms. They are J shaped or L shaped chromosomes.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="4" class="block_1049">Metacentric –</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1079"> The centromere occurs in the centre of the chromosome and form two equal arms. They are V shaped chromosomes</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_571">18.5.3Types of Chromosomes based on function</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The eukaryotic chromosomes are classified into autosomes and allosomes.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Autosomes contain genes that determine the somatic (body) characters. Male and female have equal number of autosomes.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Allosomes are chromosomes which are responsible for determining the sex of an individual. They are also called as sex chromosomes or hetero-chromosomes. There are two types of sex chromosomes, X and Y- chromosomes. Human male has one X-chromosome and one Y chromosome and human female have two X chromosomes.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_572">18.5.4Karyotype</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The number of chromosomes in any living organism (animal or plant) is constant. In human, each cell normally contains 23 pairs of chromosomes. Out of which 22 pairs are autosomes and the 23rd pair is the allosome or sex chromosome.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">In the body cells of sexually reproducing organisms, the chromosomes generally occur in pairs. This condition is called diploid (2n). The gametes produced by the organisms contain a single set of chromosomes. Hence, the gametes are said to be haploid (n).<br class="calibre26"/>Karyotype is the number, size and shape of chromosomes in the cell nucleus of an organism. Idiogram is the diagrammatic representation of karyotype of a species. It consists of all the metaphasic chromosomes arranged in homologous pairs according to decreasing length, thickness, position of centromere, shape etcetera., with the sex chromosomes placed at the end.</p>
	<p class="block_1002"><img src="images/image-293.png" alt="Normal human karyotype in explained " class="calibre395"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 18.5 Normal human karyotype</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_573">18.6 Structure of DNA</h2>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-294.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of KYEAB" class="calibre396"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">DNA is the hereditary material as it contains the genetic information. It is the most important constituent of a chromosome. The most widely accepted model of DNA is the double helical structure of James Watson and Francis Crick. They proposed the three-dimensional model of DNA on the basis of X-ray diffraction studies of DNA obtained by Rosalind Franklin and Maurice Wilkins. In appreciation of their discoveries on the molecular structure of nucleic acids Watson, Crick and Wilkins were awarded Nobel prize for Medicine in 1962.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Chemical Composition of DNA molecule</p>
	<p class="block_1001">DNA is a large molecule consisting of millions of nucleotides. Hence, it is also called a polynucleotide. Each nucleotide consists of three components.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">A sugar molecules Deoxyribose sugar.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">A nitrogenous base.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1079">There are two types of nitrogenous bases in DNA. They are</p>
	<div class="calibre397">
	<div class="block_1078">(a) Purines (Adenine and Guanine)</div>
	<div class="block_1078">(b) Pyrimidines (Cytosine and Thymine)</div>
</div>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="3" class="block_1049">A phosphate groups</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1002">Nucleoside and Nucleotide</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Nucleoside = Nitrogen base + Sugar </p>
	<p class="block_1001">Nucleotide = Nucleoside + Phosphate</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The nucleotides are formed according to the purines and pyrimidines present in them.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_574">18.6.1Watson and Crick model of DNA</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1049">DNA molecule consists of two polynucleotide chains.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">These chains form a double helix structure with two strands which run anti-parallel to one another.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Nitrogenous bases in the centre are linked to sugar-phosphate units which form the backbone of the DNA.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Pairing between the nitrogenous bases is very specific and is always between purine and pyrimidine linked by hydrogen bonds.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1196"> Adenine (A) links Thymine (T) with two hydrogen bonds (A) double bond (T)</p>
	<p class="block_1196"> Cytosine (C) links Guanine (G) with three hydrogen bonds (C) triple bond (G)</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image718.jpeg" alt="Structure of DNA in explained " class="calibre398"/></p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 18.6 Structure of DNA</p>
	<p class="block_1004"><span class="calibre15">       This is called complementary base pairing</span></p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="5" class="block_1049">Hydrogen bonds between the nitrogenous bases make the DNA molecule stable.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Each turn of the double helix is 34 A° (3.4 nm). There are ten base pairs in a complete turn.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">The nucleotides in a helix are joined together by phosphodiester bonds.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-295.png" alt="Nucleotides in a DNA Explained in the text book " class="calibre399"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 18.7 Nucleotides in a DNA</p>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_">Chargaff rule of DNA base pairing</p>
	<p class="block_">Erwin Chargaff states that in DNA, the proportion of adenine is always equal to that of thymine. and the proportion of guanine always equal to that of cytosine.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_575">18.6.2DNA Replication</h3>
	<p class="block_">DNA replication is one of the basic processes that occurs within a cell. DNA molecule produces exact copies of its own structure during replication process. The two strands of a DNA molecule have complementary base pairs, the nucleotides of each strand provide the information needed to produce its new strand. The two resulting daughter cells contain exactly the same genetic information as the parent cell. DNA replication involves the following steps</p>
	<p class="block_12">Origin of replication</p>
	<p class="block_">The specific points on the DNA, where the replication begins, is the site of origin of replication. The two strands open and separate at this point forming the replication fork.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Unwinding of DNA molecule</p>
	<p class="block_">The enzyme called helicase, bind to the origin of replication site. Helicase separates the two strands of the DNA. The enzyme called topoisomerase separates the double helix above the replication fork and removes the twists formed during the unwinding process. Each of the separated DNA strands function as a template.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Formation of RNA primer</p>
	<p class="block_1001">An RNA primer is a short segment of RNA nucleotides. The primer is synthesized by the DNA template close to the origin of replication site.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-296.png" alt="Replication of DNA in Explained " class="calibre400"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 18.8 Replication of DNA</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Synthesis of new complementary strand from the parent strand</p>
	<p class="block_1001">After the formation of RNA primer, nucleotides are added with the help of an enzyme DNA polymerase and a new complementary strand of DNA is formed from each of the parent strand. The synthesis is unidirectional.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">In one strand, the daughter strand is synthesized as a continuous strand which is called leading strand. In the other strand, short segments of DNA are synthesized. This strand is called lagging strand. The short segments of DNA are called Okazaki fragments. The fragments are joined together by the enzyme, DNA ligase.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The replication stops when the replication fork of the two sides meets at a site called terminus, which is situated opposite to origin of replication site</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_576">18.6.3Significance of DNA</h3>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_1049">It is responsible for the transmission of hereditary information from one generation to next generation.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">It contains information required for the formation of proteins.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">It controls the developmental process and life activities of an organism.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_577">18.7Sex Determination</h2>
	<p class="block_">The formation of zygote into male or female sex during development is called sex determination. Sex is determined by the chromosomes of an individual.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_578">18.7.1Sex Determination in Human</h3>
	<p class="block_">Recall that human beings have 23 pairs of chromosomes out of which 22 pairs are autosomes and one pair (23rd pair) is the sex chromosome. The female gametes or the eggs formed are similar in their chromosome type (22+XX). Therefore, human females are homogametic.</p>
	<p class="block_">The male gametes or sperms produced are of two types. They are produced in equal proportions. The sperm bearing (22+X) chromosomes and the sperm bearing (22+Y) chromosomes. The human males are called heterogametic.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-297.png" alt="This image shows the Sex Determination in Human - Part 1 " class="calibre401"/><b class="calibre6"><img src="images/image-298.png" alt="This image displays Sex determination in human - Part 2" class="calibre402"/></b></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 18.9 Sex determination in human<span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_">It is a chance of probability as to which category of sperm fuses with the egg. If the egg (X) is fused by the X-bearing sperm an XX individual (female) is produced. If the egg (X) is fused by the Y-bearing sperm an XY individual (male) is produced. The sperm, produced by the father, determines the sex of the child. The mother is not responsible in determining the sex of the child.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Now let’s see how the chromosomes take part in this formation. Fertilization of the egg (22+X) with a sperm (22+X) will produce a female child (44+XX). while fertilization of the egg (22+X) with a sperm (22+Y) will give rise to a male child (44+XY).</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_579">18.7.2Mutation</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The term mutation was introduced by Hugo De Vries in 1901 when he observed phenotypic changes in the evening primrose plant, Oenothera jamarckiana. Mutation is an inheritable sudden change in the genetic material (DNA) of an organism. Mutations are classified into two main types, namely chromosomal mutation and gene mutation.</p>
	<p class="block_63">1 </p>
	<p class="block_63">Chromosomal mutation</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The sudden change in the structure or number of chromosomes is called chromosomal mutation. This may result in</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64"><b class="calibre6">Changes in the structure of chromosomes</b>: Structural changes in the chromosomes usually occurs due to errors in cell division. Changes in the number and arrangement of genes takes place as a result of deletion, duplication, inversion and translocation in chromosomes.</li>
	<li class="block_65"><b class="calibre6">Changes in the number of chromosomes</b>: They involve addition or deletion in the number of chromosomes present in a cell. This is called ploidy. There are two types of ploidies</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054">(a) Euploidy (b) Aneuploidy.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Euploidy: It is the condition in which the individual bears more than the usual number of diploid (2n) chromosomes. If an individual has three haploid sets of chromosomes, the condition is called triploidy (3n). Triploid plants and animals are typically sterile. If it has four haploid sets of chromosomes, the condition is called tetraploidy (4n). Tetraploid plants are advantageous as they often result in increased fruit and flower size.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-299.png" alt="Euploidy in Explained " class="calibre403"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 18.10 Euploidy</p>
	<p class="block_">Aneuploidy: It is the loss or gain of one or more chromosomes in a set. It is of three types. Monosomy (2n minus 1), Trisomy (2n+1) and Nullisomy (2n minus 2). In man, Down’s syndrome is one of the commonly known aneuploid condition.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Down’s syndrome</p>
	<p class="block_">This condition was first identified by a doctor named Langdon Down in1866.</p>
	<p class="block_">It is a genetic condition in which there is an extra copy of chromosome 21 (Trisomy 21). It is associated with mental retardation, delayed development, behavioural problems, weak muscle tone, vision and hearing disability are some of the conditions seen in these children.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image726.jpeg" alt="picture " class="calibre404"/> <img src="images/image727.jpeg" alt="Down syndrome karyotype" class="calibre405"/> </p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 18.11 Aneuploidy</p>
	<p class="block_12">2 Gene or point mutation</p>
	<p class="block_">Gene mutation is the changes occurring in nucleotide sequence of a gene. It involves substitution, deletion, insertion or inversion of a single or more than one nitrogenous base. Gene alteration results in abnormal protein formation in an organism.</p>
	<p class="block_">Do you Know </p>
	<p class="block_">Sickle cell anaemia is caused by the mutation of a single gene. Alteration in the gene brings a change in the structure of the protein part of haemoglobin molecule. Due to the change in the protein molecule, the red blood cell (RBC) that carries the haemoglobin is sickle shaped.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Points to Remember</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Variations are quite apparent among closely related groups of organisms.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Mendel had chosen seven pairs of distinguishing traits: flower colour, position, seed colour, shape, pod colour, pod shape, stem length.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Every pea plant has two ‘factors’ which are responsible for producing a particular character or trait is called allele.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The process of acquiring characters or traits from parents is called ‘Heredity’.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Each human cell contains 23 pairs of chromosomes. Out of these 22 pairs are called autosomes and one pair is called allosomes.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A chromosome consists of the regions: primary constriction, centromere, secondary constriction, telomere and satellite.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Based on the position of the centromere, the chromosomes are classified as telocentric, acrocentric, sub metacentric and metacentric chromosomes.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Each nucleotide of DNA consists of a deoxyribose sugar, a nitrogenous base and a phosphate group. Pairing is always between a purine and a pyrimidine.</li>
	<li class="block_7">The sperm, produced by the father, determines the sex of the child. The mother is not responsible in determining the sex of the child.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Mutation is an inheritable change in the genetic material of an organism.</li>
</ul>
