	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_590">UNIT-19 <b class="calibre6">ORIGIN AND EVOLUTION OF LIFE</b></h1>
	<p class="block_"> <img src="images/image-303.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of UPZRJ" class="calibre409"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_591">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_9">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">Know about Big Bang theory on the origin of universe.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Understand theories of origin of life.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Discuss the process of evolution on the basis of the available evidences.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Relate the principles of Lamarck and Darwin with evolution.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Know how variation occurs and its significance.</li>
	<li class="block_66">List the importance of fossils and describe the process of fossilization.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Identify the plants of ethnobotanical importance.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Realize about extra-terrestrial life.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_592">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Living organisms possess distinct characteristics, display organisational and functional unity, entail a mechanism of origin and evolution of diversities and maintain a balanced relationship with nature. Most aspects of evolution indicate that the knowledge of the past has become essential for fully understanding the present. Life since its beginning on earth had changed through time. The history of life comprises of two aspects, one is the origin of life on earth and the other is mechanism involved in the gradual changes and adaptations of living organisms through time which is known as the evolution of life</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Origin of Earth</b>: Origin of life is linked with the origin of earth. The Big Bang theory explains the Origin of Universe. It proposes that the universe had an explosive beginning (Big Bang) and originated 15 billion years ago. The universe comprised of stars, clouds of gas and dust which form the galaxies. The solar system was probably created when the gaseous clouds started to collapse due to the force of its own gravity forming atoms and particles. Atoms, dust grains and gaseous disc aggregated to form clumps and gave rise to planets. This forms the solar system of the milky way galaxy. Earth was supposed to have been formed about 4.5 billion years back. Life appeared 500 million years after the formation of earth.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_593">19.1 Theories on Origin of Life</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Many theories have been postulated to explain the origin of life. The views on the origin of life have been put forth as</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Special creation:</b> This idea embodies that life on Earth is a divine creation and also attributes to supernatural event at a particular time in the past. It also emphasizes that life has not changed ever since its origin.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Spontaneous generation (Abiogenesis):</b> According to this theory life originated spontaneously from lifeless matter. It was believed that fishes originated from mud, frogs from moist soil and insects from decaying matter.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Biogenesis:</b> It was speculated by Louis Pasteur (in1862) that life originates from pre-existing life. He showed that pre-sterilised flasks kept closed airtight, with killed yeast, did not give rise to any life form, while in another flask kept open to air living organisms arose from killed yeast.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36">Extra-terrestrial or Cosmic origin:</b> Some scientists still believe that life came from outer space. This states that units of life called spores (Panspermia) were transferred to different planets including earth. This is still an idea of some astronomers. Chemical Evolution of Life: This idea was developed by Oparin (in1922) and Haldane(in1929). They proposed that with the condition prevailing on earth, life arose by a series of sequential chemical reactions. The first form of life could have come from pre-existing non- living inorganic molecules which gave rise to formation of diverse organic molecules which are transformed into colloid system to produce life. The modern concept on chemical evolution regarding origin of life was accepted.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_594">19.2 Evidences of Evolution</h2>
	<p class="block_1001">Evolution can be better understood only by observing the interrelationship between the existing organisms and also relating the similarities with the extinct organisms. The inter relationship of the organisms is also supported by evidences from different branches of biology. These evidences support the concept that all organisms have evolved from common ancestors.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_595">19.2.1 Evidences from Morphology and Anatomy</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">The comparative study of morphology and anatomy of animals, reveal that they possess common set of characteristics.</p>
	<p class="block_1002">1.</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><b class="calibre36"> Homologous organs:</b> The homologous organs are those which have inherited from common ancestors with similar developmental pattern in embryos. The fore limbs of mammals are homologous structures. A human hand, a front leg of a cat, flipper of a whale and a bat’s wing look dissimilar and adapted for different functions. Their mode of development and basic structure of bone are similar.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Figure 19.1 Forelimbs of vertebrates showing homologous structure</p>
	<p class="block_1001"><img src="images/image-304.png" alt="Forelimbs of vertebrates showing homologous structure has following common parts, human and cat has following homologous structure humerus radius ulna carpal meta carpal phalanges. whale and bat has following homologous structure humerus radius carpal meta carpal phalanges ulna." class="calibre410"/></p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<p class="block_">2 Analogous organs: The analogous organs look similar and perform similar functions but they have different origin and developmental pattern. The function of the wings of a bat, the wings of a bird and wings of an insect are similar, but their basic structures are different.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-305.png" alt="Image shows the Analogous structure showing a bat wing, a bird wing and an insect wing" class="calibre411"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 19.2 Analogous structure showing a bat wing, a bird wing and an insect wing</p>
	<p class="block_">3 </p>
	<p class="block_"> Vestigial organs: The degenerated and non-functional organs of animals are called vestigial organs. The same organs are found to be well- developed and functional, in some of the related forms. Some of the vestigial organs in man are vermiform appendix, nictitating membrane, caudal vertebra, coccyx etc.</p>
	<p class="block_">4 </p>
	<p class="block_">Atavism: The reappearance of ancestral characters in some individuals is called atavism. e.g., Presence of rudimentary tail in new born babies, presence of thick hair on the human body.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_596">19.2.2 Evidences from Embryology</h3>
	<p class="block_">The study of comparative embryology of different animals, supports the concept of evolution. The embryos from fish to mammals are similar in their early stages of development. The differentiation of their special characters appears in the later stages of development.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-306.png" alt="Embryonic development of vertebrates as follows fish salamander tortoise chick rabbit man." class="calibre412"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 19.3 Embryonic development of vertebrates</p>
	<p class="block_">Biogenetic law or Recapitulation theory was given by Ernst Haeckel. According to this theory, Ontogeny recapitulates Phylogeny. The stages of development of the individual animal repeats the evolutionary history of the entire race of the animal.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_597">19.2.2 Evidences from Palaeontology</h3>
	<p class="block_12"> <img src="images/image-307.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of OA2ZS" class="calibre413"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Palaeontology deals with the study of fossils. Leonardo da Vinci is called the Father of Palaeontology. The study of fossils helps us to understand the line of evolution of many invertebrates and vertebrates. Fossil records show that the evolution has taken a gradual process from simple to complex organisms. The origin of modern birds is supported by the evidences from palaeontology.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Archaeopteryx:</b> Archaeopteryx is the oldest known fossil bird. It was an early bird- like form found in the Jurassic period. It is considered to be a connecting link between reptiles and birds. It had wings with feathers, like a bird. It had long tail, clawed digits and conical teeth, like a reptile.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-308.png" alt="figure 19.4 Archaeopteryx - Fossil bird is shown." class="calibre414"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Figure 19.4 Archaeopteryx - Fossil bird</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_598">19.3 Theories of Evolution</h2>
	<p class="block_985">Life had evolved along with evolution of earth towards the end of 18th century. Evolution is the gradual change occurring in living organisms over a period of time. Formation of new species due to changes in specific characters over several generations as response to natural selection, is called evolution. The natural changes occurring is explained through the theories of evolution as proposed by Lamarck and Darwin.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_599">19.3.1 Lamarckism</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Jean Baptiste Lamarck (1744-1829) was a French naturalist, well known for his theory of evolution. Lamarck’s theory of evolution was published in ‘Philosophic Zoologies’ in the year 1809. It is popularly known as ‘Theory of inheritance of Acquired Characters” or “Use and Disuse theory” or Lamarckism.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Principles of Lamarckism</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_64">Internal vital force</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1180">Living organisms or their component parts tend to increase in size continuously. This increase in size is due to the inherent ability of the organisms.</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="2" class="block_1055">Environment and new needs</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1180">A change in the environment brings about changes in the need of the organisms. In response to the changing environment, the organisms develop certain adaptive characters. The adaptations of the organisms may be in the form of development of new parts of the body.</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="3" class="block_1055">Use and disuse theory</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1180">Lamarck’s use and disuse theory states that if an organ is used constantly, the organ develops well and gets strengthened. When an organ is not used for a long time, it gradually degenerates. The ancestors of giraffe were provided with short neck and short forelimbs. Due to shortage of grass, they were forced to feed on leaves from trees. The continuous stretching of their neck and forelimbs resulted in the development of long neck and long forelimbs which is an example for constant use of an organ. The degenerated wing of Kiwi is an example for organ of disuse.</p>
	<p class="block_1197">Flow chart showing the postulates of Lamarckism</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Environmental change</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Need for new structure</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Development of new structure</p>
	<p class="block_1198"> </p>
	<p class="block_1180">Organs of use Organs of disuse</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Inheritance of adaptive characters Degeneration of the structure</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Origin of new species</p>
	<p class="block_1199"> </p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-309.png" alt="flow chart showing the postulates of lamarckism. environmental change causes need for new structure. need for new structure causes development of new structure. development of new structure has two types 1. organs of use which has inheritance of adaptive characters and origin of new species. 2. organs of disuse which causes degeneration of the structure. " class="calibre415"/></p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="4" class="block_64">Theory of Inheritance of acquired characters</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1197">When there is a change in the environment, the animals respond to the change. They develop adaptive structures. The characters developed by the animals during their life time, in response to the environmental changes are called acquired characters. According to Lamarck, the acquired characters are transmitted to the offspring by the process of inheritance.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_600">19.3.2 Darwinism or Theory of Natural Selection</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Charles Darwin (1809-1882) was one of the great naturalist and philosopher of 18th century. He was born in England in 1809. While studying in college through his friendship with Professor J S Henslow he was fascinated towards nature. At that time the British Admiralty planned a voyage of exploration for 5 years on a ship named H.M.S. Beagle around South America. Dr Henslow was asked to nominate a young naturalist for the voyage. Darwin was given the opportunity. During his five years (1831–1835) voyage he visited many parts of the world, a number of islands including the Galapagos Island and Pacific Island. Darwin made elaborate observations on nature of the land, plants and animals of the regions he visited. He further worked for a period of 20 years to develop the theory of natural selection.</p>
	<p class="block_">Darwin published his observations and conclusions under the name ‘Origin of species’ in 1859. The book of Darwin demonstrates the fact of evolution. It elaborates on the theory of Natural selection for evolutionary transformation,</p>
	<p class="block_12">Principles of Darwinism</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6"><b class="calibre6">Overproduction</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_533">Living beings have the ability to reproduce more individuals and form their own progeny. They have the capacity to multiply in a geometrical manner. This will increase reproductive potential leading to overproduction.</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="2" class="block_7"><b class="calibre6">Struggle for existence</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1180">Due to over production, a geometric ratio of increase in population occurs. The space to live and food available for the organisms remain the same. This creates an intense competition among the organisms for food and space leading to struggle. The struggle for existence is of three types:</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_1169"><b class="calibre6">Intraspecific struggle:</b> Competition among the individuals of same species.</li>
	<li class="block_1169"><b class="calibre6">Interspecific struggle</b>: Competition between the organisms of different species living together.</li>
	<li class="block_1169"><b class="calibre6">Environmental struggle</b>: Natural conditions like extreme heat or cold, drought and floods can affect the existence of organisms</li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="3" class="block_1055"><b class="calibre6">Variations </b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1180">The occurrence of variation is a characteristic feature of all plants and animals. Small variations are important for evolution. According to Darwin favourable variations are useful to the organism and unfavourable variations are harmful or useless to the organism.</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="4" class="block_1055"><b class="calibre6">Survival of the fittest or Natural selection </b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1197">During the struggle for existence, the organisms which can overcome the challenging situation, survive and adapt to the surrounding environment. Organisms which are unable to face the challenges, are unfit to survive and disappear. The process of selection of organisms with favourable variation is called as natural selection.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Flowchart showing the postulates of Darwinism.</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Overproduction</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Struggle for existence</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Variations</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Organisms eliminated from environment Natural selection</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Survival of the fittest</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Inheritance of acquired characters</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Gradual accumulation of </p>
	<p class="block_1180">favourable Characters</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Origin of new species</p>
	<p class="block_533"><img src="images/image-310.png" alt="Flowchart Showing the postulates of darwinism  over production causes struggle for existence. struggle for existence causes variation. variation has two types 1. organisms eliminated from the environment 2. natural selction natural selection has following characters survival of fittest inheritance of acquired characters gradual accumulation of favourable characters." class="calibre416"/></p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="5" class="block_8">Origin of species According to Darwin, new species originates by the gradual accumulation of favourable variations for a number of generations.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_601">19.4 Variation</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Sexual reproduction, which involves meiosis helps in recombination of genes during gametic fusion. This leads to differences in the phenotype of the offspring from its parents. These differences are called variation.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Variation is the difference found among individuals of the same species and the offspring of the same parent. Variation is the raw material which plays an important role in evolution. Evolution would not be possible without variation.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Types of variations</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Somatic variation</b>: These are the variations which affect the body (somatic) cells of the organisms. They are not heritable. They occur due to environmental factors.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Germinal variation:</b> These variations are produced in germ cells of an organism. They are inherited. They may be present in ancestors or may occur suddenly. They are classified into two types:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Continuous variation</li>
	<li class="block_65">Discontinuous variation</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Continuous variation:</b> These are small variations which occur among individuals of a population. They are also called as fluctuating variations. They occur by gradual accumulation in a population. Example  skin colour, height and weight of an individual, colour of eye, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Discontinuous variation: </b>These are sudden changes which occur in an organism due to mutations. They do not have any intermediate forms. These large variations are not useful for evolution. </p>
	<p class="block_1054">Example  short legged Ancon sheep, six or more digits (fingers) in human, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Discontinuous variation forms the basis for Mutation theory proposed by De Vries.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Relationship between Mutation and Variation</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Mutation and Variation are two events involved in the process of evolution. Mutation arises due to errors occurring in DNA during replication or exposure to UV rays or chemicals. Mutation leads to variation. It brings about changes in a single individual.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_602">19.5 Palaeobotany</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Palaeobotany is derived from Greek words pale on that means “old” and botany the study of plants. It is the branch of palaeontology that deals with recovery and identification of plant remains of geological past.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">A plant fossil is any preserved part of a plant that has died long back. Fossils may be a prehistoric impression that may be hundred to millions of years old. Majority of the plant fossils are disarticulated parts of plants. it is rare to find plants to be preserved as whole.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Importance of fossils</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1193">They throw light on phylogeny<span class="tab">      </span>and evolution of plants.</li>
	<li class="block_1194">Fossil plants give a historical approach to plant kingdom.</li>
	<li class="block_1194">Fossils are useful in classification of plants.</li>
	<li class="block_1195">Fossil plants can be used in the field of descriptive and comparative anatomy.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Kaspar Maria Von Sternberg</p>
	<p class="block_1054">He is the “Father of Palaeobotany” (1761– 1838) was born in Europe. He established the Bohemian National Museum in Prague and is deemed to be the founder of Modern Palaeobotany.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Birbal Sahani</p>
	<p class="block_1054">He is the “Father of Indian Palaeobotany” (1891–1949). He presented his research on two different areas of Palaeobotany </p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_64">The anatomy and morphology of Palaeozoic Ferns</li>
	<li class="block_65">The fossil plants of the Indian Gondwana Formations.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_603">19.5.1 Fossilization</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The process of formation of fossil in the rocks is called fossilization.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Common methods of fossilization include petrifaction, Molds and cast, carbonization, preservation, compression and infiltration.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Petrifaction</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Minerals like silica slowly penetrate in and replace the original organic tissue and forms a rock like fossil. This method of fossilization can preserve hard and soft parts. Most bones and wood fossils are petrified.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Mold and Cast</p>
	<p class="block_1054">A replica of a plant or animal is preserved in sedimentary rocks. When the organism gets buried in sediment it is dissolved by underground water leaving a hollow depression called a Mold. It shows the original shape but does not reveal the internal structure. Minerals or sediment fill the hollow depression and forms a cast.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Preservation</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Original remains can be preserved in ice or amber (tree sap). They protect the organisms from decay. The entire plant or animal is preserved.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Compression</p>
	<p class="block_1054">When an organism dies, the hard parts of their bodies settle at the bottom of the sea bed and are covered by sediment. The process of sedimentation goes on continuously and fossils are formed.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Infiltration or Replacement</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The precipitation of minerals takes place which later on infiltrate the cell wall. The process is brought about by several mineral elements such as silica, calcium carbonate and magnesium carbonate. Hard parts are dissolved and replaced by these minerals</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Do you Know </p>
	<p class="block_1054">Living Fossils: These are living organisms that are similar in appearance to their fossilized distant ancestors and usually have no extinct close features. Example Ginkobiloba.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_604">19.5.2 Determination of age of Fossils</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The age of fossils is determined by radioactive elements present in it. They may be carbon, uranium, lead or potassium. It is used in palaeobotany and anthropology for determining the age of human fossils and manuscripts.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Radioactive carbon(C14) dating method</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><span class="calibre28">This method   was   discovered   by W.F. Libby (1956). Carbon consumption of animals and plants stops after death and since then, only the decaying process of C14 occurs continuously. The time passed since death of a plant or animal can be calculated by measuring the amount of C14. present in their body.</span></p>
	<p class="block_1054">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_63">What is the Geologic Time Scale?</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The geological time scale is a system of chronological dating that relates geological rock strata to time, and is used by geologists, palaeontologists, and other Earth scientists to describe the timing and relationships of events that have occurred during Earth’s history.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Do you Know </p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Thiruvakkarai fossil wood park (Villupuram district, Tamil Nadu):</b> </p>
	<p class="block_1054">2 million years ago tree trunks that got buried along the river, in course of time the organic matter was replaced by silica and was fossilized. They retained their color, shape and texture and was converted into solid rocks. The annular rings, the texture, colors of the layers, nodes and all properties of plants are still visible.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-311.png" alt="Image shows the fossil wood" class="calibre417"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_605">19.6 Ethnobotany</h2>
	<p class="block_9">Ethnobotany is the study of a region’s plants and their practical uses through the traditional knowledge of the local culture of people. The term Ethnobotany was coined by J.W. Hershberger in 1895 to include the study of plants used by the primitive and aboriginal people. Though this discipline has existed for ages, ethnobotany emerged as a distinct academic branch of natural science in 20th century.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Aspects of ethnobotany</p>
	<p class="block_9">Ethnobotany has relevance with problems of nutrition, health care and life support system, faith in plants, cottage industries, economic upliftment, conservation of biodiversity and sustainable use of plant resources.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Importance of Ethnobotany</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_66">It provides traditional uses of plant.</li>
	<li class="block_66">It gives information about certain unknown and known useful plants.</li>
	<li class="block_66">The ethnos medicinal data will serve as a useful source of information for the chemists, pharmacologists and practitioners of herbal medicine.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Tribal communities utilize ethnos medicinal plant parts like bark, stem, roots, leaves, flower bud, flowers, fruits, seeds, oils, resins, dyes, gum for the treatment of diseases like diarrhoea, fever, headache, diabetes, jaundice, snakebites, leprosy, etcetera.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_606">19.7 Astrobiology or Exobiology </h2>
	<p class="block_">Are we alone in the universe? If your answer is no, then how do you detect the existence of life in space? Astrobiology or exobiology is the science which looks for the presence of extra-terrestrial life in the universe.</p>
	<p class="block_">Astrobiology deals with the origin, evolution and distribution of life in the universe and to investigate the possibility of life in another world.</p>
	<p class="block_">The major concept in astrobiology is the habitable zone. The theory explains that any planets can support the existence of life, if it fulfils two important criteria.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">It must have a right mass to retain an atmosphere.</li>
	<li class="block_8">It must have an orbit at just the right distance from its star (Sun) that it allows liquid water to exist. Thus, the distance needs to be neither too hot or not too cold and is often referred as Goldilocks Zone for life.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">In our solar system ‘Earth’ is the only planet in the goldilocks zone. Since, this zone varies at times as the star evolves, we know that Mars have also been habitable. The life on Mars is likely to be the creatures, we find in extreme environments on earth.</p>
	<p class="block_">The organisms which live in extreme environmental conditions on earth are called extremophiles. Thus, within our own Solar System, there are many areas that are different from the Earth where it is probable to find the presence of life similar to extremophile bacteria.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-312.png" alt="Image displays Microbial diversity from sandstone from the McMurdo Dry Valleys, Antarctica" class="calibre418"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-313.png" alt="Image displays Microbial diversity from  granite from the McMurdo Dry Valleys, Antarctica" class="calibre419"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 19.5 Microbial diversity from sandstone and granite from the McMurdo Dry Valleys, Antarctica</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do you Know </p>
	<p class="block_">NASA is developing the Mars 2020 astrobiology to investigate an Astro biologically relevant ancient environment on Mars, its surface geological processes and the possibility of past life on Mars and preservation of biosignatures within accessible geological materials.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_607">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Lamarck proposed that the acquired characters are passed on to the off springs in the next generation</li>
	<li class="block_7">Internal vital force, environment and new needs, use and disuse theory and inheritance of acquired characters are the main principles of Lamarckism. </li>
	<li class="block_7">Overproduction, struggle for existence, variations, survival of the fittest or Natural selection and origin of species are the main postulates of Darwinism.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Each species tends to produce large number of off springs, but only the fittest can survive.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Homologous, analogous organs and embryological evidences explain evolutionary relationships.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Some traits in organisms would be similar because they are inherited from a common ancestor.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Fossils are evidences of ancient life forms or ancient habitats which have been preserved by natural processes.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Ethnobotanical importance of various types of plants are known through traditional knowledge.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Astrobiology or exobiology is the science which looks for the presence of extra-terrestrial life in the universe</li>
</ul>

	<ol class="list_">

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_612">4 Match the following</h3>
	<p class="block_">Column A <span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span>Column B</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_13">a) Atavism <span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span>caudal vertebrae and vermiform appendix</div>
	<div class="block_13">b) Vestigial organs<span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span>a forelimb of a cat and a organs bat’s wing</div>
	<div class="block_13">c) Analogous organs<span class="tab">      </span>rudimentary tail and organs thick hair on the body</div>
	<div class="block_13">d) Homologous organs<span class="tab">      </span>a wing of a bat and organs a wing of an insect</div>
	<div class="block_13">e) Wood park <span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span>radiocarbon dating</div>
	<div class="block_14">f) W.F. Libby <span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span>Thiruvakkarai</div>
</div>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_613">5 Answer in a word or sentence</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">A human hand, a front leg of a cat, a front flipper of a whale and a bat’s wing look dissimilar and adapted for different functions. What is the name given to these organs?</li>
	<li class="block_7">Which organism is considered to be the fossil bird?</li>
	<li class="block_8">What is the study of fossils called?</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_614">6 Short answers questions</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">The degenerated wing of a kiwi is an acquired character. Why is it an acquired character?</li>
	<li class="block_7">Why is Archaeopteryx considered to be a connecting link?</li>
	<li class="block_7">Define Ethnobotany and write its importance.</li>
	<li class="block_8">How can you determine the age of the fossils?</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_615">7 Long answer questions</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Natural selection is a driving force for evolution-How?</li>
	<li class="block_7">How do you differentiate homologous organs from analogous organs?</li>
	<li class="block_8">How does fossilization occur in plants?</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_616">8 Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Arun was playing in the garden. Suddenly he saw a dragon fly sitting on a plant. He observed the wings of it. He thought it looked similar to a wing of a crow. Is he correct? Give reason for your answer.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Imprints of fossils tell us about evolution- How?</li>
	<li class="block_8">Octopus, cockroach and frog all have eyes. Can we group these animals together to establish a common evolutionary origin. Justify your answer.</li>
</ol>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_617">UNIT-20 <b class="calibre6">BREEDING AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</b></h1>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-318.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of 6 W 8 V N" class="calibre424"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_618">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Define and discuss the steps and methods involved in plant breeding.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Know the crop varieties produced by crop improvement.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Understand animal breeding and its implications.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Point out the differences between inbreeding and outbreeding.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Know what is hybrid vigour and its importance.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Identify the steps involved in genetic engineering.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Understand the practical applications of DNA fingerprinting.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Gain knowledge on gene therapy.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Know the importance of stem cell technology.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_619">Introduction</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">India’s population is likely to reach 1.7 billion by 2050. Current rate of India’s food production will be able to meet only 59% of the country’s food demand at that time. How can India feed 1.7 billion people by 2050? This can be made possible by ‘Plant breeding’ and ‘Animal husbandry’.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Plant breeding is the art of developing economically important plants with superior quality.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Animal husbandry involves the breeding of animals. It aims at improving the genotypes of animals to make them more useful to the welfare of mankind. This emphasizes domestication and propagation of animals, under controlled conditions to enhance food production and food quality.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Another breakthrough was the emergence of biotechnology as an entity of modern biology, which paved way to develop advanced healthcare products, diagnostic kits and food production to improve the quality of human life.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_620">20.1 Modern Agricultural Practices and Crop Improvement</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Modern agricultural practices are activities carried out to improve cultivation of plants. It includes preparation of soil, sowing, application of manures and fertilizers, proper irrigation, protection from weeds and pests harvesting, threshing and storage.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The aim of crop improvement is to develop improved crop varieties possessing higher yield, better quality, resistance to diseases and shorter duration.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_621">20.2 Green Revolution</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Green Revolution is the process of increasing food production through high yielding crop varieties and modern agricultural techniques in underdeveloped and developing nations. <b class="calibre6">Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, </b>an American agronomist the <b class="calibre6">“Father of the Green Revolution”,</b> received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1970. In India <b class="calibre6">Dr. M. S. Swaminathan</b> joined with <b class="calibre6">Dr.Borlaug</b> in bringing Green Revolution by introducing Mexican wheat varieties. This eventually increased wheat and rice production between 1960 and 2000.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_622">20.2.1Breeding for high yield and better quality</h3>
	<p class="block_">Major challenge that India faced during post-independence period was having enough food production for the growing population. Efforts were taken to develop high yielding varieties of crops, leading to Green Revolution.</p>
	<p class="block_">Semi-Dwarf varieties in Wheat and Rice </p>
	<p class="block_">Sonalika, Kalyan Sona are semi-dwarf varieties of wheat developed from high yielding, semi-dwarf, fertilizer responsive wheat varieties from Mexico. IR-8 (Miracle rice) is a high-yielding semi-dwarf rice variety developed by International Rice Research Institute (IRRI), Philippines. In 1966, this was first introduced in Philippines and India. It was a hybrid of a high yielding rice variety Peta from Indonesia, and Dee-geo-woo-gen (DGWG) a dwarf variety from China.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-319.png" alt="Image shows the picture of IR-8" class="calibre425"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Figure 20.1 IR 8</p>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know </p>
	<p class="block_12">Dr. M. S. Swaminathan</p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-320.png" alt="Image of M.S. Swaminathan" class="calibre426"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Dr. Mankombu Sambasivan Swaminathan is an Indian scientist known for his leading role in India’s Green Revolution. His research on potato, wheat, rice and jute are well known plant breeding experiments. Due to his efforts the wheat production increased from twelve million tonnes in 1960's to seventy million tonnes now. He is aptly called as the “Father of Indian Green Revolution”.</p>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know </p>
	<p class="block_12">Dr. G. Nammalvar</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-321.png" alt="Image of Dr. G. Nammalvar" class="calibre427"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Dr. G. Nammalvar (1938-2013) was a Tamil agricultural scientist, environmental activist and organic farming expert. He founded Nammalvar Ecological Foundation for Farm Research and Global Food Security Trust (N E F R G F S T - Vanagam) to create public awareness about the benefits of organic farming.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_623">20.2.2Plant Breeding for Disease Resistance</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Plant diseases are caused by pathogens like viruses, bacteria and fungi. This affects crop yield. Hence, it is important to develop disease resistant varieties of crops, that would increase the yield and reduce the use of fungicides and bactericides. Some disease resistant varieties developed by plant breeding are given below:</p>

	<p class="block_1054">In addition to microorganisms, a large number of insects and pests also cause damage to the crops. Hence, insect and pest resistant crop varieties were developed. Some of them are given below:</p>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_625">20.2.4Plant Breeding for Improved Nutritional Quality</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Undernutrition and protein malnutrition among human population is a major health problem which has been receiving much focus throughout the world. Apart from humans, it also affects the health of farm animals. To combat these conditions, human and animal health are to be determined by the nutritional quality of the feed crops. The nutritional quality of crops depends on quality and quantity of nutrients. The nutritional quality may be improved with respect to its</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Protein content and quality of protein</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Oil content</li>
	<li class="block_65">Mineral content</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Biofortification</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Biofortification is the scientific process of developing crop plants enriched with high levels of desirable nutrients like vitamins, proteins and minerals. Some examples of crop varieties developed as a result of biofortification are given below:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1150">Protina, Shakti and Rātana are lysine rich maize hybrids (developed in India).</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image813.jpeg" alt="Atlas 66-protein rich Wheat" class="calibre428"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">Figure 20.2 Protina–lysine rich Maize</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="2" class="block_1150">Atlas 66, a protein rich wheat variety.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image814.jpeg" alt="Atlas 66-protein rich Wheat" class="calibre429"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Figure 20.3</b> Atlas 66-protein rich Wheat</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="3" class="block_64">Iron rich fortified rice variety.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Vitamin A enriched carrots, pumpkin and spinach.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_626">20.3 Methods of Plant Breeding for Crop Improvement</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Methods of plant breeding to develop high yielding varieties are given below:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Introduction of new varieties of plants</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Selection</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Polyploidy breeding</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Mutation breeding</li>
	<li class="block_65">Hybridization</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_627">20.3.1Introduction of New Varieties of Plants</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">It is a process of introducing high yielding varieties of plants from one place to another. Such plants are called as exotic species. These imported plant materials may carry pathogens and pests; hence they are thoroughly tested in a plant quarantine before being introduced to the fields. <b class="calibre6">Example ,</b> Phaseolus mungo was introduced from China.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_628">20.3.2Selection</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Selection is one of the oldest methods of plant breeding in which individual plants or groups of plants are sorted out from a mixed population based on the morphological characters.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Methods of selection</p>
	<p class="block_1054">There are three methods of selection. They are</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Mass selection</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Pure line selection</li>
	<li class="block_65">Clonal selection</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">1. </p>
	<p class="block_63">Mass selection</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Seeds of best plants showing desired characters are collected from a mixed population. The collected seeds are allowed to raise the second generation. This process is carried out for seven or eight generations. At the end, they will be multiplied and distributed to the farmers for cultivation.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Some common examples for mass selection are groundnut varieties like TMV–2 and AK–10. Its schematic representation is given below.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image815.jpeg" alt="Mass Selection" class="calibre430"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Figure 20.5</b>Mass Selection</p>
	<p class="block_63">2</p>
	<p class="block_63">Pureline selection</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Pure line is “the progeny of a single individual obtained by self-breeding”. This is also called as individual plant selection. In pure line selection large numbers of plants are selected from a self-pollinated crop and harvested individually.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Individual plant progenies from them are evaluated separately. The best one is released as a pure line variety. Progeny is similar both genotypically and phenotypically.</p>
	<p class="block_63">3</p>
	<p class="block_63">Clonal selection</p>
	<p class="block_1054">A group of plants produced from a single plant through vegetative or asexual reproduction are called clones.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">All the plants of a clone are similar both in genotype and phenotype. Selection of desirable clones from the mixed population of vegetative propagated crop is called clonal selection.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_629">20.3.3Polyploidy Breeding</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Sexually reproducing organisms have two complete set of chromosomes in their somatic cells. This is called diploid (2n). The gametic cells have only one set of chromosomes. This is called haploid (n). An organism having more than two sets of chromosomes is called <b class="calibre6">polyploid</b> </p>
	<p class="block_1054">(In Greek: Polys = many + aploos = one-fold + eidos = form). Such condition is called <b class="calibre6">Polyploidy</b>. It can be induced by <b class="calibre6">physical</b> agents such as heat or cold treatment, X-rays and chemical agents like colchicine.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Achievements of polyploidy breeding</p>
	<p class="block_">Some achievements of polyploidy breeding are</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_13">a) Seedless watermelons (3n) and bananas (3n).</div>
	<div class="block_13">b) TV-29 (triploid variety of tea) with larger shoots and drought tolerance.</div>
	<div class="block_13">c) Triticale (6n) is a hybrid of wheat and rye. To make this plant fertile polyploidy is induced. It has higher dietary fibre and protein.</div>
	<div class="block_14">d) Raphine brassica is an allotetraploid by colchicine treatment.</div>
</div>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_630">20.3.4Mutation Breeding</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Mutation is defined as the sudden heritable change in the nucleotide sequence of DNA in an organism. It is a process by which genetic variations are created which in turn brings about changes in the organism. The organism which undergoes mutation is called a mutant.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The factors which induce mutations are known as mutagens or mutagenic agents. Mutagens are of two types namely physical mutagens and chemical mutagens.</p>
	<p class="block_63">More to know</p>
	<p class="block_63">Gamma Garden</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Gamma garden or atomic garden is a concept popularised after World War II for the peaceful use of atomic energy for crop improvement. This is a type of induced mutation breeding where radioactive sources particularly gamma rays from Cobalt-60 or Caesium-137 are used to induce desirable mutations in crop plants.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-322.png" alt="Image displays picture of Gamma Garden" class="calibre431"/></p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li class="block_64"><b class="calibre6">Physical mutagens</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1180">Radiations like X-rays, α, β and γ-rays, UV rays, temperature etcetera. which induce mutations are called physical mutagens</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li value="2" class="block_1055"><b class="calibre6">Chemical mutagens</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1180">Chemical substances that induce mutations are called chemical mutagens. </p>
	<p class="block_1180">Example  Mustard gas and nitrous acid. The utilisation of induced mutation in crop improvement is called mutation breeding.</p>
	<p class="block_1201">Achievements of mutation breeding</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Some achievements of mutation breeding are</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_1169"><b class="calibre6">Sharbati Sonora</b> wheat produced from Sonora-64 by using gamma rays.</li>
	<li class="block_1169"><b class="calibre6">Atomita</b> 2 rice with saline tolerance and pest resistance</li>
	<li class="block_1170"><b class="calibre6">Groundnuts</b> with thick shells</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_631">20.3.5Hybridization</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Hybridization may be defined as the process of crossing two or more types of plants for bringing their desired characters together into one progeny called hybrid. Hybrid is superior in one or more characters to both parents. Hybridization is the common method of creating genetic variation to get improved varieties.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Hybridization Experiment: Triticale (The first man – made cereal)</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Triticale is the first man- made cereal hybrid. It is obtained by crossing wheat (Triticum durum, 2n = 28) and rye (Secale cereal, 2n = 14). The F1 hybrid is sterile (2n = 21). Then the chromosome number is doubled using colchicine and it becomes a hexaploidy Triticale (2n = 42).</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The cycle of crop raising and selection continues till the plants with the desired characters are finally obtained. The development of new varieties is a long-drawn process. Two main aspects of hybridization are to combine the characters of two plants in one plant and to utilize hybrid vigour.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_632">20.4 Animal Breeding</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">A breed is a group of animals of common origin within a species that has certain distinguishing characters that are not found in other members of the same species like general appearance and others striking features.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Breeding involves mating parents of different varieties each having some desired trait which are passed onto the offspring.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Objectives of Animal Breeding</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Animal breeding aims at improving the genotypes of domesticated animals to increase their yield and improve the desirable qualities to produce milk, egg and meat.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">When breeding takes place between animals of the same breed, it is called inbreeding. The cross between different breeds is called outbreeding.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_633">20.4.1Inbreeding</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Inbreeding refers to the <b class="calibre6">mating of closely related animals within the same breed</b> for about 4-6 generations. Superior males and superior females of the same breed are identified and mated in pairs. It helps in the accumulation of superior genes and elimination of genes which are undesirable.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Hessdalen is a new breed of sheep developed in Punjab by crossing Bikaneri (Magra) ewes and Australian Marino rams.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Inbreeding depression:</b> Continued inbreeding reduces fertility and productivity. Inbreeding exposes harmful recessive genes that are eliminated by selection.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_634">20.4.2Outbreeding</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">It is the breeding of unrelated animals. The off springs formed are called hybrids. The hybrids are stronger and vigorous than their parents. Cross between two different species with desirable features of economic value are mated. Let’s see what cross produce a mule.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Cross Breeding</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Male Donkey Female Donkey</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Gives</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Mule</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-323.png" alt="This picture shows the Cross Breeding Concept of Mule. Where you can See Male Donkey is cross breed with Female Horse to get Mule." class="calibre432"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Mule is superior to horse in strength, intelligence, ability to work and resistance to diseases but they are sterile.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image817.jpeg" alt="Cross breeding to produce Mule with superior characters" class="calibre433"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Figure 20.6</b> Cross breeding to produce Mule with superior characters</p>
	<p class="block_63">Info Bits </p>
	<p class="block_63">Cross breed of fowls:</p>
	<p class="block_1054">White Leghorn and Plymouth Rock</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Gives</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Hybrid fowl - yield more eggs</p>
	<p class="block_63">Cross breed of cows:</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Developed by mating the bulls of exotic breeds and cows of indigenous breeds.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Brown Swiss and Sahiwal</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Gives</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Karan Swiss - yield 2-3 times more milk than indigenous cows.<span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_635">20.4.3 Heterosis</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">The superiority of the hybrid obtained by cross breeding is called as heterosis or hybrid vigour.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Effects of hybrid vigour in animal breeding</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Increased production of milk by cattle</p>
	<p class="block_1180">Increased production of egg by poultry</p>
	<p class="block_1180">High quality of meat is produced</p>
	<p class="block_1197">Increased growth rate in domesticated animals</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_636">20.5 Genetic Engineering</h2>
	<p class="block_63"> <img src="images/image-324.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of BHFLX" class="calibre434"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Genetic engineering is the manipulation and transfer of genes from one organism to other organisms to create a new DNA called as recombinant DNA (r DNA). The term recombinant is used because DNA from two different sources can be joined together. Hence, genetic engineering is also called as recombinant DNA technology.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Do you Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Plasmid is the small circular double stranded DNA molecule found in the cytoplasm of bacterial cell and separated from chromosomal DNA. It can replicate independently.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-325.png" alt="Image displays the picture of Plasmid" class="calibre435"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">More to Know </p>
	<p class="block_1054">Restriction enzymes recognises a specific base pair sequence (palindromic sequence) in DNA called as restriction site and cleaves the phosphodiester bond within DNA.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-326.png" alt="Image displays picture of " class="calibre436"/></p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_637">20.5.1 Techniques of Genetic Engineering – Basic Requirements</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Important discoveries that led to the stepping stone of r DNA technology were</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_1202">a) Presence of plasmid in bacteria that can undergo replication independently along with chromosomal DNA.</div>
	<div class="block_1202">b) Restriction enzymes cuts or break DNA at specific sites and are also called as molecular scissors.</div>
	<div class="block_1203">c) DNA ligases are the enzymes which help in ligating (joining) the broken DNA fragments.</div>
</div>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_638">20.5.2 Gene Cloning</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">What reminds to your mind when you hear the word clone? Of course, ‘DOLLY’ the cloned sheep. The carbon copy of an individual is often called a clone. However, more appropriately, a clone means to make a genetically exact copy of an organism.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In gene cloning, a gene or a piece of DNA fragment is inserted into a bacterial cell where DNA will be multiplied (copied) as the cell divides. A brief outline of the basic steps involved in gene cloning are:</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li class="block_64">Isolation of desired DNA fragment by using restriction enzymes</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Insertion of the DNA fragment into a suitable vector (Plasmid) to make rDNA</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Transfer of rDNA into bacterial host cell (Transformation)</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Selection and multiplication of recombinant host cell to get a clone</li>
	<li class="block_65">Expression of cloned gene in host cell.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1054">Using this strategy several enzymes, hormones and vaccines can be produced</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-327.png" alt="Genetic engineering technique (Gene cloning)" class="calibre437"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Figure 20.7</b> Genetic engineering technique (Gene cloning)</p>
	<p class="block_63">Info Bits </p>
	<p class="block_63">Development of Dolly</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Dolly was the first cloned female sheep, developed by Dr. Ian Wilmut and his colleagues at the Roslin Institute Scotland in July 1996. She was created by somatic cell nuclear transfer technique. She lived for 6.5 years and died in 2003 because of lung disease.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-328.png" alt="This picture shows the Development of Dolly" class="calibre438"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_639">20.6 Biotechnology in Medicine</h2>
	<p class="block_">Using genetic engineering techniques medicinally important valuable proteins or polypeptides that form the potential pharmaceutical products for treatment of various diseases have been developed on a commercial scale.</p>
	<p class="block_1204">Pharmaceutical products developed by rDNA technique</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_13">a) Insulin used in the treatment of diabetes.</div>
	<div class="block_13">b) Human growth hormone used for treating children with growth deficiencies.</div>
	<div class="block_13">c) Blood clotting factors are developed to treat haemophilia.</div>
	<div class="block_13">d) Tissue plasminogen activator is used to dissolve blood clots and prevent heart attack.</div>
	<div class="block_14">e) Development of vaccines against various diseases like Hepatitis B and rabies</div>
</div>
	<p class="block_">Do you Know</p>
	<p class="block_">Eli Lilly and Company, United States, in 1979 first started commercial production of human insulin by using rDNA technology.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Gene Therapy</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Gene therapy refers to the replacement of defective gene by the direct transfer of functional genes into humans to treat genetic disease or disorder. The genetic makeup of the ‘patient’ cell is altered using recombinant DNA technology. It was first successfully implemented in 1990.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Somatic genetherapy</b> is the replacement of defective gene in somatic cells.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Germ line genetherapy</b> replacement of defective gene in germ cell (egg and sperm).</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Gene therapy conducted till date has targeted only somatic (non-reproductive) cells. Correction of genetic defects in somatic cells may be beneficial to the patient but the corrected gene may not be carried to the next generation.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_640">20.7 Stem Cells</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Our body is composed of over 200 specialised cell types, that can carry out specific functions. Example  neurons or nerve cell that can transmit signals, or heart cells which contract to pump blood or pancreatic cells to secrete insulin. These specialised cells are called as differentiated cells.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In contrast to differentiated cells, stem cells are undifferentiated or unspecialised mass of cells. The stem cells are the cells of variable potency. Potency refers to the number of possible fates that a cell can acquire. The two important properties of stem cells that differentiate them from other cells are:</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li class="block_64">its ability to divide and give rise to more stem cells by self-renewal</li>
	<li class="block_65">its ability to give rise to specialised cells with specific functions by the process of differentiation.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_63">Types of stem cells</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Embryonic stem cells can be extracted and cultured from the early embryos. These cells are derived from the inner cell mass of blastocyst. These cells can be developed into any cell in the body.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Adult stem cell or somatic stem cell are found in the neonatal (new born) and adults. They have the ability to divide and give rise to specific cell types. Sources of adult stem cells are amniotic fluid, umbilical cord and bone marrow.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><span class="calibre28">   </span><img src="images/image-329.png" alt="This picture shows the Differentiation of stem cells " class="calibre439"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Figure 20.8</b> Differentiation of stem cells</p>
	<p class="block_63">Stem-cell therapy</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Sometimes cells, tissues and organs in the body may be permanently damaged or lost due to genetic condition or disease or injury. In such situations stem cells are used for the treatment of diseases which is called stem-cell therapy. In treating neurodegenerative disorders like Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease neuronal stem cells can be used to replace the damaged or lost neurons.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_641">20.8 DNA Fingerprinting Technology</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">The human genome has 3 billion base pairs. Did you know that the DNA pattern of two individuals cannot be same except for identical twins. Each person’s DNA sequence is unique due to the small difference in the base pairs. Therefore, if we want to compare the genetic difference among the two individuals, DNA fingerprinting is the easier and quicker method. This technique was developed by Alec Jeffrey.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The technique analyses each individual’s unique DNA sequences and provides distinctive characteristics of individual which helps in identification. Variable number of tandem repeat sequences (VNTR s) serve as molecular markers for identification.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">In human beings, 99 % of the DNA base sequences are the same and this is called as bulk genomic DNA. The remaining 1 % DNA sequence differs from one individual to another. This 1 % DNA sequence is present as small stretch of repeated sequences which is known as satellite DNA. The number of copies of the repeat sequence also called as VNTR s differs from one individual to another, and results in variation in the size of the DNA segment.</p>
	<p class="block_63"><img src="images/image-330.png" alt="This image shows the VNTRs illustration of three persons" class="calibre440"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">VNTRs illustration of three persons</p>
	<p class="block_1054">As shown in the illustration, the sequence AGCT is repeated six times in first person, five times in second person and seven times in third person. Because of this, DNA segment of third person will be larger in size followed by DNA segment of first person and then the second person. Thus, it is clear that satellite DNA bring about variation within the population. Variation in DNA banding pattern reveals differences among the individuals.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Applications of DNA Fingerprinting</p>
	<ol class="list_3">
	<li class="block_64">DNA fingerprinting technique is widely used in forensic applications like crime investigation such as identifying the culprit. It is also used for paternity testing in case of disputes.</li>
	<li class="block_65">It also helps in the study of genetic diversity of population, evolution and speciation.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_642">20.9 Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs)</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">One of the most tremendous developments of genetic engineering is the production of genetically modified (GM) plants and animals. Genetic modification refers to the alteration or manipulation of genes in the organisms using rDNA techniques in order to produce the desired characteristics. The DNA fragment inserted is called transgene. Plants or animals expressing a modified endogenous gene or a foreign gene are also known as transgenic organisms.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The transgenic plants are much stable, with improved nutritional quality, resistant to diseases and tolerant to various environment conditions. Similarly, transgenic animals are used to produce proteins of medicinal importance at low cost and improve livestock quality.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Some examples of genetically modified plants and animals are given in the table below.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Genetically Modified Plants</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_643">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Crop improvement is the development of improved crop varieties possessing higher yield, better quality, resistance to diseases and shorter duration.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">When breeding takes place between animals of the same breed, it is called inbreeding. The cross between different breeds is called outbreeding.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">The superiority of the hybrid obtained by cross breeding is called as heterosis or hybrid vigour.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">genetic engineering is the manipulation and transfer of genes from one organism to another organism.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Stem cells are undifferentiated or unspecialised mass of cells and can be used for the treatment known as stem cell therapy.</li>
</ul>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_649">5 Understand the assertion statement, justify the reason given and choose the correct choice</h3>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_1202">a) Assertion is correct and reason is wrong</div>
	<div class="block_1202">b) Reason is correct and the assertion is wrong</div>
	<div class="block_1202">c) Both assertion and reason are correct</div>
	<div class="block_1202">d) Both assertion and reason are wrong.</div>
</div>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_1177">Assertion: Hybrid is superior than either of its parents.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1178"><b class="calibre6">Reason:</b> Hybrid vigour is lost upon inbreeding.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="2" class="block_1177">Assertion: Colchicine<span class="tab">      </span>reduces the chromosome number.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1178"><b class="calibre6">Reason:</b> It promotes the movement of sister chromatids to the opposite poles.</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="3" class="block_1177">Assertion: rDNA is superior over hybridisation techniques.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1206">Reason: Desired genes are inserted without introducing the undesirable genes in target organisms.</p>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_651">7 Short answers questions</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">Discuss the method of breeding for disease resistance.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Name three improved characteristics of wheat that helped India to achieve high productivity.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Name two maize hybrids rich in amino acid lysine</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Distinguish between</li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_1169">somatic gene therapy and germ line gene therapy</li>
	<li class="block_1169">undifferentiated cells and differentiated cells</li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="5" class="block_1055">State the applications of DNA fingerprinting technique.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">How are stem cells useful in regenerative process?</li>
	<li class="block_65">Differentiate between outbreeding and inbreeding.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_652">8 Long answers questions</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">What are the effects of hybrid vigour in animals.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Describe mutation breeding with an example.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Biofortification may help in removing hidden hunger. How?</li>
	<li class="block_1055">With a neat labelled diagram explain the techniques involved in gene cloning.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Discuss the importance of biotechnology in the field of medicine.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_653">9 Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_64">A breeder wishes to incorporate desirable characters into the crop plants. Prepare a list of characters he will incorporate</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Organic farming is better than Green Revolution. Give reasons</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Polyploids are characterised by gigantism. Justify your answer.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">‘P’ is a gene required for the synthesis of vitamin A. It is integrated with genome of ‘Q’ to produce genetically modified plant ‘R’.</li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_1169">What is P, Q and R?</li>
	<li class="block_1170">State the importance of ‘R’ in India.</li>
</ol>
