	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_720">22.4 Soil Erosion</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">The top layers of soil contain humus and mineral salts, which are vital for the growth of plants. Removal of upper layer of soil by wind and water is called soil erosion. Soil erosion causes a significant loss of humus, nutrients and decrease the fertility of soil.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_721">22.4.1Agents of Soil Erosion</h3>
	<p class="block_">Agents of soil erosion are high velocity of wind, air currents, flowing water, landslide, human activities (deforestation, farming and mining) and overgrazing by cattle.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_722">22.4.2Management of Soil Erosion</h3>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Retain vegetation cover, so that soil is not exposed.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Cattle grazing should be controlled.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Crop rotation and soil management improve soil organic matter.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Runoff water should be stored in the catchment.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Reforestation, terracing and<span class="tab">      </span>contour ploughing.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Wind speed can be controlled by planting trees in form of a shelter belt.</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_723">22.5 Renewable and Non-Renewable Energy Resources</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Energy is an important input for development. The expansion of possible energy resources has been directly related with the pace of agricultural and industrial development in every part of the world. Energy resources can be classified as non-renewable and renewable.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Non-renewable (Exhaustible) energy resources</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Energy obtained from sources that cannot renew themselves over a short period of time is known as non-renewable energy. These are available in limited amount in nature. They include coal, petroleum, natural gas and nuclear power. These conventional energy resources account for 90% of the world’s production of commercial energy and nuclear power account for 10%.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Renewable (Inexhaustible) energy resources</p>
	<p class="block_1054">These energy resources are available in unlimited amount in nature and they can be renewed over a short period of time, inexpensive and can be harvested continuously. These comprise the vast potential of non- conventional energy resources which include biofuel, biomass energy, geothermal energy, water energy (hydroelectric energy and tidal energy), solar energy, wave energy and wind energy.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_724">22.5.1Fossil Fuels</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Fossil fuels are found inside the earth’s crust and are energy rich substances formed by natural process, such as anaerobic decomposition of buried dead organisms, over millions of years. As the accumulating sediment layers produce heat and pressure, the remains of the organisms are gradually transformed into hydrocarbons. Example petroleum, coal and natural gas.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_725">22.5.2Coal and Petroleum</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Coal and Petroleum are natural resources. They are called fossil fuels as they are formed from the degradation of biomass buried deep under the earth millions of years ago.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Do You Know</p>
	<p class="block_1054">India is the third largest consumer of crude oil in the world, after the United States and China.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Coal is used for generation of electricity at Thermal power plants. Petroleum also known as crude oil is processed in oil refineries to produce petrol and diesel which are used to run automobiles, trucks, trains, ships and airplanes etcetera. Kerosene and LPG (Liquefied Petroleum Gas) obtained from petroleum is used as domestic fuel for cooking food.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The coal and petroleum reserves can get exhausted if we continue using them at a rapid rate. The formation of these fossil fuels is a very slow process and takes very long period of time for renewal.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_726">22.5.3Steps to Conserve Coal and Petroleum Resources</h3>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">It is necessary to conserve or save coal and petroleum resources for the future use, which can be done by reducing their consumption.</p>
	<p class="block_154"> </p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_66">If electricity is saved, it will in turn reduce the use of coal</li>
	<li class="block_66">Using bicycle for covering short distances instead of using cars, scooters or motorcycles</li>
	<li class="block_66">Using pressure cooker can reduce the consumption of kerosene and LPG while cooking food. Solar cooker and solar heaters can be used wherever possible</li>
	<li class="block_66">Motor vehicles should be designed with fuel efficient engines to increase efficiency and also reduce air pollution</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">Case study of Taj Mahal</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_1001">The Taj Mahal is one of the seven wonders of the world and is located in Agra, Uttar Pradesh. It is built with white marble. The Mathura oil refinery owned by Indian Oil Corporation present around this area produce sulphur and nitrogen oxides. The white marble became yellow due to air pollution. The Government of India has set up emission standards around the monument to protect it from the damage.</p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_727">22.6 Non-Conventional (Alternative) Energy Resources</h2>
	<p class="block_">The energy crisis has shown that for sustainable development in energy sector we must conserve the non-renewable conventional resources from its rapid depletion and replace them by non-polluting, renewable sources which are environmentally clean.</p>
	<p class="block_">Efforts are made to develop new sources of energy which is called non-conventional sources of energy. It would provide greater initiative to local people who could assess their needs and resources and plan a strategy that could be useful to them.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_728">22.6.1Solar Energy</h3>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-346.png" alt="A QR code is given with a code of XR9NB" class="calibre456"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Solar energy is the energy obtained from the sun. The sun gives out vast amount of light and heat. It is only a little less than half (47 %) of solar energy which falls on the atmosphere reaches the earth’s surface. If we could use just a small part of this energy it would fulfil all the country’s need for power. Solar energy has advantages and also certain limitations.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solar Energy Devices</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The energy from the sun can be harnessed to provide power. The various devices used for harnessing sun’s energy are called solar energy devices.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Solar Cells</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Solar cells (Photovoltaic devices) are made up of silicon that converts sunlight directly into electricity. Solar cell produces electricity without polluting the environment. Since it uses no fuel other than sunlight, no harmful gases, no burning and no wastes are produced. These can be installed in remote and inaccessible areas (forests and hilly regions) where setting up of power plant is expensive.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Uses of Solar cells</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">It can be used for street lighting, traffic signals, water pumping, battery charging system etc.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is used in artificial satellites and space probes</li>
	<li class="block_7">It provides radio and TV transmission to remote areas</li>
	<li class="block_8">It is used in calculators, electronic toys and watches.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Solar Panel</p>
	<p class="block_">Arrangement of many solar cells side by side connected to each other is called solar panel. The capacity to provide electric current is much increased in the solar panel. But the process of manufacture is very expensive<b class="calibre6">.</b></p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-347.png" alt="Figure 22.1 Solar Panel  Arrangement of many solar cells side by side connected to each other is called solar panel. The capacity to provide electric cuurent is much increased in the solar panel. " class="calibre457"/><b class="calibre6"> </b></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 22.1 Solar Panel</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solar Cooker</p>
	<p class="block_">It consists of an insulated metal box or wooden box which is painted from inside so as to absorb maximum solar radiations. A thick glass sheet forms the cover over the box. The reflector is the plane mirror which is attached to the box. The food is cooked by energy radiated by the sun.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-348.png" alt="Solar cook The food is cooked by energy radiated by the sun." class="calibre458"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Solar Cooker</p>
	<p class="block_12">Solar thermal power plant</p>
	<p class="block_">In solar thermal power plants, many solar panels are used to concentrate sun rays, to heat up water into steam. The steam is used to run the turbines to produce electricity.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know</p>
	<p class="block_">A capacity of 100 litres solar heater can save up to 1500 units of electricity per year.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Advantages of Solar Energy</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">It is available in abundance in our country and is free of cost.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is a renewable source of energy.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It can be used for generating electricity or heat.</li>
	<li class="block_8">It does not cause pollution.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_729">22.6.2Biogas</h3>
	<p class="block_1054">Biogas is the mixture of methane (nearly 75 %), hydrogen sulphide, carbon dioxide and hydrogen. It is produced by the decomposition of animal wastes (cow dung) and plant wastes in the absence of oxygen. It is also commonly called as ‘Gobar gas’ since the starting material used is cow dung which means gobar in Hindi.</p>
	<p class="block_19">Uses of biogas</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_66">It is used as fuel for cooking.</li>
	<li class="block_66">It is used to run motors and pump sets.</li>
	<li class="block_66">It is used to generate electricity.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_19">Advantages of biogas</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_66">It burns without smoke and therefore causes less pollution.</li>
	<li class="block_66">An excellent way to get rid of organic wastes like bio-waste and sewage material.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Left over slurry is a good manure rich in nitrogen and phosphorus</li>
	<li class="block_66">It is safe and convenient to use</li>
	<li class="block_66">It can reduce the amount of greenhouse gases emitted.</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_730">22.6.3Shale gas</h3>
	<p class="block_1001">Shale refers to the soft finely stratified sedimentary rock that is formed from the compaction of small old rocks containing mud and minerals – such as quartz and calcite, trapped beneath earth’s surface. These rocks contain fossil fuels like oil and gas in their pores.</p>
	<p class="block_1001">The fuel is extracted by a technique called hydraulic fracturing (drilling or well boring of sedimentary rocks layers to reach productive reservoir layers).</p>
	<p class="block_1002">Environmental concerns of shale gas</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1049">Shale drilling could affect groundwater reserves, which can contaminate the drinking water resources and also affect the fertility of the soil.</li>
	<li class="block_1049">Million gallons of water is needed to break and release the shale gas, which in turn can affect the water table.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1002">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_1001">India has identified six basins as areas for shale gas exploration: Cambay (Gujarat), Assam-Arakan (North East), Gondwana (Central India), Krishna Godavari onshore (East Coast), Cauvery onshore and Indo- Gangetic basins.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_731">22.6.4Wind Energy</h3>
	<p class="block_">The kinetic energy possessed by the wind is due to its high speed that can be converted into mechanical power by wind turbines. The rotatory motion of windmill produces wind energy.</p>
	<p class="block_">It can be used for </p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">generating electricity</li>
	<li class="block_7">Run water pumps, flour mills etc.</li>
	<li class="block_8">draw water from wells.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Do You Know</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">The world’s largest and tallest wind turbine is situated in Hawaii.</li>
	<li class="block_8"> One wind turbine can produce electricity for 300 homes.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_19">Windmill</p>
	<p class="block_1001">Windmill is a machine that converts the energy of wind into rotational energy by broad blade attached to the rotating axis. When the blowing air strikes the blades of the windmill, it exerts force and causes the blades to rotate. The rotational movement of the blades operate the generator and the electricity is produced. The energy output from each windmill is coupled together to get electricity on a commercial scale.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Advantages of Wind energy</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">Wind energy is free, eco-friendly, renewable source of energy.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It does not cause pollution.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Expenses on periodic maintenance is low when compared to the other power sources.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_1002"><img src="images/image-349.png" alt="Windmil When the blowing air strikes the blades of the windmill, it exerts force and causes the blades to rotate. The rotational movement of the blades operate the generator and the electricity is produced." class="calibre459"/></p>
	<p class="block_1002">Figure 22.2 Windmill</p>
	<p class="block_1087"> </p>
	<p class="block_12">Activity 1</p>
	<p class="block_">Collect information regarding the</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">Tehri Dam project</li>
	<li class="block_8">Sardar Sarovar Dam project</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_732">22.6.5Water Energy</h3>
	<p class="block_">Earth’s surface is covered with nearly 71 % of water. Harnessing the energy from the flowing water can be used to produce electricity. The technique to harness the water energy is called Hydropower.</p>
	<p class="block_">The electrical energy is derived from water flow, water falling from a height. Hilly areas are suitable for this purpose where there is continuous flow of water in large amounts falling from high slopes. It does not cause environmental pollution or waste generation.</p>
	<p class="block_">Hydropower plants converts the kinetic energy of flowing water into electricity. This is called hydroelectricity.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_733">22.6.6Tidal Energy</h3>
	<p class="block_">Tidal energy is the energy obtained from the movement of water due to ocean tides. Tides are the rise and fall of sea levels caused by the combined effects of the gravitational forces exerted on the oceans of the earth.</p>
	<p class="block_">A tidal stream is a fast-flowing body of water created by tides. Turbines are placed in tidal streams. When the tides hit the turbine, the turbine rotates and converts the tidal energy into electric energy</p>
	<p class="block_12">Advantages of tidal energy</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">Tidal energy does not produce any pollution.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It does not use any fuel and does not produce any waste.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Tides are predictable, so tidal energy can be produced at any time.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Water is denser than air and therefore can generate electricity at lower speeds than wind turbines.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_734">22.7 Rainwater Harvesting</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Rainwater harvesting is a technique of collecting and storing rainwater for future use. It is a traditional method of storing rain water in underground tanks, ponds, lakes, check dams and used in future.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The main purpose of rainwater harvesting is to make the rainwater percolate under the ground so as to recharge ‘groundwater level’.</p>
	<p class="block_63">Methods of rainwater harvesting</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_1150">Roof top rainwater harvesting: Roof- tops are excellent rain catchers. The rain water that falls on the roof of the houses, apartments, commercial buildings etc. is collected and stored in the surface tank and can be used for domestic purpose.</li>
	<li class="block_66">Recharge pit: In this method, the rainwater is first collected from the roof tops or open spaces and is directed into the percolation pits through pipes for filtration. After filtration the rainwater enters the recharge pits or ground wells.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9"><img src="images/image-350.png" alt="Figure 22.3 Rain water Harvesting (i) Roof top rainwater harvesting: Roof- tops are excellent rain catchers. (ii) Recharge pit: In this method, the rainwater is first collected from the roof tops or open spaces and is directed into the percolation pits through pipes for filtration. " class="calibre460"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 22.3 Rain water Harvesting</p>
	<p class="block_">People living in rural areas adopt a variety of water collecting methods to capture and store as rain water. Some of the methods used are</p>
	<p class="block_27"><b class="calibre6">Digging of tanks or lakes (Eris):</b> </p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">It is one of the traditional waters harvesting system in Tamil Nadu. Eris are constructed in such a way that if the water in one Eris overflows, it automatically gets diverted to the Eris of the next village, as these Eris are interconnected.</li>
	<li class="block_8"><b class="calibre6">Ooranis:</b> These are small ponds to collect rainwater. The water is used for various domestic purposes (drinking, washing and bathing). These ponds cater the nearby villages.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_">kallanai Dam, also known as Grand Anicut, is the fourth oldest dam in the world, constructed by King KarikalaChola of the Cholla Dynasty in the 2nd century A D(CE). It still serves the people of Tamilnadu, the dam is located on the River Kaveri, approximately 20 km from the city of Tiruchirappalli.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Advantages of rainwater harvesting</p>
	<p class="block_12">Rainwater harvesting helps to</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">Overcome the rapid depletion of ground water levels.</li>
	<li class="block_7">To meet the increase demand of water.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Reduces flood and soil erosion</li>
	<li class="block_8">Water stored in ground is not contaminated by human and animal wastes and hence can be used for drinking purpose.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_735">22.8 Electrical Energy Management</h2>
	<p class="block_">Electricity or electric power is produced by generators. The generators are operated by the turbines attached to it. The turbines are rotated by steam, moving water or wind power to produce electricity.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Conservation of electrical energy</p>
	<p class="block_">The following measures can be taken even at home and school to save electricity</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">Use energy efficient appliances to save electricity like Compact Fluorescent Lamps (CFL), Light Emitting Diode (LED) bulbs and other electric equipment.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Switch off the lights and fans, television and other electrical appliances when not in use.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Switch of the mobile phone chargers when not in use.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Maximise the use of solar radiation. Solar water heating system can be used instead of electric geysers.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Minimise the use of air conditioners.</li>
</ol>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_736">22.9 E-Wastes and its Management</h2>
	<p class="block_">E-wastes are generally called as electronic wastes, which includes the spoiled, outdated, non-repairable electrical and electronic devices. These wastes contain toxic metals like lead, cadmium, chromium and mercury, though also contain iron, copper, silicon, aluminium and gold which can be recovered. Nevertheless, only 5 % of e-wastes produced are recycled.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Sources of e-wastes</p>
	<p class="block_">Electronic devices: Computers, laptops, mobile phones, printers, monitors, televisions, DVD players, calculators, toys, sport equipment's, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Household electrical appliances: Refrigerators, washing machine, microwave oven, mixer, grinder, water heater, etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Accessories: Printing cartridges, batteries and chargers.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9">Do you Know </p>
	<p class="block_9">E-wastes include</p>
	<p class="block_9">Computer components - 66%</p>
	<p class="block_9">Telecommunication components - 12 %</p>
	<p class="block_9">Electronic components - 5 %</p>
	<p class="block_9">Biomedical components - 7 %</p>
	<p class="block_9">Other components - 6 %</p>
	<p class="block_19">Environmental impact of e-wastes</p>
	<p class="block_9">Disposal of any kind of electrical and electronic devices without knowledge can become the landfill and water pollutants.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Electronic equipment's contain many hazardous heavy metals such as lead, cadmium that can cause severe soil and groundwater pollution.</p>
	<p class="block_9">E-waste dumping yards and the places nearby are polluted and cause severe health hazard.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_19">More to Know</p>
	<p class="block_9">Health Effects of E- Wastes</p>
	<p class="block_9">Lead: Damages central and peripheral nervous system; affect brain development in children.</p>
	<p class="block_18"> </p>
	<p class="block_9"> Chromium: Asthmatic bronchitis.</p>
	<p class="block_9"> Cadmium: Accumulates in kidney and liver, neural damage.</p>
	<p class="block_9">Mercury: Chronic damage to brain and respiratory system</p>
	<p class="block_9"><span class="calibre15">Plastics including Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC):    </span></p>
	<p class="block_9">Burning produces dioxin which can cause developmental and reproductive problems, damages the immune system.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_737">22.10 Sewage Management</h2>
	<p class="block_">Untreated sewage or wastewater generated from domestic and industrial process is the leading polluter of water sources in India. Sewage water results in agricultural contamination<span class="tab">      </span>and<span class="tab">      </span>environmental degradation.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Sources of Sewage or wastewater</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_321">Domestic purpose or household activities</li>
	<li class="block_322">Dye and textile industries</li>
	<li class="block_322">Leather industries</li>
	<li class="block_322">Sugar and breweries industries</li>
	<li class="block_323">Paper and pulp industries</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image228.jpeg" alt="A view of sewage treatment plant" class="calibre138"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 22.4 A view of sewage treatment plant</p>
	<p class="block_12">Sewage or wastewater treatment method</p>
	<p class="block_">The conventional wastewater treatment methods involve the following steps</p>
	<p class="block_">(a) Pre-screening (b) Aeration (c) Sludge Management and (d) Water Reuse.</p>
	<p class="block_">Pre-screening: Wastewater generated from domestic and industrial activities is screened to remove soil and solid particulates. </p>
	<p class="block_">Aeration: Screened wastewater is then pumped to an aeration tank. Here the microbial contaminants are removed by the biological degradation that occurs in the presence of air. </p>
	<p class="block_">Sedimentation process: In this process, the solid particles in suspension form are allowed to settle. The particles that settle out from the suspension is known as sludge.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Sludge removal:</b> The sludge generated by the degradation process is transferred periodically from the tank for safe disposal.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Disinfection:</b> Chlorination and ultraviolet (UV) radiation of treated water is required to remove any microorganism contamination.</p>
	<p class="block_">Water recycling: The water will then be supplied for domestic or industrial purposes.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_738">22.11 Solid Waste Management</h2>
	<p class="block_">Solid wastes mainly include municipal wastes, hospital wastes, industrial wastes and e- wastes etcetera. The solid wastes are dumped in the soil which results in landscape pollution.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image229.jpeg" alt="Figure 22.5 Conventional Wastewater Treatment Solid-waste management involves the collection, treatment and proper disposing of solid material that is discarded from the household and industrial activities. " class="calibre461"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 22.5 Conventional Wastewater Treatment</p>
	<p class="block_">Solid-waste management involves the collection, treatment and proper disposing of solid material that is discarded from the household and industrial activities.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Methods of solid wastes disposal</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6"><b class="calibre6">Segregation:</b> It is the separation of different type of waste materials like biodegradable and non-biodegradable wastes.</li>
	<li class="block_7"><b class="calibre6">Sanitary landfill:</b> Solid wastes are dumped into low lying areas. The layers are compacted by trucks to allow settlement. The waste materials get stabilised in about 2-12 months. The organic matter undergoes decomposition.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_533"><img src="images/image230.jpeg" alt="Figure 22.6 Collection of degradable and non- degradable solid wastes" class="calibre462"/></p>
	<p class="block_1213">Figure 22.6 Collection of degradable and non- degradable solid wastes</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li value="3" class="block_7"><b class="calibre6">Incineration: </b>It is the burning of non- biodegradable solid wastes (medical wastes) in properly constructed furnace at high temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_8"><b class="calibre6">Composting:</b> Biodegradable matter of solid wastes is digested by microbial action or earthworms and converted into humus.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-351.png" alt="Figure 22.7 Collection of various types of solid wastes in separate bins" class="calibre463"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Figure 22.7 Collection of various types of solid wastes in separate bins</p>
	<p class="block_12">Recycling of wastes</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Papers from old books, magazines and newspapers are recycled to produce papers in papermills.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Agricultural wastes like coconut shells, jute cotton stalk, bagasse of sugarcane can be used to make paper and hard board. Paddy husk can be used as livestock fodder.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Cow dung and other organic wastes can be used in gobar gas plant to provide biogas and manure for fields.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">4R Approach</p>
	<p class="block_">The 4R approach such as Reduce, Reuse, Recovery and Recycle may be followed for effective waste management.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_739">Points to Remember</h2>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6"> Conservation is a process which is concerned with the use, preservation and proper management of natural resources from destructive activities of human being.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Conservation of natural resources contributes to the social and economic development of the country.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Forests of a country constitute a major asset for the people of the country.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> National park is a reserved area for the conservation of entire wildlife including plants and animals.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Sanctuary is a place reserved exclusively for the use of animals.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Solar cell is a device that absorbs sunlight and converts it into electric energy.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> Solar water heater does not require electricity, they heat up water directly from sunlight.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Biogas is produced by the anaerobic decomposition of cow dung.</li>
	<li class="block_7"> The technique of collecting and storing rain water for future purpose is known as rainwater harvesting.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Unwanted, non-working and outdated electronic products become e-waste.</li>
</ul>

	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_746">6 Short answer questions</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">What is the importance of rainwater harvesting?</li>
	<li class="block_7">What are the advantages of using biogas?</li>
	<li class="block_7">What is the environmental effect caused by sewage?</li>
	<li class="block_8">What are the consequences of deforestation?</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_747">7 Long answer questions</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">How does rainwater harvest structures recharge ground water?</li>
	<li class="block_7">How will you prevent soil erosion?</li>
	<li class="block_7">What are the sources of solid wastes? How are solid wastes managed?</li>
	<li class="block_7">Enumerate the importance of forest.</li>
	<li class="block_7">What are the consequences of soil erosion?</li>
	<li class="block_8">Why is the management of forest and wildlife resource considered as a challenging task?</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_748">8 Assertion and Reasoning</h3>
	<p class="block_">In each of the following question a statement of assertion(A) is given and a corresponding statement of reason (R). Of the four statements given below mark the correct answer.</p>
	<p class="block_1229"><span class="calibre28">       </span>Assertion: Rainwater harvesting is to collect and store rain water.</p>
	<p class="block_566">Reason: Rainwater can be directed to recharge the underground water source.</p>
	<div class="calibre10">
	<div class="block_13">a) Both assertion and reason are true and reason is correct explanation of assertion.</div>
	<div class="block_13">b) Both assertion and reason are true but reason is not the correct explanation of assertion.</div>
	<div class="block_13">c) Assertion is true but reason is false.</div>
	<div class="block_14">d) Both assertion and reason are false.</div>
</div>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_749">9 Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Although coal and petroleum are produced by degradation of biomass, yet we need to conserve them. Why?</li>
	<li class="block_7">What are the objectives for replacing non-conventional energy resources from conventional energy resources?</li>
	<li class="block_8">Why is the Government imposing ban on the use of polythene bags and plastics? Suggest alternatives. How is this ban likely to improve the environment?</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_750">10 Value based questions</h3>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Why is it not possible to use solar cells to meet our energy needs? State three reason to support to your answer.</li>
	<li class="block_7">How would you dispose the following wastes?</li>
</ol>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_322">Domestic wastes like vegetable peels</li>
	<li class="block_322">Industrial wastes like metallic cans. </li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_566">Can the disposal protect the environment? How?</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="3" class="block_8">List any three activities based on 4R approach to conserve natural resources.</li>
</ol>

	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_751">UNIT-23 <b class="calibre6">VISUAL COMMUNICATION</b></h1>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-354.png" alt="A QR Code with code of DZEVO IS given" class="calibre466"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_752">Learning Objectives</h2>
	<p class="block_">At the end of this lesson the students will be able to:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Differentiate a File from a Folder</li>
	<li class="block_7">Know how to create a File and a Folder</li>
	<li class="block_65">Use the software application to create Animation</li>
</ul>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_753">INTRODUCTION</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">In general, whenever we think of computers, the things that come to our mind is computer screen, keyboard, mouse and CPU. We learnt about computer and parts of a computer as introductory part in standard 6. Apart from that, software and hardware also play vital role in the working of computer. Now, shall we learn how to operate the computer?</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-355.png" alt="This image shows the computer" class="calibre467"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">The reason we prefer computer is its speed and the ability to store data. How can we save data and information in computer? We can save them in folders which accommodate multiple files or a single file. Let us understand the terminologies like file and folder before moving further.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-356.png" alt="This image shows the various File formats such as Doc, XLS, PPT, PDF, JPG, EPS, PSD,PNG, ZIP, CSS, HTM, MP3, AVI, WAV" class="calibre468"/></p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_754">23.1FILE</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">The output we get from any application is commonly referred as ‘file’ Therefore the application for the specific purposes determines the nature of the file.</p>
	<p class="block_63">23.1.1 FOLDER</p>
	<p class="block_63"><img src="images/image-357.png" alt="This picture shows the Image of the Folder" class="calibre469"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">A folder is a storage space that contains multiple files. We can create files as per the user’s need. For clear understanding, we can take the example of a bookshelf in a library. The individual book can be considered as a ‘file’ and the whole set of books in a shelf can be considered as folders. When we right click on the mouse, the popup menu appears on the screen with multiple options. Select ‘NEW’ option and a secondary menu comes up with another set of options. Select ‘Folder’ option in the menu. You can now save your file or files in the newly created folder.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">More people are using Windows and LINUX operating systems in their computers. We can do many activities like collect notes, draw or paint, create animations or spreadsheets or word docs or PPTs etcetera.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">We use ‘Guide Board’ to go to the unknown places. </p>
	<p class="block_1054">like that </p>
	<p class="block_1054">when we ‘On’ the computer click the ‘START’ button at the left corner of the computer, it shows the list of all programs in the computer. Now select the required program and create the required files.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image341.jpeg" alt="START MENU OPTION AND We use ‘Guide Board’ to go to the unknown places like that when we ‘On’ the computer click the ‘START’ button at the left corner of the computer, it shows the list of all programs in the computer.  " class="calibre470"/></p>
	<p class="block_63">How can we create Files?</p>
	<p class="block_1054">For example if the computer is operating on the Windows OS, we can collect our notes in ‘Notepad’ application and draw pictures in ‘Paint’ application.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">As per its name we can type notes in ‘Notepad’ and save the created files in a folder. Likewise in the ‘Paint’ app we can draw and edit pictures. With these pictures, let us see how we can create image gallery, animations and graphics easily.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image-358.png" alt="‘Notepad’ application and draw pictures in ‘Paint’ application. create image gallery, animations and graphics easily." class="calibre471"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054"> Pictures and audio-visuals give us more understanding than teaching and writing on the black board. Is it right?</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image340.jpeg" alt="writing on the black board" class="calibre472"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">Instead of saying a story like ‘once upon a time there was a king’ we can understand the concept easily by seeing the video and also it registers firmly in the minds of the students. The device which helps in explaining the concepts easily through pictures is known as ‘Visual Communication Device’. For example photos, audio -visuals, drawings, animations all these can be created easily with the help of computer. Cinema is a good example for ‘Visual Communication Device’.</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_755">23.2. SCRATCH</h2>
	<p class="block_1054">Introduction</p>
	<p class="block_1054">‘Scratch’ is a software used to create animations, cartoons and games easily. Scratch is a visual programming language. It was developed in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Media Lab to make programming easier and more fun to learn.</p>
	<p class="block_1054">Scratch Environment Editor</p>
	<p class="block_1054">The Scratch editor has three main parts: They are Stage, Sprite and Script editor.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Stage:</b> Stage is the background appearing when we open the scratch window. The background will most often be white. You can change the background colour as you like.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Sprite:</b> The characters on the background of a Scratch window are known as Sprite. Usually a cat appears as a sprite when the Scratch window is opened. The software provides facilities to make alternations in sprite.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><b class="calibre6">Script editor or costume editor:</b> Where you edit your programs or your sprite’s pictures.</p>
	<p class="block_1054"><img src="images/image342.jpeg" alt="Script editor / costume editor: Where you edit your programs or your sprite’s pictures." class="calibre473"/></p>
	<p class="block_1054">You should see a single window with at least the following three panes: the Stage (top left), the Sprite List (bottom left), and the Scripts tab (right), which contains the Blocks tab and the Scripts Area. The right pane also contains two additional tabs, Costumes and Sounds.</p>
	<p class="block_63">The script editor has three main parts:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_64">Script area: Where you build scripts.</li>
	<li class="block_1055">Block menu: Where you choose the category of blocks (programming statements) to use.</li>
	<li class="block_65">Block palette: Where you choose the block to use.</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_">When the Costumes tab is chosen, the costume editor is shown (outlined in red):</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image343.jpeg" alt="The costume editor is shown (outlined in red)" class="calibre474"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Movement and Loops</p>
	<p class="block_">Click File , and click New to create a new project and enter a project name.</p>
	<p class="block_">Click the menu <b class="calibre6">Script → Event, drag a when green flag clicked</b> block to the scripts area. Your scripts area should look like this:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image344.png" alt="Click the menu Script → Event, drag a when green flag clicked block to the scripts area. " class="calibre475"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Click the menu <b class="calibre6">Script → Motion</b> menu, drag a <b class="calibre6">go to x:</b> 0 y: 0 block to the scripts area and snap it to the bottom of the <b class="calibre6">when green flag clicked block.</b> Your script should look like this:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image345.png" alt="Click the menu Script → Motion menu, drag a goto x: 0 y: 0 block to the scripts area and snap it to the bottom of the when green flag clicked block." class="calibre476"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Add a move 10 steps block to the bottom of your script and change the 10 into 100.</p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image346.png" alt="Add a move 10 steps block to the bottom of your script and change the 10 into 100." class="calibre477"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Click the green flag at the top right corner of the stage to run your program.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Adding Sound</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Click Sprite1 in the sprite list and click the Sounds tab.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Try the meow sound already there. If you don’t like it, click the speaker icon to choose a different sound from the sound library.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Click the Scripts tab and find the play sound block from the Sound menu. Add this block to the when space key pressed script. (Select the sound you want from the drop-down list.)</li>
	<li class="block_8">Run your program.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Example:</p>
	<p class="block_">Program for print the word “Hello” with sound</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image347.jpeg" alt="Example  Program for print the word “Hello” with sound" class="calibre478"/></p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Click events in script option</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_61"><img src="images/image348.jpeg" alt="1. Click events in script option" class="calibre479"/></p>

</ol>

	<ol class="list_">

</ol>

	<ol class="list_">

</ol>
	<p class="block_61"><img src="images/image351.jpeg" alt="2.Type “Hello “ word in say tab." class="calibre482"/></p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_761">PHYSICS</h2>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_762">1 DETERMINATION OF WEIGHT OF AN OBJECT USING THE PRINCIPLE OF MOMENTS</h3>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-361.png" alt="A QR Code with code of OMDV3 IS given" class="calibre488"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To determine the weight of an object using the principle of moments </p>
	<p class="block_12">Apparatus required:</p>
	<p class="block_">A metre scale, a knife edge, slotted weights, thread</p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<ol class="list_1">
	<li class="block_6">A metre scale is supported at its centre of gravity by a knife edge or suspended by using a thread tied to its centre so that the scale is in the horizontal position. Ensure that the scale is in equilibrium position.</li>
	<li class="block_7">A known weight W2 and an unknown weight W1 are suspended from to either side of the scale using the weight hangers.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Fix the position of one weight hanger and adjust the position of the second weight hanger such that the scale is in equilibrium.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Measure the distance d1 and d2 of the two weight hangers from the centre of the scale accurately.</li>
	<li class="block_8">The experiment is repeated for different positions of the unknown weight. Measure the distances. The reading is tabulated as follows:</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Observation:</p>
	<table class="table_2">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_814"><p class="block_9">Serial Number</p></td>
			<td class="td_815"><p class="block_9">Weight in the weight hanger W2 (kilogram)</p></td>
			<td class="td_816"><p class="block_9">Distance of known weight d1 (meter)</p></td>
			<td class="td_817"><p class="block_9">Distance of unknown</p><p class="block_9">Weight d2 (meter)</p></td>
			<td class="td_818"><p class="block_9">W suffix 2 into d suffix 2</p><p class="block_9">(kilogram meter)</p></td>
			<td class="td_671"><p class="block_9">Unknown weight</p><p class="block_9">W suffix1 is equal to w suffix 2 into d suffix 2 divided by d suffix 1 into kilogram</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_819"><p class="block_9">1</p></td>
			<td class="td_820"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_821"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_822"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_823"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_673"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_819"><p class="block_9">2</p></td>
			<td class="td_820"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_821"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_822"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_823"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_673"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_824"><p class="block_9">3</p></td>
			<td class="td_825"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_826"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_827"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_828"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_675"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_1233"><span class="calibre28">Mean:   </span><span class="tab">      </span><span class="tab">      </span></p>
	<p class="block_">Calculations:</p>
	<p class="block_">Moment of a force can be calculated using the formula</p>
	<p class="block_">Moment of the force = Force × distance</p>
	<p class="block_">Anti clock wise moment by unknown weight = W1 × d1</p>
	<p class="block_">Clockwise moment by known weight = W2 × d2</p>
	<p class="block_">W1 × d1= W2 × d2</p>
	<p class="block_">Unknown weight = W suffix1 is equal to w suffix 2 into d suffix 2 divided by d suffix 1 </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-362.png" alt="This image shows the Pictorial representation of the experiment " class="calibre489"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Result:</p>
	<p class="block_">Using the principle of moments, the weight of the unknown body W1 = dash kilogram weight.</p>

<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_763">2. DETERMINATION OF FOCAL LENGTH OF A CONVEX LENS</h3>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To determine the focal length of a convex lens by using</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Distant object method</li>
	<li class="block_8">uv method</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Apparatus required:</b> </p>
	<p class="block_">A convex lens, stand, wire gauze object, screen and measuring scale.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Formula: f is equal to u into v divided by u plus v</p>
	<p class="block_">Here,</p>
	<p class="block_">u is the distance between the object (light source) and the convex lens</p>
	<p class="block_">v is the distance of the image (screen) from the convex lens</p>
	<p class="block_">f is the focal length of the convex lens</p>
	<p class="block_12">1. Distant Object Method:</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-363.png" alt="This image shows the Pictorial Representation of Distant Object Model" class="calibre490"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Fix the given convex lens vertically on the stand and place it on the table near an open window of the laboratory. Locate a distant object (tree or building) through the open window. Place the screen behind the convex lens. Adjust the position of the convex lens and the screen so as to get a sharp, inverted and diminished image. Measure the distance between the screen and the convex lens with the help of the measuring scale. This distance is equal to the approximate focal length of the convex lens (f)</p>
	<p class="block_12">2). uv - Method:</p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-364.png" alt="This image displays the pictorial representation of UV-method" class="calibre491"/></p>
	<p class="block_">Fix the given convex lens vertically on the stand and place it on the table. Place the wire gauze object on the left side of the convex lens (say at a distance greater than 2f). Measure the distance between the object and the lens (u). Place the screen on the right side of the convex lens and adjust its position to get a sharp, inverted and diminished image. Measure the distance between the screen and the lens (v). Repeat the same procedure, by changing the distance of the object (u) and tabulate your observations.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Observation:</p>
	<p class="block_">Focal length of the convex lens (By distance object method) is (f) = dash centimetre</p>
	<p class="block_">2f = dash centimetre</p>
	<p class="block_2"> </p>
	<table class="table_2">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">

			<td class="td_838"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_839"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_840"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>

	<p class="block_12">Result:</p>
	<p class="block_">The focal length of the given convex lens</p>
	<p class="block_">1. By distance object method f = dash centimetre</p>
	<p class="block_">2. By ‘uv’ method f = dash centimetre</p>

	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_764">3. DETERMINATION OF RESISTIVITY</h3>
	<p class="block_12">Objective:</p>
	<p class="block_">To determine the resistivity of the material of the given coil of wire.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Equipment required:</p>
	<p class="block_">A coil of wire, screw gauge, a metre scale, battery, key, ammeter, voltmeter, rheostat and connecting Wires.</p>
	<p class="block_1234"><span class="text_68">Formula:</span><span class="text_69"> ρ </span><span class="text_13"> = A by L multiply by R in ohm meter</span></p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">The resistivity of the material of the coil of wire is  </span></p>
	<p class="block_">Where A is the area of cross section of the wire (m power2)</p>
	<p class="block_">L is the length of the coil of wire (meter)</p>
	<p class="block_1234"><span class="text_12">R is the resistance of the coil of wire (ohm)</span><span class="text_69"> </span></p>
	<p class="block_12">Circuit Diagram:</p>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-365.png" alt="This image shows the Circuit Diagram" class="calibre492"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<ul class="list_4">
	<li class="block_6">Connect the battery, ammeter, given wire, rheostat and key in series, as shown in the circuit diagram.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Connect the voltmeter in parallel to the unknown resistor.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Close the key and hence the circuit is closed.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Adjust the rheostat such that the ammeter reads a current of 0.5 ampere.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Note down the potential difference across the resistor as shown by the voltmeter.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Adjust the rheostat and change the current in steps of 0.5A (that is 0.5A, 1.0A, 1.5A, etc.).</li>
	<li class="block_7">For each current, note down the corresponding potential difference as shown by the voltmeter.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Tabulate the observations.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Measure the diameter of the wire using a screw gauge.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Measure the length of the coil using metre scale</li>
</ul>
	<p class="block_12">Observations:</p>
	<p class="block_">(1) To find the resistance:</p>
	<table class="table_2">

	<p class="block_">CHEMISTRY</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_765">4). IDENTIFY THE DISSOLUTION OF THE GIVEN SALT WHETHER IT IS EXOTHERMIC OR ENDOTHERMIC.</h3>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-366.png" alt="A QR Code with code of 3BJ8V IS given" class="calibre493"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To test the dissolution of given salt is exothermic or endothermic</p>
	<p class="block_12">Principle:</p>
	<p class="block_">If the reaction or process liberates the heat, then it is called exothermic. </p>
	<p class="block_">If the reaction or process absorbs the heat, then it is called endothermic</p>
	<p class="block_12">Apparatus required:</p>
	<p class="block_">Two beakers, Thermometer, stirrer, weighed amount of two samples.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<p class="block_">Take 50ml of water in two beakers and label them as A and B. Note the temperature of the water from beaker A and B. Then, add 5gram of sample A into the beaker A and stir well until it dissolves completely. Record final temperature of the solution. Now, repeat the same for the sample B. Record the observation.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Observation:</p>
	<table class="table_2">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_814"><p class="block_9">Serial Number</p></td>
			<td class="td_873"><p class="block_9">Sample </p></td>
			<td class="td_95"><p class="block_9">Temperature before addition of sample (degree C)</p></td>
			<td class="td_95"><p class="block_9">Temperature after addition of sample (degree C)</p></td>
			<td class="td_874"><p class="block_9">Inference (temperature</p><p class="block_9">increases or decreases)</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_819"><p class="block_9">1</p></td>
			<td class="td_875"><p class="block_9">A</p></td>
			<td class="td_99"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_99"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_876"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_824"><p class="block_9">2</p></td>
			<td class="td_877"><p class="block_9">B</p></td>
			<td class="td_103"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_103"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_878"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_12">Result:</p>
	<p class="block_">From the inferences made</p>
	<p class="block_">The dissolution of sample A is dash. (Exothermic or endothermic)</p>
	<p class="block_">The dissolution of sample B is dash. (Exothermic or endothermic)</p>
	<p class="block_">Note:</p>
	<p class="block_">Sodium hydroxide, ammonium nitrate, glucose, calcium oxide etcetera. may be given as the sample.</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_766">5. TESTING THE SOLUBILITY OF THE SALT</h3>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-367.png" alt="A QR Code with code of MEUXN IS given" class="calibre494"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To test the solubility of the given salt based on the saturation and un saturation of the solution at a given temperature.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Principle:</p>
	<p class="block_">A solution in which no more solute can be dissolved in the solvent at a given temperature is called saturated solution. If the solvent can dissolve more solute than what is present, the solution is called unsaturated solution.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Materials Required:</p>
	<p class="block_">A 250 ml beaker, a Stirrer, sufficient quantity of distilled water, 100 ml measuring jar, table salt in three packets weighing as 25gram, 11 gram, and 1 gram.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<p class="block_">In a 250ml beaker ,pour 100 ml water using measuring jar. To this water add table salt (25 gram) from first packet. stir the content very well. Add the next packet containing 11-gram salt followed by constant stirring Now add the third packet containing 1 gram salt Record your observations.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Observation:</p>
	<table class="table_2">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_879"><p class="block_9">Serial number. </p></td>
			<td class="td_95"><p class="block_9">Amount of salt added</p></td>
			<td class="td_880"><p class="block_9">Observation </p><p class="block_9">[Salt dissolved or un dissolved]</p></td>
			<td class="td_881"><p class="block_9">Inference </p><p class="block_9">[unsaturated or</p><p class="block_9">Saturated or super saturated]</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_882"><p class="block_9">1</p></td>
			<td class="td_99"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_883"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_884"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_882"><p class="block_9">2</p></td>
			<td class="td_99"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_883"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_884"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_855"><p class="block_9">3</p></td>
			<td class="td_103"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_885"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
			<td class="td_886"><p class="block_18"> </p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_">Result: From the above observation, it is inferred that the amount of salt required for saturation is dash gram</p>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_767">6. TESTING THE WATER OF HYDRATION OF SALT</h3>
	<p class="block_12"><img src="images/image-368.png" alt="A QR code is given with code of MWUXN" class="calibre495"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To check whether the given sample of salt possesses 'Water of Hydration' or not. To verify the presence of water molecules in the given hydrated salt </p>
	<p class="block_12">Principle:</p>
	<p class="block_">Water of crystallization or water of hydration is the phenomenon shown by certain salts in which water molecules are present inside the crystals are responsible for their colour and geometry. Example Crystalline copper sulphate CuSO4 5H2O</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Materials Required:</b> A pinch of crystalline copper sulphate in a test tube, tongs, spirit lamp.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-369.png" alt="Image displays water of crystallization" class="calibre496"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<p class="block_">A pinch of crystalline copper sulphate taken in a test tube and heated for some time Water droplets are seen on the inner walls of the test tube. This shows that the given salt contains water of crystallization. If the above observation is not noticed for the given salt, the water of hydration is absent.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Result:</p>
	<p class="block_">In the given sample of salt, Water of crystallization or hydration is</p>
	<ol class="list_6">
	<li class="block_6">Present </li>
	<li class="block_8">Absent</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_21" id="calibre_pb_33"> </p>
</body></html>

<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_768">7). TEST THE GIVEN SAMPLE FOR THE PRESENCE OF ACID OR BASE</h3>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-370.png" alt="A QR Code with code of NHY5V IS given" class="calibre497"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To identify the presence of an acid or a base in a given sample.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Materials Required:</p>
	<p class="block_">Test tubes, test tube stand, glass rod, phenolphthalein, methyl orange, sodium carbonate salt and the given sample.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Principle:</p>
	<p class="block_">In acid medium, </p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_6">Phenolphthalein is colourless </li>
	<li class="block_7">Methyl orange is pink in colour </li>
	<li class="block_8">Sodium carbonate gives brisk effervescence. </li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">In Base medium,</p>
	<ol class="list_2">
	<li class="block_6">Phenolphthalein is pink in colour</li>
	<li class="block_7">Methyl orange is yellow in colour</li>
	<li class="block_8">Sodium carbonate does not give brisk effervescence.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<table class="table_2">
		<tbody class="calibre5"><tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_814"><p class="block_9">Serial number</p></td>
			<td class="td_887"><p class="block_9">Experiment</p></td>
			<td class="td_888"><p class="block_9">Observation</p><p class="block_9">(Colour change)</p></td>
			<td class="td_776"><p class="block_9">Inference</p><p class="block_9">(Acid or Base)</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_819"><p class="block_9">1</p></td>
			<td class="td_889"><p class="block_9">Take 5ml of the test solution in a test tube and add a few drops of Phenolphthalein in it.</p></td>
			<td class="td_890"><p class="block_9">a) No change in colour.</p><p class="block_9">b) Solution Turns pink in colour</p></td>
			<td class="td_779"><p class="block_9">a) Presence of acid</p><p class="block_9">b) Presence of base</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_819"><p class="block_9">2</p></td>
			<td class="td_889"><p class="block_9">Take 5ml of the test solution in a test tube and add a few drops of Methyl orange in it.</p></td>
			<td class="td_890"><p class="block_9">a) Solution Turns pink in colour</p><p class="block_9">b) Solution Turns yellow in colour</p></td>
			<td class="td_779"><p class="block_9">a) Presence of acid</p><p class="block_9">b) Presence of base</p></td>
		</tr>
		<tr class="calibre12">
			<td class="td_824"><p class="block_9">3</p></td>
			<td class="td_891"><p class="block_9">Take 5ml of the test solution in a test tube and add a pinch of sodium carbonate salt.</p></td>
			<td class="td_892"><p class="block_9">a) Brisk effervescence occurs.</p><p class="block_9">b) No brisk effervescence.</p></td>
			<td class="td_782"><p class="block_9">a) Presence of acid</p><p class="block_9">b) Presence of base</p></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody></table>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Result</b>: The given test solution contains dash (acid or base).</p>
	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_769">BIO-BOTANY</h2>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li value="8" class="block_66" id="toc_id_770"><b class="calibre36">PHOTOSYNTHESIS-TEST TUBE AND FUNNEL EXPERIMENT (DEMONSTRATION)</b></li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-371.png" alt="A QR Code with code of TDXI6 IS given" class="calibre498"/></p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Aim</b>: </p>
	<p class="block_">To prove that oxygen is evolved during photosynthesis.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Materials required:</p>
	<p class="block_">Test tube, funnel, beaker, pond water and Hydrilla plant.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Take a few twigs of Hydrilla plant in a beaker containing pond water.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Place an inverted funnel over the plant.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Invert a test tube filled with water over the stem of the funnel.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Keep the apparatus in the sunlight for few hours.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-372.png" alt="Image shows the PHOTOSYNTHESIS-TEST TUBE AND FUNNEL EXPERIMENT " class="calibre499"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Observation:</p>
	<p class="block_">After one hour, it is noted that water gets displaced down from the test tube.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Inference</p>
	<p class="block_">During photosynthesis, oxygen is evolved as a by-product. Gas bubbles liberated from the Hydrilla plant reach the top of the test tube and it displaces the water downwards. Take the test tube and keep the burning stick near the mouth of the test tube. Increased flame will appear. Hence, it is proved that oxygen is evolved during photosynthesis.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_771">9. PARTS OF A FLOWER</h3>

	<p class="block_12">Materials Required:</p>
	<p class="block_">Flower, needle and paper </p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<p class="block_">With the help of the needle dissect the different whorls of the flower</p>
	<p class="block_">Floral Parts:</p>
	<p class="block_"><span class="calibre28">Accessory Organ- Calyx, Corolla  </span></p>
	<p class="block_">Reproductive Organ - Androecium - Male part of the flower, Gynoecium - Female part of the flower </p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-373.png" alt="Image displays the L.S of a flower - Calyx, Corolla , Androecium, Gynoecium , Petal." class="calibre500"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Observation:</p>
	<p class="block_">Draw and label the parts of the flower.</p>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_772">10). MENDEL'S MONOHYBRID CROSS</h3>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Aim</b>:</p>
	<p class="block_">To study the monohybrid cross by using model or picture or photograph. To find out the phenotypic ratio and genotypic ratio in pea plant using checkerboard</p>
	<p class="block_">Note: Depict parental generation and the gametes using colour chalk pieces</p>
	<p class="block_12">Definition:</p>
	<p class="block_">Cross involving one pair of contrasting characters is called monohybrid cross.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Procedure:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Pure breeding tall plant is crossed with pure breeding dwarf plant.</li>
	<li class="block_7">All the F1 hybrid plants were tall (Tt)</li>
	<li class="block_8">Selfing the F1 hybrid plants resulted in tall and dwarf plants in F2 generation.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_21" id="calibre_pb_34"> </p>

	<p class="block_">Phenotypic ratio = Tall - 3 : Dwarf - 1</p>
	<p class="block_">Genotypic ratio = Pure Tall - 1 : Hybrid Tall - 2 : Pure Dwarf – 1</p>

	<h2 class="block_5" id="toc_id_774">BIO-ZOOLOGY</h2>
	<h3 class="block_15" id="toc_id_775">12. OBSERVATION OF MODELS-HUMAN HEART AND HUMAN BRAIN</h3>
	<p class="block_">Identification of longitudinal section (L S) of the human heart.</p>
	<p class="block_83" id="calibre_pb_36"> </p>
</body></html>

<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:epub="http://www.idpf.org/2007/ops" lang="en" xml:lang="en">
  <head>
    <title>Unknown</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="stylesheet.css"/>
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="page_styles.css"/>
    <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"/>
  </head>
  <body class="calibre">
<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To observe and draw a labelled sketch of L.S of human heart and describe the structure.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Materials Required:</p>
	<p class="block_">Model showing the LS of human heart</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-377.png" alt="This Image shows the LS of Heart" class="calibre504"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Observation:</p>
	<p class="block_">The given model is identified as LS. of human heart</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">The human heart has four chambers. It is made up of two auricles and two ventricles</li>
	<li class="block_7">The auricles are separated by interauricular septum and ventricles are separated by interventricular septum. It prevents the mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Tricuspid valve - It is located between the right auricle and the right ventricle</li>
	<li class="block_7">Bicuspid valve - It is located between the left auricle and the left ventricle</li>
	<li class="block_7">The heart is covered by a protective double walled membrane called pericardium</li>
	<li class="block_8">The heart pumps blood to all parts of the body.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Identification of LS of the human brain.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To observe and draw a labelled sketch of LS of human brain and comment on it</p>
	<p class="block_12">Materials Required</p>
	<p class="block_">Model showing the L.S of human brain</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-378.png" alt="This image displays L.S. Of Human Brain" class="calibre505"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">Identification:</p>
	<p class="block_">The given model is identified as LS of human brain</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">The brain is enclosed in the cranial cavity</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is the controlling centre of all the body activities.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is covered by three connective tissue membrane or meninges: Durometer Arachnoid membrane and Piamater</li>
	<li class="block_8">The human brain is divided into three parts namely forebrain, midbrain and hindbrain</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_776">13. IDENTIFICATION OF BLOOD CELLS</h3>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">Identification of blood cells (Red blood cells and white blood cells). To draw a neat labelled diagram and write a note on the blood cells identified.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Materials Required</p>
	<p class="block_">Permanent prepared slides of blood cells.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Identification:</p>
	<p class="block_">The given slide is identified as Red blood cells</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-379.png" alt="This picture shows the image of RBC" class="calibre506"/></p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">They are biconcave and disc shaped.</li>
	<li class="block_7">They are also known as erythrocytes</li>
	<li class="block_7">Mature mammalian RBC’s do not have nucleus.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Haemoglobin is a respiratory pigment which gives red colour.</li>
	<li class="block_8">It transports oxygen from lungs to tissues and carbon- dioxide from tissues to lungs</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_">The given slide is identified as White blood cells</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-380.png" alt="This picture shows the image of WBC" class="calibre507"/></p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">WBCs are colourless and they have nucleus.</li>
	<li class="block_7">They are also known as Leucocytes</li>
	<li class="block_7">They show amoeboid movements.</li>
	<li class="block_7">They fight against germs and other foreign bodies and thus protect the body from microbial infections and diseases.</li>
	<li class="block_8">There are five different types of WBC namely Neutrophils, Eosinophils, Basophils, Lymphocytes and Monocytes</li>
</ol>
	<h3 class="block_11" id="toc_id_777">14. IDENTIFICATION OF ENDOCRINE GLANDS</h3>
	<p class="block_12">Aim:</p>
	<p class="block_">To identify the endocrine gland, its location, hormone secreted and functions - Thyroid gland and Pancreas</p>
	<p class="block_12">Materials Required:</p>
	<p class="block_">1 Endocrine glands – (a) Thyroid gland (b) Pancreas – Islets of Langerhans</p>
	<p class="block_">2 Any one endocrine gland should be flag labelled.</p>
	<p class="block_">For the purpose of flag labelling a model or a chart or photograph showing all endocrine glands should be used. (Mark the endocrine glands mentioned for the practical)</p>
	<p class="block_12">Identification:</p>
	<p class="block_">Identify the flag labelled endocrine gland, write its location, the hormones secreted and its functions.</p>
	<p class="block_"><img src="images/image-381.png" alt="Image displays different endocrine Glands" class="calibre508"/></p>
	<p class="block_12">(a) Thyroid gland</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Identification:</b> The flag labelled endocrine gland is identified as Thyroid gland</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Location:</b> Thyroid gland is a bilobed gland located in the neck region on either side of </p>
	<p class="block_">the trachea.</p>
	<p class="block_"><b class="calibre6">Hormones secreted:</b> Triiodothyronine (T3) and Thyroxine (T4)</p>
	<p class="block_12">Functions of Hormones:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Thyroid hormones increase the basal metabolic rate (BMR).</li>
	<li class="block_7">It increases the body temperature.</li>
	<li class="block_7">It regulates metabolism</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is required for normal growth and development</li>
	<li class="block_7">It is also known as personality hormone.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Deficiency of thyroxine results in simple goitre, myxoedema (in adults) and cretinism (in children).</li>
	<li class="block_8">Excess secretion causes Grave’s diseases.</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">(b) Pancreas – Islets of Langerhans</p>
	<p class="block_12">Identification:</p>
	<p class="block_">The flag labelled endocrine gland is identified as Islets of Langerhans in the Pancreas.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Location:</p>
	<p class="block_">Islets of Langerhans are seen embedded in the pancreas which is located in the abdominal region.</p>
	<p class="block_12">Hormones secreted:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">α cells secrete glucagon</li>
	<li class="block_8">β cells secrete insulin</li>
</ol>
	<p class="block_12">Functions of Hormones:</p>
	<ol class="list_">
	<li class="block_6">Insulin converts glucose into glycogen and stores it in liver and muscles.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Glucagon converts glycogen into glucose.</li>
	<li class="block_7">Insulin and glucagon maintain the blood sugar level (80 – 120 mg/dl) by their antagonistic function.</li>
	<li class="block_8">Decrease in insulin secretion causes diabetes mellitus.</li>
</ol>
	<h1 class="block_4" id="toc_id_778">GLOSSARY</h1>
